webTitle: Villagers left high and dry by tide of progress

fields.headline: Villagers left high and dry by tide of progress
fields.standfirst:
Turkish dam funding condemned
Scandal that rocked Tories
fields.trailText: "They could have waited until we had picked the pistachios one more time", says Ahmet Erdogan, "it would have been a good crop this year". He is standing by a new manmade lake, where the rising waters have just submerged the five domes of Halfeti's historic Turkish bath.
fields.body:
"They could have waited until we had picked the pistachios one more time", says Ahmet Erdogan, "it would have been a good crop this year". He is standing by a new manmade lake, where the rising waters have just submerged the five domes of Halfeti's historic Turkish bath.

Down the road his neighbours are hard at work knocking down their house for salvage, to sell wood and concrete for scrap. The pistachio groves disappeared weeks ago and soon half of this village, which has been a functioning settlement since 1000BC, will be under water.

As controversy mounts over the British government's plans to back the construction of the Ilisu dam, other dams are already rearranging the topography of south-eastern Turkey and forcing thousands of people out of their homes.

Halfeti is the village where the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan was born. It clings to the side of a valley which the Euphrates river cuts through the region. People who have been displaced are being resettled a few miles away in a new village on the barren plain.

"There have been public meetings every step of the way," says Ibrahim Tugrul, who works for Turkey's regional development agency, known as Gap. "We asked people about where they wanted to move, the type of houses they preferred, and what kind of help they would need once they got there".

Unfortunately, most people did not want to move at all, but that was not an option. A random sample of villagers produces complaints of a lack of consultation, of insufficient compensation and of a general feeling that they are losing much more than they stand to gain.

"It's not going to be like this any more," says Celal Guneri, casting his eye over the old village. "There are nice gardens and trees here. Up there it's dry, there's no work - it's all artificial".

The new Halfeti is indeed a regimented place - row after row of identical concrete structures in a neat grid on the stony brown earth. Perhaps it just needs time to develop, but at the moment the jumbled feeling of a real riverside community has been replaced by a village without a soul.

The state rejects suggestions that old Kurdish communities are being deliberately broken up, to allow central government to gain better control over an unruly region. Many Kurdish pressure groups are convinced the allegation is true, but local villagers have more pressing economic needs.

The residents of Halfeti who decide to stay have little choice but to place their faith in the promises of senior officials in the Gap administration who seem to believe in the participatory approach to resettlement. They plan reafforestation and a programme of retraining people in skills ranging from beekeeping to hairdressing.

But consultation can only work properly in an open atmosphere, and democratic discussion is an ingredient which is in desperately short supply in most parts of south-eastern Turkey. Halfeti is at least better off than Ilisu, which is in a region governed by emergency rule where grassroots protests are crushed before they can begin.

Supporters of the big dam projects argue that the disappearance of old village communities is a necessary price of progress, and that some things have to be sacrificed for the greater good. With or without Ilisu, south-eastern Turkey is already in a cycle of irreversible change.

webTitle: Ignore the hype, New Deal works

fields.headline: Ignore the hype, New Deal works
fields.standfirst: Jobless rate at 25-year low
fields.trailText: Having made a reduction in youth unemployment one of their five initial pledges, ministers are understandably keen to assert that the New Deal has been a rip-roaring success. But the government is now being more cautious about its claims.
fields.body:
Having made a reduction in youth unemployment one of their five initial pledges, ministers are understandably keen to assert that the New Deal has been a rip-roaring success. But the government is now being more cautious about its claims.

Yes, they say, youth unemployment is at a 25-year-low. But no, that is not solely due to the New Deal; it also reflects the strength of the economy, which has been responsible for most of the reduction in the jobless total since Labour came to power three years ago.

This is a far more realistic assessment of what the programme has achieved, and in the long-run will serve the government's cause better.

The reason is that the New Deal was never meant to be a short-term fix for reducing the dole queue, but was designed to improve the long-term employability of the jobless, to build up their skills levels and prevent those skills atrophying through lack of use.

In the early days, however, the self-imposed political pressure for quick results led to inflated claims about its direct impact on the unemployment figures.

In the year before New Deal became fully effective in spring 1998, the number of people between 18 and 24 who were unemployed for more than six months fell by more than 60,000 as a result of strong economic growth. Work by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, commissioned by the Department for Education and Employment, has shown that, of the 146,000 people on the New Deal who found jobs lasting more than three months, 106,000 would have found work anyway.

Ministerial hype obscured the real benefits of the scheme: its cost effectiveness (about £1,000 per job, according to Niesr); the fact that every participant is assigned a personal adviser rather than dealing with a range of jobcentre staff; that three in four of the jobs found by young people were sustained; and its genuine potential for improving the employability and productivity of those at the bottom of the labour market.

There has been quiet praise for the scheme. Despite scepticism in some quarters about New Deal measures to tackle unemployment, the OECD said last month that they have helped.

An independent overview of the government's evaluation, published yesterday by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, found that the role of personal advisers was pivotal.

"Most participants felt that they were being dealt with individually," says Professor Jane Millar of the University of Bath, who wrote the Rowntree report.

Martin Weale, director of Niesr, said the New Deal would be extremely valuable if the economy eventually turns down. But, with an election looming, the government is not keen to see its pride and joy tested under battle conditions.

webTitle: Spottiswoode's H2go heats up water market

fields.headline: Spottiswoode's H2go heats up water market
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Anglian Water yesterday urged ministers to introduce far greater competition into the water industry after launching H2go, a new unit designed to capture large industrial users from its rivals.
fields.body:
Anglian Water yesterday urged ministers to introduce far greater competition into the water industry after launching H2go, a new unit designed to capture large industrial users from its rivals.

The new company will be chaired by Clare Spottiswoode, the charismatic former gas industry watchdog who forced through liberalisation of the domestic gas market. She has been appointed by Anglian to grab a bigger share of the industrial market in the absence of domestic competition.

Yesterday's launch marks a new phase in the restructuring of the industry, 10 years after privatisation. Chris Mellor, Anglian's chief executive, said it could be as fundamental for water and other utilities as the original state sell-off.

Anglian wants to retain its capital assets for the time being and offer competitive management services across regions via H2go.

Other utility companies, including Kelda, the owner of Yorkshire Water, intend to spin off assets from their daily operations and entrust them to non-profit mutuals.

Huntingdon-based Anglian has so far won five of the eight licences to provide water services to large customers outside its region, including Kodak in Harrow, Buxted Chickens and a housing estate and business park in the north-east.

Mr Mellor said a further 30 contracts under negotiation would come within H2go's ambit, with the aim of reaching £30m turnover in three years. At present users consuming more than 250m litres a year can switch suppliers; the limit is expected to fall to 100m litres in a new water bill this autumn.

"As in electricity and gas deregulation this greater competition will inexorably continue in water and we hope to be in pole position to take advantage of it," Mr Mellor said.

He added: "Clare was instrumental in bringing about deregulation in gas. We hope she will help shape the rules in competition in water."

Ms Spottiswoode said: "Increased choice through competition has delivered price cuts for gas and electricity customers. Many large users are now asking for the same for water." Anglian plans to undercut rivals by around 20%.

Mr Mellor said it would be a long time before the benefits of liberalisation - such as common carriage - which consumers were now ejoying from other utilities, also applied to water supplies. But he urged the government and the new regulator, Philip Fletcher, to spur greater competition.

Water companies are virtually precluded from pursuing mergers or takeovers and Mr Mellor remains unconvinced that the Kelda mutual model is apt for groups such as his own. But, he said, the government should include in the forthcoming water bill measures to force the regulator to promote competition rather than simply facilitate it as of now.

The shares fell 24p or nearly 4% to close at 600p on news of the strategy.

fields.headline: One-time teenage prodigy
fields.trailText:
Gary Burton/ Makoto Ozone
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London ****
fields.body:
Gary Burton/ Makoto Ozone
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London ****

For a machine capable of such a pretty shimmer, the vibraphone has remained a petulantly unmusical instrument in all but a few hands. Gary Burton, the one-time teenage prodigy, is still an astonishing master of the vibes after 40 years. He plays his very mixed repertoire with dazzling ingenuity and grace, supported by a long-time partner who seems wired directly into his brain - Japanese pianist Makoto Ozone.

Burton, a renowned Berklee conservatoire teacher as well as a virtuoso, emits a scholarly air, but there's not an iota of that in his music, which brims with life and an elegant euphoria. Perhaps his educationalist's urge to enlighten accounts for the breadth of his current repertoire, as if he were revealing to a doubtful world the vibraphone's potential. Burton spans everything from the pre-bop swing of vibes legends Red Norvo and Lionel Hampton to those softly lyrical, piquantly harmonised, jazz-rock pieces that made him one of the subtler pioneers of fusion in the 70s.

Burton gave a straight account of Red Norvo's freewheeling swinger Hole in the Wall, revelling in its endlessly convoluted melodic surprises, while Ozone pumped in a supply of stomping stride piano. Afro Blue - over a Cuban feel that Ozone switched to swing and back in midstream - featured a vibes solo that soared around the harmonies.

Burton's resourcefulness gave him the unruffled urbanity of a Teddy Wilson piano solo rather than the fluffiness of the vibes on Lionel Hampton's Opus Half, and his ear for improvisation made a hypnotic affair of an Ozone ballad composition with early Keith Jarrett echoes. It's a jazz-buff's night that isn't just for jazz-buffs, and it's very classy.

Till Sunday. Box office: 020-7439 8722. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: My boss resents me
fields.trailText: 13 July: I've just taken a job as a secretary but my boss never wanted one. He is now rebelling against senior management by refusing to give me any work.
fields.body:
The problem

This sounds really silly but I have just taken a job as a secretary to a senior manager but he doesn't want a secretary. He has been told he has to have one and he is now rebelling against this by refusing to give me any work (apart from filing), never telling me what he is doing and doing his best to ignore my existence. T

The thing that really annoys me is that when I was interviewed (by him and another senior manager) I was told that I would be getting involved in the day-to-day running of the department and that there were lots of projects I could work on.
Victoria

The solution

What a nightmare! First of all, this guy sounds like a bit of a control freak since he seems so unwilling to accept the sort of help that most of us would give our right arm for. He may feel insecure about handing over anything of importance, which is probably why he rejected the idea of a secretary in the first place. He may also be worried that his being forced to have a secretary is somehow a reflection on his ability to cope with his workload and he is now stubbornly trying to demonstrate that he can indeed cope.

What he probably hasn't really considered, however, are your feelings in all this. He is so busy proving his point to senior managers that he hasn't noticed that you are going through hell. I would thus advise you to request a meeting with him, perhaps even over lunch away from the office. Tell him how redundant you feel, whilst reassuring him that if he just gave you a chance, you could really help make his work-life easier. You will need to nurse his insecurities, however, by reassuring him that you couldn't possibly do half of the skilled work that he does, but that you are more capable than just doing the filing. Ask him to give you a chance with one small project.

If he does lighten up a little, you will then need to build up his confidence in you. Keep him regularly informed of progress so he doesn't feel out of control. Check everything out with him until he feels he can trust you. Do everything you can to demonstrate the benefits of having secretarial support.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Now Psion buys into Canada
fields.standfirst:
Second takeover in as many days sets record for wireless technology operation
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The British technology firm Psion has announced its second acquisition in two days with a £242m agreed takeover of Canadian wireless network and software developer Teklogix.
fields.body:
The British technology firm Psion has announced its second acquisition in two days with a £242m agreed takeover of Canadian wireless network and software developer Teklogix.

The acquisition is the largest in Psion's history. It will pay 35 Canadian dollars per Teklogix share - a 41% premium on its closing price on Tuesday of C$24.9.

The acquisition will be funded by a combination of shares and around £100m in cash. The equity element is based on an assumed Psion share price of 650p - its trading average over the past few weeks. The deal pushed Psion shares down 17.5 to 647.5p at close of trading yesterday.

Psion plans to merge Teklogix with its enterprise division, creating a larger operation focused on developing mobile internet technology for industry.

Chief executive David Levin said Psion settled on Teklogix after looking at a number of companies in the sector. "This is a company with real earnings, and complementary technology," he said. "Psion Enterprise is too small as it is."

Mr Levin said the merger made sense because there was no duplication of products, and rationalisation and redundancies were not an issue.

Teklogix had a turnover of $93m and pre-tax profits of $14m in the year to March 2000.

The merged operation will be based in Canada and headed by the president of Teklogix, Ian McElroy. The latter's clients include Cadbury Schweppes, Compaq and Volkswagen.

Analysts say the deal is sound but unexciting. One predicted that market capitalisation might be "marginally improved" but that underlying performance in the group was of concern.

However, Mr Levin pointed out that the technology might be extended to other, more lucrative areas. "In a few years you could see this type of technology spread to public institutions such as schools and government offices."

First quarter figures for turnover, released yesterday, were up 47% on the same period in 1999. The statement also said that group margins had been affected by the strength of sterling and heavy investment in product development.

Mr Levin said there was no hint of a profit warning but analysts were cautious. In the financial year to December 1999 Psion had a turnover of £150m with pre-tax profits of £5m.

Psion's first acquisition of the week was announced on Tuesday with the £1.1m pur chase of wireless internet portal Fonedata. A separate announcement on the same day concerned Trivanti, a £9.5m internet services joint venture with United News and Media. Psion has made no secret of its plans to expand by acquisition and further deals were not ruled out in the next 12 months.

Last month Psion's shares rose in response to speculation that the phone software maker Symbian, in which Psion has a 28% stake, would float later in the year for up to £5bn. Psion has repeatedly denied a commitment to flotation of Symbian, which it owns jointly with Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola.

fields.headline: Too studied a passion
fields.standfirst:
Romeo and Juliet **
Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon
fields.trailText:
Romeo and Juliet **
Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon
fields.body:
What is it with director Michael Boyd? First he delivers the sexiest, sprightliest A Midsummer Night's Dream we've seen in years. Now he offers a Romeo and Juliet that is about as passionate as a cold dip at Margate.

Tom Piper's design sets the tone with two curving concrete walls that you initially think could be an abstract nod towards the Berlin Wall but which turn out to be just two curving concrete walls. These create logistical problems for the production, not least in the final scenes. In these, the lovers lug each other around like sacks of potatoes and the bereaved stare down into the mausoleum, like a gaggle of pensioners gathered around a hole in the road.

There is nothing wrong with taking the romance out of Romeo and Juliet. A bloodstain on the concrete stares you in the face all evening - a reminder of the violence that simmers beneath Veronese society. But the rest of the production doesn't carry this idea through, although the ghosts of the dead are ever present, lounging around on the wall.

David Tennant and Alexandra Gilbreath are fine actors but they do not make a convincing pair of lovers. Their performances are too studied, and although Tennant captures the callowness and impetuosity of Romeo, Gilbreath's Juliet seems far too much a middle-aged teenager to fall for him. She has one of the most beautiful voices of her generation but lacks Juliet's vulnerability.

Elsewhere, the production is undercast, with a Mercutio who lacks edge; a stereotyped nurse and a Friar Lawrence you wouldn't trust with your watch, let alone your life. The best thing about the evening is Chris Davey's lighting, which throws an increasingly ghostly pall upon the proceedings.

Until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403.

Tom Piper's design sets the tone with two curving concrete walls that you initially think could be an abstract nod towards the Berlin Wall but which turn out to be just two curving concrete walls. These create logistical problems for the production, not least in the final scenes. In these, the lovers lug each other around like sacks of potatoes and the bereaved stare down into the mausoleum, like a gaggle of pensioners gathered around a hole in the road. There is nothing wrong with taking the romance out of Romeo and Juliet. A bloodstain on the concrete stares you in the face all evening - a reminder of the violence that simmers beneath Veronese society. But the rest of the production doesn't carry this idea through, although the ghosts of the dead are ever present, lounging around on the wall. David Tennant and Alexandra Gilbreath are fine actors but they do not make a convincing pair of lovers. Their performances are too studied, and although Tennant captures the callowness and impetuosity of Romeo, Gilbreath's Juliet seems far too much a middle-aged teenager to fall for him. She has one of the most beautiful voices of her generation but lacks Juliet's vulnerability. Elsewhere, the production is undercast, with a Mercutio who lacks edge; a stereotyped nurse and a Friar Lawrence you wouldn't trust with your watch, let alone your life. The best thing about the evening is Chris Davey's lighting, which throws an increasingly ghostly pall upon the proceedings. Until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403.

webTitle: Delay to Lastminute.com's website revamp irks analysts

fields.headline: Delay to Lastminute.com's website revamp irks analysts
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com is close to announcing a more technologically advanced and user-friendly version of its website, but analysts fear that a delay in the process and higher than anticipated development costs will hit short-term results.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com is close to announcing a more technologically advanced and user-friendly version of its website, but analysts fear that a delay in the process and higher than anticipated development costs will hit short-term results.

The late-bookings service pledged at the time of its stock market flotation in March to introduce version 2 of its website by June 30, but the service is still a few weeks from going live.

Analysts received demonstrations of dummy versions of the new site for the first time yesterday morning. They were broadly impressed by what they saw and by the announcement of new technology partners to support it, but the delay led some to downgrade quarterly forecasts as a result.

Geoff Ruddell of Deutsche Bank said he had expected the new and faster version of the site to be operational by now, boosting sales and third quarter revenues. He has trimmed his revenue forecast for the third quarter from £10.4m to £9.7m and has added £1m to his marketing and development cost forecast of £7.7m.

Lastminute.com is due to report its third quarter results next month. In common with most internet start-ups, Lastminute.com's website was built quickly and cheaply. The rapid growth of the company's customer base and traffic has quickly made it outmoded. Technology companies NCorp, Epiphany, and whereonearth.com are to help provide more targeted services.

Lastminute.com has built one of Europe's best-known internet brands and at relatively little cost. Yesterday internet research agency MMXI Europe named it Britain's best-known online travel brand.

Shares in the company have steadily recovered from the lows experienced in the aftermath of its botched flotation. Morgan Stanley, its own stockbroker, claims Lastminute.com has been Britain's best-performing internet share since March 14.

Lastminute.com shares closed up 4.5p at 216p yesterday, 94p above the low experienced in mid-May.

fields.headline: Grunge therapy
fields.standfirst:
Graham Coxon ****
Sheffield Leadmill
fields.trailText:
Graham Coxon ****
Sheffield Leadmill
fields.body:
There's something surreal about seeing half of one of the biggest bands of the 90s in the cramped confines of the Leadmill, especially when that half includes Graham Coxon. The idiosyncratic Blur guitarist is painfully shy and famously loathes the spotlight. This would prompt anyone to wonder just why he is not only embarking on a solo tour but actually fronting a band. However, Coxon has semi-jokingly referred to this tour as "my therapy" and is clearly relishing the chance to get out of himself (and his Blur persona) and return to venues he grew up in.

Having failed to shake off an awkwardness with fame by guzzling alcohol, Coxon has turned to something stronger: unfeasibly loud, American- influenced punk rock. Coxon's homage to punk obscurities such as Mission of Burma and the Meat Puppets could be seen as a rock star showing off his leftfield credentials. But he genuinely loves this music. Assembling a fearsome band (Blur's drummer Dave Rowntree, along with guitarists from Idlewild and unknowns Thirteen Thirteen), Coxon's excursions sound like punk-grunge should: fabulously tight and exceedingly rough. It's actually a compliment to say that on the phobia- confronting The Fear they recall a drunk being attacked by a swarm of bees.

That this isn't a "solo career" intended to be taken seriously is underlined when Coxon howls with laughter as the cymbal stand almost crashes over. And yet, the untold emotion he puts into Mission of Burma's Fame & Fortune shows that there is sincerity behind the tomfoolery.

As a frontman, Coxon makes a fabulous guitarist. Adjusting the microphone stand so he can stare at the floor, he introduces one song as "er about er goats" and another, wearily, as being about "adolescent persecution complexes". The ensuing Leave me Alone may be discordant, but only a cold heart could fail to warm to Coxon's sense of the ridiculous.

Following the hypnotic, Joy Division groove of The Lake, he exits the stage the wrong way. Looking up in mock horror at the chuckling audience, he buries his head in his hands and howls, before running off to the sanctity of the tour bus.

Graham Coxon plays the Garage, London N5 (020-7607 1818) tomorrow and Saturday.

webTitle: UBS pays $10bn for stronger foothold in US

fields.headline: UBS pays $10bn for stronger foothold in US
fields.standfirst:
PaineWebber will help Swiss partner find other American targets but deal is no threat to big investment banks
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Swiss banking group UBS yesterday bought US broking firm PaineWebber for $10.8bn and indicated it would make further acquisitions.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Swiss banking group UBS yesterday bought US broking firm PaineWebber for $10.8bn and indicated it would make further acquisitions.

While the deal gives UBS a stronger foothold in the attractive US market, analysts said the Swiss bank still could not compete with leading investment banks such as Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley in the US.

Donald Marron, the head of PaineWebber, said he would help the Swiss banking group look for further US acquisitions following completion of their merger.

Yesterday's deal, which could amount to $12.4bn if all share options are exercised, is the latest example of rapid consolidation in the global financial services industry, accelerated in the US since regulatory changes allowed banks to own broking firms.

Mr Marron, whose bank lists America's richest citizens among its clients, said UBS would be a "perfect fit" because of limited overlap and a complementary global client base.

UBS, the world's largest private bank, owns investment banking group Warburg, which employs thousands of bankers in London who are expected to be untouched by this US deal.

PaineWebber, largely a domestic US broking firm, employs just 200 in the City, and the companies said yesterday that a $400m restructuring job would probably cover cuts to back office staff in the US. Fewer than 1,000 job losses are expected. It also expects to spend $875m to tie in "key PaineWebber professionals" over the next three years.

"There's very little overlap in London," one relieved UBS Warburg insider said yesterday. When asked about future mergers, Mr Marron said: "I think that's what they ought to do. There are lots and lots of opportunities [in the US]."

The 65-year-old, who is understood to have signed a three-year contract with UBS, will continue at the merged bank as chairman of UBS North America and strategic adviser to Marcel Ospel, the UBS chief executive. Mr Ospel was instrumental in the creation of UBS when he merged his Swiss Banking Corporation with Union Bank of Switzerland two years ago.

Shares in PaineWebber rose more than 30% yesterday morning, to $661/16, following the $73.50 a share offer. Shares in other Wall Street banks, including JP Morgan and Lehman, rose as traders predicted further merger activity.

Mr Ospel said the deal represented a "full and fair price for PaineWebber's shareholders". Shares in UBS fell by about 6% after the bank said it would issue 42m new shares to pay for part of the acquisition.

Mr Ospel, who first approached Mr Marron about a takeover in late spring, said the group would consider other, smaller acquisitions in the US.

"We obviously have high aspirations to grow our business," he said. "It is conceivable that we cannot fulfil these ambitions with organic growth only and we will have to consider other acquisitions."

The takeover, which still has to win regulatory approval in the US and is not expected to close until later this year, does little to improve the group's investment banking operations in the US, where it operates as UBS Warburg.

Judah Kruashaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that the enlarged UBS "would appear not to pose a meaningful new threat to the major US bulge bracket securities firms".

fields.headline: Jobless rate at 25-year low
fields.standfirst:
Loss of 95,000 manufacturing workers is sole blot on employment figures
Money Unlimited
Ignore the hype, New Deal works
fields.trailText: In a move which wiped out the bad news from Tuesday's poor inflation figures and sparked renewed speculation that interest rates might have peaked, the office for national statistics said average earnings grew by just 4.6% in the latest three months, down from 5.1% previously, despite a drop of 11,900 in the number of people out of work and claiming benefit in June.
fields.body:
The government opened a major public relations offensive yesterday after new figures showed that the unemployment rate fell to a 25-year low last month without putting upward pressure on wages.

In a move which wiped out the bad news from Tuesday's poor inflation figures and sparked renewed speculation that interest rates might have peaked, the office for national statistics said average earnings grew by just 4.6% in the latest three months, down from 5.1% previously, despite a drop of 11,900 in the number of people out of work and claiming benefit in June.

The fall in the claimant count took the unemployment level down to 1,109,900, 3.8% of the workforce - the lowest rate since November 1975 when it was 3.7%.

The government's preferred measure of unemployment, the internationally agreed ILO definition, which has wider scope, was also down - by 47,000 in the latest quarter to 1,668,000 - and employment climbed by 126,000 to a record high of 27,909,000.

Flanked by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, the prime minister hailed the figures as a milestone for the British economy. "The employment figures mean that there are now over 1m more people in work since we took office just over three years ago," Mr Blair told a Downing Street news conference.

"Those who said our policies could not create, or would destroy jobs, those who predicted recession have been proved wrong ... It is now possible for the first time in a generation to talk about full employment."

The only blot on this latest set of labour market statistics was a continued loss of jobs in manufacturing, where the strong pound has contributed to weak orders and output.

The ONS said manufacturing employment was down by 95,000 over the year, with people being laid off in all industrial sub-sectors apart from wood products. Kate Barker, chief economic adviser at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "The rise in jobs is great news, but this data also shows a weakness in the manufacturing sector where the rate of decline in employment has recently accelerated."

City analysts said the marked fall in average earnings growth, caused by millennium-related payments dropping out of the calculation, took away the only credible argument that hawks on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, such as deputy governor Mervyn King and chief economist John Vickers, had for higher interest rates.

While some warned that the earnings figures should be treated with caution after their recent overhaul, most were satisfied that the danger of a wage-price spiral identified earlier in the year had passed. "A very encouraging set of data, indicating that the inflationary threat from the labour market is receding," said Dharshini David of HSBC.

"Headline earnings growth fell to 4.6% - only just above the maximum the Bank of England views as consistent with the inflation target."

She added that, while the fall in unemployment showed the labour market was continuing to tighten, the absence of an acceleration in wage inflation backed the case that interest rates had peaked at 6%.

Neil Mackinnon, economist at Merrill Lynch, agreed. "While the Bank of England will certainly remain alert over the impact of higher oil prices on the inflation rate, generally the underlying picture is pretty good."

Gilts and interest rate futures gained ground on the perception that interest rates were less likely to rise again.

fields.headline: Somerfield drops final dividend
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Somerfield revealed the extent of its woes yesterday when a 70% drop in profits forced it to abandon its final dividend payment to beleaguered shareholders.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Somerfield revealed the extent of its woes yesterday when a 70% drop in profits forced it to abandon its final dividend payment to beleaguered shareholders.

The group, which installed new management three months ago in an attempt to stem its decline since the £1.4bn takeover of Kwik Save in 1998, warned that the situation would get worse in the coming six months before improving.

Such is the extent of its problems - sales in Kwik Save fell 14% over the year and Somerfield's fell 2% - that analysts were reluctant to predict when a dividend might be paid again.

Despite this, the new chief executive, Alan Smith, former head of Punch Taverns, insisted that Somerfield should remain listed on the stock market and not be forced to engage in talks with venture capitalists about taking the company private. He and new chairman John von Spreckelsen, who is credited with turning round Budgens, enjoyed running public companies, he said.

While careful not to make any forecast about when dividend payments might be restored, Mr Smith said that even a 1% increase in sales might give enough leeway for a resumption. One analyst said: "This is a business that could be focusing on its business and not having to look over its shoulder at the stock market and shareholders. At this price, though, they are likely to be reluctant to sell."

The company paid an interim dividend of 1.5p per share, compared with 13.2p total for the previous year. Its shares, which only 18 months ago were at 470p, ended yesterday at 57.5p, down 5%.

The supermarket group's official broker, Deutsche Bank, estimated that cash could be tight for the next 18 months.

Reporting a fall in profits for the year to end-April to £71m, compared with £218m the previous year, Mr Smith insisted that he was optimistic. "These results are about the past," he said.

Instead of rebranding Kwik Save stores with the Somerfield name as initiated by the previous chief executive, David Simons, the group is now running the two brands separately.

Up to 200 of the 450 Kwik Save discount stores will have up to £70,000 each spent on a facelift this year.

Mr Smith indicated that details of a new look and strategy for the 650 Somerfield stores might be discussed in six months' time.

The group has shut down its 24-7 home shopping chain.

fields.headline: Altruism undone
fields.standfirst:
The Good Samaritan ***
Hampstead Theatre, London
fields.trailText:
The Good Samaritan ***
Hampstead Theatre, London
fields.body:
I missed David Haig's first play, My Boy Jack, at Hampstead Theatre. His second one, dealing with the dangerous involvement between a posh Samaritans volunteer and a sexy suicide case, is an informative, intelligent work - the kind of linear, issue- raising play that people allegedly don't write any more.

Haig's hero, Alan, is a married publisher with three children who spends his spare time manning help-lines for the Samaritans. But although Alan's wife works alongside him, his downward spiral begins when the desperate, knife-bearing Carol bursts into her local Samaritans centre. Alan establishes a rapport with her through a shared passion for Bob Dylan: she, against all the rules, becomes dependent on him. What follows is a study in mutual obsession that raises a key question: how do you avoid personal involvement when you are trying to save lives?

You could easily find fault with Haig's play. Facts, such as that 35% of Samaritan callers are silent, are blandly peddled. The flaws in Alan's marriage are never really explained. And a major scene, in which Alan and Carol achieve erotic ecstasy without touching, is eerily reminiscent of an episode in Martin Sherman's play, Bent. But Haig plausibly shows how the altruistic liberalism that drives people like Alan to do voluntary work also leaves them curiously exposed.

Conventionally reared, Alan is clearly turned on by Carol's south London sassiness and emotional vulnerability. It's an old point, dating back to Mr Gladstone's remedial work with London prostitutes, but a valid one: that do-gooding is inseparable from sex, and that helpers are often the ones most in need of attention.

But Haig, an ex-Samaritan, raises these doubts without undermining the principle of voluntary work. And, in John Dove's alert production, his play comes fiercely alive in the bruising confrontations between Alan and Carol.

Partly, it's a matter of class. Julian Wadham has just the right too-good-to-be-true quality of a smooth man who knows a bit about everything. But the revelation is Claudie Blakley. She gives a brilliantly accurate portrayal of a working-class mother who is shrewd, sexy, manipulative but also aware that life has dealt her a series of dud hands. Jane Gurnett does all she can with the underwritten role of Alan's wife.

The real thrill comes from the Wadham-Blakley encounters in which Haig mercilessly exposes the weaknesses of the public-school liberal who suddenly discovers himself a slave to passion.

Until August 26. Box office: 020-7722 9301.

webTitle: Pride of Wales make a name for themselves

fields.headline: Pride of Wales make a name for themselves
fields.standfirst: The club who took on Uefa and won play in the European Cup tonight
fields.trailText: Llansantffraid-ym-Mechain, the club who took on Uefa and won, play in the European Cup tonight. Grahame Lloyd traces their path to Europe.
fields.body:
The north Wales village side of Llansantffraid-ym-Mechain already have a victory to celebrate in the new European Champions League season even before they kick off in the elite competition tonight.

Having taken on the might of Uefa and won, a qualifying-round first leg against Estonia's Levadia Maardu at the Racecourse ground in Wrexham should hold little fear for the League of Wales champions.

In a classic case of David versus Goliath, or perhaps David Holdings Incorporated (Wales) versus Goliath, the minnows triumphed over the mighty thanks to a typically robust performance by Mike Harris, the club's diminutive but doughty benefactor.

When the European draw was made in Geneva last month, the Welsh representatives in the Champions League were listed as TNS Llansantffraid rather than Total Network Solutions FC, the club's official name under its deal with Harris's Oswestry data communications firm.

"We were quite horrified to find out half an hour before the draw that we were being referred to as TNS Llansantffraid," said Harris, who insisted on the name change when his firm became involved in 1997.

"Uefa officials said there had to be a geographical location but we pointed out that Celtic and Rangers were there without any mention of Glasgow, so their argument didn't hold up."

As a formal protest was considered the draw for European football's most prestigious competition was delayed and the error was corrected verbally when the team were drawn against Levadia Maardu. "We've since had a very amicable conversation with Uefa," said Harris, "and I think they'll be correcting their mistake permanently in the very near future."

Breaking eggs and ruffling feathers comes naturally to Harris. Having persuaded the locals to accept the change of name and then put Uefa in its place, he is locking horns with the BBC over their treatment of League of Wales results on Saturday Final Score.

Harris denies he is just using the club as a marketing tool for his company. The first half of a five-year £250,000 sponsorship deal has seen TNS's turnover rise to £35m while the club have qualified for the Champions League for the first time.

The players may still change in the nearby community centre but the clubhouse, originally two fabricated classrooms, has been refurbished and extended, a new 400-seat stand is being built and a television studio and camera gantry have rounded off the development of Recreation Park.

Andy Cale's appointment as manager two years ago proved the catalyst for the club's success. Armed with a doctorate in sports science and sports psychology, the assistant coach to England's under-15, under-16 and under-18 teams has moulded a bunch of part-timers into an efficient unit that opponents have found a tough nut to crack.

"Andy brought a new air of professionalism to the club," said Graham Breeze, Cale's predecessor and now general manager. "We've got great strength in depth, having scrapped our reserve side and concentrated on a first-team squad of 20 players last season.

"We also based our game on not conceding goals and, although on occasions we weren't pretty to watch and received a bit of criticism, we defended well and won a lot of matches by the odd goal."

The squad boasts the usual motley crew, including an electrican, a couple of students, a British Aerospace engineer and a TNS account manager.

Uefa safety regulations mean that tonight's first leg is at the Racecourse, where the groundsman is John Edwards, the father of TNS's captain and defender Timmy - a self-employed builder.

The midfielder Gary Evans is the sole survivor of the Llansantffraid team who, four years ago, as the Welsh Cup winners, drew 1-1 with Ruch Chorzow at the Racecourse before losing 5-0 in Poland.

"We were a bunch of lads who didn't really expect to win anything," said Evans, an office worker from nearby Welshpool. "We'd have a few beers and a good time but now everything's very well organised. It's sad that the village team with a few local players in it has gone for ever but we need to keep going forward."

Going forward is something very much in keeping with the style of the club's backer Harris, a self-driven maverick who assured a sceptical Llansantffraid committee back in 1997 that, with the help of TNS, the Saints would lift the League of Wales title within five years.

Harris has won over everyone by competing with bigger Welsh clubs, delivering ahead of schedule and, more importantly, by not alienating the locals. His company may provide the backbone but the heart of the village team is still beating. A legion of chief cooks and bottlewashers still run the club, perched on a hill side two miles inside the Welsh border.

Their opponents tonight can boast half a dozen Estonian internationals. TNS's club president Mike Hughes can hardly wait to test them. "We love being in the limelight," he says beaming.

webTitle: Not many drinkers in the Anelka Lounge

fields.headline: Not many drinkers in the Anelka Lounge
fields.trailText: It is 15 years since Gary Lineker last raised an arm to celebrate scoring for Leicester City. But Leicester fans can still raise a nostalgic, post-match glass to an absent friend in the Gary Lineker Suite, named not in recognition of his recent fame as Match Of The Day presenter or as the face of Walker's crisps but because he is fondly remembered as the local boy who scored 95 goals in 194 appearances for the Foxes.
fields.body:
It is 15 years since Gary Lineker last raised an arm to celebrate scoring for Leicester City. But Leicester fans can still raise a nostalgic, post-match glass to an absent friend in the Gary Lineker Suite, named not in recognition of his recent fame as Match Of The Day presenter or as the face of Walker's crisps but because he is fondly remembered as the local boy who scored 95 goals in 194 appearances for the Foxes.

Similarly fans at Birmingham City can enjoy a pie and a pre-match pint in a lounge named after Trevor Francis, not because he is the current manager but because they can still take the chill off the darkest days by recalling the thrill of seeing him score four goals against Bolton as a 16-year-old and another 114 in 278 appearances.

One could not, however, imagine a Nicolas Anelka suite at Highbury - unless, of course, it featured a sulky portrait, a much stamped passport, a selection of flight tickets, a broken contract and a getaway car.

Anelka, the ultimate papillon of modern football, made an acrimonious exit from Arsenal last year, declaring his undying love for Real Madrid. Now, having fallen out of love faster than Patsy Kensit, he is apparently ready to rekindle his relationship with his first club, Paris St-Germain.

In a modern game reflecting today's peripatetic workforce one does not expect blind loyalty of a player to a club but there has never been such a cynical abuse of the transfer system from players who, without a hint of self-mockery, lift their shirts to kiss the club badge after scoring a goal.

Players, like employees anywhere, have always been lured by the chance of fame and wealth in greener and larger pastures, and fans have always accepted that. Thus Lineker left Filbert Street with the blessing of Leicester's management and supporters, who understood that his ambition and talent had outgrown them.

Birmingham fans knew, too, they could not hang on to a boy of Francis's ability but they took vicarious pleasure in his achievements at Nottingham Forest, Manchester City, Sampdoria and with England.

It is difficult these days for supporters to identify with would-be heroes who pass through so quickly they barely leave a stud mark to remember them by. And, though one risks being accused of looking at life through rose-tinted spectacles, or at least sepia-toned ones, fans did have more empathy with local players with whom they might have played alongside at school or nodded at across a garden fence. Today, even if a player is local, he is likely to dwell in a gated mansion on the outskirts of town.

Arsenal's assistant manager Pat Rice, who still lived in one of the tiny houses around Highbury when helping the club win the Double in 1970-71, was one of nine home-grown players in that side who had known no other club. Of Arsenal's 1998 Double winners only Ray Parlour and the captain Tony Adams can claim that.

Adams is not the only example of a modern player allowing loyalty at least a seat at the negotiating table. Although he brokered a fantastic salary increase, Roy Keane clearly did not want to leave Manchester United. And Sol Campbell, despite endless speculation about his future, is still at Tottenham, whom he joined as a trainee.

Campbell's agent Sky Andrew says: "No one gives Sol any credit for still being with the club. He loves the club and wants them to do well." Sadly the likes of Anelka would probably dismiss him as a mug.

fields.headline: Court fines Sutton for assault
fields.trailText: Chris Sutton's £6m transfer to Celtic was yesterday overshadowed by a conviction for spitting in the face of a Manchester United fan.
fields.body:
Chris Sutton's £6m transfer to Celtic was yesterday overshadowed by a conviction for spitting in the face of a Manchester United fan.

The Chelsea striker was found guilty of two counts of common assault at London's Horseferry Road magistrates court. He was ordered to pay a total of £700 made up of fines of £300, costs of £200 and £200 compensation to his victim, a 25-year-old trainee barrister Richard Partridge.

The incident happened outside a Soho restaurant in the early hours of a Sunday morning last October after Sutton, 27, had been celebrating his wife Samantha's birthday.

Sutton's conviction follows his trouble with the law six years ago when, on the occasion of his then record £5m transfer from Norwich City to Blackburn, he spent a night in the police cells following a row in a nightclub after which he damaged a car and was chased by two police cars. Last year his agent claimed Sutton had been the victim of a malicious internet campaign.

 Charlton's goalkeeper Simon Royce has completed his transfer to Leicester. The former Southend player, who was out of contract, will replace Pegguy Arphexad who has moved to Liverpool.

webTitle: Crespo to join Lazio in record £36m transfer

fields.headline: Crespo to join Lazio in record £36m transfer
fields.trailText: The Italian champions Lazio said yesterday they had agreed to make Hernan Crespo the world's most expensive footballer in a deal worth £36m.
fields.body:
The Italian champions Lazio said yesterday they had agreed to make Hernan Crespo the world's most expensive footballer in a deal worth £36m.

The Rome club are to give Parma two midfielders, Argentina's Matias Almeyda and Portugal's Sergio Conceicao, plus 35bn lire (£12m), in exchange for Crespo, who scored 22 goals last season.

All told, the deal is valued at 110 billion lire (£36m). That would beat the record fee of £31m which Internazionale paid Lazio for another striker, Christian Vieri a year ago.

Lazio have already signed another Argentine forward, Claudio Lopez, from Valencia.

Meanwhile Lazio's owner, Sergio Cragnotti, has dismissed suggestions that his side could be stripped of their first Serie A title for 26 years.

Cragnotti and the club's midfielder Sebastian Veron are under investigation over the validity of the Argentine player's Italian citizenship.

The inquiry could lead to the pair being charged with forgery but Cragnotti insists that the club is innocent, pointing out that Lazio did not handle Veron's naturalisation. "They want to take the title from us? They can do everything," he said. "I am not worried."

Veron had applied for Italian citizenship last autumn so that he might be exempt from an Italian football federation ruling banning a team from fielding more than three non-EU players in a match. He believed his maternal great-great-grandmother had emigrated from Calabria to Argentina in the early 1920s.

The Rome public prosecutor Silverio Piro, however, alleges that papers were forged to prove Veron's Calabrian origins. Last weekend Piro indicated that in October he will apply to a judge to have Veron, Cragnotti and other Lazio officials tried on forgery charges.

If the documentation were to prove false, Lazio would have broken the rules in at least 19 Serie A games last season when Veron played alongside three non-EU players.

 Zlatko Zahovic, Slovenia's impressive midfielder in Euro 2000, has signed for Spain's Champions League finalists Valencia in a £6m move from Olympiakos of Greece.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe reduce Adams to despair
fields.trailText: It is uncertain what Pythagoras would have made of the NatWest series but he might have concluded that the sum of Zimbabwe is clearly greater than the sum of the other two sides. Only a duffer at trig would suggest this is an equilateral triangle.
fields.body:
It is uncertain what Pythagoras would have made of the NatWest series but he might have concluded that the sum of Zimbabwe is clearly greater than the sum of the other two sides. Only a duffer at trig would suggest this is an equilateral triangle.

Zimbabwe have not only won their three opening matches in this series but have done so with some elan, by six wickets, five wickets and, against West Indies here yesterday, by 70 runs. With half their matches still to play, they have already qualified for the final of this tournament on Saturday week.

West Indies and England may well have played out a Test match of heroic measurements at Lord's but it obviously took a considerable toll. There is a terrible torpor about these sides at the moment that nudges recollection of a scene in the film Beau Geste, in which dead soldiers are propped up in the parapets to mimic the alive and dangerous.

Well though Zimbabwe played, it must be said that West Indies were simply awful. This was a horror show from the Jimmy Adams family that matched anything from their famously tortured tours of recent years.

When Courtney Walsh, Curtly Ambrose and Brian Lara are not performing, and the first two were not even playing yesterday (Walsh, like Shivnarine Chanderpaul, is to take no further part in the series), this looks a side of distinct ordinariness.

In pursuit of a target of 257 they batted like tyros and scored only 186 for eight. When they were 57 for six, on a good pitch, it seemed likely that they would undercut their lowest score in one-day internationals, the 87 they scored against Australia in 1992-93. They seemed certain to be heading for only their sixth defeat by 100 runs or more in 403 one-day internationals.

In the field they were even worse. After winning the toss and choosing to field, presumably on the basis that Zimbabwe had proved themselves more redoubtable chasers than the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in this series, they dropped six catches and missed a stumping.

Their ground fielding, meanwhile, was so abysmal that Adams must have been tempted to move the famous lime tree to cover point. Their bowling was merely weak.

Adams said afterwards: "It was a very bad performance. Our batting, bowling and fielding were all poor. We must all sit down and decide where we are going to go from here."

It did not help them, of course, that this was another chill, damp day from a blighted summer. They do not enjoy fielding with frozen fingers and the conditions were almost as bleak as the day last summer when this ground staged its first international, the World Cup fixture between England and Kenya.

It was so cold and wet that day that everyone felt sorry for the streaker, before the announcer came out with the delicious and unconscious double entendre : "The covers are now coming off." This time it was the wheels that came off as far as West Indies were concerned.

It was a tribute to the fine running of the Zimbabwe batsmen that only 50 of their runs came in boundaries. Neil Johnson and Guy Whittall set the tempo with a first-wicket stand of 89 in 20 overs. But Johnson (51) was dropped when he had scored 17 and Whittall (83) may not have won his man of the match award if he had not been dropped on 40, 49 and 80.

The rejuvenated Alistair Campbell played the most fluent innings, a 78-ball unbeaten 77 which included a six over long-on off Adams. But Ridley Jacobs, who had a nightmare behind the wicket, should have stumped him off Chris Gayle when he had made only five.

In reply West Indies were 23 for three when Sherwin Campbell clipped to square-leg, Gayle chipped to mid-on and Wavell Hinds was caught and bowled by Bryan Strang. It was all over for them when Adams was run out and Lara bowled from successive deliveries. Zimbabwe's only gripe was when the crowd taunted the quirky-actioned Grant Flower as a chucker. They can put up with that.

 Andy Flintoff, who hopes to be fit for England's next match, against Zimbabwe at Old Trafford tomorrow, has responded to criticism of his weight. Only a duffer at trig would suggest this is an equilateral triangle. Zimbabwe have not only won their three opening matches in this series but have done so with some elan, by six wickets, five wickets and, against West Indies here yesterday, by 70 runs. With half their matches still to play, they have already qualified for the final of this tournament on Saturday week. West Indies and England may well have played out a Test match of heroic measurements at Lord's but it obviously took a considerable toll. There is a terrible torpor about these sides at the moment that nudges recollection of a scene in the film Beau Geste, in which dead soldiers are propped up in the parapets to mimic the alive and dangerous. Well though Zimbabwe played, it must be said that West Indies were simply awful. This was a horror show from the Jimmy Adams family that matched anything from their famously tortured tours of recent years. When Courtney Walsh, Curtly Ambrose and Brian Lara are not performing, and the first two were not even playing yesterday (Walsh, like Shivnarine Chanderpaul, is to take no further part in the series), this looks a side of distinct ordinariness. webTitle: Time for the media to end the Boycott boycott

fields.headline: Time for the media to end the Boycott boycott
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel calls for the rehabilitation of Geoff Boycott and his immediate return to the commentary box.
fields.body:
Dominic Cork returned to the England team in triumph at Lord's after a long period in exile, having been scorned as divisive and difficult. The views of the most divisive and difficult cricketer of them all were not vouchsafed to most of us.

Geoff Boycott apparently spent the game working for TalkSport, the station now relegated back to obscurity, having spent the series in South Africa always mentioning its sponsors but only occasionally the score. I also thought I caught a snatch of him giving a mini-pontification on Radio 5 Live. From the mainstream cricket media he remains barred, the upshot of the court case in 1998 when he was convicted by a French court for assaulting one of his lovers, Margaret Moore, who said he hit her at least 20 times during a row in a French hotel bedroom.

Channel 4 employs various analysts not fit to blanco his boots as players, or polish his microphone as broadcasters, but Boycott stays unselected. Over the past few days, however, a campaign has been gathering momentum to free the Fitzwilliam One. It began with a piece by Boycott's biographer, Leo McKinstry, in the Spectator, complaining that his conviction was "an outrage" and his banishment from the commentary box "an ever greater disgrace".

"Margaret Moore was given damages of one franc after the trial," wrote McKinstry. "Boycott appears to have been handed a life sentence." His call was taken up on Saturday by the Daily Mail's star columnist Ian Wooldridge, who called the article "a masterpiece" and said: "I know Boycott was not guilty of the offence as charged and, had he hit Miss Moore 20 times, he would have killed her."

"Masterpiece" is pushing it a bit, though the article was a pretty smart way for McKinstry to plug his book (Boycs: The True Story, Partridge Press, £16.99). The book is, in any case, worth plugging for its own merits. It is well researched and well written but above all fair-minded and balanced (pause for joke about Boycott having a chip on both shoulders). This is rare indeed when it comes to this subject who, as a player, divided people into lovers and haters like no one of his era save his heroine Margaret Thatcher.

It is hard now, when county cricket seems so drab, even to remember the tempests that roared round Yorkshire when Boycott was playing. But everyone agrees he is a brilliant broadcaster, where his persona, as McKinstry puts it, is the exact opposite of his dreary batting: "Passionate, animated, daring". I think they are two sides of the same coin.

Boycott mastered the craft of commentary as carefully as he did batting, and evolved his technique in the same studied manner - he decided the way to carve out a career as a commentator was to take risks and play shots, which he often does brilliantly. It is also hard to remember now that he was one of England's worst ever captains - but then that goes for several others still in business.

Boycott was fatuously casual about the French judicial system, which led to his downfall. His near-comical arrogance and his insularity made him easy for the judge to convict. But, as McKinstry says, a lump on the forehead and a bit of bruising are an improbable outcome of 20 blows. And a study of Moore's behaviour after the case - first attempting desperately to stay in touch with Boycott, then apparently trying to sell her story for £1m - hardly suggests to me a convincingly pathetic victim. No one knows what goes on in another couple's bedroom but I find it hard to imagine that any jury could have thought the case proved beyond reasonable doubt.

He has been arrested before, you know. For reasons that were obscure enough at the time, never mind now, Boycott was placed under house arrest in 1986 in Trinidad in company with the then-Guardian cricket correspondent for non-possession of a work permit. This fails to make McKinstry's biography, though I have dined out on the story ever since.

Having thus shared a bedroom with Boycott, I have to say he behaved impeccably, and very peaceably, towards me. I am not so sure I would be so trusting about Miss Moore. Guilty or not, Boycott has been punished by the court. It is time for cricket to rehabilitate him.

webTitle: South Africa feel the heat in Colombo

fields.headline: South Africa feel the heat in Colombo
fields.trailText: South Africa need a victory in today's encounter with Pakistan to qualify for Friday's final of the triangular Singer tournament after suffering an eight-wicket defeat yesterday by Sri Lanka in Colombo.
fields.body:
South Africa need a victory in today's encounter with Pakistan to qualify for Friday's final of the triangular Singer tournament after suffering an eight-wicket defeat yesterday by Sri Lanka in Colombo.

On a day of stifling heat Sri Lanka maintained their unbeaten run in the tournament, winning with 22.3 overs remaining. After a woeful batting performance by the Proteas an exhilarating innings by Avishka Gunawardene, who scored 87 runs off only 76 balls, completed the rout.

After three successive defeats Pakistan had all but resigned themselves to elimination but now have a chance of salvation, the difference in the net run rate having been narrowed.

Pakistan now have a net run rate of -0.43 with South Africa, who would have reached the final had they won yesterday, only marginally ahead on -0.89.

The 23-year-old Gunawardene, a player of immense strength, was in magnificent form after the South Africans had been bundled out for 167.

His second-wicket partner Marvan Atapattu remained on 44 not out after Gunawardene had plundered 16 boundaries. The troubled South Africans did not help themselves by bowling shoddily, yielding 22 extras, including eight wides.

Last week South Africa lost 10 wickets for 62 runs in another defeat by Sri Lanka and they self-destructed again in front of a sparse crowd yesterday. South Africa's openers Lance Klusener and Gary Kirsten were both dismissed with only four runs on the scoreboard and the side never really recovered.

Their innings was only saved from being totally shambolic by Jacques Kallis who remained on 83 not out off 148 balls. The only other significant contribution from Shaun Pollock's side came from Andrew Hall who made 32 off 34 deliveries.

webTitle: Australians rally to defence of 'chucker' Lee

fields.headline: Australians rally to defence of 'chucker' Lee
fields.trailText: Brett Lee, the latest claimant to the title of the fastest bowler on earth, is under investigation for throwing by the International Cricket Council - nearly four months after Test umpires first expressed official doubts about his action.
fields.body:
Brett Lee, the latest claimant to the title of the fastest bowler on earth, is under investigation for throwing by the International Cricket Council - nearly four months after Test umpires first expressed official doubts about his action.

The affair has brought angry Australian accusations of ineptitude against the game's governing body, with the ICC, true to form, not caring to offer any explanation for the extreme delay before an investigation was launched.

"I'm shocked. I'm absolutely confident with my action. My action is pure," Lee said in Sydney yesterday, only hours after he had learned that the council's illegal deliveries panel will review his action and report their findings to the Australian Cricket Board.

Australia's prime minister, John Howard, even lent his support during a flying visit to India. "I can't believe it, he looks a beautiful bowler to me," he said.

Lee, who has taken 31 wickets in his first five Tests, is the second out-and-out fast bowler to run foul of Test umpires this year as international cricket stands on the brink of its greatest throwing crisis for 40 years. Pakistan's Shoaib Akhtar was suspended by the panel following video evidence taken in Australia last winter, a series in which Lee, ironically, usurped him as the world's fastest bowler.

The suspension was controversially overturned by Jagmohan Dalmiya, then the ICC president, and the throwing panel's power to suspend a player was removed. Responsibility for remedial action now rests with the national boards, under ICC supervision.

The Australian board's chief executive Mal Speed insisted that, while the action is being studied, Lee will play in next month's indoor one-day series against South Africa in Melbourne. Australia will also request an independent assessment from their fast bowling great, Dennis Lillee.

The former England captain Mike Denness might be able to explain the four-month delay between umpires' report and ICC inquiry. He was the match referee who received reports questioning Lee's action from Srinivas Venkataraghavan and Arani Jayaprakash during the series in New Zealand.

fields.headline: Asian appeal
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on how charities are courting ethnic minorities
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill on how charities are courting ethnic minorities
fields.body:
The traditional image of a charity supporter is white, middle class, elderly and female. Yet, the disposable income of Britain's black and ethnic minority communities is estimated at £13.4 bn. Deepak Mahtani, a fundraising consultant, says: "For many wealthy members of ethnic minorities, financial success leads to philanthropy and charities should wake up to this."

Next week, Mahtani will tell delegates at the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers' (ICFM) convention in Birmingham just how to tap into this potentially rich source of income. Mahtani is the international director of the South Asian Development Partnership, a trustee of three other charities and an adviser to a number of voluntary organisations.

"Charities need to understand how cultural differences impact on attitudes to giving within individual communities," says Mahtani. Hindus, he points out, are superstitious about drawing up wills in case it precipitates their demise. And the role of women, dowries and the older son as heir can affect donor behaviour.

However, Mahtani believes attitudes are shifting as people from black and ethnic minorities become more integrated. "The first generation of immigrants focused on surviving, but the second generation is looking to go one step further and be accepted in mainstream society," he says.

A key motivator, particularly for some members of the Asian community, is public recognition. "It is about becoming part of the inner circle, it is about status symbols, about achieving more than their parents."

Another factor is often a wish to give something back to a country of origin. Health and education tend to be areas of keen interest, especially among communities that are prone to particular diseases such as leukaemia, certain eye conditions and diabetes.

Some charities working in these fields do not seem to be moving very fast to cultivate support, however. Afro-Caribbean and Asian people are three times more likely to become diabetic than their European counterparts, yet Diabetes UK, for one, does not specifically target ethnic minority groups for fundraising.

A charity which has investigated the potential in this area is the Cancer Research Campaign (CRC). It was prompted by the fact that Afro-Caribbean men are more prone to prostate cancer than are white men. The charity has set up focus groups, involving community leaders, to raise awareness and generate support.

Claire Mallinson, CRC director of fundraising and marketing, says: "I am conscious that historically we haven't communicated effectively with all groups in society. At the moment we are doing a lot of listening to find out how we can be more accessible."

Fundraising from within black and ethnic minority communities can also be a challenge. The ICFM, itself, has just started a three-year project with two charities within the sector to develop fundraising training. The plan is to disseminate to others the experience of HIV charity Blackliners and the Sickle Cell Society.

Louise Engleman, the ICFM's head of training and development, says many small charities lack the infrastructure to fundraise and they rely solely on state funding. "We will be looking at how to attract donations from companies and celebrities and how to motivate individuals to volunteer," she says.

Mark Blake, executive director of Blackliners says: "Fundraising from our own community can be difficult because of taboos, but the main problem is having the capacity to do marketing and fundraising."

Two charities with enormous capacity, the NSPCC and Oxfam, have reaped the benefits of fundraising from ethnic minority communities. Oxfam is working closely with the Asian community to raise funds for those affected by the floods in Bangladesh and Orissa in India. Anne Bissell, a spokeswoman, says: "On each occasion, the emergency appeals have been successful and the Asian community has responded very positively." Oxfam has also just launched a marketing campaign in Leicester, with the aim of furthering relationships with the Asian community.

While Oxfam has the advantage of helping causes with which ethnic minority communities may have an affinity, the NSPCC cannot rely on the same appeal. Media officer Avis Johns says: "It was quite a challenge when confronted with the claim that child abuse doesn't happen within Asian communities." However, it was the suggestion of an Asian member of the charity's national appeal board that led to a gala dinner in March this year to celebrate the Hindu festival Holi. The event raised £38,000.

Mahtani emphasises that, traditionally, there has always been a lot of giving within ethnic minority communities. But now that the second and third generations in Britain are more integrated and want recognition for their contribution to society, the time is ripe for charities to develop mutually beneficial relationships. Mahtani warns: "Charities will miss out if they don't widen their donor profile to include young, upwardly mobile people from ethnic minority communities."

fields.headline: Years of wasted talent
fields.standfirst: The need for legislation on age discrimination
fields.trailText: Analysis: The need for legislation on age discrimination
fields.body:
Michelangelo, Benjamin Franklin, Bismarck, Chagall and Churchill all worked into their 80s. Thus, at first glance, there is nothing particularly exceptional about the story of John Brown's dad. Yet it raises some interesting issues. As we forge into the 21st century with an ageing population unprecedented in the history of mankind, what attitudes do we have to work and older age?

For many people in the third world, retirement is not an option. In the developed world, the state pension age is edging upwards as governments struggle to restrain the growth of pension expenditure. While encouraging people to work longer may be official policy, the prevalence of age discrimination in employment remains a real concern and the number of men in active, paid-for employment has tumbled in the past two decades.

Winning the Generation Game, a report from the government's performance and innovation unit, earlier this year addressed some of these issues. It pointed to a macro-economic need for more people to work for more years and proposed a raft of retraining measures and social security reforms to support this policy. It also discussed the value of work, including voluntary work, to the individual. At that individual level, too, the option of retiring on a decent pension is perhaps receding.

There is growing pressure to improve the state pension: it desperately needs improvement since it now represents less than 15% of average earnings. Occupational pensions, hailed as the success story of the last century, are under strain from increasing longevity and falling annuity rates - let alone the spread of defined contribution schemes. Since second tier pensions still remain optional in this country, many people make no contribution to one at all. For them, some "little jobs" may be of real importance in older age.

Too readily, in employment and other fields, we dismiss older people as of little worth or importance. Shrinking from legislation, the government introduced a code of practice for employers, but this shows no sign of changing attitudes substantially. John Brown's dad refused to be bowed by age discrimination, and his story shows the positive value of active ageing.

 Mervyn Kohler is head of public affairs at Help the Aged

John Brown's dad refused to be bowed by age discrimination, and his story shows the positive value of active ageing.  Mervyn Kohler is head of public affairs at Help the Aged

webTitle: Royal family pays tribute to Queen Mother

fields.headline: Royal family pays tribute to Queen Mother
fields.standfirst:
Pomp and circumstance as more than 2,300 people attend service in St Paul's in early celebration of 100th birthday

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The royal family launched celebrations for the Queen Mother's 100th birthday three weeks early yesterday, as nearly the entire family and half the crowned heads of Europe attended a service of celebration and thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral.
fields.body:
The royal family launched celebrations for the Queen Mother's 100th birthday three weeks early yesterday, as nearly the entire family and half the crowned heads of Europe attended a service of celebration and thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral.

The focus of attention, dressed in salmon pink, gave every appearance of robust health and of enjoying the attention, though like her daughter Princess Margaret - who has had a stroke - she used an automatic lift to mount the stairs into the cathedral.

More than 2,300 people attended the hour-long ceremony, men mostly in morning suits and top hats, women in floral hats and dresses, giving the occasion the appearance of a society wedding. Not all such social gatherings, however, have in attendance the band and fanfare trumpeters of the Coldstream Guards, the Yeomen of the Guard, nor even the ageing members of the Honorable Corps of Gentlemen at Arms, resplendent in scarlet and marching to the tap of a walking stick.

They heard the Archbishop of Canterbury in his address mention the A word, abdication, which catapulted the Queen Mother's husband unwillingly to the throne in 1936. Otherwise his words were saccharine: "At a time when such a premium is placed on the young and the new, it is glorious indeed to be celebrating the birthday of someone who can help us travel that country called life... For we cherish in you, ma'am, a continuing openness and responsiveness to people, not just of all backgrounds, but of all ages ... Thank you and God bless you, our dear Queen Mother. Amen."

Of the immediate royal family only Zara Phillips and, of course, the Duchess of York - now consigned to outer darkness - were absent. The grand duke and duchess of Luxembourg, the king and queen of Norway, the king and queen of Belgium, ex-king Constantine of Greece, King Michael of Romania, and Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma were present. Also there were the prime minister, the speaker of the Commons, Betty Boothroyd, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the education secretary, David Blunkett, and the culture secretary, Chris Smith.

They were joined by 14 pensioners who are also 100 this year, some of whom shared a word with the Queen Mother as she was escorted into the cathedral by Prince Charles and his teenage sons. Alex Forsyth, from Aberdeen, who will reach his centenary in September, said afterwards: "It was lovely to see the Queen Mother looking so well."

The diminutive figure sat for the ceremony, flanked by the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh. Afterwards she discarded one of her two walking sticks to wave to the crowd.

There will be two more appearances: at a show at Horseguards Parade next week, and on her birthday, August 4, a drive down the Mall and an appearance on the balcony at Buckingham Palace.

Tony Blair and the Tory leader, William Hague, later led tributes to the Queen Mother in the Commons. Mr Blair said she held "a unique place in the heart of the nation and many people across the world", while Mr Hague hailed her as a "remarkable lady" and said her birthday was an occasion to unite the whole nation.
