fields.trailText: LAZIO FAIRE
fields.body:
LAZIO FAIRE

If The Graduate had begun with a scene in which a plump middle-aged man says "I have two words for you Benjamin: 'tomato ketchup'", then everyone would have laughed. Everyone, that is, apart from the Lazio chairman Sergio Cragnotti, who would have sat up, taken note, formed his own condiments empire, called it Cirio, and used a sizeable chunk of it to fund the biggest transfer outlay in history.

Yesterday Lazio bought the shaggy Argentine goal-junkie Hernan Crespo for £36m (or £12m plus a couple of proven internationals to you, mate). And they did it without his knowledge too. Even as late as this morning Hernan was protesting: "I don't know anything and no one has spoken to me. I am a Parma player." But you don't knock Sergio for long, and by this afternoon Hernan was smothering his chips in a different sauce. "Who could say no to a team like Lazio?" he said, somewhat predictably. "I am ready for the title and the Champions League with Lazio."

But the signing of Crespo does not mark the end of the saga. It wasn't the beginning either, what with Sergio having already signed that nippy Claudio Lopez for £18m - but we digress. Yes, today's news is that Boudewijn Zenden, the Dutch international winger who impressed everybody at Euro 2000 with his name, seems set for a Roman holiday leaving no-hopers Barcelona for a fee of £4m.

Next up on the list is Stefano Fiore who looks set to join the Scudetto winners from Udinese along with teammate Giuliano Giannichedda. "It is part of the job of a team that wins the Italian title to look for young talent," said Cragnotti today as his close season spending headed towards the £80m mark. It helps if you've got a few quid with which to look of course, and to that end the Fiver would like to suggest that Sergio's Cirio top up their funds by licensing the gunk that star signing Hernan seems to favour on his barnet. Crespo'n'dry anyone?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MAMBO NUMBER 13

Hey mambo! Brazilian midfielder Edu here. You know, I've only just got off the plane from steamy South America, but I'm already loving your England. You get me?! I thought you would. Anyway, I'm going through Heathrow terminal three's passport control, so I'll meet with you a bit later.

Hey, hey, hey, what's going on? What do you mean my Portuguese passport is a forgery? What do you mean I can't come in to your England? I was told I did not need a visa! Heh, lady, did anyone ever tell you how beautiful you look? OK, that's not going to work. And I don't suppose there's any way I can avoid leaving Britain immediately on Varig airlines flight RG761 is there? Nooooo!!!!!! Don't give up on me Arsenal Wenger!

Hello there, I am an Arsenal statement. "The club and the player have acted in good faith. Unbeknown to both parties, there was a problem with Edu's passport and, consequently, he has returned to Brazil where the situation can be resolved. We hope to have a clearer indication in the next few days of when he can come back to Britain and join up with the club."

Hey man, the boy Edu's back and he's as sick as a cockatoo. See how I've already picked up one of your sayings? Anyway, I hope to return in about a week, but it doesn't look good. I've yet to make my international debut, so your Home Office isn't looking kindly on my application. And unless I can prove my EU citizenship through a Portuguese passport my career in England looks over before it has begun. Unless Now where did I put that number for Juan Sebastian Veron?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"You can train a donkey to get fit, but ball skills have to be worked on day in, day out. In England all the training seems to be directed towards engine rooms." George Best repeats what the papers were saying about England's failure at Euro 2000. Two weeks later.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ARE YOU A MISUNDERSTOOD MIDFIELDER?

Why not take the Fiver's quick quiz to find out?

1 You spend several hundred quid on a haircut. It makes the front pages of the small papers. How do you feel about it?

a) Really good. In fact, your next goal celebration is even smugger than ever.

b) OK. Although they could have blended the sides a little bit more.

c) Really bad. "Front page headlines are a bit much for getting your hair cut," you think.

2 Famous for posing like a crucified Jesus at Easter last year, you have a tattoo done on your back of a man with his arms outstretched. What does it signify to you?

a) A crucified figure.

b) A crucified figure, quite like a crucified Jesus in fact.

c) "It's not a crucified figure, it's a guardian angel!"

3 A fan of the high life, you have a pop star girlfriend, and spend half your time jetting around the globe. How would you describe yourself?

a) A ponce.

b) A superstar shining bright in fame's firmament.

c) Just one of the lads who has "never thought of myself as someone special".

4 You feel very strongly about the criticism levelled at Phil Neville following England's dismissal from Euro 2000. Which statement best describes your sentiments?

a) The critics have a point, Phil's rubbish.

b) The critics have a point, Phil's rubbish.

c) I didn't come here to talk about football.

d) "Any Manchester United player who plays for England is going to get unfair criticism. Sadly it is part of the national disease."

Your scores: Mostly As: You are not David Beckham.

Mostly Bs: You are not David Beckham.

Mostly Cs: You are still not David Beckham, but you did well to spot David's words from an interview in this month's Manchester United magazine.

Mostly Ds: You are Alex Ferguson talking to the Manchester Evening News. No, really you are.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Taribo West has been linked with a move to England after being told that he can leave AC Milan.

Roberto Baggio's agent, Vittorio Petrone, has been spotted again in London. Could the Divine Ponytail be set for a move to either Arsenal or Chelsea?

Porto have expressed an interest in Wimbledon striker Andeas Lund. "We are waiting to see what Porto have to say," said his agent Rune Hauge.

Celtic manager Martin O'Neill has targeted Norwegian international defender Bjorn Otto Bragstad, according to his club Rosenborg.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, has again reacted bitterly to his country's failure to host the 2006 World Cup, attributing it to a "globalisation of apartheid". He told an ANC meeting that the issue was not Africa's readiness to host the cup, but the Europe's continuing determination to marginalise Africa.

Fiorentina have claimed they turned down a £50m bid for Italian keeeper Francesco Toldo. The club chairman, Vittorio Cecchi Gori, would not name the interested club, but said: "The offer came at the end of last season, but I told them he was not for sale. I'm holding on to him, he's unique. You can't put a price on that sort of talent."

Don Hutchison has been given permission by Everton to open transfer talks with Sunderland.

Cambridge striker Trevor Benjamin will move to Leicester today in a £1.5m deal.

Everton have had a £4.5m bid accepted for Lens' Ghanaian midfielder Alex Nyarko. The Everton manager, Walter Smith, said: "The player will travel here today and we will sit down and discuss personal terms with him and his advisors. If the outcome of that is successful the player will have a medical."

John Gregory claims Gareth Southgate will retain the captaincy at Villa Park despite having stated his desire to leave the club. "I still feel he is the right man for the job," said Gregory.

Arsenal youth striker Jay Bothroyd has criticised Arsenal for not promoting their youth team squad after he completing a £1m transfer to Coventry. "Arsenal want to buy success, but Coventry are bringing up youth. The first team are not interested in youth at Arsenal," he said.

Tranmere have signed former Everton striker Paul Rideout.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC 1: Vinnie Goes to Hollywood (9.30pm) And still doesn't get a mention on the poster for his latest film.

Sky Sports One: Futbol mondial (7pm) The action from Azerbaijani second division is peaking at just the right time.

Six-a-side football - Live! (7.30pm) Or, as Alan Partridge might put it, moribund!

fields.headline: Blair blasts Tory tax u-turn
fields.standfirst: The Labour leader was on good form today as he lambasted William Hague over his change of heart on taxation, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The Labour leader was on good form today as he lambasted William Hague over his change of heart on taxation, writes Julian Glover
fields.body:
The prime minister got stuck in to William Hague today over his apparent u-turn on taxation, accusing the opposition leader of building a "cuts guarantee" into his policies - a theme likely to dominate the run-up to the general election.

Bouncing back from his drubbing in the chamber the week before, Tony Blair told the Commons that the Conservative party's change of heart on taxation was a threat to public services and in some instances "cruel".

The Labour leader's attack on Tory taxation policies dominated the half-hour session. "Yesterday a very significant thing happened", he said, claiming that the shadow chancellor had impaled the Tory leader on "a £17bn spending cuts guarantee". This would mean "£24m of cuts in every constituency".

The Conservative leader was put under pressure over a range of promises. "The one thing everyone knows," said Mr Blair, "is if they vote Tory at the next election it means fewer nurses, fewer teachers, fewer police and fewer hospitals".

He took the opportunity to emphasise that Labour was the party which could best protect public services and insisted there were now clear "dividing lines" between the parties.

Using all six of his permitted questions, William Hague attempted to taunt the prime minister over the foreign secretary's comment last week that British membership of a European single currency was "inevitable".

"Don't we have an utterly divided and shambolic government where you can't agree with the foreign secretary on a central issue of policy," he asked.

"He goes on about his five economic tests but the test that really matters is leadership and he has failed it", Hague added, before turning to the rise in crime expected to be revealed by figures next week.

The prime minister admitted that the government had not always met with success. "It is true that in the last year there has been a three-to-four per cent rise in crime", he said. "The question is what do we do?"

He also agreed that "for the last six years, police numbers have fallen". But he said forthcoming investment would turn this around.

All debate was overshadowed, however, by the announcement by House of Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd that she is to retire this summer.

Related story
Boothroyd bows out

webTitle: We are getting there, says fightback Blair

fields.headline: We are getting there, says fightback Blair
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has attempted to put the troubles of the last few weeks behind him, with a confident performance at a fightback news conference held this morning in Downing Street.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has attempted to put the troubles of the last few weeks behind him, with a confident performance at a fightback news conference held this morning in Downing Street.

With the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, standing alongside, the prime minister shifted the focus from criticism of the government's style of media management towards the hard policy issues he believes will form the focus of debate in the run-up to the next general election.

"I do believe in the end that people will come back to the big issues and the things that I came into politics to do", he told reporters.

He was buoyed by the release of figures showing that general unemployment has hit a 20-year low, and that levels of youth unemployment are the lowest for 25 years. The jobless rate fell to just 3.8%, the lowest since December 1975. Employment rose to just under 28m, equivalent to 74.6% of people of working age. This is the highest level ever recorded.

Asked about the figures, Mr Blunkett said: "Our next challenge is to end long-term unemployment. The figures have been improving steadily over the last three years, with the help of policies put in place by this government."

As a result, said the prime minister, the nation's welfare bill was falling for the first time in 30 years. "We are beginning to make real inroads into the dependency culture," he said. "We now need the next stage - to tackle the problem of poor productivity and lack of essential investment in the nation's future."

Responding to criticism that he was out of touch with the problems facing industry over the high pound, he sounded conciliatory. "I totally understand that if you're in manufacturing industry, it's been tough," he said. "But our record on the economy is a good record - we can be really proud of what Gordon has done."

"Britain is stronger because we are delivering on the fundamentals," Mr Blair said. "We are getting there."

fields.headline: Boothroyd to quit this summer
fields.standfirst: Contenders for the speaker's seat
fields.trailText: House of Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd is to retire this summer, she announced to surprised MPs in the Commons this afternoon.
fields.body:
House of Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd is to retire this summer, she announced to surprised MPs in the Commons this afternoon.

"Be happy for me," the popular 70-year-old told MPs, who greeted the news of her retirement after eight years in the job with a warm round of applause.

Ms Boothroyd's move will spark a race for her prestigious post, with Liberal Democrat MP Menzies Campbell the frontrunner thought to be favoured by Tony Blair.

Many Labour backbenchers are believed to prefer one of their own, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Labour MP for Crewe and Nantwich and veteran of 34 years in the Commons.

MPs will be given a "free" vote to decide which MP becomes the new speaker when parliament reconvenes after the summer recess.

Parliamentary tradition decrees that the chair alternates between the Tories and Labour, but MPs are expected to ignore that by electing a Labour or Liberal Democrat speaker. If Mr Campbell were elected, he would be the first Liberal speaker since 1924.

The speaker's job comes with a £95,000-plus salary similar to that of a cabinet minister but the holder's role as Commons referee guarantees a media profile higher than most ministers.

Although a popular figure, well respected by senior MPs, Ms Boothroyd had been rumoured for some months to be planning her retirement, though most had expected she would stay in the post until after the next general election.

Privately, some ministers have suggested she was too resistant to New Labour's programme of reforms.

Commons leader Margaret Beckett led the tributes to Ms Boothroyd, telling her that MPs had taken "much pride and pleasure" from her tenure.

Ms Beckett confirmed that, according to precedent, Ms Boothroyd would make a valedictory statement to the House before it went into recess on July 26.

fields.headline: Contenders for the speaker's seat
fields.standfirst: Boothroyd to quit this summer
fields.trailText:
Menzies "Ming" Campbell

fields.headline: Waste not, want not
fields.standfirst: Nuclear policy causes tension between Ireland and the UK
fields.trailText: Nuclear policy causes tension between Ireland and the UK
fields.body:
One of British Nuclear Fuels' greatest tormentors for many years has been the Irish government. Now, ministerial papers obtained by the Guardian shed new light on this friction between the Irish and British governments over the Sellafield plant. Britain's largest nuclear complex, on the Cumbrian coast, has even been the subject of several high-level talks between Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern and Tony Blair. In recent months, British Nuclear Fuels Ltd (BNFL), the commercial operator of Sellafield, has suffered a series of humiliating body blows which have cast grave doubt on the future of the plant.

The documents, released under the Irish freedom of information act, highlight several areas of dispute between Britain and Ireland.

They show the Irish are especially irked over the radioactive rubbish which has been discharged into the Irish Sea by Sellafield since 1951. This contamination, which has spread on to the shores of Ireland and of Nordic countries, has included plutonium, one of the most dangerous substances on earth. One Irish government briefing paper from last year noted: "Radioactive discharges from Sellafield to the Irish Sea are a matter of serious concern to Ireland and have been the subject of numerous representations to the UK authorities, both at official and ministerial level."

BNFL has been under fire over one particular radioactive substance discharged by Sellafield, technetium-99, which Irish experts found had increased tenfold over four years.

In October 1998, the Environment Agency announced that BNFL would have to cut by around half the authorised amount of technetium-99 which it could discharge.

But this failed to satisfy the Irish. On the same day, Joe Jacob, the Irish energy minister, wrote to the British government protesting that the decision was completely "unacceptable and would not be in keeping with the commitments made by UK ministers" to cut discharges to virtually none by 2020. And he urged the environment minister, Michael Meacher, to overrule the Environment Agency and reduce the discharges of technetium-99 to a much smaller level. Meacher, believed to be sympathetic to the protests, replied formally that he had noted the Irish views, but scrawled a handwritten note: "I assure you that I am acutely aware of your concerns over this issue, especially over technetium."

In the following month, Blair and Ahern discussed the radioactive discharges and the many Irish objections to the proposed £300m reprocessing plant to produce mixed oxide (MOX) nuclear fuel.

In repeated diplomatic exchanges with British ministers, the Irish have also been agitated about the possibility of a nuclear accident spraying radioactive fallout over their country.

Highly dangerous nuclear waste has been stored in tanks at Sellafield, but the Irish are worried that this unstable waste could rupture the tanks and spew over a wide area. BNFL has been struggling to make safe mounting quantities of this waste by turning it into more manageable glass blocks which can be stored securely. This process, called vitrification, was meant to solve the problem, but a backlog of unprocessed liquid waste has been building up.

John Battle, the then British energy minister, wrote to Jacob in April last year, saying: "You expressed the wish for all liquid high level waste at Sellafield to be vitrified by 2015."

But, in a tart reply Jacob riposted: "I have consistently expressed my desire to see this process accelerated to facilitate a much earlier target date than 2015 for the removal of the backlog of waste."

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Even on a wet afternoon the Diana Memorial Playground in London's Kensington Gardens was heaving with children. We asked six of them to score it out of 10
fields.trailText: The Question: Even on a wet afternoon the Diana Memorial Playground in London's Kensington Gardens was heaving with children. We asked six of them to score it out of 10
fields.body:
Georgia Gray: From London, aged seven

"It's very good. There's a telescope on the ship, and I thought when you looked into it it would be like a telescope, but there's patterns - it's a kaleidoscope. I liked that best." Her first verdict was 7/10 - but her sister came back to say Georgia was so impressed by the "cool loos", hidden in a Tellytubbies mound, that she wanted to give two more points.

Samuel Kennedy: Irish, living in London, aged five

"Those stones like a bridge where you cross the water, that's quite dangerous - I like that. Yeah, it was good. I liked the water place at the top best. I liked the deep bits best. I didn't like the music bit, I didn't like that bit where you push a button and you hear the sea, that was boring. But the water bits were really good."

Harry Bain: Australian, living in London, aged five

"It was the best thing. It's fine. No, it's fantastic. I liked the pirate ship. But I didn't like the silly old music place [the solar-powered sound posts]. And I didn't like that place beside it [a wooden climbing frame built into a circle of oak trees]: the slides didn't work very well - they weren't very fast. I liked the swinging boat best; it was very slopey and scary."

Marianne Pilloux: French, living in London, aged seven

"It is very good. I have seen it before, but this is the first time I have actually played in it. I like the sand and the sort of little water. I don't go very often to playgrounds. We don't have a garden; usually I just play in my room. I like playing with my Barbie best. This is very, very good." Yes, 10/10, but then she modified it, after deep thought.

Rhiannon Long: From Maida Vale, London, aged three

"It's like the seaside - it's good. I like the water. [Rocks, pools and waterfalls which the children can control by moving giant stoppers]. I liked climbing on the rocks. I like the swings - I want to go on the swings now." She returned to say: "A good girl park." She reached her verdict after consultation with her family.

James Doolan: From Liverpool, aged four

James liked the metal pieces, which can be struck like drums and gongs, but was particularly pleased with the Peter Pan pirate ship, which is the centrepiece of the park with a "beach" of sand around it. "It's good. I liked climbing right to the top of the ship. There's nothing I didn't like but it's not as good as my park at home - it has a big tyre swing."

fields.headline: Baby, look at you now
fields.standfirst: Leo Blair will be eight weeks old on Saturday, as will 2000 other babies who arrived on the same day.  Joanna Moorhead  spoke to the parents of some of these babies hours after they were born and now returns to see how they are coping
fields.trailText: Leo Blair will be eight weeks old on Saturday, as will 2000 other babies who arrived on the same day. Joanna Moorhead spoke to the parents of some of these babies hours after they were born and now returns to see how they are coping
fields.body:
Baby: Joshua Parkin.

Family: Helen Bracewell, 24, a travel agent, and Stuart Parkin, 26, a car salesman. They live in the village of Thaxted, near Cambridge, with both sets of grandparents nearby.

How it's going: "I'm surprised by how easy it is," says Helen. "I thought he'd be harder to look after, but in fact he's a very good baby.

"I'm breastfeeding him and I think that makes everything more straightforward - I don't have to make up bottles, and feeding him in the middle of the night is easy because I just bring him into our bed.

"Having our parents nearby makes a big difference, especially as a lot of my friends are out at work all day. His grandparents pop in all the time and it does help: you feel a lot more supported. Having Joshua has changed me: I'm a lot more patient now."

Baby: Jordan McCabe.

Family: Joanne McCabe and Ian Macmillan, both 29. The couple, who live in the centre of Glasgow, already have a two-year-old son, Cameron. Joanne is a finance assistant with a housing association and Ian works for a distillery.

How it's going: "In many ways, life has carried on much as before," says Joanne. "Because of Cameron we had already completely adapted to having a small child around, so this time it's been nothing like the upheaval it was when he arrived. Luckily for us, he doesn't seem to be jealous at all - although I do try very hard to give him lots of time.

"Jordan sleeps a lot in the daytime, which makes it easier. The main thing I've noticed this time around is how much more confidence I've got about everything; it's obviously because I'm a second-time mum and you just worry a lot less.

"I remember with Cameron I could hardly sleep because I was so afraid something might happen to him, but once you've done it you realise it's not so scary."

Baby: Jack Picton.

Family: Mother is Maxine Picton, 34, a TV cabinet packer. Maxine lives with her mum in Ovenden, a former council estate outside Halifax town centre.

How it's going: "Since Jack was born I only see his dad when I take the baby up there. We're not together any more; it was always a bit on-off anyway. But I don't feel isolated as a single mum; I've got lots of help on hand because I live with my mother. It makes it a lot easier really.

"I do hope that Jack and I get somewhere of our own to live in the long term. But for now things are fine. Jack isn't a difficult baby: he only wakes once during the night and my mum often looks after him in the daytime so I can catch up on my sleep.

"He's on bottles now. I did try breastfeeding but it didn't work out - he didn't seem to be able to do it - so I moved him onto bottles at two days. I do feel a bit different myself since having Jack. He comes first now, so I always have to think about him before anything else."

Baby: Emily Rose Hale.

Family: Sheila Hale, 35, a school cook, and husband Graeme. Like Cherie Blair, Sheila already has a 12-year-old daughter, Leanne, and a 14-year-old son, Christopher (pictured). But Emily is a first baby for Graeme, 28, a dairy worker.

How it's going: "I can understand what happened to the Blair family last week with Euan," says Sheila. "It's not easy to have time for everyone when you have a baby. The older children seem to get on with their lives, while the baby is very demanding. You have to make the effort to have time for the older ones: they still have needs, although they're not as obvious as the baby's.

"I'm lucky because Emily is a good sleeper; I use the time when she's napping to be with Leanne and Christo pher. They love Emily to bits; they're always picking her up and playing with her. It's great for me; when they come in from school I know that, if it's been a tough day, I'll get five minutes to myself because they'll look after Emily for me."

For Graeme, Emily has brought the realisation that fathering a child himself is not like having stepchildren. "It's definitely different having a child of our own. Emily is lovely - we all enjoy her a lot. She's really smiley and we have lots of fun with her.

"Sometimes, if I'm honest, I do worry about the future and the responsibility of what's now quite a big family, but I don't think it's worth letting that spoil our pleasure in the children now. I think it will be all right in the end."

Baby: Scott Lee Rosser.

Family: Sarah Charles, 19, and Mark Rosser, 36, are both unemployed. Sarah recently finished a nursery nursing course. They live in a flat on a council estate.

How it's going: Although this is Sarah's first baby, it's Mark's 10th. "It is quite a lot," he agrees. "It gets me down a bit sometimes. The eldest is 16, and there are three other mothers as well as Sarah. I see all my children regularly - I think it's really important - and they've all seen Scott and love him.

"Of course I've done all this baby bit many times before, but I don't mind it. In a way, Scott is special because he's definitely going to be the last. And I'm going to stay with Sarah, so he's the one I'll be bringing up myself full time."

For Sarah, the main surprise about mothering has been how exhausting it is. "I feel tired all the time," she says. "He sleeps at night, but he's awake all day. I really thought babies slept a lot in the daytime. I feel as though I'm always changing him or feeding him and then if he does have a little sleep, I have to quickly start doing the washing and all the other jobs."

Sarah's mother, who lives nearby, is a big help. "She'll have him for me whenever I ask and, as he's bottle-fed, it means I can get out from time to time. My mum takes him into town with her every Saturday for a couple of hours, and I catch up on some sleep while he's gone."

Baby: Bethany Elliott.

Family: Claire and Stuart Elliott, both police officers. Claire, 27, and Stuart, 33, live in a large three-bedroomed flat in Bexley, Kent.

How it's going: "I'm loving it," says Claire. "I worked up to a week before Bethany was born, so I didn't have time to think a lot about how it would be once the baby arrived.

"The only problem I've had was with breastfeeding: Bethany just failed to gain any weight. It was so upsetting. The midwives kept coming round to weigh her, and she was losing weight - 10oz in the end.

"The midwives were really supportive. They came round every day for the first week or so, and then at least three times a week for the first month. In the end I had to put Bethany on to bottles to build up her weight, but I'm still breastfeeding as well and I like the sense of closeness that involves.

"Stuart and I have adapted to parenthood far more easily than I thought we would. In the early weeks we shared getting up for night feeds, but now Bethany is a brilliant sleeper; she goes down at about 9.30pm and sleeps until 5am or so. She's an independent little thing; we tried having her cot in our room with us but she just screamed, so we moved her to her own room and she seems to prefer it there.

"Our eight-week check is this week, and Bethany will have her first jab. We're happy to have immunisations: I had them all and I've been OK.

"Physically, I feel more or less back to normal. I go to a postnatal exercise class once a week and I've lost most of the weight I put on during the pregnancy."

Baby: Alexander FitzGerald.

Family: Lauren, 29, and Patrick, 34, FitzGerald are Australians who came to live in London last year. She's a commercial lawyer (on maternity leave) and he's an IT consultant.

How it's going: "Really well. We've been very lucky in that we've had a lot of support, and I think that matters a lot," says Lauren. "We hired an independent midwife for Alexander's birth and she was visiting us regularly until last week.

"She was a lifeline, especially as I had a lot of problems establishing breastfeeding. Alexander wasn't able to latch on properly and it was incredibly painful. In the end I had to express my milk, which was very time-consuming. It turned out that he needed a minor operation on his tongue. That's now been done and the difference is amazing - I'm enjoying feeding him and it's much easier, as well as being so convenient.

"I've been surprised by how little he sleeps during the day. I had plans to do a bit of work here and there, but I get no time. Some days I feel I accomplish nothing; I go to bed at night and all I've done is feed the baby. The lack of sleep is hard to live with; Patrick and I feel we've been coping quite well, but it is draining. We're used to between six and eight hours of unbroken sleep a night, and now the most we ever get at a stretch is five hours.

"I'm taking Alexander to the clinic next week and I'm going to ask some questions about immunisations, but we've not decided yet what to do. It's not something we'll do automatically; I want to make an informed decision and need to do some research before we decide.

"Having Alexander has definitely changed me. I hadn't realised - I don't know if you can - how overwhelming the love you have for your baby is, how tiny and needy they are. It's changed my priorities, how I see the world.

"And it's amazing how much goodwill a new baby generates: we've had emails from all over the world, from people we hadn't seen for 10 years!"

"Stuart and I have adapted to parenthood far more easily than I thought we would. In the early weeks we shared getting up for night feeds, but now Bethany is a brilliant sleeper; she goes down at about 9.30pm and sleeps until 5am or so. She's an independent little thing; we tried having her cot in our room with us but she just screamed, so we moved her to her own room and she seems to prefer it there. "Our eight-week check is this week, and Bethany will have her first jab. We're happy to have immunisations: I had them all and I've been OK. "Physically, I feel more or less back to normal. I go to a postnatal exercise class once a week and I've lost most of the weight I put on during the pregnancy." Baby: Alexander FitzGerald. Family: Lauren, 29, and Patrick, 34, FitzGerald are Australians who came to live in London last year. She's a commercial lawyer (on maternity leave) and he's an IT consultant. How it's going: "Really well. We've been very lucky in that we've had a lot of support, and I think that matters a lot," says Lauren. "We hired an independent midwife for Alexander's birth and she was visiting us regularly until last week. "She was a lifeline, especially as I had a lot of problems establishing breastfeeding. Alexander wasn't able to latch on properly and it was incredibly painful. In the end I had to express my milk, which was very time-consuming. It turned out that he needed a minor operation on his tongue. That's now been done and the difference is amazing - I'm enjoying feeding him and it's much easier, as well as being so convenient. "I've been surprised by how little he sleeps during the day. I had plans to do a bit of work here and there, but I get no time. Some days I feel I accomplish nothing; I go to bed at night and all I've done is feed the baby. The lack of sleep is hard to live with; Patrick and I feel we've been coping quite well, but it is draining. We're used to between six and eight hours of unbroken sleep a night, and now the most we ever get at a stretch is five hours. "I'm taking Alexander to the clinic next week and I'm going to ask some questions about immunisations, but we've not decided yet what to do. It's not something we'll do automatically; I want to make an informed decision and need to do some research before we decide. "Having Alexander has definitely changed me. "And it's amazing how much goodwill a new baby generates: we've had emails from all over the world, from people we hadn't seen for 10 years!"

fields.headline: Generation XXX
fields.standfirst: So Euan Blair got drunk. His parents should be relieved: alcohol isn't all that's on the menu when Marina Parker, 16, is out celebrating ...
fields.trailText: So Euan Blair got drunk. His parents should be relieved: alcohol isn't all that's on the menu when Marina Parker, 16, is out celebrating ...
fields.body:
Casting my mind back to the end of my GCSEs, Euan's behaviour seems almost tame. That night we too went out to celebrate at one of London's most exclusive clubs, rubbing shoulders with famous footballers and pop stars.

How did a group of 16-year-olds get in? With no problem at all. We strolled through the doors, welcomed by 6ft bouncers. This was no surprise to us. We have all been regulars at select London pubs since we were 14. The age of house parties is long gone and, since pubs shut at 11pm, we began to visit these so called "exclusive" hot spots, becoming friendly with various club promoters, owners and the regular club crowds - who were all a lot older and richer than us.

Of course our return home in the early hours of the morning did not go unnoticed by our parents, who would question us on our whereabouts and our company. Just as over-anxious parents can come up with extremely unlikely scenarios (Louise's mother, for example, worries about drugs being slipped into her drink, but who wants to give drugs away?), so the more naive parents often underestimate their children's behaviour. One friend's mother imagines her daughter to be religious, hardworking and not interested in boys. The daughter in question first had sex at the age of 13 in a Portaloo.

However, some parents have the misfortune to find these things out first hand. Take Emma, whose boyfriend's mother walked in on them having a shower, or Jessica and Mark, who were otherwise engaged when her mother walked in to tell Jessica that tea was ready.

Sex, drugs and alcohol appear in most of our lives but usually not in the form most parents would think. My parents are worried about the availability of drugs such as Ecstasy when cocaine is a far more fashionable and accessible drug.

In some West End clubs, tables require a minimum input of about £300, but "fashionable" drugs such as cocaine can be bought for £50 a gram and are widely available in the middle-class houses of north London where they are seen as a step up from "draw" [cannabis].

Drugs are sold by many of our friends, who handle large quantities for an even larger profit. One such dealer, David - then 16 and now in early retirement - took his "business" so seriously that he invested in silver weighing scales, a designer bag for his drugs and two mobiles: one for his friends, one for his clients.

Of course, image has a great deal to do with teenage life. However shallow it may seem, phones, the latest clothes and fast cars all show your wealth and social standing. One 22-year-old friend already owns a Lotus Elise, which he says represents his personality.

For my friends it's age that matters. While boys are searching for a free house in which to smoke draw to their heart's content, the girls look to older men for fun and independence. Our friend Rachel has been seeing a 28-year-old for the past year and most of our weekends are spent at clubs with people between the ages of 18 and 24.

Teenage activity varies according to age, sex and wealth but the aim is the same: to go out and have a good time. Of course our parents will worry. We know deep down that they are only looking out for us because they have been there themselves. But things haven't changed that much and they probably never will. Just ask yourself, will your children get up to what you got up to? Probably.

Names have been changed

fields.headline: Sun, sea and sour grapes
fields.standfirst: Are you and the kids looking forward to your summer holiday?  Simon Hattenstone is - kind of. Here, he explains why this annual ritual brings him out in a cold sweat
fields.trailText: Are you and the kids looking forward to your summer holiday? Simon Hattenstone is - kind of. Here, he explains why this annual ritual brings him out in a cold sweat
fields.body:
Get away from it all, have a break, recharge the batteries. Dream on, suckers. Holidays are about misery, despair, being scared witless, falling out with friends, falling out of love, separation, counselling, crisis. Holidays are about taking away the kids for a fetid fortnight of the soul. We're talking deep underbellies and psychic displacement.

I admit I've always had my negative side, but holidays give me the existential wobbles. I look at a holiday brochure and, without wishing to come over all Proustian, I think of loss.

The family holiday airlifts us out of reality and splat-drops us in on the unknown. And do we like the unknown? Do we rise to the challenge, strap on our adventure boots and stride purposely on to the great plains of experience? Do we buggery. We hate it. And so do the kids.

In normal life, we just about cope by swaddling ourselves in everyday securities - Countdown, Jaffa Cakes, the gym, our bed. Some of us even manage to keep relationships going by allowing ourselves sufficient physical and emotional space. On holiday we do away with all that. We strip ourselves of our protective layers, expose ourselves to the elements and burn in a claustrophobic hell.

I've associated holidays with horror ever since I was five and got lost on an Italian beach. More of a desert than a beach actually. Mile after mile of it. I had gone off for an ice cream, and couldn't find my way back. I walked forever in a straight line until I was soaked in exhaustion and sick with panic. The beach began to empty, and I was left, tiny and terrified and too proud to tell the few remaining stragglers that I was lost. After the panic came resignation, which was even worse because I'd given up. Eventually a policeman scooped me up off the sand, put me on the back of his bike and carried me off to my weeping mother.

Then a few years ago at the seaside I took little Maya for a wee in a forbidding, heavily tattooed pub. Alix, who was five and all grown up, decided to wander when we were in the loo. No one in the pub looked me in the face when I asked whether they'd seen her. It was probably only a couple of minutes later that we found her wandering along the pier, but it felt like decades.

You never get lost in your own street back home. This is something my children know too. They hate the unfamiliar. The other week we got a new car. Alix and Maya still say it's horrible, and ask why we can't go in the lovely old car, despite the fact that it doesn't work. They had never shown any affection for the car until it was taken away from them. Maya suggested a compromise - perhaps we could keep the car so she can look at it every day and wave hello.

Don't they call it the shock of the new? Same with holidays. When we go away the kids suddenly see home in a new light. Yes, the beach and the pool and the sea are nice enough, but where's our lovely bedroom and our lovely kitchen and our lovely garden which is too small to play games in, and our lovely hose with which we can drench ourselves and pretend we're on holiday swimming in the pool? From the moment we set off they are mourning the loss of the home that they take for granted for the other 51 weeks of the year.

Fair enough, kids are contrary sods. But even so they are right to be confused about hols. There is something truly bizarre about the notion that you give the children the treat of their lives by removing them from all they love: no TV, no games, no home, no friends ... Have a nice trip!

Still, at least the kids make new friends, hey? Yes, for about half an hour. And then they're gone. Every year they manage to fall in love with some sweet little tot as they're packing away the swimming costume for the last time. Half an hour for a week's worth of mourning the loss of a soulmate: the pictures that weren't taken, the disco nights they could have shared, the Agadoo dance routines that oh so nearly were.

Well, there's always the beach for light relief. Sure, it's a little uncomfy with the sand down the pants and the mozzies and the ice cream-stick splinters buried in the sand. But there is the glorious moment when the sandcastle is complete. The grin of pure pleasure, concentrated achievement. Until some vindictive little git kicks it over or the waves soak it into history. If a holiday teaches children anything, it's that nothing lasts forever, that the world is as cruel as it's transient. "Won't you take me back home ...", as Slade sang all those years ago.

Still, the summer is here and Majorca beckons. A compromise: a holiday, but nothing new. Home from home. So safe and familiar that the kids forget they're on holiday and start to enjoy themselves. Hotel Tucan, Cala D'or, if you're interested. Nice place, familiar feel to it. Pool table by the swimming pool, table tennis by the pool table, Smarties at the bar, straw donkeys at the mini-store next door.

Now let's get one thing straight. This is not an advert for the Hotel Tucan or for Cala D'or. There is nothing exceptional about either hotel or resort. The hotel looks like every other hotel on the block. The food is great on the first day, quite good the second, and gross for the rest of the week. The pool's wet.

We went to the same hotel last year. The year before that we had a break from our normal break. But the kids were disorientated by Portugal - strange fish, alien sand, no disco. The year before that we had a week at the Hotel Tucan, Cala D'or. Interesting old life.

Only one difference. We've always taken people away with us. My parents, my partner's parents, my mate Les, who's old enough to be my dad at a pinch. They know they're basically there to look after us, but they don't mind so much because they can pretend they're looking after the grandchildren. Anyway, this year we're going by ourselves, braving it. Which will be exciting and liberating. Except for the fact that we won't be able to go out at night unless we fancy lugging the kids around with us or going out by ourselves on a rota basis. Sitting alone in a Majorcan pub, not a friend in the land, can't be bad. Still, not to worry. Only two grand for the four of us, and it'll be over soon.

webTitle: Suddenly, the oil firms are awash with dosh

fields.headline: Suddenly, the oil firms are awash with dosh
fields.standfirst: Happy quandary for Shell and BP
fields.trailText: An embarrassment of riches is the only way to describe the situation facing BP Amoco and Royal Dutch/Shell. They are gushing money and beginning to worry about how to spend it. Despite their public image as uncaring monsters, oil majors are acutely aware there is little that angers highly taxed motorists more than a wealthy oil man.
fields.body:
An embarrassment of riches is the only way to describe the situation facing BP Amoco and Royal Dutch/Shell. They are gushing money and beginning to worry about how to spend it. Despite their public image as uncaring monsters, oil majors are acutely aware there is little that angers highly taxed motorists more than a wealthy oil man.

Sir John Browne outlined a few ways yesterday of siphoning off the cash. He told financial analysts attending BP Amoco's annual strategy review that he would be pouring more of it into the ground through his exploration and development department.

But even increasing expenditure to $13.5bn (£9bn) a year like this is not so easy, at least in presentation terms. Barely 18 months ago Sir John was almost as keen on "prudence" as his near namesake at the Exchequer, Gordon Brown.

So how else will Sir John dispose of the growing mountain of cash produced by crude prices at a nine-year high and record earnings coming in quarter after quarter?

Share buybacks will be used to save some of the blushes, but investors can also look forward to higher dividend payments. BP Amoco has ensured this by raising its estimates on future oil prices from $14 per barrel to $16.

Then, of course, there is the acquisition trail. The latter is unlikely in the short term - except for smaller "filler" assets - if only because BP is still digesting the $80bn Amoco, Arco, Burmah Castrol binge.

Round at Shell, on the other hand, the situation is more interesting. There are persistent rumours of potential deals and chairman Mark Moody-Stuart is definitely hard at work crunching numbers - other people's as well as his own. What is more, Shell is under more pressure than BP Amoco to offload cash because it is unable to effect any share buybacks until the Dutch change the law next year.

Durlacher dent

There was something rather sad about a statement issued yesterday, halfway through lunch, by Durlacher, the one-time fringe stockbroker which became something of an icon within the British internet investment scene - rushing around, investing in dozens of start-ups, hiring high-powered staff, and showing its much bigger investment banking rivals how to do it in the New Economy.

The announcement said simply that Durlacher had completed the placing of 15.8m new shares at 65p apiece. It added that "the placing facilitates both the continuing expansion of the existing functions of Durlacher and the stated goal of becoming a premier European emerging technology and new media group", and that was just about it.

The news was not accompanied by an orgy of speculation on the internet investment bulletin boards. There was no flurry of news stories guessing how Durlacher might spend the money. The boss, Geoffrey Chamberlain, was not having to tell potential interviewers that he was too busy and in any case wanted to maintain a low profile.

Nothing. Just a penny up-tick in the share price to 60.5p. What the announce ment did say, in as many words, is that Durlacher and its shotgun internet investment portfolio are in trouble. The investment bank is strapped for cash.

Four months ago, the shares were riding above 440p and the bank's market capitalisation had ballooned to more than £2bn. Now, with the market cap back below £300m, it is reduced to raising £10m from what are described as "a small number of international investors" - presumably foreign and/or offshore players who do not want their names bandied about.

The sloth turns

The "big four" clearing banks - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest (now owned by Royal Bank of Scotland) and HSBC - are trying to avoid participating in a pilot scheme which will make it easier for disillusioned customers to move accounts.

The scheme is being run under the auspices of Apacs (the Association for Payment Clearing Services) and is only able to list a small part of Barclays - its premier account - and the exclusive Coutts arm of NatWest, among the participating trial banks and building societies.

The half-hearted support of the clearers is dangerous, given the views of the Don Cruickshank report into competition in the sector, but little surprise given that between them they have 75% of the current account market.

Abbey National and Halifax, the traditional mortgage banks, have upped the stakes in the current account market by making it clear they will bend over backwards to try to lure lucrative customers.

This might explain the big four's attitude. Perhaps they are concerned that the age-old lethargy that makes customers more likely to divorce their spouses than change their current accounts is about end.

webTitle: How the battle of the Boyne earned its place in history

fields.headline: How the battle of the Boyne earned its place in history
fields.standfirst: King Billy's 1690 victory was a minor military triumph, but a landmark in British affairs, says Derek Brown
fields.trailText: 12 July, 4pm: King Billy's 1690 victory was a minor military triumph, but a landmark in British affairs, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Today is battle of the Boyne day, marking the 310th anniversary of King Billy's famous victory in Ireland and the triumph of Protestantism. For Orangemen in Northern Ireland and beyond, July 12 is an almost sacred day.

This is odd, because the battle was actually fought on July 1, and King William was on the side of the Pope.

The date is easily explained: in William's day Britain was still using the old Roman calendar devised by Julius Caesar. More than half a century after the battle, the Julian system was superseded by the Gregorian; 11 days were wiped from British calendars; and July 1 became July 12.

The papal alliance, which many Protestants prefer to gloss over, must also be seen in the context of the times, in which dynastic ambition often outweighed religious allegiance or scruple.

King William III was the Protestant head of the Dutch royal house of Orange. He was married to Mary, the Protestant-raised daughter of King James II of Britain, a convert to Catholicism.

James's naked ambition to lead Britain back into the old church alienated the court and many of his subjects. In 1688, powerful establishment figures invited William and Mary to take the throne. But when they landed in England, the royal army, led by John Churchill, the future Duke of Marlborough, defected and James fled to France.

But he had friends among his mostly Catholic subjects in Ireland and a redoubtable ally in Louis XIV of France, then at the height of a ruthless drive to make himself Europe's overlord.

William was rabidly anti-French, and was an eager recruit to the alliance of powers which opposed Louis. Other leaders of the League of Augsburg - later the Grand Alliance - included the Austrian emperor, Leopold, and Pope Alexander VIII.

Thus, when James landed in Ireland in a doomed attempt to win back his throne and promote the Catholic faith, he was indirectly fighting the Pope. And William, defending the Protestant ascendancy in both of John Bull's islands, was at the same time advancing the cause of the Vatican.

For all that, the victory at Oldcastle, near the mouth of the River Boyne, was hugely significant for Ireland and Britain. It glued William and Mary firmly on the throne, and consolidated the momentous changes in the British way of government known as the Glorious Revolution.

King James was the last of the Stuart kings who hankered after absolute rule. King Billy, though he was no democrat, astutely accepted the supremacy of parliament. In that sense, the battle of the Boyne, though relatively minor in military significance, was a landmark event in British affairs, as well as a continuing landmine in Irish history.

webTitle: Cosmic habitat that's a waste of space

fields.headline: Cosmic habitat that's a waste of space
fields.standfirst:
Construction of the International Space Station reached another crucial phase today, with the launch of the Russian 'Portakabin' Zvezda. But there are better things to spend £40bn on, argues science correspondent James Meek
Russian space station module has extra topping
fields.trailText:
Construction of the International Space Station reached another crucial phase today, with the launch of the Russian 'Portakabin' Zvezda. But there are better things to spend £40 billion on, argues science correspondent James Meek
Russian space station module has extra topping
fields.body:
If the International Space Station (ISS) currently under construction is a building site, today was the day they sent up the Portakabin. The generator-cum-lock-up - another Russian module called Zarya - is already in place, as is the foundation stone, a piece of US hardware called Unity, to which most of the future parts of the ISS will be connected.

But the launch of Zvezda sets the scene for the arrival of the construction workers, cosmonauts and astronauts, later in the year. Once it docks with Unity and Zarya, crews will not only be able to take their tea breaks in its kitchen but also sleep in it, look out of the windows, use an exercise bicycle and generally make it a home while they tackle the complex five-year job of putting the station together.

But why are the US, Europe, Canada, Japan, Russia and Brazil shelling out £40bn for this baroque space habitat, which when complete in 2005, will be so large it will be one of the brightest objects in the evening sky, weighing half a million kilos, with six laboratories and the live-work space of a jumbo jet?

Cynics say the motives are more political than rational. Originally dreamed up in 1984 in the America of Ronald Reagan, it was set to collapse for lack of funds when, in 1994, Bill Clinton reinvented it as a means to promote cooperation between the west and Russia.

But Washington and Nasa underestimated the extent to which the Russian space programme was being starved of funds. Russia's part of the programme - with its unique expertise, having run its own space station, Mir, for more than a decade - had to be repeatedly bailed out by the US. At times it looked as if the programme would be scrapped altogether.

Far from encouraging cooperation between the west and Russia, it has heightened tensions, with Washington angry that Russia has gone on funding Mir instead of concentrating all its meagre resources on the ISS, and Moscow fearful that the (English language only) station is the death knell of their independent manned space programme.

Now, with the successful launch of Zvezda, the project seems to have reached critical mass, and is set to proceed, although the Russians' own labs may never materialise, making the station slightly smaller. The question still remains how useful the station will be to science - particularly as it goes against Nasa's own philosophy of "smaller, cheaper, faster" missions.

Scientists will use the ISS mainly to examine how familiar chemical and physical processes on earth change when they occur in conditions of weightlessness. One of the key questions for researchers in the hot field of genetics research is to see whether proteins, the chemicals which act as messengers and maintainers in our bodies, "fold" into different shapes in microgravity. Another important area of research will be the study of how humans themselves react to long periods in space, a possible precursor to a manned expedition to Mars.

None of this work will be enough to silence the critics, however, who argue that the money would be better spent on other, less gargantuan projects.

fields.headline: Mortal combatant
fields.standfirst: Becky Miles, cancer survivor with a mission
fields.trailText: Profile: Becky Miles, cancer survivor with a mission
fields.body:
Facing up to a disrupted life that may end in death is an experience common to most cancer sufferers - and one which often triggers furious resentment at the inadequacies of health care in Britain. If the NHS is finally gearing up to modernise cancer therapy, it is at least partly thanks to the productive channelling of one cancer survivor's angry response to her care.

Ten years ago, Becky Miles - now 41 - was told she had Hodgkin's disease, with a tumour the size of a cantaloupe melon entangled in her chest cavity. In the previous two years, she had seen 13 different consultants who all missed the cancer despite "textbook symptoms". Once diagnosed as a case of "a difficult red-haired woman", she says most consultants were well-meaning. "It was the system, not the individuals, that let me down."

As a patient, Miles took nothing for granted. She had two children, the youngest still not one, and her sister had died of breast cancer at age 35. Told there was no choice about chemotherapy regimens, she bought a haematology textbook, a dictionary to translate it and fought for access to medical journals. As a result, she was "continually aware of doctors making weird, idiosyncratic decisions about treatment, rarely based on research, delivered in a way that seemed designed to disempower me".

Over the intense weeks and months during, and recovering from, chemotherapy, she developed a vision of how cancer services should be provided. "I didn't just want better mannered doctors, I wanted to change the system," she recalls. Her experience as director of Scientists against Nuclear Arms had taught her that the way to effect change quickly - "I didn't know how long I had" - was to influence key decision-makers.

So she made her voice heard strategically. By 1993, she was appointed a member of the London implementation group, then reviewing cancer services in the capital, and later became the patient representative on the influential Calman/Hines working party on cancer care.

With the support of doctors, including top specialist Karol Sikora, she set up the National Cancer Alliance (NCA), a small but highly influential alliance of cancer patients and health professionals. And she sat down after dinner with a group of cancer patients (only two of whom are still alive) and a few bottles of wine and wrote down, on a long piece of wallpaper, a list of the needs of people at different stages in cancer treatment.

David Kerr, professor of clinical oncology at the Institute for Cancer Studies at Birmingham University, says meeting her dramatically changed his view of cancer care. "For the first time, I became aware of how badly patients can be let down by doctors , how poor communication can have a devastating impact on outcome, how services are organised for the benefit of the professionals, not the public."

Mike Richards, a fomer NCA trustee and now the government's "cancer tsar", says Becky was pivotal in developing the philosophy of care that informed both Calman/Hines and the forthcoming national cancer plan that he will launch this autumn. "The word patient-centred was not really in the language 10 years ago. The fact that it now informs all our thinking is largely down to her," he says. "She has put enormous pressure on health care professionals to work in multi-disciplinary teams, learning to exchange information with each other, as well as the person they're treating."

Challenged by Miles to acknowledge that changing the system could achieve more mortality gain than new buildings or pouring money into new drugs, Kerr persuaded West Midlands regional health authority to hire her as the region's cancer co-ordinator. Together they embarked on a four-year appraisal programme, visiting the 24 acute trusts in the region, using peer review to measure the service provided against the standards set by Calman/Hine. "We were known as the cancer police," recalls Kerr.

Since then, Miles has continued to work part-time for West Midlands using the job of cancer co-ordinator to drive up standards in 13 health authorities, as well as continuing as part-time director of the NCA. Kerr believes that she may be spreading herself thinly - and that she might have done better concentrating on building up the alliance as a powerful, fundraising, patient advocacy organisation - something that is common in the US but almost non-existent so far in Britain.

Miles disagrees. The impact of the "lean, mean" NCA has been substantial, she says, without advertising for members or rallying for funds. At its annual meeting on Saturday, the alliance is to launch its latest project, the"teamwork file" - a personal information file which will provide cancer patients with far better written information than any number of generalised patient information leaflets. And working with NHS professionals is the best way, she says, to avoid the trap of blaming professionals. "What's wrong with the service is not just that patients are disempowered. So are doctors and other professionals who have been pressured to compete with each other and forced to keep quiet about inadequacies in the service. Even senior managers are often exhausted and bruised and treated badly."

But with the NHS poised to implement much of her vision of a service fit to provide a responsive, holistic treatment across the country, she admits her future role is unclear. Though all regions have followed the West Midlands example and appointed cancer coordinators, other appointments were internal. "The NHS has got to decide whether it wants people like me working within it, challenging orthodoxy, asking difficult questions, driving up standards. I am not clear at the moment whether that is the case."

She has no doubt, however, that her job is not yet finished. "I took a call the other day from the father of a boy who had just been diagnosed with a rare cancer of the palate and told the local hospital was going to operate. He'd found the number on the internet and he was still crying when I spoke to him. I was able to find out the nearest specialist centre for the particular cancer. The boy himself answered when I called to hand on the information - something he won't be able to do in a week's time. Realising the agonising year ahead facing that family convinced me once again how important it is that the NHS does get it right."

fields.headline: Stressed out of work
fields.standfirst: Stark warning of a recruitment crisis in mental health
fields.trailText: Stark warning of a recruitment crisis in mental health
fields.body:
Evidence of staffing problems in mental health care is nothing new, but an authoritative report today warns starkly that if difficulties of recruitment and retention are not addressed "there is a danger that large sections of existing mental health services will not be sustainable". Based on a review led by Sir Graham Hart, former permanent secretary at the Department of Health, the report says there is also a risk that it will not be possible to achieve the government's national service framework for mental health without more staff and rapid improvement in their skills and competencies. According to Andrew McCulloch, one of the report's authors: "We are in potentially serious trouble".

The review was commissioned by the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health in order not only to get a clear perspective on staffing problems, but also to point the way forward. The report says services need to break out of a costly and destabilising cycle of short-term solutions, exemplified by a reliance on agency workers, and to set strategic goals of making mental health more attractive to recruits, creating stronger leadership for the sector and doing far more to support and sustain staff.

Beyond this, though, the review group is calling for targeted solutions to specific problems - not all of them local in nature. The government, it says, should, among other things, reappraise NHS pension rules to determine what negative effect they are having on efforts to retain older mental health workers whose role is likely to be vital in keeping services going.

The report, Finding and Keeping, comes a week after the annual conference of the Royal College of Psychiatrists heard dire warnings of the state of mental health care. Peter Kennedy, co-director of the Northern Centre for Mental Health, told the conference in Edinburgh: "We have stood like rabbits in the headlights wondering what to do and where to start, knowing that the situation is worsening. There is an urgent need to explore methods of developing standards and implementing them on a broad front over relatively short periods of time."

Kennedy was referring to acute care, but the state of many community services is little better. Overall, more than third of NHS trusts employing psychiatrists report trouble recruiting them and, at the last count, 14% of consultant posts were vacant. While the picture for mental health nurses looks rather better on paper, almost a quarter of them are aged 45-54 and many have the old "mental health officer" status, entitling them to retire on pension at 55.

As if maintaining existing services is not challenging enough, the report estimates that the national service framework's standard of 24-hour access to care services might require an increase of 10-30% in staffing of community mental health teams alone - the equivalent of 1,000 extra nurses. Similarly, supporting just the 50,000 most hard-pressed informal carers, in line with the framework's ambitions, could require almost 1,700 more social workers.

The attractions of working in mental health are not immediately obvious, however. Health and social care as a whole has problems competing for young recruits, but mental health suffers the added handi- cap of a negative image. "Many of the staff we spoke to in the course of the review felt that mental health nursing was seen as a job with low pay and low status, but with high levels of risk," says the report.

In view of this, the review team is urging a focus on retaining and making full use of older staff. But it says those who could be persuaded to stay on in their late 50s and 60s, perhaps on shorter hours or with a switch to a less pressured role, can be deterred by rules linking their pension to their final three years' salary.

McCulloch, senior adviser to the Sainsbury centre, says: "There is a big disincentive, almost an overwhelming one, to changing to a less high-powered job and a smaller disincentive to going part-time. Surely it can't be beyond the wit of man to do something about it. We would be stupid not to, because this is a group of people with a lot of experience to offer."

With mental health facing such difficult workforce issues, a period of organisational stability might be indicated. Yet the break-up of combined community and mental health trusts continues apace, with community services going to the new primary care trusts. The jury is out on whether the emerging specialist mental health trusts, often very large indeed, will fare any better.

One area where they should be able to improve their act, thinks McCulloch, is in meeting a crying need for a robust human resource (HR) function. "The big trusts do provide an opportunity to produce really good HR managers," he says. "There are some talented people out there, but they are not properly supported. The best that can be said about HR in mental health is that it is variable -variable from the good-but-struggling to the awful."

fields.bodyText: Evidence of staffing problems in mental health care is nothing new, but an authoritative report today warns starkly that if difficulties of recruitment and retention are not addressed "there is a danger that large sections of existing mental health services will not be sustainable". Based on a review led by Sir Graham Hart, former permanent secretary at the Department of Health, the report says there is also a risk that it will not be possible to achieve the government's national service framework for mental health without more staff and rapid improvement in their skills and competencies. According to Andrew McCulloch, one of the report's authors: "We are in potentially serious trouble". The review was commissioned by the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health in order not only to get a clear perspective on staffing problems, but also to point the way forward. The report says services need to break out of a costly and destabilising cycle of short-term solutions, exemplified by a reliance on agency workers, and to set strategic goals of making mental health more attractive to recruits, creating stronger leadership for the sector and doing far more to support and sustain staff. Beyond this, though, the review group is calling for targeted solutions to specific problems - not all of them local in nature. The government, it says, should, among other things, reappraise NHS pension rules to determine what negative effect they are having on efforts to retain older mental health workers whose role is likely to be vital in keeping services going. fields.headline: Thankful task
fields.standfirst: Thousands of teenagers need foster homes but few people are willing to take them on, reports  John Cunningham
fields.trailText: Thousands of teenagers need foster homes but few people are willing to take them on, reports John Cunningham
fields.body:
Diane Hewitt's relief on reading the note pushed under her door just about erased the stress of a sleepless night of worrying. It was from J, the 16-year-old girl she is fostering, and it read: "I am really sorry I didn't come home last night but I was drinking with friends. The truth is I wasn't thinking about you at all - and I know you're thinking that, just as she is going well, she goes straight back down. But that's not true. I love being here with you and I thank you for all you are doing for me."

Fostering can be full of dramas, but while there are thousands of teenagers in need of foster homes, carers like Hewitt are scarce. So scarce that John Hutton, the social care minister, is today launching a £2m drive to find 7,000 more carers among those long overlooked as volunteers, and therefore least likely to offer: single people and ethnic groups. A website and a hotline, set up and run by the National Foster Care Association (NFCA), will be the main conduits.

Fostering is a fraught field. Hardest to place are teenagers, and the need to find adults to offer a temporary replacement for family life is desperate. About two-thirds of the 50,000 children in the care system are fostered, but 60% of councils are seriously short of carers. In some London boroughs, up to a quarter drop out every year.

This relatively high turnover is because people foster, on average, for three to five years. Youngsters typically stay with them for several weeks or months. Children have become more stressed and traumatised in recent times, which makes fostering more demanding, says NFCA's executive director, Gerri McAndrew. Even so, two-thirds are able to return to their families after six months.

Fostering needs to be accepted as a "much more mainstream" activity, argues McAndrew. A bigger pool of volunteers will make it easier to match the needs of children to the skills of carers.

Enter Hewitt. Two years ago, she gave up her career as a barrister to try caring. She's 52, single and was a trained nurse before she took up law. Though there wasn't a gap as such in her busy life, a long-term relationship had ended several years before, and at 50 - too late to have children - she considered fostering. It made sense: she had both time and financial security. And kids to her were hardly the aliens they are to some childless adults: she grew up in a family of 14 in Trinidad. Her legal work was a bonus: "I'd come across so many youths who had been in trouble, I found I had a rapport with them," she says.

J, the girl who gave her a sleepless night recently, is the fifth youngster placed with Hewitt by Wandsworth council, south London. She prefers to foster girls between 12 and 14 - before they get too wilful - but J had stayed with her before, when she was younger, so Hewitt bent her own rule and took her back four months ago.

She takes one girl at a time. They have their evening meal together and, if they're watching TV, she encourages the girl to stay for at least the first five minutes of the news. There's an occasional touch of Caribbean scolding in the relationship: she accepts that J "adores" being out late, but that's balanced by the serious way J is taking her life skills course at college.

Since Hewitt has got to know the childcare world, she sees several weaknesses in it. She's glad that more volunteers from ethnic groups are coming forward. But there are carers who treat their charges like lodgers. "Some Afro-Caribbeans shouldn't be foster parents," she says. "You cannot have a child in your home and just provide a TV, a stereo and meals on a tray in their bedroom."

She thinks also that children should be able to talk freely to social workers calling for a home visit, without the foster carer hovering round and inhibiting frankness.

But, in two areas, Hewitt reckons it's the fosterers who are sold short. Training courses and regular meetings for carers are all very well, but don't give the full picture. She was asked if she was prepared to take difficult kids, yet "most of the videos were positive, and I didn't think the children were that damaged". She was too optimistic: her front door has been smashed by an enraged teenager, and there have been 2am visits by police returning a runaway.

Is all this work and worry worth it for the £500 she receives every two weeks from Wandsworth, one of the highest payers in London?

Hewitt points out that the money is classed as expenses for providing for the child. As she still has income from legal and consultancy work, the issue of full remuneration matters less to her than other carers, she says. And while Hewitt understands the pressure for carers to be paid a proper salary, she is also slightly worried that it "might attract the wrong kind of person".

Money certainly isn't a factor for Anthony Cross, who is 41, single and works in Fleetwood, Lancashire. Between the demands of his career as an NHS pensions administrator, and doing sport most evenings, he reckoned he could devote two weekends a month to respite care to youngsters. For taking one into his home for three nights, including food, entertainment and travel, Lancashire county council pays him £34.

All the other potential fosterers on his training course (six mornings) have now dropped out. For several, "as soon as they realised they weren't going to get paid, they were off". But to be fair to them, he says, they were interested in full-time placements, rather than just weekends.

Cross persevered. As a result, he has "seen every new film at the local Odeon, been to Alton Towers five times last year", and to Blackpool more times than he can remember. He expects to be out of pocket, but that seems to be accepted by all parties. He doesn't cook - "but I do microwave" - so that means one or two restaurant meals in a weekend.

Respite care is one of the niches which can take the strain when relationships with family are at breaking point. One teenager Cross currently is helping is epileptic, overweight, attends special school and lives with his grandmother.

Cross could not become a full-time carer, but what he offers is useful: he plays and coaches badminton and tennis, and plays squash and swims. And he has bikes that don't stay unused for long on his respite weekends.

But does taking a child for just one weekend a month help a teenager? Cross is sure it does. "It gives a break to the child and the family," he says. "It suits me and my lifestyle. Living on my own, with a full-time job, fostering full-time wouldn't be possible." However, the teenagers have improved in the several months he's known them. "I like to think I've helped," he says.

Cross plans to continue for as long as he can; Hewitt, though, reckons that she'll give up fostering after five years. Children's services may be lucky to have them, but they will need many more.

 NFCA hotline: 0800 965985; website: www.fosteringnetwork.co.uk
