webTitle: Stories of life on sorrowful sites

fields.headline: Stories of life on sorrowful sites
fields.trailText: Lynne Wallis looks at the cases of two people living in mobile homes who may benefit from the campaign to improve residents' rights.
fields.body:
The battle of the bills

Richard Carrington moved on to Drayton Park, near Chichester, West Sussex, three years ago under the site management of Barry Weir. Carrington queried a £70 bill for two weeks' water supply, and then requested that a quarterly bill be itemised because it was so high. He was met with a "Don't you trust me?" response. When he pressed for itemisation, he was charged £70 for the paperwork.

"Our agreements with Weir, such as they are, say commodities are supplied at cost, but he's charging £1,000 a quarter instead of the actual £250," claims Carrington.

Carrington was taken to court by Weir for non-payment of charges. But while the latter brought in a Lincoln's Inn barrister, Carrington could not afford a lawyer and so represented himself. The verdict was found in favour of Weir and Carrington paid up, but says he plans to seek a judicial review.

Weir owns seven sites in West Sussex and charges VAT on domestic sewerage at Drayton Park, even though it is zero-rated. He has applied for planning permission for permanent homes there, which is baffling for the residents, who believe they have security of tenure. The war with Weir has taken over their lives - hardly the relaxed retirement some of them had hoped for.

The Guardian was told that Weir had embarked on a world tour in May and was thus unavailable for comment.

The repairs run-in

Penny Summerland is disabled and lives on the Clearways Park site in West Kingsdown, near Brands Hatch, Kent. She bought her home in 1986 and was told it had a new roof. It didn't. In fact, it leaked. She was also told the walls needed repairs to the tune of £30; she says she had to spend £1,200. She tried to sue for misrepresentation and won £9,000 plus costs at Dartford county court, but the site owner dissolved his company while litigation was underway.

Summerland, who stresses that she has no grievance with the present site owner, has lived under four differ ent regimes since her unfortunate purchase. "One of them wanted to 'survey' my home to check for repairs," she says. "I refused access and took them to court and won, but they were still granted the survey. They do this so they can get you on some little thing and then charge you for works. "I wish I'd had a survey done when I bought my home, but I was persuaded it wasn't necessary. I can't sell now. My home is worthless, so I'm stuck here. But meanwhile I'm going to carry on fighting for a better deal for park home residents."

One site owner tried to force a friend of Summerland's off a site for having a mobile home four inches too wide. The resident threatened legal action and the owner backed down. The following week, Summerland claims a huge bonfire was lit dangerously close to his home. "That's a common way of threatening residents," he says. "People have had their homes burned down for trying to stand up to owners. They do it to let us know who's boss."

fields.headline: Age of rage
fields.standfirst: The wild child of the environment movement is now 30 years old.  Fred Pearce  looks back at trails blazed by the Ecologist magazine
fields.trailText: The wild child of the environment movement is now 30 years old. Fred Pearce looks back at trails blazed by the Ecologist magazine.
fields.body:
Arrogant, sometimes outrageously authoritarian, but always fizzing with ideas, the Ecologist magazine has always been the wild child of the environment movement. Like The Who song, it seemed destined to die before it got old. But here it is, 30 years on, with founder Teddy Goldsmith in the process of handing over to his brother's son, Zac. And it's still in a rage - over Monsanto, globalisation, toxic chemicals, nuclear power and much more.

The Ecologist began life in the glory days of the environment movement. It first hit the news stands in 1970, after Silent Spring, Rachel Carson's seminal book on pesticide poisoning, and Paul Ehrlich's doom-laden demographic vision, The Population Bomb, but before the first Earth Summit, at Stockholm in 1972. Its birth coincided with the emergence of Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth and helped forge a global environmental movement.

Goldsmith was the son of a Tory MP, elder brother of Jimmy, future financier and bosom pal of the gambling club owner and maverick zoo-keeper John Aspinall, who died recently. Teddy was a dropout anthropologist who devoted his twenties to travelling the world and campaigning to save endangered tribes. "I began to realise that the survival of primitive peoples and of the environment were inseparable," he says. "The root problem was economic development. So I decided to start a paper to explore these issues."

Teddy has never believed in half measures. The first issue, published in July 1970, declared overpopulation to be the world's number one problem and proposed enforced sterilisation to halve the world's population. But his creation has enjoyed considerable skills in prophesy. That same first issue predicted an Alaskan oil spill two decades ahead of the Exxon Valdez and warned of a Chernobyl-like nuclear disaster. Meanwhile, in an early excursion on his lifelong search for a "bio-ethic", Teddy wrote on "cybernetics, society and the ecosystem" - creating an image of the planet as a single self-sustaining organism that pre-dated James Lovelock's first book on Gaia by nine years.

Perhaps it was Teddy's French upbringing, but his magazine has always had more affinity with pyrotechnic intellectuals of the Parisian Left Bank than with the more sedate rubbish recyclers of Richmond in south-west London, where it was for many years produced.

In its first months, the Ecologist compiled a Blueprint for Survival, a radical green manifesto that went on to sell 750,000 copies in paperback and kept the magazine financially afloat for years. The blueprint proposed the formation of a movement for political survival, which led directly to the creation of the People Party, later renamed the Ecology Party and finally the Green Party.

The Ecologist has been first with many of the big environmental stories - often by many years. It was discussing global climate change during the African droughts of the mid-1970s. It revealed the torching of the Amazon rainforest in the early 1980s. It was the first to expose the worldwide social and environmental destruction from large dams - at a time when most greens still saw hydroelectricity as the key to a cleaner, greener future.

It exposed the fallacy of cheap nuclear energy long before conventional economists tumbled to the truth. And it railed against the World Bank and the globalisation of world trade 15 years before Seattle. It poured scorn on the briefly fashionable "green consumerism". And it was producing cover features on the politics of seeds and the patenting of life back in the mid-1980s. In short, the modern green agenda has a striking resemblance to the Ecologist's back catalogue.

Because it takes itself immensely seriously, the magazine has often been a hotbed of internal disputes. Teddy's flirtations with the far right have caused several colleagues to leave in disgust. An early article by Robert Allen, apparently backing Pol Pot's murderous Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, didn't go down too well. Nor has what stalwart Peter Bunyard calls "Teddy's adherence to the notion that traditional societies alone have the key to sustainable living".

Such dogmatism attracted and later repelled Nick Hildyard, a student volunteer who came to be probably the second most influential person in the magazine's history. The eventual split between the two men in 1996 lit up a major schism within the environment movement itself.

Goldsmith's approach, best exemplified by his belief in population control, is essentially authoritarian. But Hildyard turned the magazine for long periods into an anti-authoritarian mouthpiece for progressive community groups from around the world opposing the forces of globalisation - whether dam builders or seed companies or military juntas or timber companies. And he embraced concepts largely alien to Goldsmith, such as feminism and anti-racism.

One of Hildyard's final issues, a 1996 special on the green revolution, launched a full-frontal assault on Goldsmith's views on population. It declared: "No matter how much food is produced, how few babies are born or how dramatically human numbers fall, it is the nature of the modern market economy remorselessly to generate scarcity . . . Blaming [this] on 'over-population' has long provided the most powerful with an explanation for human misery that does not indict themselves."

Few were surprised when the two parted shortly afterwards. Hildyard says now he regrets staying so long. But the truth is that the tension between the two approaches could be immensely creative.

The magazine is now being reborn, edited by Jimmy Goldsmith's son Zac. It looks more like a conventional magazine these days, with colour pictures and celebrity columnists. Its cover says it is "rethinking basic assumptions". But it still packs a punch. Its Monsanto files special issue was so hot that the Ecologist was forced to change its printers. Its uncompromising opening lines could have come out of any era of the magazine's past: "Genetic engineering threatens to upset the Earth's ecological balance, and to undermine the livelihoods of millions of people round the world. It is a technology that is almost entirely controlled by a handful of giant transnational corporations, and its effects are often irreversible."

In a world of global media groups, you cannot imagine any conglomerate opening a bidding war for the Ecologist. And that is the measure of its success.

Meanwhile, in an early excursion on his lifelong search for a "bio-ethic", Teddy wrote on "cybernetics, society and the ecosystem" - creating an image of the planet as a single self-sustaining organism that pre-dated James Lovelock's first book on Gaia by nine years. Perhaps it was Teddy's French upbringing, but his magazine has always had more affinity with pyrotechnic intellectuals of the Parisian Left Bank than with the more sedate rubbish recyclers of Richmond in south-west London, where it was for many years produced. In its first months, the Ecologist compiled a Blueprint for Survival, a radical green manifesto that went on to sell 750,000 copies in paperback and kept the magazine financially afloat for years. The blueprint proposed the formation of a movement for political survival, which led directly to the creation of the People Party, later renamed the Ecology Party and finally the Green Party. The Ecologist has been first with many of the big environmental stories - often by many years. It was discussing global climate change during the African droughts of the mid-1970s. It revealed the torching of the Amazon rainforest in the early 1980s. It was the first to expose the worldwide social and environmental destruction from large dams - at a time when most greens still saw hydroelectricity as the key to a cleaner, greener future. It exposed the fallacy of cheap nuclear energy long before conventional economists tumbled to the truth. And it railed against the World Bank and the globalisation of world trade 15 years before Seattle. It poured scorn on the briefly fashionable "green consumerism". And it was producing cover features on the politics of seeds and the patenting of life back in the mid-1980s. In short, the modern green agenda has a striking resemblance to the Ecologist's back catalogue. Because it takes itself immensely seriously, the magazine has often been a hotbed of internal disputes. Teddy's flirtations with the far right have caused several colleagues to leave in disgust. An early article by Robert Allen, apparently backing Pol Pot's murderous Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, didn't go down too well. Nor has what stalwart Peter Bunyard calls "Teddy's adherence to the notion that traditional societies alone have the key to sustainable living". Such dogmatism attracted and later repelled Nick Hildyard, a student volunteer who came to be probably the second most influential person in the magazine's history. The eventual split between the two men in 1996 lit up a major schism within the environment movement itself. Goldsmith's approach, best exemplified by his belief in population control, is essentially authoritarian. But Hildyard turned the magazine for long periods into an anti-authoritarian mouthpiece for progressive community groups from around the world opposing the forces of globalisation - whether dam builders or seed companies or military juntas or timber companies. And he embraced concepts largely alien to Goldsmith, such as feminism and anti-racism. One of Hildyard's final issues, a 1996 special on the green revolution, launched a full-frontal assault on Goldsmith's views on population. It declared: "No matter how much food is produced, how few babies are born or how dramatically human numbers fall, it is the nature of the modern market economy remorselessly to generate scarcity . . . Blaming [this] on 'over-population' has long provided the most powerful with an explanation for human misery that does not indict themselves." Few were surprised when the two parted shortly afterwards. Hildyard says now he regrets staying so long. But the truth is that the tension between the two approaches could be immensely creative. The magazine is now being reborn, edited by Jimmy Goldsmith's son Zac. It looks more like a conventional magazine these days, with colour pictures and celebrity columnists. Its cover says it is "rethinking basic assumptions". But it still packs a punch. Its Monsanto files special issue was so hot that the Ecologist was forced to change its printers. Its uncompromising opening lines could have come out of any era of the magazine's past: "Genetic engineering threatens to upset the Earth's ecological balance, and to undermine the livelihoods of millions of people round the world. It is a technology that is almost entirely controlled by a handful of giant transnational corporations, and its effects are often irreversible." In a world of global media groups, you cannot imagine any conglomerate opening a bidding war for the Ecologist. And that is the measure of its success.

webTitle: From acid to bread and roses

fields.headline: From acid to bread and roses
fields.standfirst: Laurie Taylor
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
It was late 1969 when my friend and comrade from the International Socialists, Paul Walton, suggested that we call round to a flat in Islington and meet Sheila Rowbotham, someone he described as a real-life radical feminist.

There was nothing too intimidating about Sheila's appearance, but after 10 minutes in her company I began to have serious difficulty following the direction of her thoughts. I'd heard some feminists attack what they called "the phallocentrism of traditional rationality" but this hardly seemed to account for my host's tendency to lurch violently from one subject to another and then relapse into long periods of complete silence.

After about half-an-hour of increasingly bizarre interaction, we made our excuses and left. "What did you think?" asked Paul. I confessed that, although I'd rather liked Sheila, I'd found it difficult to follow her conversation. "Of course you did," said Paul dismissively. "She was as high as a kite. Probably coming down from an acid trip."

To judge from Sheila's recently published memoir of life in the 60s (Promise of Desire), Paul got it right. Although much of the book is a record of her political activities during this period, she happily admits to her fascination with acid. "It intensified for me the capacity to see beauty in details which my eye would normally have passed over, and it deconstructed the customary."

Ten years after I'd met Sheila, I went to California to make a television documentary about the 60s. One of my interviewees was a former hippie who'd become a drug counsellor. I asked if he missed his former life. No, he explained, he didn't miss it. He only wondered about its reality. "Whereas I used to take acid and have the most astonishing revelations about the nature of the world and its potential for transformation, when I ask my clients now about their acid experiences all they say is that they see lots of pretty colours. Perhaps that's the way others will come to regard the whole of the 60s. As nothing much more than a wonderful dream."

Sheila is far less dismissive about the achievements of the 60s than my Californian counsellor, but she eventually became sufficiently dissatisfied with the ego trips and sectarian disputes to imagine a new kind of politics, one which would "assert the claims of working-class women, not only those of the more privileged, and it was going to be about bread and about roses". Something more was needed, she decided, than "the promise of a dream".

 Laurie Taylor talks to Sheila Rowbotham about life in the 60s on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed, 4pm today. An exclusive extract of her book Promise of Desire will appear in Guardian Weekend this Saturday

fields.headline: Chaos rules
fields.standfirst: The housing benefits system is collapsing under the weight of constant changes. But who is to blame?  Steve Brown reports
fields.trailText: The housing benefits system is collapsing under the weight of constant changes. But who is to blame? Steve Brown reports
fields.body:
Some 4.4m low income households throughout Britain rely on housing benefit to pay for their basic accommodation costs. If the benefit goes unpaid, so does the rent. And with some 40% of claimants aged over 60, it is vital the system runs smoothly. So it is rather alarming to be told that, in some areas, the housing benefit system is in chaos.

This is exactly the accusation made in a new report by the London Housing Federation (LHF), which is calling on the government to find immediate solutions. Failure to act swiftly, the housing body says, could leave rent arrears spiralling, "causing tenants panic and distress and pushing some housing associations to the edge of bankruptcy".

Housing benefits administration is forcing its way on to the government's agenda. All around the country there have been reports of mounting backlogs of claims, towers of unanswered correspondence and threats of eviction to tenants over unpaid rent that they are in no position to pay because their housing benefit has not come through yet. Sheffield, Manchester, Taunton Deane in Somerset, Wyre in Lancashire and, in London, Lambeth and Hackney are just some of the councils where housing benefit problems have hit the front pages. But they are just the tip of the iceberg. And while the media attention has frequently focused on councils that have outsourced benefits administration, the problems are hitting services run both in the public and private sectors.

According to the audit commission, just over half of councils nationally deliver an adequate housing benefit service. In London, the figure drops below 50%. The report from the LHF, which represents independent social landlords in the capital, reveals that just two in five of London's 33 boroughs are managing to meet housing benefit administration targets. The federation says this means that of the capital's 680,000 residents receiving housing benefit, just 270,000 are receiving payments consistently on time. The remaining 410,000 get an inadequate service, with many having to wait months for their benefit to be paid.

The government accepts the scheme has its faults. But it is clear where it believes the real blame lies. Speaking at a conference in London last week, at which the federation'sreport was launched, junior social security minister Angela Eagle pointed the finger firmly at the councils that administer the scheme on behalf of government. She said: "The delivery of housing benefit is complicated, can be confusing and is frequently time consuming. The benefit rules are complex for staff and claimants. The performance of local authorities who are responsible for delivering housing benefit is inconsistent. Some are excellent, others are appalling."

But both housing providers and benefit administrators believe the government is failing to take its share of the blame. Jim Coulter, chief executive of the National Housing Federation, says: "The government is in denial about its responsibility and trying to shift the blame on to local authorities."

The new report says that some 85 regulation changes during 1999, instructed by government, have been a significant factor in the "chaos" that has been witnessed. That trend of constant change has been continued in 2000, with over 30 changes so far forced on councils.

According to Gwyneth Taylor, housing policy officer at the Local Government Association, this "drip drip" of changes has slowly worn the system down. The changes, many related to the government's welfare-to-work agenda, are often relatively minor. But they still require staff training, software changes and new leaflets. "Any other system that required two software changes a week couldn't cope," says Taylor. "We acknowledge that there are differences in how local authorities are performing, but the government needs to acknowledge that part of that is due to them."

Perhaps the biggest problem for councils over the last year has been a cumbersome new verification framework introduced last September. So far, some 250 out of the 409 benefit administering authorities around the country have signed up. Its purpose is to stamp out fraudulent claims and it requires claimants to provide proof of their identity, income, capital, household details and rent. This proof has to be demonstrated using original documents that, in practice, have to be presented in person.

Ten authorities in the group of councils surveyed by the LHF had implemented what is known in housing circles as VF. Nine said it had had an adverse impact on the time taken to process claims. Six currently have backlogs, which they say were caused by the introduction of the anti-fraud measures. The funding to implement the framework has also proved inadequate, with some councils estimating that direct grant covers just 50% of the additional staffing costs. This has added to concerns that councils are already having to subsidise general administration costs.

While benefit claimants are the main casualties of the problems, housing associations are suffering, too. Rising rent arrears have left many associations with cash flow problems.

South London Family Housing Association manages some 8,000 homes, most of which are in the capital. "Our rent from south London is £22m a year," says Ben Wilson, the association's chief executive. "At the moment, we have £2.5m outstanding in arrears." That is more than double the 5% standard set by the Housing Corporation. In some areas, the association's problems are even more acute. For instance, in Lambeth the arrears due to the association from its 2,000 homes are a staggering 17-18% of the receivable rent. Wilson says the financial problems created by the benefit delays are making new housing development schemes unviable.

Although Eagle accepts that the system has problems, she believes the government's recent housing green paper contains proposals to address these weaknesses. But housing leaders are unconvinced. In fact, they say proposals last year to simplify the benefits system were shelved while the green paper was worked up. And now the paper has arrived, Coulter describes the proposals on housing benefit as "wishy-washy".

Taylor says the fundamental problem is that the scheme is "not really administerable" and, without change, there will always be problems. With last week's report and the recent high profile problems, councils, housing associations and tenants feel they have finally got the government's attention on housing benefit. What they want is a solution. And they want it now.

 Reaping the Benefit: Improving Housing Benefit Administration in London is obtainable at £10, plus £2.50 p&p, from the London Housing Federation, email: violetar@housing.org.uk

webTitle: On a wing and a prayer

fields.headline: On a wing and a prayer
fields.standfirst: The blossoming of mayflies offers hope for a Hungarian river
fields.trailText: The blossoming of mayflies offers hope for a Hungarian river
fields.body:
The world's largest mayfly, the Tiszavirág, emerged from the depths of Hungary's river Tisza last month to reproduce and then die. Its name means "Tisza Flower", and it blossoms for just a couple of hours on just a couple of afternoons in June, when the surface of the river explodes into a living carpet of mating mayfly.

That the Tiszavirág flowered at all this year is particularly surprising because the Tisza, to which this species is endemic, has experienced an ecological disaster reckoned to be the biggest to hit Europe since Chernobyl.

In January, a dam in north-west Romania, used to recover gold from mined rock, overflowed, unleashing around 100,000 cubic metres of cyanide and heavy metals into tributaries of the Tisza. That's the equivalent of more than 25 Olympic-sized swimming pools full of toxic waste. Within two weeks, this massive river, one of the largest natural riparian ecosystems in Europe, had been destroyed. In villages the length of the river, church bells tolled in mourning as shoals of dead fish floated on the surface. But there was still some hope for the Tisza's future. Thanks to a low water table, the destruction had been largely confined to the riverbed and had not spread to the vast floodplains and oxbows that adorn its banks. There was some consolation too that the uppermost 120km of the river had escaped damage because it lay above the tributary that brought the pollution into Hungary. The spring floods would link these sinks of biodiversity to the dead riverbed and seed the rebirth of the river.

Ironically, it was the spring flood that caused a second spill from a second Romanian mine. Just five weeks after the first disaster, melting snow and heavy rains brought down a dam wall at a metal mine near the Tisza's source. Roughly 20,000 cubic metres of toxic sludge - this time a mere five Olympic pools - entered the river, seriously damaging the uppermost section that had been spared the first spill.

Mayfly are commonly used as bio-indicators of freshwater pollution. As key representatives of the local food chain, they can speak honestly about the health of their ecosystem.

The flowering of Tiszavirág (Palingenia longicauda), just as the goldmine recommenced operations, threw a much-needed line of hope out to Hungary's villagers, farmers and fishermen. Palingenia translates as "born again". The people of eastern Hungary are hoping that this small triumph of the mayfly is more than just an idle metaphor.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Bribery backfires | The pest test | Eternal flame
fields.body:
Bribery backfires
Japan has been accused before of "buying" votes at the International Whaling Commission by giving lumps of aid to tiny countries to get them to join and vote for resumption of whaling - or at least to block further protection measures. There were signs at last week's annual meeting that this is beginning to backfire. The Dominican minister of environment, Atherton Martin, resigned after his country's delegates voted with Japan to successfully block a plan to create a new sanctuary in the Southern Pacific. He said: "This is undignified and unacceptable and must be resisted . . . there is absolutely no reason for us to be held ransom by Japan . . . in return for promises of aid." Six Caribbean nations, including Dominica, voted with Japan all week. They were crucial to continuing the stalemate at the IWC since a three-quarters majority is needed among the 40 countries present.

The pest test
For EuropaBio, the European Association for Bioindustries, "it is obvious that US farmers continue to be confident about [GM] improved seeds and increasingly prefer the biotech alternative which allows them to better manage their crop production". They say this on the basis that the area of GM crops planted in the US this year is only marginally down on last year. There is, however, a big drop in GM maize from 28.3m acres to 19.9m. This is explained by "a decreased occurrence of the European corn borer, a particularly harmful pest in many parts of the American corn belt. This year's decrease in corn borer has made farmers decide not to buy GM seeds, which are in fact an 'insurance' against a problem which - at least this year - does not exist". The alternative possible explanation that farmers may plant normal seed because they are not confident of selling GM maize to food or fodder companies is not considered.

Eternal flame
A flame lit from the fire caused by the Hiroshima atomic bomb on August 6, 1945, made a brief appearance on stage at the Glastonbury festival with a Japanese band called the Tenkoo Orchestra. The band obtained special permission to take a light from the perpetual flame burning in Japan and bring an offshoot to England. The band leader, Hiroki Okano, is now looking for a responsible body of peaceniks or monks to become guardians of the flame in Britain.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Mission impossible
fields.body:
Mission impossible

With reference to your article on the impact of changes in the NHS on health workers (A health check, June 28) and the continuing correspondence on day services for clients with learning disabilities, I believe the two are linked.

From my perspective as a care worker who works with learning disabilities on a daily basis, the government and, indeed, our own management are trying to get us to do the impossible.

Not only are they rightly trying to get as much day service activity for the clients as possible, they also expect us to write out elongated reports on what we do. Why are we doing the activity? What is its ultimate goal? How it went? Whether it is worth doing again? Then there are reports at the end of each month, risk assessment criteria, updating all policy and procedures, taking part in periodical reviews, going on training courses - and writing reports on them.

Accuse me of being cyncial, but with all the paperwork we have to do, we could happily spend all day preparing for an activity and never actually do it.

Name and address withheld

Reporting the truth

Good, honest journalists were doing "the hard work of uncovering the truth" long before it became fashionable for social scientists to question taken-for-granted assumptions (Laurie Taylor, July 5).

It is precisely because those journalists have been doing such a good job that social scientists have been given the freedom to develop new ways of reporting those truths. One prominent example is "reportage", stories about "a day in the life of" such and such a person or group or community. This technique originated with those sociologists who adopted essentially anthropological approaches and it began to be popularised in the (sadly now defunct) New Society back in the late 1960s.

It is now of course a standard technique in the repertoire of every good, honest journalist. But it originated precisely from academic questioning of the best ways to represent reality.

Richard Hull
Hebden Bridge, West Yorkshire

Insurance fiddly

Thank you to Jane Lewis and Ruth Lister for sharing their experiences of arranging care for their mothers (The cost of caring, June 28). I also have been through this experience over the past two years, first arranging a place in a residential home, then transfer to a nursing home.

One thing which made the whole process much easier was that my mother had enough money in pensions, attendance allowance and savings not to have to prove her case to the social services. I was able to control it and make things happen at the right time for her.

I have considerable reservations about proposals to encourage people to insure against the need to pay for residential care. Would one then have to prove need to an insurance company instead of social services? Would this really be much easier?

Margaret Gregory
Manchester

Signs of peace

For those of us who work in deaf education, "Blood on the pages" (July 5) was a distressing headline. Progress in provision for the deaf, of all persuasions, has been severely hindered by the sector's proclivity for in-fighting, but the last two years have seen a sea change which promises much - if it is not dissipated by another squall.

The RNID represents all the deaf and hearing impaired. Under David Livermore and James Strachan, it has been most influential in establishing new working relations across the "signing/oralist" divide which, for the first time, have led to collaborative projects. My own organisation is totally committed to our approach (the development of natural, effective spoken language) which we believe provides the young deaf person with the maximum choices and opportunities - including the choice and the right subsequently to reject the hearing world and adopt British sign language (BSL).

However, we do not challenge recognition of BSL, nor does any other "oralist".

We do challenge the notions that there is only one "deaf agenda", that BSL is the only acceptable route for the deaf, and that severely and profoundly deaf hearing aid users living in the hearing world are "not deaf".

Wendy Barnes
National director

Deaf Education through Listening and Talking

Laing's lasting legacy

Jane Feinmann's article on cognitive therapy for schizophrenia (It's good to talk, June 28) presented a travesty of RD Laing's life and work. By all means mention his excesses and mistakes, but also acknowledge his achievement in developing a different way of seeing the experiences and behaviours we crudely describe as "schizophrenia".

Laing is not responsible for other people's simplification of his ideas and his critique of psychiatry is unanswerable.

Peter Linnett
London

Your article opens up a useful debate, but does not go far enough. Laing argued not only that madness was meaningful and understandable in context but, even more controversially, that the concept of "schizophrenia" itself was nonsensical. It is vested interests ranging from the medical profession to drug companies, rather than political correctness, which prevent us from acknowledging this today.
Lucy Johnstone
Clinical psychologist
University of West of England

Smart move

Congratulations on getting rid of that vapid, patronising front page (letters, July 5). Is the dumbing down tide at last beginning to turn?

Hudson Pace
Teddington, Middlesex

fields.bodyText: Mission impossible With reference to your article on the impact of changes in the NHS on health workers (A health check, June 28) and the continuing correspondence on day services for clients with learning disabilities, I believe the two are linked. From my perspective as a care worker who works with learning disabilities on a daily basis, the government and, indeed, our own management are trying to get us to do the impossible. Not only are they rightly trying to get as much day service activity for the clients as possible, they also expect us to write out elongated reports on what we do. Why are we doing the activity? What is its ultimate goal? How it went? Whether it is worth doing again? Then there are reports at the end of each month, risk assessment criteria, updating all policy and procedures, taking part in periodical reviews, going on training courses - and writing reports on them. Accuse me of being cyncial, but with all the paperwork we have to do, we could happily spend all day preparing for an activity and never actually do it. Name and address withheld Reporting the truth Good, honest journalists were doing "the hard work of uncovering the truth" long before it became fashionable for social scientists to question taken-for-granted assumptions (Laurie Taylor, July 5). fields.headline: Behind closed doors
fields.standfirst: Why are so many Asian women driven to suicide and self-harm?  Chris Arnot meets a brave survivor who knows the pain of isolation, low self-esteem and sexual abuse
fields.trailText: Why are so many Asian women driven to suicide and self-harm? Chris Arnot meets a brave survivor who knows the pain of isolation, low self-esteem and sexual abuse.
fields.body:
Bobbie was 13 when she discovered that the man she thought was her brother was really her father, and the woman she thought was her mother was really her grandmother. It didn't stop there. The woman in a frame on the wall was not, as she had been told, an aunt who lived far away in India. She was her real mother. What's more, she had committed suicide when Bobbie was a baby.

Confused? Not half as much as Bobbie was when these brutal facts of her life were blurted out, in the heat of a family argument, by another "brother", who turned out to be an uncle. It was a devastating catalogue of deception to pile on to the shoulders of a budding adolescent - albeit one who was hardly innocent of the cruel complexities of an adult world. She had been sexually abused from the age of five by the man she had thought was her father but who was, of course, her grandfather.

Thirty years on from learning the truth about her mother, Bobbie is curled up on the sofa in her council house, talking with remarkable composure about her life as a victim and survivor of almost unimaginable emotional turmoil. "Mine is an unusually intense and ugly story," she says, "but I'm still here to tell it." This is despite four suicide attempts, despite savage beatings by men and despite her own apparent need to hurt herself physically, sometimes banging her head against a wall until it bled.

She started self-harming in her teens. "At first I would go into the toilet to pinch and scratch myself so that the pain on the outside would temporarily shift the focus from the pain inside," she says. Her real name is Kusum Wason. She was born in Nairobi, to Indian parents, 43 years ago. The family moved to London when she was 11. Bobbie is the name she took on during her time as a "flirtatious" dancer, and it stuck. It's what she chooses to be called in a television documentary for the East series, to be shown next Monday on BBC2. Two other, younger women are also featured. All three are self-harmers. All three are Asian.

Statistics show that Asian women are three times more likely than their white counterparts to attempt suicide. And when the Newham Asian Women's Project, in east London, analysed those attending its counselling and mental health support groups, it found that three out of five were inflicting physical pain upon themselves. Some cut themselves with razors or knives. Others would scald themselves with irons or pummel walls with their fists.

The project's patron is the actress, writer and comedienne Meera Syal, who says she was pleased to be asked to present the TV documentary. "I'm becoming more and more concerned about Asian women and what's happening to us in this country," she says. "It's shocking that the incidences are so high in such a specific group at a time when the same group is being applauded for its achievements in education."

So why is it happening? The reasons put forward by Anjum Mouj, chair of the Newham project, are "domestic violence, neglect and sexual abuse in childhood". But those factors could apply to any number of women from all backgrounds. Over and above these wellsprings of discontent are other factors to which Asian women are particularly vulnerable.

One is racism. A young woman called Humerah tells Syal how, when she was 14, she would be alone in the house during school holidays. "The National Front people used to ring up and give me delightful messages." She goes on to say: "I just thought I'd try out what the razor was really like because I just felt so numb, so alone and pretty desperate... It just made me feel something, and that was important."

Isolation is another factor, sometimes coupled with an identity crisis. Sita was separated from her brothers and sisters at 13, after her mother had a mental breakdown, and sent to live with white foster parents. "The message they were giving me was that it was wrong to be Asian... I still don't know who I am," she says as the camera closes in on her face and her big eyes glisten with imminent tears.

There is one other factor which makes Asian women prone to low self-esteem and, consequently, at higher risk of self-harming: they were born female in a community where it is still common for male offspring to be valued more highly.

Bobbie knows all about that, and tells me what it has meant for her. "Girls are not looked upon favourably in our culture," she says. "Once I found out about my mother, I was told that she killed herself because of me. The rest of my family regarded me as a jinx."

Until comparatively recently, her life has been like the improbable plot of a harrowing melodrama. At 17, she had two children, and a mother-in-law who insisted on keeping them from her. Bobbie was shown the door. She had short spells of homelessness and alcohol abuse, drifting from one violent relationship to another.

Her current partner, Navid, has proved to be a rarity in her chaotic life: a kind man. And she appears to be blossoming as a result. The mental legacy will always be there, but she now confines any self-harming to poking at her ears, occasionally and surreptitiously. She knows that banging her head against a wall would alarm the three children who still live at home. "My kids provide my energy source," she says, proudly.

Certainly, she seems to exude an inner strength which is now being put to wider use. She is active in the local tenants' association and wants to stand as a Labour councillor in the next elections. Meanwhile, she's working as a counsellor for the Southall Black Sisters, trying to help other women who are harming themselves. "I know what they're going through because I've been there myself," she says. She knows what it's like to be abused, rejected and so angry inside that physical pain seems like the only diversion from mental torture.

"I'm still angry with my family and my community," she says. "I used to be angry with my mother for not being there for me. Now I just feel sad for her. When I help a young girl to give up suicidal feelings, I find myself talking to my mother afterwards. 'There you go, mum,' I say. 'One more for you. Your death wasn't in vain'."

 East: Suffering in Silence is on BBC2 next Monday at 7.30pm.

fields.headline: On active service
fields.standfirst: John Brown worried about his elderly father being alone when Mum died. He needn't have done. Odd jobs kept Dad fully occupied
fields.trailText: John Brown worried about his elderly father being alone when Mum died. He needn't have done. Odd jobs kept Dad fully occupied
fields.body:
Dad retired on an army pension at the age of 50. During the war, he had been promoted from sergeant-major to captain. Mum was so proud. His father had been a Sergeant of Hussars in the Boer War, but never before had anybody in our family gained a King's Commission.

After 30 years of soldiering, Dad couldn't bear to be out of uniform and so he joined the War Department police as a constable. He and Mum lived in police quarters and he worked shifts for 15 years.

At 65, Dad had to retire again. They moved to a small house in the Cambridgeshire village where Mum had been born, and he got a job on the production line at a radio assembly plant, working there full time.

At 70, retirement was again forced upon him, but immediately he got a job as a warehouseman for a golfing goods distributor, where he worked for 10 years.

By the time he was 80, we had all begun to realise that, for Dad, retirement was just another word for unemployment. Mum had now gone into hospital with senile dementia, and he had moved into a Royal British Legion apartment near Cambridge. "Now what am I going to do?" he wrote to us.

We had a letter duplicated for him. In essence it read: "Dear Neighbour, I am an old age pensioner with time on my hands. If there are any odd jobs you'd like me to do, please telephone."

He put 50 of these through letter boxes of local houses, and almost immediately his phone began to ring. "Can you walk my dogs, dig some potatoes, clean my silver, watch my house, etc?" He began a paper round, and a local school employed him to clean two classrooms each day. To get the job he'd declared his age as 68.

Twice weekly he made the six-mile round trip by bicycle to visit Mum in hospital. She always greeted him with a kiss and a smile, but she didn't know him; she thought he was her brother.

At 85, dad was finding the cold winter mornings a bit tough and decided to give up his paper round. The local newspaper printed a story about Cambridge's oldest paper boy calling it a day. There he was, pictured with a huge smile, in his old raincoat, his bike beside him. But, two weeks later, he started up again and continued for two more years.

By the time he was 87, Mum had died and Dad had fallen off his bike on his way back from the pub. Without a bike he had to give up the paper round and classroom cleaning, but his other "little jobs" remained.

He was offered good accommodation in a home for old soldiers, where he would be well cared for, but Dad would have none of it. "I'm not giving up my home and my little jobs," he said. My brother and I were worried. He lived alone and far from either of us, but he was adamant.

As his 89th birthday approached, the family wanted to give him a celebration. We arrived the night before and suggested we take him out for a meal. "Thanks, but I can't," he said. He took us to the apartment above, where we met Eileen, a fellow pensioner. "Eileen and I always have supper together," he said. "Then we drink some whisky and do a crossword." We almost felt that we were in the way, though Eileen was very hospitable.

Next day, his birthday, he said: "I must go and put flowers on Mum's grave." We drove him and tended the grave. Then we went to the Dog and Duck. He always went to the pub, which was near to the cemetery, after visiting the grave each Saturday.

Dad led us into the pub and was met by a chorus of "Happy Birthday to You." They had all been waiting for him, thrust a pint into his hand and an elderly lady gave him a kiss and a card. "This is Jean," he said. "She gives me lunch on Saturdays, then her son drives me home."

And to think we were worried. He'd kept his independence, and a lifestyle that suited him. He could still charm the ladies and have lots of friends. He didn't need us.

 John Brown senior died a week before his 90th birthday, following a fall on his way downstairs from Eileen's flat.

fields.headline: Mobile phoney
fields.standfirst: Owning a 'park homes' site has been described as a licence to print money by residents campaigning for changes in the law.  Lynne Wallis reports
fields.trailText: Owning a 'park homes' site has been described as a licence to print money by residents campaigning for changes in the law. Lynne Wallis reports.
fields.body:
Swopping urban bricks and mortar for a home set in neat, well-tended grounds in the countryside has a certain appeal - particularly if the new home is cheaper than the old one, freeing up a bit of capital for retirement. Two-thirds of the country's 200,000 residents of "park homes", formerly known as mobile homes, are elderly. Their 60x20ft homes are either two large caravans put together or wooden huts on wheels which usually make only one journey, from the factory.

But all is not well in these garden gnome-fringed, mainly white, working-class idylls; park home land is green, but the atmosphere can be far from pleasant, and some of those who dreamed of a tranquil new life find they are unprotected in law and being mercilessly exploited by site owners. Investigation into the problems encountered by residents has thrown up horrific evidence from pensioners who said they had had excrement smeared over their homes, or had seen site owners patrolling with baseball bats. At the beginning of this month, some park home residents handed in a petition to No 10, coinciding with a campaign launched by homelessness magazine the Big Issue.

Today, a consultation report by a park homes working party is published by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR). It makes plain that the park home industry, which currently comes under the woefully inadequate 1983 Mobile Home Act, is crying out for proper regulation.

Problems of regulation have arisen because a mobile home is considered a chattel (because it has wheels) and not a property, which means residents are not protected under property law. Some vulnerable, retired residents are suffering intimidation, extortion and bullying at the hands of unscrupulous site owners who can charge what they like in rent, maintenance and repairs.

Colin Packman, of the Independent Park Homes Advisory Service which helps residents in difficulty, says: "The trouble is, we're a small number spread out over the country, so we're not a vote winner." Philip Kenny, head of law at the University of Northumbria, has campaigned for years for improvements to the law for the residents of Britain's 1,300 park homes. He has described ownership of a park home site as a licence to print money.

Kenny, who has worked with homelessness charity Shelter on the park homes issue, says: "Pitch fees, or ground rents, are often put up arbitrarily by site owners. Most people wouldn't think a £30 increase is a lot of money, but to many retired people it makes a difference between having treats and not. They are often timorous, elderly folk who'd rather give in and have a quiet life. The ones who get to court find the owners employ expensive lawyers and they can't afford to compete."

Pitch fees are around £70-£150 a month and residents pay between £40,000 and £80,000 for a park home, although some luxury homes can reach the £180,000 mark. And here's the rub. The 1983 act allows mobile home owners to sell their home on site - the value is in the location, not the home itself - but there is no sanction to prevent site owners interfering, perhaps by putting off prospective owners.

Residents who need to sell up - to go into a nursing home, for example - can end up selling their home for peanuts to the site owner, who then buys a brand new home for £20,000 and sells it for £80,000 to a new resident. High turnover means more profit, which is why some of these landlords are intimidating residents off their sites. Most landlords ban residents' associations.

Another classic site owner's money-spinner is to supply Calor Gas at an extortionate price and then interfere with competitors' deliveries. One resident insisted on using an alternative gas supplier, so the site owner went to court to get his pitch fee increased to cover his "losses". Kenny says: "It's the only industry where you can actually get compensation for an extortion you failed to extract."

The park homes working party was set up by the DETR in 1998 after homeowners drew attention to the serious tensions between residents and site owners. Members include bodies representing site owners and residents, the Local Government Association, the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health and the Office of the National Assembly for Wales, with the DETR as chair.

Their report has made 30 recommendations for change covering rules on sale of homes, provision of written statements, termination of agreements, harassment, site licensing by local authorities, pitch fees and commission rates. Ministers are due to consider implementation of the recommendations after the consultation deadline of October but even then, changes to the existing regulations could require primary and secondary legislation, so slowing the process even further.

The National Park Homes Council, one of two bodies representing the mobile home parks, and a member of the working party, welcomes today's report but would have liked to have seen recommendations for an independent ombudsman for mobile home owners, as there is in the housing sector. Pauline Bruton, vice-chair, says: "It is a minority of site owners who are finding loopholes and using them to their own ends, but we want these people out of the industry because it is tarnishing all of us."

 One month before the sale of a mobile home, a statement must be signed by both parties, in the presence of witnesses.

 Breaches of agreements which then become null and void owing to the condition of a home will apply only to its exterior (to avoid intimidating "surveys").

 Residents' associations, meeting specific criteria, should be encouraged, with rights to information from site owners.

 Price information of all utilities must be available to residents, and a statutory maximum price introduced for the re-sale of gas.

 The Caravan Sites Act be amended to protect against harassment and illegal eviction.

 The government to identify a maximum level of site owner commission on goods and services supplied, and decide how pitch fees will be set.

 Tightening up on park home licensing.

 Mobile homes should not come under housing law, as they would then be subject to building regulations which could drive park owners out of the industry.
fields.bodyText: Swopping urban bricks and mortar for a home set in neat, well-tended grounds in the countryside has a certain appeal - particularly if the new home is cheaper than the old one, freeing up a bit of capital for retirement. Two-thirds of the country's 200,000 residents of "park homes", formerly known as mobile homes, are elderly. Their 60x20ft homes are either two large caravans put together or wooden huts on wheels which usually make only one journey, from the factory. But all is not well in these garden gnome-fringed, mainly white, working-class idylls; park home land is green, but the atmosphere can be far from pleasant, and some of those who dreamed of a tranquil new life find they are unprotected in law and being mercilessly exploited by site owners. Investigation into the problems encountered by residents has thrown up horrific evidence from pensioners who said they had had excrement smeared over their homes, or had seen site owners patrolling with baseball bats. At the beginning of this month, some park home residents handed in a petition to No 10, coinciding with a campaign launched by homelessness magazine the Big Issue. Today, a consultation report by a park homes working party is published by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR). It makes plain that the park home industry, which currently comes under the woefully inadequate 1983 Mobile Home Act, is crying out for proper regulation. Problems of regulation have arisen because a mobile home is considered a chattel (because it has wheels) and not a property, which means residents are not protected under property law. Some vulnerable, retired residents are suffering intimidation, extortion and bullying at the hands of unscrupulous site owners who can charge what they like in rent, maintenance and repairs. Colin Packman, of the Independent Park Homes Advisory Service which helps residents in difficulty, says: "The trouble is, we're a small number spread out over the country, so we're not a vote winner." Philip Kenny, head of law at the University of Northumbria, has campaigned for years for improvements to the law for the residents of Britain's 1,300 park homes. He has described ownership of a park home site as a licence to print money. Kenny, who has worked with homelessness charity Shelter on the park homes issue, says: "Pitch fees, or ground rents, are often put up arbitrarily by site owners. Most people wouldn't think a £30 increase is a lot of money, but to many retired people it makes a difference between having treats and not. They are often timorous, elderly folk who'd rather give in and have a quiet life. The ones who get to court find the owners employ expensive lawyers and they can't afford to compete." Pitch fees are around £70-£150 a month and residents pay between £40,000 and £80,000 for a park home, although some luxury homes can reach the £180,000 mark. And here's the rub. The 1983 act allows mobile home owners to sell their home on site - the value is in the location, not the home itself - but there is no sanction to prevent site owners interfering, perhaps by putting off prospective owners. Residents who need to sell up - to go into a nursing home, for example - can end up selling their home for peanuts to the site owner, who then buys a brand new home for £20,000 and sells it for £80,000 to a new resident. High turnover means more profit, which is why some of these landlords are intimidating residents off their sites. Most landlords ban residents' associations. Another classic site owner's money-spinner is to supply Calor Gas at an extortionate price and then interfere with competitors' deliveries. One resident insisted on using an alternative gas supplier, so the site owner went to court to get his pitch fee increased to cover his "losses". Kenny says: "It's the only industry where you can actually get compensation for an extortion you failed to extract." The park homes working party was set up by the DETR in 1998 after homeowners drew attention to the serious tensions between residents and site owners. Members include bodies representing site owners and residents, the Local Government Association, the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health and the Office of the National Assembly for Wales, with the DETR as chair. Their report has made 30 recommendations for change covering rules on sale of homes, provision of written statements, termination of agreements, harassment, site licensing by local authorities, pitch fees and commission rates. Ministers are due to consider implementation of the recommendations after the consultation deadline of October but even then, changes to the existing regulations could require primary and secondary legislation, so slowing the process even further. The National Park Homes Council, one of two bodies representing the mobile home parks, and a member of the working party, welcomes today's report but would have liked to have seen recommendations for an independent ombudsman for mobile home owners, as there is in the housing sector. Pauline Bruton, vice-chair, says: "It is a minority of site owners who are finding loopholes and using them to their own ends, but we want these people out of the industry because it is tarnishing all of us."  One month before the sale of a mobile home, a statement must be signed by both parties, in the presence of witnesses.  Breaches of agreements which then become null and void owing to the condition of a home will apply only to its exterior (to avoid intimidating "surveys").  Residents' associations, meeting specific criteria, should be encouraged, with rights to information from site owners.  Price information of all utilities must be available to residents, and a statutory maximum price introduced for the re-sale of gas.  The Caravan Sites Act be amended to protect against harassment and illegal eviction.  The government to identify a maximum level of site owner commission on goods and services supplied, and decide how pitch fees will be set.  Tightening up on park home licensing.  Mobile homes should not come under housing law, as they would then be subject to building regulations which could drive park owners out of the industry.

fields.headline: A juggling of power
fields.standfirst: Changes planned for the provision of social care
fields.trailText: Changes planned for the provision of social care
fields.body:
A shake-up of social care services in England will be announced towards the end of this month by Alan Milburn, the health secretary. Although the final shape of the new regime is still under discussion in Whitehall, it seems certain that the outcome will involve an unequal trading of powers between the NHS and local authorities.

Elected councillors will be allowed to commission a wider range of services for children, in return for abandoning their monopoly of control over the much larger and more costly range of social care services for mentally ill and elderly people.

"The current inflexible partitions between primary care, social care and hospital care leave patients bewildered, sometimes lost, in a maze of conflicting services," Milburn told the NHS Confederation conference in Glasgow. "That is why the national plan will include new roles for staff and new means for integrating health and social care services."

Mental health services and mental health social work could be delivered through a single provider trust. And services for older people could be commissioned by primary care "super trusts" - partnerships under the 1999 Health Act allowing the NHS and local authorities to pool their budgets to deliver an integrated package of medical and social care.

"But this is not one-way traffic, with health organisations taking on social care functions," Milburn said. "It is perfectly possible, for example, that more child care and child protection services could become part of the early years directorates with in local authorities."

He added that the local authorities' role might extend to commissioning medical services for children with disabilities, tackling their health and educational needs together.

For local government chiefs there are too many unanswered questions to feel relaxed about the plan. The first is uncertainty about what Milburn means when he talks about partnership.

"If he is suggesting a new approach to commissioning that would bring more consistent consultation and partnership, then we have declared ourselves naturally interested," says Jim Kennedy, the Local Government Association's head of social affairs and health. "But that is in stark distinction to giving the whole process of commissioning social care to one side or the other."

In other words, the local authorities could live with local arrangements allowing a pooling of health and social care budgets and a sharing of control over how they were distributed. It would also retain an element of local democratic accountability.

But would there be an equal partnership? Or could the NHS have such a dominant role that the local authority does little more than sign the cheques?

Ministers have not yet decided the balance of power, but the signs are that they will not be seeking to emasculate the local authorities. They want reform to proceed quickly and they know the integration of health and social care will be smoother if it can be done on a voluntary basis - although legislation may be needed to universalise the changes at a later date.

There is also uncertainty about which children's services may pass from NHS control into the hands of local authorities. Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, points out that Milburn's Glasgow speech could theoretically open up the possibility of councils taking over GP services for children, respite care and hospital paediatrics. But nobody is expecting such a radical shift. A consolidation of local authorities' responsibilities for child protection is the more likely outcome.

The reforms will have far-reaching consequences for the social care professions. The action team advising Milburn on partnerships in the health service has said that "a new, flexible, multi-skilled care worker is required to act as a personal carer, addressing the basic health and social care needs of patient/users". A new type of "specialist older people's nurse" able to work across the health and social care boundary is also envisaged.

fields.headline: Time is money
fields.standfirst: Who gives to charity in the boardroom?
fields.trailText: Who gives to charity in the boardroom?
fields.body:
Top business leaders are more heavily involved in charities than is often supposed, a new survey suggests. But finance directors tend to be the exception to the rule, pleading pressure of work.

The survey of almost one in three of the 350 leading FTSE companies comes after Gordon Brown, the chancellor, chastised British companies for their low level of charitable giving, relative to their counterparts in the US. He also called on business leaders to throw their weight behind a national campaign for a volunteering partnership with the voluntary sector.

According to the survey, based on 134 responses from 111 companies, 89% of board chairmen give time to charity - or, in almost all cases, a number of charities. On average, they each support 3.6 charities. Asked what they did to demonstrate their support, the chairmen identified 46 different roles but most were charity chairs or trustees.

Such commitment can, on paper, be worth a lot to charities. A company chairman's average 8.75 hours volunteering a month, valued by commercial salary, is put at £120,000 a year. The contribution of chief executives, an average 5.25 hours a month, is valued at £70,000 a year.

The survey, conducted by the Charities Aid Foundation, found that 61% of chief executives, and the same proportion of marketing and personnel directors, were involved with charities. But only 44% of finance directors had a commitment. Of the uninvolved majority, 41% said work took too much of their time, 34% said they gave money privately or corporately and 8% said they had never considered it or were "not interested".

This finding has particular sig nificance because finance directors' expertise is much sought after by charities. Where they are involved, they tend to serve as treasurers or auditors.

In a foreword to the report, Making Time for Charity, the chancellor restates his unfavourable comparison of corporate giving in Britain (0.2% of profits) with that in the US (1%), and callsfor a "new start" by business in terms of civic engagement.

But Ian Martin, chairman of Unigate, makes the point elsewhere that there is a big difference in attitudes across the Atlantic.

"Many people still tithe 10% of their income to charity, partly because people out there don't think that they've already paid through their taxes in the same way that people in Europe do," says Martin, who spent six years in the US. "A lot of people in the UK, for example, say: 'Look, sure I make a lot of money, but I gave 40% of it to the government. I've already given at the tax office'."

The report, sponsored by accountants Deloitte & Touche, also acknowledges that very few women occupy top business posts. Of the survey respondents, just 12 were women and none of them was a chair, chief executive or finance director.

Although women are generally considered to be more generous to charity, the report says:"There is considerable evidence of a lack of women among charitable trustees, particularly of large charities. Is this partly due to the lack of women in top business positions?"

 Making Time for Charity is available, at £12.50 inc, from CAF Research, Kings Hill, West Malling, Kent ME19 4TA (tel: 01732-520120)

webTitle: Russian space station module has extra topping

fields.headline: Russian space station module has extra topping
fields.standfirst:
Space exploration: special report
Comment: A waste of space?
fields.trailText: A Russian rocket blasted off from Kazakhstan this morning to boost the much-delayed International Space Station. In a sign of the new Russia, the rocket displayed a large Pizza Hut logo.
fields.body:
The long-delayed International Space Station got a boost Wednesday when a Russian Proton-K rocket blasted off flawlessly from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan and pushed the station's service module into orbit.

Russia and the United States have invested high hopes in the Zvezda module, the core of the $60 billion, 16-nation space station project. Without the module, no crews could be sent up to the station, because Zvezda will contain the flight controls, sewage system and living quarters.

A large logo advertising Pizza Hut had been placed about halfway up the rocket, a reflection of the funding problems that have troubled the Russian space program. Russia says that the 22-ton, 43-foot-long segment cost about $320 million to build. It has severely taxed Moscow's meagre financial resources.

At Mission Control outside Moscow, Russian and US space agency officials applauded as the module went into orbit approximately 10 minutes after being launched at 8.56am Moscow time.

The officials gathered at Mission Control and in Baikonur, in the remote steppes of Kazakhstan, were ecstatic, and they praised each other for strong commitment to the project.

The launch decided "whether Russia's space program will go on existing or not," said a beaming Yuri Koptev, director of the Russian Aerospace Agency. "It decided the fate of a great international space project."

"I have to say that this is one of the happiest and proudest days of my life," said Nasa administrator Daniel Goldin. "We set a vision eight years ago and we stuck to that vision."

US President Ronald Reagan set the International Space Station program in motion in 1984. Nine years later, with the project in turmoil, President Bill Clinton invited the Russians to join.

However, instead of saving the United States time and money as hoped, the Russians caused even more delays and created even bigger expenses for Nasa - some $3 billion. The Zvezda module was launched two years behind schedule.

"We have travelled a very long and difficult road," Koptev said. "We wish the road had been a highway but a highway it was not. It was often closed for repairs, and we experienced detours."

Goldin praised the Russians for succeeding despite adversity, saying, "I don't know of any other group that has the toughness I've seen from our Russian colleagues."

The Zvezda module went into orbit unmanned, and it is scheduled to dock on July 26 by computer with two other space station components, Zarya and Unity, which were launched in 1998. The first crew could go to the station by October, Nasa has said.

"Before we pop the champagne corks, we have two more weeks before we dock, but I have a sense everything will be OK," Goldin said.

In the event the automatic linkup goes awry, two cosmonauts are on standby to fly immediately to Zvezda aboard a Soyuz rocket from Baikonur. A live feed from the cosmodrome was broadcast on console video screens at Mission Control, while a huge screen in front of the officials tracked the rocket's flight from the cosmodrome on the wind-swept steppes of Kazakhstan into the cloudless skies.

The rocket's three stages fell away, one at a time, as the module was boosted into orbit around the Earth. As the solar panels and then several antennas unfolded on the module, applause rippled through Mission Control.

The launch could have come sooner if not for two crashes of Proton rockets over Kazakhstan last year. Russia insists problems with the rocket have been worked out, and it has put several satellites into orbit with the help of Proton rockets since the crashes.

Before the July 26 docking, space officials on the ground will be testing the control systems and will adjust the orbits of the Zarya-Unity tandem.

The International Space Station is still far from complete. Dozens more modules have to be built, and the station is expected to be finished by 2005 at the earliest, with 46 more planned space launches.

"Each piece builds from the piece before it, so from my perspective all the pieces are important," said Robert Castle Jr., Nasa's flight director for shuttle and station mission operations. "This particular part is very important because it allows us to put a crew on the station, a permanent crew."

International Space Station homepage

fields.headline: Trilobite: Eyewitness to Evolution by Richard Fortey
fields.standfirst: Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Chapter One: Discovery (cont/d)
fields.body:
Chapter One: Discovery (cont/d)

I have a geological memoir for the Boscastle area tucked into my jacket pocket. From the geological map which sketches out the pattern of the outcrops of the rocks I can see something of the tectonic agony which is so patent in the cliffs: rock formations twist and turn over the mapped ground, which is criss-crossed by faults. I can identify exactly where I am standing, on the outcrop of the Boscastle Formation; in the dry language of science the slates are described as early Carboniferous (what in the US would be called Mississippian). This corner of the world has an extremely ancient origin, older than mammals, older even than dinosaurs. These black slates would already have carried their contorted signature as a guarantee of antiquity when Tyrannosaurus was king of the hill. When they were first laid down there were only tree ferns and cockroaches and cumbrous amphibians on land. Can there be a better place to reflect upon the vastness of geological time?

The erosion which I can both see and hear is ineffably slow. I could stand here all my life and notice little difference to the cliffs. Maybe a chasm excavated along a fault might seem subtly darker as its girth increased after an exceptional storm. Perhaps a rock fall would leave a scar cleared of campion and grass. But I am certain that when Thomas Hardy stood on this spot he would have gazed upon a comparable scene; my eyes now see what his once saw. To be sure, the vegetation would have changed, but the geological signature of the cliffs would have been legible in much the same way. How can we conceive of the time needed to wear away these cliffs to nothing, to convert all the massed slates into fine silt, quartz veins into pebbles - at first angular, then worn by the constant shuffling of the sea rounder and rounder, until they acquire the contours and colours of a hen's egg? Millennia are irrelevant, species come and go, and still the cliffs stand obstinate against the inroads of time. Yet given enough time even this rampart that seems to stand so unflinchingly against the surf will be reduced to nothing, and the flagstones on the floor of the Cobweb Inn will return to sediment, joining all the other works of Man, committed once again to the great cycle of change. Rocks are eroded to sediment: sediment is hardened to rock; rock is elevated above sea level by movements of the Earth, transformed by tectonics; and, thus raised, is once more subject to the assault of the elements. This is the great wheel of the Earth. If Gustav Mahler had taken the geological view, Das Lied von der Erde (The Song of the Earth) would have been a cycle of erosion and reconstruction endlessly reiterated, enough to try the patience even of those who admire the most mantric of symphonies.

Cornwall once formed part of a vast mountain chain. It marked one end of the Hercynides, which snaked through Europe just as the Alps do today in the south. The patent folding of the rocks was the result of the slates being trapped in a great tectonic vice that showed no mercy. Rocks buckled, in an attempt to accommodate forces that were irresistible. Every tiny ruckle in the wall of Pentargon Bay is the legacy of suffering under a rule of tectonics so mighty that no mere rock could stand against the imperative of crustal stress. When the rocks were folded, structure was piled upon structure until mountains resulted. Clever geologists from the University of Exeter, like E. B. Selwood, have spent years trying to unpick the buckling. They have interpreted this stretch of coast not as merely folded, but as divided into great slices of crust which have slid over and past one another. Squeezed rocks could not absorb the forces by contortion alone, and were compelled to fracture. To attain equilibrium, vast broken slabs of rock larger than a parish slid away from the centre of the forces at a low angle, like the twisted thorn branches leaning away from the reach of the sea wind. Under the sole of these sliding masses weaker rocks were folded over and over, crumpled like a pack of playing cards in the hands of a ruined gambler. Every crack that was opened up, as the country was ground beneath the tectonic wheel, would be filled with vein quartz. Now, the eroded remains of these mountains lay before me. The lichen-covered stone walls were fabricated from the relics of ancient Alps. The farmer who orientated the slaty slabs with such care was conniving with tectonic forces of which he probably knew nothing.

Not many miles to the south, near Bodmin, a granite tor rises above the general plain. It is reminiscent of some stepped Mayan pyramid, not least in scale, but is entirely natural. The strange pile of enormous blocks is what remains behind when granite is weathered over many thousands of years. Even granite eventually succumbs to the onslaught of the elements, rain and wind and frost. But granite endures longer than shale, as I was to see in St Juliot's churchyard, not far away. Granite, too, is part of the narrative of the vanished mountain chain, although its source was utterly different from the shales of the Cornish cliffs. It was crystallized from a liquid magma, hot and invasive, within the deep heart of the former chain. Look now: you can see big crystals of felspar, and maybe the sparkle of mica. These crystals tell the story of how a mountain chain drives crumpled rocks so deep into the Earth's crust that they melt, and brew a buoyant, hot broth of liquid minerals, which once more rises through the crust to crystallize and solidify as granite batholiths and plutons. Granite lies at depth beneath the Cornish peninsula, reaching to the surface under the boggy stretches of Dartmoor and Bodmln. At the moment of their formation, some of the crystals set in motion radioactive clocks.
