This method provides the answer to that difficult question: how much time has passed? The decay rate is known: it is only a matter of exact measurement and careful calculation to obtain the date of the mineral's formation. If the Bodmin granites were intruded into the folded rocks, then it follows that the granites must postdate the folding. The crystals act almost like eyes that let us see into the past, to calibrate it, to fix it in our vision. So if the crystal age of the granite was 300 million years, it fixes our cliffs as older still - the black slates must have already been folded before the granites were intruded.

As to the soft muds which were eventually hardened and distorted into the black slates, they were deposited on a Carboniferous sea-floor, as long as 340 million years ago. Time hardened them, tectonics twisted them, granites punished them with plutonic heat, long before they came to form the cliffs which now make sites for the inaccessible nests of fulmars and kittiwakes. But messages can be passed on from that ancient sea: messages in the shape of fossils. When the sea-floor was young, shells of many kinds of animals lay littered among the muds and sands, just as clam shells can be found stranded on a beach today. These were mostly ordinary, small creatures, snails and brachiopods and the like. Their shells became incorporated into the sediment as more fine mud rained down upon them: mud originated from the erosion of an ancient landmass, which itself was the product of a previous cycle of Earth history. This is how the story of the world turns and turns again. With the passage of time - much more time - the shells were still there as the muds became deeply buried, and then hardened into shales when water was driven out. Perhaps the substance of the shells was augmented by a subtle infiltration of minerals at this time. Their original colours were leached away, a time-change that bleached shells of brightness, converting them to fossil-colour: they became stony simulacra of once-living creatures.

Their journey had only just begun. The Carboniferous sea in which animals once flourished and left their shelly tokens was consumed in the engine of plate tectonics. Rocks and fossils alike - the accumulated legacy of the sea - were passengers on a great journey. Many of the fossils were doomed to obliteration. They might be dragged to the centre of the growing Hercyman chain, fated to be squeezed or baked beyond recognition. They might be dissolved away. They might be chopped into pieces as the rocks carrying them recrystallized. Mountains grew over south-west England, great slabs of country were shrugged sideways in the melee. Granites insinuated themselves into the depths. As soon as the mountains were born, they were destined to die by erosion, so, most likely of all, the fossils could be worn away to an impalpable mash that was already on a journey to the next Earth cycle. We must marvel at the fossil survivors, their chutzpah in the face of the orogenic enemy.

Sealed in the aftermath of tectonics, the fossils still had to survive all that followed: the rendering of a mountain chain once more into the sea. Through more than 200 million years the Hercyman relic was ground down to its roots. It is certain that the granites reached the surface at a time when dinosaurs were still lumbering over the Weald and western Europe, for curious and distinctive minerals derived from these granites are found for the first time in rocks laid down in Cretaceous times, about 100 million years ago. Like a geological striptease, veils of rock were stripped slowly away to ever more fundamental levels within the ancient chain. Eventually it was stripped naked to its interior, and the show was over. What I was looking at in Pentargon Cliff was one of the inner veils, preserved from obliteration, with its strata still crumpled like discarded chiffon.

What fossils might survive in the dark slates? What miracles of endurance might they record, what cheating of the laws of chance? How could a wanderer along this slippery path high above the everlasting sea truly comprehend what is meant by the vastness of geological time, even though the evidence is everywhere displayed? Looking down on Boscastle I could almost capture the historical past - I could 'see' it as one might episodes from half-remembered movies. It is not difficult to paint a mental picture of Hardy on this path. Or to envisage, more than a century ago, filthy slate miners tottering off to the inn of their choice, with the gentry nearby spry in traps; or to conjure up a bustling Tudor port with heavy-rigged ships sheltering from the wildness of the sea in the safe haven, talk of the Armada in the runs, costumes out of Holbein; I can even visualize an Iron Age farmer's tilth and husbandry, and the discomfort of a November day like this in a simple, smoke-filled dwelling. My vision is full of details rooted in shared humanity, set in bric-a-brac drawn from memory plausibly arranged. But to quantify the geological time required for the formation of Cornwall I need to multiply time a thousand-fold, and then perhaps nearly a thousand times again. I am as accustomed to writing figures in millions (of years) as is a Swiss banker (in dollars), yet the lines of zeros do not translate in proportion. Just as the average working man can understand exactly the purchasing power of fifty bucks, and fifty thousand is probably comprehensible, 500,000,000 has an approximate feel to it - surely, it's a fortune, but what does it mean? A lottery wm of 5 million is a lot, but then, so is 22 million. We reel away from such vertiginous figures, we can envisage a huge pile of money, notes piled on notes, but we cannot comprehend its true magnitude. If our intention is to see so far into a past of many millions we shall need to develop a special way of seeing, a spyglass trained on former worlds. We will need to cultivate an indifference to magnitude, so that a million years becomes not, after all, such a long stretch of time. We will need to read rocks and cliffs as if they were books, and not shudder at the heights.

I have passed the steep side of Pentargon Cliff. Some kind soul has carved steps to ease the climb, but even so I am out of breath by the time the path levels off. It now follows a course along the middle of a steep, grassy slope, and is very slippery. There is a curious sense of suspension; the sea is far below, but the slope conceals the vast cliffs which I know must be there. I can still hear the sea clearly enough: there is an irregular bang! bang! as waves punish a sea cave along the invisible surf-line, but the great height I have now reached feels almost illusory, as if I were ambling along some unspecified stratum floating between sea and sky. I have reached Beeny Cliff, and I am grateful that the light has not yet started to weaken. A few drops of rain hit me hard in the neck. A flock of gulls suddenly rises up from beyond the cliff edge, buoyed by the updraught and mewling hysterically. The end of my walk makes me turn up my collar, and shiver.

Beeny Cliff is the scene of a terrifying episode in Hardy's novel A Pair of Blue Eyes. Stephen Knight follows the same path that I had just completed, in the company of Elfride, the first of Hardy's complex, closely-observed women heroines. Knight is a man of scientific bent. Perhaps seeking to display his knowledge - or maybe just to satisfy his curiosity - he attempts to demonstrate the contrariwise circulation of the air currents up the face of the cliff: 'an inverted cascade ... as perfect as Niagara Falls - but rising instead of falling, and air instead of water' He leaps on to the slope, below the path, and his hat is caught by the countercurrent; in a foolish attempt to retrieve it he slips down the appalling incline. He ends up dangling desperately at the edge of the cliff-face itself; Hardy describes the black slates with some precision. Here it is that Knight comes face to face with the subject of this book.

"By one of those familiar conjunctions of things wherewith the reanimate world baits the mind of man when he pauses in moments of suspense, opposite Knight's eyes was an imbedded fossil, standing forth in low relief from the rock. It was a creature with eyes. The eyes, dead and turned to stone, were even now regarding him, It was one of the early crustaceans called Trilobites. Separated by millions of years in their lives, Knight and this underling seem to have met in their place of death. It was the single instance within reach of anything that had been alive and had had a body to save, as he himself had now."

In this bleak spot, where I was gazing out towards the precipice between the wrinkled sea below and the darkening sky above, trilobites made a brief appearance in English literature. The path above Beeny Cliff was where two paths of my own life - trilobites and writing - uniquely intersected. I felt compelled to visit the place; and I was not disappointed. The eyes of the trilobite, 'turned to stone', provided the image I needed to guide the reader through this book, which will try to see the world through the eyes of fossils as a means to animate the past. Equally, I was intrigued by the difference between the novelist's truth, which has nothing to do with testability and everything to do with the impact of the work on the mind and emotions, and scientific truth, which has everything to do with testability, but also with the emotions of discovery - many of them the stuff of novels.

So to what extent was Hardy telling the truth? Hardy was writing his novel originally as a serial - he needed to keep his readers enthralled, episode by episode. Knight's predicament was a cliffhanger in the most literal sense. How can you have more suspense than to leave your character exactly suspended? The trilobite eyes provided a focus for Knight's near-nemesis; while human eyes - blue ones - provided both the title and emotional motor for the novel. The critic Pamela Dalziel has noticed how the plot twists upon 'spying' of one kind or another. The book is soaked with the implications of sight.

I was interested to see how closely Hardy had observed the setting for his cliff-hanging episode. Scholars have identified the location from many details from his early life. While he was still employed as an architect restoring St Juliot's Church in 1870, he met his future wife, Emma Gifford, who was the sister-in-law of the Rector. Locations in the area are rather thinly disguised, and it evidently lies well to the west of the rest of Hardy's Wessex. A Pair of Blue Eyes included more autobiographical elements than his other novels, and perhaps for that reason evidently remained dear to his heart (he rewrote parts of it many years later). The height of the cliff itself is rather pedantically described, even as poor Knight flounders, surely indicating that the young writer had gazetteers open, and a sharpened pencil in front of him as he catalogued its statistics: 'proved by actual measurement not to be a foot less than six hundred and fifty [feet] ... three times the height of Flamborough, a hundred feet higher than Beachy Head ... thrice as high as the Lizard' (and there is more in this vein). But what left me in no doubt at all about the site was the walk I had taken, which was duplicated exactly by the characters in the novel. Hardy had observed what was evidently the same waterfall plunging to obscurity that I had seen at Pentargon Bay, 'running over the precipice it was dispersed in spray before it was half way down, and falling like rain upon projecting ledges made minute grassy meadows of them'. He described the threatening cliffs, with their 'horrid personality' at the same point as I had seen them on my walk. In many respects passages in the novel could be described as reportage: he could recognize both quartz and slate, he recounted physical features in order along the path, he knew some geology and meteorology. While Knight clung to the cliff face his mind raced back through geological time - a series of tableaux of the past succeeded one another in his desperate mind all the way back to the ancient time of the trilobites. It is not a bad account, scientifically speaking, of the succession of life through geological time as conceived about 1860.

But now we reach a point at which fiction and description take off along different paths; perhaps the fascination of the novel lies in these deviations. Why did Hardy refer to Beeny Cliff as The Cliff with No Name? The hamlet of Beeny is clearly named on old maps and he was usually adept at near-synonyms - Camelton for Camelford, Dundagel for Tintagel. I believe that 'No Name' adds to the horror and mystery of the place. The same point was appreciated by Sergio Leone: in his brooding spaghetti westerns 'The Man with No Name', played by Clint Eastwood, was the anti-hero. Naming is the first way we domesticate our surroundings; we would expect the highest cliff along the coast to have a name. Anonymity is horror. When a series of murders are committed terror is at its worst while the perpetrator is still unknown: a case of nameless dread. The fabricator of fiction knew this; this is where artifice comes in. Hardy liked facts, but he knew also when to suspend them. The trilobite itself is a convenient fiction. The Carboniferous rocks on this part of the Cornish coast have yielded no trilobites. The rocks are of the right age, so there is no theoretical objection to finding trilobites there. Fossils are very rare from such tectonically tortured rocks. Enough have been found - precursors of ammonites, clams, microscopic fossils - to establish the geological age, but trilobites are not among them. I would be absolutely delighted to receive a trilobite from a collector lucky enough to hammer one out of these unpromising strata; it would be of appreciable scientific importance. Hardy placed the fossil in the right geological setting, but the finding of a trilobite is an invention. He needed the trilobite to stare out Stephen Knight. As readers of fiction we relish his use of this particular fossil, 'but a low type of animal existence', as heightening the drama of the situation. It matters not a jot that the occurrence is fictional, even though the rest of Hardy's account is an almost photographic reproduction of a real scene. A scientist would be appalled if one of his colleagues invented such an occurrence, for science trades on the truth - nothing but the objective fact. The truth of the artist can recombine the facts of the world in the service of creation, but the scientist has a different duty, to discover the truth lying behind the facade of appearance. Both processes may be equally imaginative.

As for Mr Knight, he escaped his predicament thanks to a rope, but a rope desperately manufactured from Elfride's undergarments. It is a turning point in the novel, symbolizing a change in the relationship between a flawed man and an unusual woman. And we are not compelled to wonder whether such an episode was fact or not, because it is woven into the fabric of a novel.

I left Beeny Cliff by climbing up the steep steps to Fire Beacon Point, a wild bluff commanding views of the whole Hercynian coast. It may have acquired its name as one of numerous beacons on which fires were lit to warn of the approach of an armada. Now, there is only a bench at the top dedicated to the memory of Paul C. Heard, but I thanked Mr Heard's relatives for the chance to rest and regain my breath. I turned inland, following an old, walled track. I wanted to see the parish church of St Juliot on which Hardy had worked. It is perfectly set on a sheltered hillside, and behind it a track leads out directly across fields upon which sheep graze unhurriedly. Despite the setting, there is something depressingly foursquare and Victorian about St Juliot's - possibly the fault of Hardy's restoration - including a rather dumpy tower with unnecessary castellation. It is as if the site deserved something much more distinguished to live up to its associations. After all, Hardy wrote that 'much of my life claims the spot as its key'. Surely it is an ancient holy place, which the church fails adequately to honour. In the graveyard there are several 'Jollows' - possibly a bastardized version of the name Juliot - the kind of family that must have grown out of the local soil as surely as wind-blown gorse. Inside the church there is a notice informing the visitor that most of the church plate has already been stolen. There was nothing to induce me to linger.

But as I left I saw the Celtic crosses, more ancient than the church itself. Close by the gate one crudely shaped column as high as a man stands sentinel; its apex is sculpted into a disc, and you might expect to find some sort of face hewn upon it, but instead there is a schematic cross. Unlike the slatey gravestones, these upright crosses are made from granite. They will endure when all the inscribed memorials to Jollows have crumbled into the same soil that long since claimed their bones. The granite was derived from one of the igneous intrusions into the bowels of the Hercynian mountain range. Maybe the blocks were derived from Bodmin or Dartmoor, but whatever the source their hewers knew about permanence. Each monument acknowledges the vast span of geological time, the durability of stone compared with a human lifetime. Each is a symbol of the crossing of human intention with tectonic history - the same history that placed Hardy's plausible but fictional trilobite into Beeny Cliff. The discoidal apex of the cross is like an eyepiece with a view clear back to the age of the tree ferns and lungfishes. This, after all, may have been what I wanted to discover on a chilly November day in Boscastle. I felt a curious elation, even as the icy raindrops began to refresh the lichens that alone could derive sustenance from incorruptible granite - set solid ever since trilobites had patrolled the shallows of a vanished ocean.

While he was still employed as an architect restoring St Juliot's Church in 1870, he met his future wife, Emma Gifford, who was the sister-in-law of the Rector. Locations in the area are rather thinly disguised, and it evidently lies well to the west of the rest of Hardy's Wessex. A Pair of Blue Eyes included more autobiographical elements than his other novels, and perhaps for that reason evidently remained dear to his heart (he rewrote parts of it many years later). The height of the cliff itself is rather pedantically described, even as poor Knight flounders, surely indicating that the young writer had gazetteers open, and a sharpened pencil in front of him as he catalogued its statistics: 'proved by actual measurement not to be a foot less than six hundred and fifty [feet] ... three times the height of Flamborough, a hundred feet higher than Beachy Head ... thrice as high as the Lizard' (and there is more in this vein). But what left me in no doubt at all about the site was the walk I had taken, which was duplicated exactly by the characters in the novel. Hardy had observed what was evidently the same waterfall plunging to obscurity that I had seen at Pentargon Bay, 'running over the precipice it was dispersed in spray before it was half way down, and falling like rain upon projecting ledges made minute grassy meadows of them'. He described the threatening cliffs, with their 'horrid personality' at the same point as I had seen them on my walk. In many respects passages in the novel could be described as reportage: he could recognize both quartz and slate, he recounted physical features in order along the path, he knew some geology and meteorology. While Knight clung to the cliff face his mind raced back through geological time - a series of tableaux of the past succeeded one another in his desperate mind all the way back to the ancient time of the trilobites. It is not a bad account, scientifically speaking, of the succession of life through geological time as conceived about 1860. But now we reach a point at which fiction and description take off along different paths; perhaps the fascination of the novel lies in these deviations. Why did Hardy refer to Beeny Cliff as The Cliff with No Name? The hamlet of Beeny is clearly named on old maps and he was usually adept at near-synonyms - Camelton for Camelford, Dundagel for Tintagel. I believe that 'No Name' adds to the horror and mystery of the place. The same point was appreciated by Sergio Leone: in his brooding spaghetti westerns 'The Man with No Name', played by Clint Eastwood, was the anti-hero. Naming is the first way we domesticate our surroundings; we would expect the highest cliff along the coast to have a name. Anonymity is horror. When a series of murders are committed terror is at its worst while the perpetrator is still unknown: a case of nameless dread. The fabricator of fiction knew this; this is where artifice comes in. Hardy liked facts, but he knew also when to suspend them. The trilobite itself is a convenient fiction. The Carboniferous rocks on this part of the Cornish coast have yielded no trilobites. The rocks are of the right age, so there is no theoretical objection to finding trilobites there. Fossils are very rare from such tectonically tortured rocks. Enough have been found - precursors of ammonites, clams, microscopic fossils - to establish the geological age, but trilobites are not among them. I would be absolutely delighted to receive a trilobite from a collector lucky enough to hammer one out of these unpromising strata; it would be of appreciable scientific importance. Hardy placed the fossil in the right geological setting, but the finding of a trilobite is an invention. He needed the trilobite to stare out Stephen Knight. As readers of fiction we relish his use of this particular fossil, 'but a low type of animal existence', as heightening the drama of the situation. It matters not a jot that the occurrence is fictional, even though the rest of Hardy's account is an almost photographic reproduction of a real scene. A scientist would be appalled if one of his colleagues invented such an occurrence, for science trades on the truth - nothing but the objective fact. The truth of the artist can recombine the facts of the world in the service of creation, but the scientist has a different duty, to discover the truth lying behind the facade of appearance. Both processes may be equally imaginative. As for Mr Knight, he escaped his predicament thanks to a rope, but a rope desperately manufactured from Elfride's undergarments. It is a turning point in the novel, symbolizing a change in the relationship between a flawed man and an unusual woman. And we are not compelled to wonder whether such an episode was fact or not, because it is woven into the fabric of a novel. I left Beeny Cliff by climbing up the steep steps to Fire Beacon Point, a wild bluff commanding views of the whole Hercynian coast. It may have acquired its name as one of numerous beacons on which fires were lit to warn of the approach of an armada. Now, there is only a bench at the top dedicated to the memory of Paul C. Heard, but I thanked Mr Heard's relatives for the chance to rest and regain my breath. I turned inland, following an old, walled track. I wanted to see the parish church of St Juliot on which Hardy had worked. It is perfectly set on a sheltered hillside, and behind it a track leads out directly across fields upon which sheep graze unhurriedly. Despite the setting, there is something depressingly foursquare and Victorian about St Juliot's - possibly the fault of Hardy's restoration - including a rather dumpy tower with unnecessary castellation. It is as if the site deserved something much more distinguished to live up to its associations. After all, Hardy wrote that 'much of my life claims the spot as its key'. Surely it is an ancient holy place, which the church fails adequately to honour. In the graveyard there are several 'Jollows' - possibly a bastardized version of the name Juliot - the kind of family that must have grown out of the local soil as surely as wind-blown gorse. Inside the church there is a notice informing the visitor that most of the church plate has already been stolen. There was nothing to induce me to linger. But as I left I saw the Celtic crosses, more ancient than the church itself. Close by the gate one crudely shaped column as high as a man stands sentinel; its apex is sculpted into a disc, and you might expect to find some sort of face hewn upon it, but instead there is a schematic cross. Unlike the slatey gravestones, these upright crosses are made from granite. They will endure when all the inscribed memorials to Jollows have crumbled into the same soil that long since claimed their bones. The granite was derived from one of the igneous intrusions into the bowels of the Hercynian mountain range. Maybe the blocks were derived from Bodmin or Dartmoor, but whatever the source their hewers knew about permanence. Each monument acknowledges the vast span of geological time, the durability of stone compared with a human lifetime. Each is a symbol of the crossing of human intention with tectonic history - the same history that placed Hardy's plausible but fictional trilobite into Beeny Cliff. The discoidal apex of the cross is like an eyepiece with a view clear back to the age of the tree ferns and lungfishes. This, after all, may have been what I wanted to discover on a chilly November day in Boscastle. I felt a curious elation, even as the icy raindrops began to refresh the lichens that alone could derive sustenance from incorruptible granite - set solid ever since trilobites had patrolled the shallows of a vanished ocean. fields.body:
Chapter One: Discovery (cont/d)

If you can have love at first sight, then I fell in love with trilobites at the age of fourteen.

The peninsula of St Davids forms the south-western promontory of South Wales, extending westwards like a miniature version of the Cornish peninsula where Hardy, too, encountered love. Like Cornwall, it is a region of spectacular and ancient cliffs, while inland the scenery is flat and characterless. There are little coves here, too, with names like Solva and Abercastle, formerly wild and remote fishing villages, but now spruce with whitewash over the rough stone. But the cliffs are as wild as ever they were, and displaying rock folds as convoluted as anything in Cornwall. A walk along the coastal path parades one rock formation after another, delineated by contrasts in colour and texture: here massive yellow or purple sandstones plunge like naked ribs into the churning foam, there a group of contorted dark shales zig-zag up the cliffs like some sort of beserk concertina. In Caerfai Bay there are bright red shales, looking improbably pert in a world of dun geology. All of these rocks are still more ancient than their Cornish counterparts. They date from the Cambrian period, the oldest of the shales having been laid down as muds beneath the sea something like 545 million years before the present. This is getting back to the beginning of things, to a time before there were any plants on land, to a time before any kind of backboned animal existed. Yet there were already trilobites to witness this nascent world. These trilobites were 200 million years older than Thomas Hardy's invented fossil (or, I should say, its real equivalents) - a span a hundred times longer than Man's brief tenancy of this planet. This was the time I explored with a coal hammer at a period of my life when my voice had just turned unreliably falsetto and baritone by turns. While others discovered girls, I discovered trilobites.

I had marked the presence of fossils on a local map. They were described as the oldest fossils in the British Isles. What could be more irresistible? There was something extraordinarily exciting about tapping into a vein of such prehistory. The top dressing of the landscape of human tenancy was stripped away to reveal some deeper reality, layer after layer of geological time unpeeled in my imagination. While my long-suffering mother knitted or read, I beat the rocks at Nine Wells and Porth-y-rhaw*. These were places where the rocks were accessible by foot and could be broken by sheer effort. I did not even have a proper geological hammer. The fever of discovery was upon me. I learned how to break the hard rock so that it split in the same direction as the former sea floor - this way I was more likely to retrieve something recognizable. It was clear that tectonic forces had tipped the strata vertically. I had to scrabble to dislodge reasonable-sized blocks for breakage. I ignored the sharp pieces of gorse that speared the backs of my hands. Time had made the rock both hard and brittle: it seemed to want to break anywhere but in the right direction. On the broken surfaces there were scraps and fragments of what might, or might not have been the remains of past life: black patches, a little shinier than the rest of the rock. Then, at last, I found a trilobite. The rock simply parted around the animal, like some sort of revelation. The truth is that the fossil itself had rendered the rock weaker: it was predisposed to reveal itself, almost as if it desired disclosure. I was left holding two pieces of rock: in my left hand the positive impression of the creature itself (known as the part); in my right hand the negative mould which had once comprised its other half (the counterpart); the two together snuggling up to survive the vicissitudes of millions of years of entombment. There was a brownish stain on the fossil, but to me it was no disfigurement - surely what I held was the textbook come alive. Drawings and photographs could not compare with the joy of actually touching a find which seemed, in the egotistical glow of boyhood, dedicated to yourself alone. This was my first discovery of the animals that would change my life. The long thin eyes of the trilobite regarded me and I returned the gaze. More compelling than any pair of blue eyes, there was a shiver of recognition across 500 million years.

I would one day learn that the trilobite had a name, Paradoxides. When we first exchanged glances I knew nothing of classification or nomenclature, and it did not matter to me: there was plenty of time to learn more. What I held was a specimen that fitted comfortably into the palm of my hand. It was clearly divided along its length into three lobes - a convex central portion and to each side of it identical, but slightly flattened, areas. These were the lobes implied by the name - trilobite. The whole animal seemed to bulge towards one end. I knew, by some principle which I could not articulate, that the wider end was the head of the animal. And of course upon this head there were the eyes. Despite the unfamiliar conformation of the fossil, I knew that eyes must always belong on heads. So despite the exoticism of the fossil there was already a common bond between me and the trilobite - we both had our heads screwed on the right way. I could see that the body was subdivided into a number of little divisions - or segments, as I would learn to call them. Then there were cracks running across the body. These had nothing to do with the original structure of the animal, rather they were testimony to the long journey through geological time that the Cambrian creature had travelled before it fell apart under my hammer blow. They were joints in the fabric of the rock itself, the scars of an adventure that might have seen the trilobite eroded into oblivion or obliterated in the vice of a thousand tectonic accidents.

This book grew out of that first encounter. I want to invest the trilobite with all the glamour of the dinosaur and twice its endurance. I want you to see the world through the eyes of trilobites, to help you to make a journey back through hundreds of millions of years. I will show that Hardy's description of the trilobite as 'but a low type of animal existence' was hardly just, but that his placing the animal at the centre of a drama of life and death might have been nearer the mark. This will be an unabashedly trilobito-centric view of the world.

For trilobites have been witnesses to great events. Stephen Knight might have read from the trilobite's stony eyes that the predicament of a mere individual meant nothing. They have seen continents move, mountain chains elevated and eroded to their granite cores, they have survived ice ages and massive volcanic eruptions. No living thing can disengage itself from the biosphere, and trilobites followed the same pattern: their history was also shaped by the events they witnessed. When strangers express their surprise that it is possible to devote a lifetime to studying extinct 'bugs' I remind them of how much has happened in the last few thousand years and invite them to imagine what it is to be a historian of dozens of millions of years. We are doomed to know so little, like fishermen trying to understand an entire ocean by throwing in a few baited handlines. And if anyone wonders how it is possible to invest such devotion in a group of organisms which died out long ago as a result of who-knows-what inadequacies, there is an obvious answer. Trilobites survived for a total of three hundred million years, almost the whole duration of the Palaeozoic era: who are we johnny-come-latelies to label them as either 'primitive' or 'unsuccessful'? Men have so far survived half a per cent as long.

There are accounts of scientific research that present the story of discovery as a series of glittering prizes that must be won by the most muscular intellect; this is science as a version of trial-by-combat. Or else scientific research is contained in a metaphor of a journey into uncharted territory, as expressed by Robert Louis Stevenson (in Pulvis et umbra): 'science carries us into realms of speculation, where there is no habitable city for the mind of man.' It is certainly true that there are races to be first in science and that a few massive minds venturing into 'realms of speculation' command the most attention - and they deserve it. Such models of scientific progress are typified by mathematicians and physicists, beautifully elaborated by Karl Popper in Conjectures and Refutations. Nonetheless, as a description of much of scientific endeavour, both the combative and the adventurous-speculative views are flawed. Many scientists - perhaps most of them - are a curious species for whom the pleasure of finding out is at least as important as the size of the goal. He or she is often a co-operative creature, comfortable with the happy exercise of innate ability, and if a momentous discovery comes it may arrive unexpectedly, like an unanticipated legacy. The unique property of the scientific endeavour is that so many of the regular footsoldiers contribute to the victory. Unlike a poetaster whose burblings are destined for true oblivion while the creations of a Keats survive, even a minor scientist might well make a permanent contribution to a famous campaign - an uncelebrated private who did not die in vain.

Even the most singular fields of scientific inquiry relate in subtle or unexpected ways to larger questions. We shall see that an apparently self-contained and esoteric occupation like the study of trilobites has contributed to mighty debates about the origin of new species, or the nature of major features of evolution, or the distribution of the ancient continents. Those who started with a deep desire to know more about the details of life habits of vanished anamals - out of sheer curiosity - may suddenly realize that the detailed knowledge they have accrued relates to something different and more general: something as grand as the structure of an ancient ocean or the arrival of an asteroid on Earth.

I believe that a more accurate image for the way much of science works might be a series of interconnecting paths. Each one has its own interests and delights; sometimes we know where a path leads, on others we are taken by surprise by twists and turns. And where there are intersections with other paths there can be unanticapated new directions which may lead to wholly unexpected views. Like Stephen and Elfride on the path above The Cliff with No Name there may be a crucial conjunction of circumstances which changes everything, and something as small and ancient as a trilobite may be the catalyst for the transformation.

This book will follow a few of the paths that led me from that first schoolboy find. In pursuit of trilobites I shall visit remarkable places and spend time with remarkable people. Knowledge has been hard won, and there are heroes whose names are known only to me and a few of my friends, who deserve wider recognition. There are stories of personal tragedies which have influenced this tale of trilobites. Discovery isn't a simple matter of 'onwards and upwards'. It is imbued with all the tawdry and magnificent stuff of human lives. The story of that small part of science which is important to me will illustrate the way this defining human activity works better than some other accounts of greater endeavours: like relativity or the first few nanoseconds of the universe. Sometimes, a miniature gives a better likeness than a grandiose portrait.

Come and see the world as it once was through the crystal eyes of the trilobite. We shall find out how trilobites tell us the pattern of evolution, and how it can be read from the rocks. We shall discover how faith in trilobites not merely moves mountains but shifts whole continents. We shall see how cast-off shells can be re-animated into living animals. We shall understand something of the origins of the richness of the animal kingdom. Through trilobites, we shall take possession of the geological past.

* Both these sites are now legally protected from hammering, although they were not at the time of my schoolboy excursions.

fields.headline: Is spin the new sleaze?
fields.standfirst: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at the government's crisis over presentation
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 2pm: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at the government's crisis over presentation.
fields.body:
It is almost as if this government has invented an ogre that is about to turn on its creator and eat it up. For New Labour back in the late Eighties invented the political communications revolution in Britain, and now the word "spin" is haunting government, raising nebulous but negative images in the public mind just as the tag "sleaze" became a caricature the Conservatives found impossible to shake off.

At the very least, for a government that prides itself on the skills of its presentation and communications, something has gone horribly wrong. Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, has retreated to his lair, refusing to take the twice-daily lobby briefings. He openly admits "we cannot get our message up" and rails at the media for their obsession with trivia. He frequently compares the seriousness and respect for Blair shown by the European press with the negativism of the domestic commentators.

Widespread cynicism greets any government announcement. A press release trumpeting new cash for schools or hospitals is examined forensically and held up to the light to make sure it is not a forgery. Plans for new targets are greeted with groans. The deputy prime minister John Prescott, once the antithesis of spin, has even taken to writing to Campbell demanding to know why the government is losing control of the agenda. Mr Campbell himself seems in a state of irresolution.

The prime minister returned from his two-week paternity break promising that the government would not chase every headline. Yet Campbell finds it difficult to let go. With a 24-hour news agenda, it just seems too dangerous not to have anything to announce. If you don't make the agenda your opposition will, seems to be the motto inside Downing Street.

As a result Tony Blair seems to be working ever more feverishly to stay in touch with the electorate. He speaks to black church leaders, he faces an hour-long grilling on BBC Question Time, he brokers deals at the National Policy Forum, he agrees to hold two day-long debates in the Commons this week and he soon flies to Japan for the G8 Summit. All the while the commentators study the lines on his forehead and the pallor of his skin for signs of a man unable to take the strain.

Today, brushing aside the inevitable media accusations of a relaunch, Blair tried a new technique. In a rare 40-minute press conference inside Downing Street, he tried to cut through the media disinterest to highlight the creation of a million jobs in the British economy since Labour came to power. A cut in unemployment to its lowest level for 20 years is a creditable achievement, even if it is unclear how far the government can legitimately claim that this good news story is a central part of the government's own narrative.

Yet all this frenetic energy is suffering from a law of diminishing returns. The more the government spins, or presents, or communicates, the more cynicism the process engenders. Some of the brighter cabinet ministers privately believe the solution lies in a period of silence from government. The electorate just need time to see and feel for themselves the impact on the ground of government spending on schools, hospitals and crime.

For it is almost a commonplace among ministers that they have erred at the outset by trumpeting their plans too much. Equally, ministers admit ruefully that they did not realise how long it would take to translate their grand ideas into progress on the ground. The snail-like process of a policy idea, green paper, white paper, government legislation, the start of a pilot project and then full implementation sends ministers demented with frustration. It is still the biggest cultural shift they face, and it is still not resolved. In the meantime, the vacuum has to be filled, and that leaves Campbell working as furiously as ever.

fields.headline: Missing Sarah: man arrested
fields.standfirst:
Police e-fit image
Timetable: Sarah's disappearance
Graphic: What's happened to Sarah?
Sussex police
fields.trailText: A man has been arrested on the Wirral in connection with the   disappearance of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne,   Merseyside police said.
fields.body:
A man has been arrested on the Wirral in connection with the disappearance of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne, Merseyside police said.

It is believed the man, thought to be in his 30s, was detained last night, but sources said the arrest was not a "significant" development and he was likely to be released soon.

Police are also investigating a possible second sighting of the girl, it emerged today.

Strathclyde police are following up reports that she was seen at a Shell garage off the A80 at Cumbernauld, near Glasgow, at about 6am on Monday. A garage worker is reported to have told police he had CCTV footage of a girl matching Sarah's description, accompanied by a man who resembled an e-fit image released by Sussex police yesterday.

The e-fit is a likeness of a man seen with a young girl fitting Sarah's description at a motorway service station at Knutsford on the M6 in Cheshire on 2 July, a day after she went missing from near her grandparents' home at Kingston Gorse, near Worthing, West Sussex.

Police told a news conference that they had received almost 1,500 calls from the public this morning, as the missing girl's mother appealed directly to the man who was spotted at Knutsford with a child fitting her daughter's description.

In an appeal on GMTV, Sarah Payne said: "If this is you or if you know who this is, come forward so we can stop wasting time."

As the Sun newspaper offered a £50,000 reward for information about Sarah, the girl's favourite pop group, Steps, recorded a message sending Sarah their love and renewing appeals for anyone with information to come forward.

It was hoped that the message, played on television and radio broadcasts across the country, would boost Sarah's spirits if she heard it.

webTitle: Violence shrouds marching season's big day

fields.headline: Violence shrouds marching season's big day
fields.trailText: Security force barriers kept Orangemen from nationalists today as tens of thousands of Orange Order members went on the march across Northern Ireland after another night of violence in which two people were murdered and more than 20 RUC officers injured.
fields.body:
Security force barriers kept Orangemen from nationalists today as tens of thousands of Orange Order members went on the march across Northern Ireland after another night of violence in which two people were murdered and more than 20 RUC officers injured.

Large metal barricades went up on the Ormeau Bridge in south Belfast to enforce the Parades Commission ban on the local Orange lodge marching down the mainly nationalist section of the lower Ormeau Road.

But the violence overshadowed the key day in the Orange calendar. A loyalist suspected of being linked to the Ulster Volunteer Force terrorist group was shot dead at a commemoration bonfire in Larne, Co Antrim; a man was stabbed to death in Coleraine, Co Londonderry; and another man was stabbed and critically injured at a bonfire in east Belfast.

None of the attacks were believed to have been sectarian. During rioting in Portadown, 21 police officers and several soldiers were injured.

Lt General Sir Hew Pike, commander of the troops in Northern Ireland, visited the Ormeau Bridge fortifications ahead of the parade by several hundred local Orangemen. They marched to the barriers where they staged a peaceful protest and religious service.

The Lodge chaplain, Rev William Hoey, said: "We want to protest in the strongest possible terms at being stopped on this bridge."

He said the order were "unashamedly Protestant" and were fighting for their faith, but insisted "not in the physical sense".

After their demonstration the Orangemen marched into the neighbouring Ormeau Park where the Belfast parades were converging to show solidarity with the blocked men from the Ormeau Road.

Several thousand Orangemen converged on Killylea, Co Armagh, for the biggest July 12 celebration outside Belfast. There was loud applause as members of the Portadown District marched through the village, led by their controversial district master Harold Gracey.

The Portadown men had left a 20-strong contingent back on Drumcree Hill to maintain their three-year-long protest.

The grand master of the Orange Order, Robert Saulters, led the parade involving lodges from throughout the county, Scotland and Co Monaghan in the Irish Republic.

There was a low key police presence in the area despite the latest night of disturbances across Northern Ireland, especially in Portadown, where 21 police officers and several soldiers were injured during sustained rioting in the early hours during which water cannon and plastic bullets were used against the loyalist mobs.

A woman soldier suffered facial injuries after a large firework exploded close to her during clashes in the Corcrain and Edgarstown areas.

Numerous petrol bomb attacks were recorded in towns across the province, there were several paramilitary shows of armed strength and dozens of roads were blocked.

In Londonderry rioting in the Waterside area lasted until almost dawn during which up to 100 petrol bombs were thrown at police. Two officers were injured and several arrests made.

fields.headline: Runcie: maligned man of God
fields.standfirst:
Religious affairs correspondent Stephen Bates remembers an archbishop of Canterbury whose social concern in the face of a rightwing government made him one of the most vilified ever to hold office
Obituary
'He loved people very much indeed'
The 'reluctant archbishop' in his own words
fields.trailText: Religious affairs correspondent Stephen Bates remembers an archbishop of Canterbury whose social concern in the face of a rightwing government made him one of the most vilified ever to hold office.
fields.body:
As tributes were today paid to Lord Runcie, the former archbishop of Canterbury, it was hard to remember that he was at one stage probably the most vilified and denigrated holder of his office since the pre-civil war days of archbishop Laud. For a period in the 1980s, taking their lead from government ministers, many national newspapers were happy to attack him savagely for his supposed liberalism and (somewhat contradictorily) for his alleged failure to give leadership.

In fact Runcie was one of the most distinguished and able archbishops of modern times, who skilfully kept the fractious Anglican communion together and led it with charm, intellect and wit, preaching a Christian message sometimes at odds with what politicians wanted or expected. It is nevertheless true that under his leadership the Church of England probably finally lost its tag as the Tory Party at Prayer.

Mrs Thatcher famously fell out with the archbishop when he used the celebratory service at the end of the Falklands War to ask his congregation to remember those who mourned on both sides. As a former soldier and winner of the Military Cross he knew precisely what war meant and preached a Christian message inconvenient and embarrassing to a bellicose prime minister who herself had never experienced combat.

Later he had words of comfort for the striking miners and endorsed a devastating Church of England report called Faith in the City which dared to criticise policy in tackling deprivation and poverty in the inner cities - an assault which some Tory ministers took as a personal affront, leading them to describe its clerical authors as Marxists.

Runcie did not always go down well with some of his clergy either. They resented him for not coming down more firmly on their side - whichever side they happened to be on. This led to the infamous Crockford's affair when the embittered Oxford don - and friend of Runcie - Gary Bennett penned a vitriolic anonymous introduction to the annual Crockford's clerical directory and committed suicide when he was publicly exposed. He said Runcie was too used to nailing his colours firmly to the fence. Bennett, bitter at being passed over for a bishopric, was probably alarmed at the thought of being identified for attacking a man who had befriended him, seemingly unaware that Runcie knew who had written the piece all along and was supremely unconcerned about it.

There were happier times too: perhaps the greatest being the Pope's visit to England in 1982, when the two men kneeled side by side in prayer at Canterbury Cathedral - the first time that a reigning pope had ever visited Britain and a sight inconceivable even a few years before.

Dr Runcie looked and sounded like an archbishop and will be remembered by many within the church both for his wit and charm and for his phenomenal memory for names and faces. My wife, taught the piano as a child by Mrs Runcie, was astonished decades later on meeting the primate to find that he recollected her.

Today's tributes to his wisdom and leadership were fully justified.

webTitle: MPs tell government to ditch dam funding

fields.headline: MPs tell government to ditch dam funding
fields.standfirst: The full report
fields.trailText: The government should abandon its "shotgun wedding" financial support for the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey, MPs said today.
fields.body:
The government should abandon its "shotgun wedding" financial support for the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey, MPs said today.

The Commons international development select committee ruled that the proposed £1.25bn dam contravenes international standards and professed its "astonishment" that the Foreign Office had not raised any human rights concerns over the government's £200m contribution to the project.

The MPs' report accused the government of failing to consider the rights of the Kurdish people whose homes would be flooded by the dam on the Tigris River in south-east Turkey. The committee said the government had also failed to take into account the political repercussions of the dam, which would cut the flow of water into Syria and Iraq.

But the Foreign Office rejected the MPs' criticism. "It is because the government takes human rights so seriously that it will agree to provide export credit support for the project only if tough conditions are met," it said in a statement.

In May, the government backed away from supporting the dam, indicating its acceptance that the British building contractor Balfour Beatty would not be given an export credit guarantee unless Turkey first consulted the downstream countries, Syria and Iraq, about the scheme and properly compensated displaced Kurds.

Environmental campaigners said they were "delighted" by the report, which follows a similarly critical trade and industry select committee report on the dam. Friends of the Earth's policy director, Tony Juniper, called the latest report a "vindication" of "every criticism we have made of this miserable project".

He added: "The prime minister's own MPs are telling him what we have known all along - the Ilisu dam is an environmental disaster, a human rights scandal and a threat to peace."

The dam, 40 miles upstream from Syria and Iraq, will submerge 52 villages and 15 towns, including Hasankeyf, an ancient centre of Kurd culture which was given archaeological protection by the Turkish government in 1978.

The Turkish government argues that the hydro-electric project, which will also be used to irrigate Turkish fields, is necessary to boost economic growth in an area hit by electricity shortages. But the human cost is the forcible removal of 20,000 Kurds, who under current plans will not be compensated by the Turkish government.

The committee of MPs, chaired by Tory MP Bowen Wells, said: "The Ilisu dam was from the outset conceived and planned in contravention of international standards, and it still does not comply. For that reason cover should not be given."

The MPs' report also criticised the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, who announced in December last year that he was "minded" to grant export credit guarantees for the project before the Turkish government had agreed a series of measures intended to minimise environmental impact and address resettlement issues.

"The shotgun wedding approach to export credit that we find in the case of the Ilisu dam does not in our view bode well for the implementation of commitments but is rather the worst form of export credit practice."

Balfour Beatty asked the DTI's export credit guarantee department (ECGD) to underwrite its £200m contract. The ECGD provides insurance for British companies' foreign investments: if the foreign country in question defaults on payments the ECGD - in effect the UK taxpayer - foots the bill.

The committee also urged wide-ranging reform of the ECGD, which it said should make a clear commitment to respect and protect internationally-agreed human rights in all its activities and consult the Department for International Development on the impact of the projects it provides export credit support for.

The committee also called on the ECGD to blacklist companies convicted of bribery or corruption, or those ineligible for World Bank financed contracts because of involvement in such practices. The MPs said that 36 of the 54 companies on the World Bank's blacklist were UK firms.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Why is the nutmeg so called? How many Premiership footballers are vegetarians? And just why do Italy play in blue? For all the answers, check out today's Knowledge Unlimited.
fields.trailText: "Why is a nutmeg so called?" asks Michael Edwards.
fields.body:
"Why is a nutmeg so called?" asks Michael Edwards.

So far we have failed to crack this old chestnut, and short of slipping an expert some cash(ew) we appear to have hit a wall(nut). However, here are the two most credible explanations we have uncovered. The first is that nutmeg is cockney rhyming slang for legs, referring to the parts of the body central to the completion of any nutmeg. The online Cockney rhyming slang dictionary (http://www.bio.nrc.ca/cockney/) does not support this assertion, but seeing as it offers at least three alternative options (Mystic Megs, pegs and bacon and eggs), the possibility cannot be ruled out.

The second spurious suggestion is more visual. Picture the bandy movements a defender's legs make in the process of being nutmegged. Not too dissimilar from the shape of a nutcracker, no? Then imagine the ball to be a nut passing through said cracker and there you have it. Sort of.

Are there any vegetarian footballers playing in the Premiership? asks Dr Adz E Marshall.

While there is a veritable vegetarian army of rock stars and actors willing to champion the pleasures of abstaining from animal flesh (Damon Albarn, Ozzy Osbourne, Michael Jackson, Howard Jones, Mel C, Drew Barrymore, Kim Basinger, Alicia Silverstone, Liv Tyler and Pam Ferris to name but ten), there are remarkably few professional sportsmen who openly do the same.

But contrary to popular belief, many sports stars are vegetarian, including Carl Lewis, Greg Chappell and Martina Navratilova (check out her recipe for pesto sauce at: http://www.vegsoc.org/news/1996/nvw/nvw-96.html#pest). However we've drawn a blank on professional footballers currently playing in the Premiership - although Liverpool's former physio Mark Leather says that Phil Babb (who's now at Sporting Lisbon) was definitely one. Can anyone help?

"Football is a simple game - you play for 120 minutes and then the Germans win on penalties." This quote has been attributed to a lot of people - and even Guardian reporters seem to disagree, some accrediting it to Lineker and others to Lothar Matthaus. Who really said it? One of those two or someone else entirely? wonders Joe Banerjee.

The quote is Gary Lineker's, although it only gained widespread currency when a typical modest Lothar Matthaus reminded the English press pack of it on the eve of last year's Champions League final. "I remember a saying from your own player Gary Lineker that football is where 22 players run round after the ball and at the end the Germans always win," Lothar told them. Perhaps this explains the resulting confusion.

Why do Italy play in blue when their flag is orange, white and green? asks Jon Davis

The Italian national team wear blue because it is the colour of Savoia, the ruling house of Italy from 1861 to 1946. Until the end of the second world war, the Italian flag always had the Savoy coat of arms in the centre, and it was only after the family were overthrown, and the Italian Republic established in 1946, that the plain tricolor was adopted as the national flag.

Am I correct in thinking there is a restriction on clubs fielding more than two non-EU players? If so, won't Leeds have problems seeing as they've signed Mark Viduka and also have Harry Kewell and Lucas Radebe on their books? enquires Gareth Crossman

You're right - there is a restriction. But according to Premier League rules, a side can play a maximum of three non-EU players in one game and not two. There's no limit, however, on how many can be registered with a club at one time.

Can you help?

Somewhere in the back of my brain, I seem to recall Chris Nicol scoring all four goals in a 2-2 draw between Aston Villa and Leicester City. Is my memory failing me? And are there similar own-goal scoring feats of similar ineptitude? asks Nick Evans.

I've asked this before, and I really am curious to know the answer, which is why I persevere with such tiresome persistence. Southampton legend Le Tiss has scored 48 out of 49 penalties. Can anyone better this record? (and dodgy chancers who've scored six out of six and likewise don't count) says Toby Blake

After hours of heated debate my friends and I are still in disagreement on this one. Who was the first East German to represent the unified team? I think it may be Thomas Doll but a lot of people tell me that it's Sammer and others have been mentioned. Can anyone help? asks Martin Widdicks.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

But contrary to popular belief, many sports stars are vegetarian, including Carl Lewis, Greg Chappell and Martina Navratilova (check out her recipe for pesto sauce at: http://www.vegsoc.org/news/1996/nvw/nvw-96.html#pest). However we've drawn a blank on professional footballers currently playing in the Premiership - although Liverpool's former physio Mark Leather says that Phil Babb (who's now at Sporting Lisbon) was definitely one. Can anyone help? "Football is a simple game - you play for 120 minutes and then the Germans win on penalties." This quote has been attributed to a lot of people - and even Guardian reporters seem to disagree, some accrediting it to Lineker and others to Lothar Matthaus. Who really said it? One of those two or someone else entirely? wonders Joe Banerjee. The quote is Gary Lineker's, although it only gained widespread currency when a typical modest Lothar Matthaus reminded the English press pack of it on the eve of last year's Champions League final. "I remember a saying from your own player Gary Lineker that football is where 22 players run round after the ball and at the end the Germans always win," Lothar told them. Perhaps this explains the resulting confusion. Why do Italy play in blue when their flag is orange, white and green? asks Jon Davis The Italian national team wear blue because it is the colour of Savoia, the ruling house of Italy from 1861 to 1946. Until the end of the second world war, the Italian flag always had the Savoy coat of arms in the centre, and it was only after the family were overthrown, and the Italian Republic established in 1946, that the plain tricolor was adopted as the national flag. Am I correct in thinking there is a restriction on clubs fielding more than two non-EU players? If so, won't Leeds have problems seeing as they've signed Mark Viduka and also have Harry Kewell and Lucas Radebe on their books? enquires Gareth Crossman You're right - there is a restriction. But according to Premier League rules, a side can play a maximum of three non-EU players in one game and not two. There's no limit, however, on how many can be registered with a club at one time. Can you help? Somewhere in the back of my brain, I seem to recall Chris Nicol scoring all four goals in a 2-2 draw between Aston Villa and Leicester City. Is my memory failing me? And are there similar own-goal scoring feats of similar ineptitude? asks Nick Evans. I've asked this before, and I really am curious to know the answer, which is why I persevere with such tiresome persistence. Southampton legend Le Tiss has scored 48 out of 49 penalties. Can anyone better this record? (and dodgy chancers who've scored six out of six and likewise don't count) says Toby Blake After hours of heated debate my friends and I are still in disagreement on this one. Who was the first East German to represent the unified team? I think it may be Thomas Doll but a lot of people tell me that it's Sammer and others have been mentioned. Can anyone help? asks Martin Widdicks. Any questions? Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

fields.headline: Division 2 half-term report
fields.trailText: Essex
fields.body:
Essex

Ch'ship (Div 2) 3rd NCL (Div 2) 6th

With Nasser Hussain either out of touch or captaining his country, and Stuart Law not quite as prolific as in recent summers, there's been lots to do for Ronnie Irani. He has responded well: averaging over 50 with the bat and under 25 with the ball, he led his side to the top of the table in early June. Promotion is a possibility, especially now that Peter Such (12 wickets on his return to the side at Chelmsford) is back in favour with Irani but Essex need to find more runs from outside the top six.
Performance of the season Ricky Anderson 11-111 v Northants
Disappointment of the season Hussain's miserable form (31 runs in the Championship at 7.75)

Glamorgan

Ch'ship (Div 2) 5th NCL (Div 2) 3rd

They breed 'em tough in the valleys. Since missing out on their first-ever knockout pot in the B&H final on June 10, Glamorgan have been unbeaten in all competitions. Their top order, led by Matthews Elliott and Maynard, has been a mixture of reliable and spectacular; their lower order has just been spectacular. Glamorgan used to have the longest tail outside the England team, but this season Steve Watkin has made his maiden fifty, keeper Adrian Shaw averages almost 45, and No. 8 Alex Wharf passed 20 twice - and made centuries both times.
Performance of the season Alex Wharf 101* v Northants
Disappointment of the season That Lord's defeat by Gloucestershire

Gloucestershire

Ch'ship (Div 2) 8th NCL (Div 1) 5th

They're the only team to have won a trophy this season (the B&H). And they could become the first side to win the NatWest after losing a match (their third-round match was replayed after Worcestershire fielded an ineligible player). But Gloster remain fall-guys in the four-dayers. Not that it bothers them much: they're the only county to rest their overseas player - Ian Harvey - for the Championship. Jonathan Lewis (28 wickets at 21.89) has taken over from Mike Smith as the premier strike bowler.
Performance of the season Lewis's 8-95 out of a total of 568 against the Zimbabweans
Disappointment of the season The first-class form of the whole side

Middlesex

Ch'ship (Div 2) 7th NCL (Div 2) 5th

The star players have done better than the team. Justin Langer has made 685 runs, Phil Tufnell, almost back to his alluring best, has snared 31 cheap wickets, and Angus Fraser and Mark Ramprakash are riding high in the averages. Even Mike Roseberry, whose career was petering away at Durham, is back in the runs. But Middlesex didn't win a Championship match until the end of June. Which was a surprise, because some of their younger players weren't doing too badly either: now that the Ramps experiment has been abandoned, they have a promising opening pairing in Andrew Strauss (487 runs at 37.46) and Ben Hutton, while wickets have come from some unexpected sources, such as Aaron Laraman and Tim Bloomfield.
Performance of the season Justin Langer's 96 and 104 v Notts - none of his team-mates passed 36 in either innings
Disappointment of the season Owais Shah - still underachieving

Northamptonshire

Ch'ship (Div 2) 9th NCL (Div 1) 6th

When will they get it together? Once in a blue moon, Northants click. But that's already happened this season - they beat Notts by an innings - and they've settled into their blundering ways with the ease of a Gower cover drive. Even Oxford Universities toppled them. The batsmen keep getting out in the forties and the best young spin trio in the country - Michael Davies, Graham Swann and Jason Brown - has failed to live up to expectations. Which is a bit of a Northants disease really.
Performance of the season David Sales's 276 v Notts
Disappointmennt of the season The rest of Sales's batting - 143 runs in 10 innings

Nottinghamshire

Ch'ship (Div 2) 6th NCL (Div 2) 1st

Like British Rail, Notts are getting there. But then no team led by Clive Rice would be allowed to perform so abominably two seasons running. Now that Notts have got used to the idea that Shoaib Akhtar won't be coming to Trent Bridge after all, fortunes have picked up. The one-day form has been a revelation and the batting more solid than it has been for years - even if it has been thanks to their new glut of veterans, an outrageous piece of short-term thinking that will do England no good at all. Still, an outside bet for two promotions in one season.
Performance of the season Guy Welton (200*) and Darren Bicknell (180*) putting on a county record 406* for the first wicket v Warwickshire
Disappointment of the season Chris Read (219 runs at 21.90) - has failed to take his chance in the middle order to put pressure on the England selectors.

Sussex

Ch'ship (Div 2) 4th NCL (Div 2) 7th

Comme ci, comme ca. Sussex have had their moments (notably, when they became the first side to beat Worcestershire in division 2 of the Championship), but they've suffered for their lack of penetrating batsmen and bowlers. Only Jason Lewry (26 at 29.34) has taken more than 20 wickets, and only Tony Cottey and Michael Bevan have hit first-class hundreds. Chris Adams has exploded occasionally - on and off the field - but there hasn't been enough of the same.
Performance of the season Chris Adams's 100 off 93 balls in the National League v Northants
Disappointment of the season Sussex's three-run one-day defeat by Kent. They began the final over needing five runs with seven wickets in hand and Bevan at the crease. They managed just a single.

Warwickshire

Ch'ship (Div 2) 1st NCL (Div 2) 4th

Bob's Bears are back. Just three defeats in all competitions so far, and Allan Donald has barely played. Huge first-innings scores have been the secret: 551 for 6 v Glamorgan, 548 for 7 v Sussex, 400 for 8 v Essex, 568 for 9 v Northants. And in a seamer's season, Ashley Giles has been outstanding, with 33 wickets at 22.51 plus two bonus centuries. Five batsmen average more than 50, and with Donald back from injury, division one beckons.
Performance of the season Dougie Brown (203) and Giles (128*) adding 289 for the sixth wicket against Sussex
Disappointment of the season Donald's injury - and his announcement that he won't be back next season

Worcestershire

Ch'ship (Div 2) 2nd NCL (Div 1) 1st

What a difference a ferocious fast bowler makes. Glenn McGrath has snarled his way to 37 very cheap Championship wickets, and Worcestershire, until the past couple of weeks, were virtually unbeatable. They won seven one-day games on the trot and were undefeated in the Championship until Sussex upset the pear-cart in mid-June. The wheels have come off recently, but if Stuart Lampitt (25 wickets at 19.2) keeps providing the bowling back-up, they should be back on again soon.
Performance of the season McGrath's 8-86 v Notts
Disappointment of the season losing the NatWest fourth-round replay to Gloucestershire after fielding an ineligible player, Kabir Ali, in the first game.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous County View, on the rise and rise of Surrey, click here. Additional research by Tom Bowtell

fields.headline: Division 1 half-term report
fields.trailText: Derbyshire
fields.body:
Derbyshire

Ch'ship (Div 1) 7th NCL (Div 2) 8th

The personnel may have changed (again) but the results haven't got much better. A seam attack that blends old hands (Dominic Cork and Tim Munton) with young Turks (Paul Aldred, Kevin Dean and Trevor Smith) has only rarely sparkled, while the batting has been over-reliant on Michael Di Venuto and has passed 250 just twice in the Championship. And with Cork likely to be on England duty in August, things could get worse.
Performance of the season Munton's 7-34 v Surrey (having taken 3 for 284 in his first four games)
Disappointment of the season Former England Under-19 star Mathew Dowman - 286 runs at 23.83

Durham

Ch'ship (Div 1) 6th NCL (Div 2) 7th

An early-season drubbing of Surrey was quickly forgotten as the batsmen had a collective shocker (Nick Speak scored 19 runs in seven Championship innings) - until the innings win over Derbyshire at the end of June. Simon Brown (31 Championship wickets at 14.70) and Melvyn Betts (35 at 17.91) have carried the attack superbly, but Durham's one-day form fell away after reaching the B&H quarter-finals: having done well to qualify from the tough Northern group, they lost eight games out of 11 in all competions.
Performance of the season Nicky Peng's 98 in that game v Surrey - though he has only scored 113 in 11 innings since
Disappointment of the season The opening partnership of Jonathan Lewis (216 runs at 16.61) and James Daley (95 at 10.55)

Hampshire

Ch'ship (Div 1) 8th NCL (Div 2) 9th

Proof that money doesn't buy you happiness. Alan Mullally got injured early on, Shane Warne started with four ducks and not many more wickets, and Hampshire became the laughing stock of the circuit. The middle order - including Robin Smith - forgot how to reach 50, and the mood wasn't improved by a two-run defeat at The Oval. Things did pick up with the return of Mullally, and Hampshire even won a Championship match, against Durham, but the batsmen will have to improve on their combined return of one century in all competitions if relegation is to be avoided.
Performance of the season the 10th-wicket stand of 90 between Dimitri Mascarenhas and Simon Francis that took Hants to the verge of a famous win at The Oval.
Disappointment of the season the batting of one-time England opener John Stephenson (49 Championship runs at 5.44)

Kent

Ch'ship (Div 1) 9th NCL (Div 1) 8th

County cricket's perennial bridesmaids will be lucky to make it to the wedding reception this year. Deprived of Dean Headley, Martin McCague and Dr Julian Thompson, their attack has been led by Mark Ealham - which says it all. But their batting - Rahul Dravid apart - has been even worse: even accounting for the miserable summer in the South-East, four batting points is an embarrassment. Could they become the first side to be relegated twice in one season?
Performance of the season David Fulton's 115 v Somerset (after totalling 35 in his previous 7 innings)
Disappointment of the season Alan Wells, with just 139 runs in 10 Championship innings

Lancashire

Ch'ship (Div 1) 3rd NCL (Div 1) 9th

A case of role reversal: the only undefeated side in the top flight of the Championship, Lancashire have forgotten how to win in the one-day league. Their batting has been a let down: John Crawley hit 126 v Cambridge and 156 v New Zealand A but hasn't passed 37 in the Championship, while Mike Atherton averages less than 10 (but then, if you've slagged off a competition, you're allowed to flop in it). Even Sourav Ganguly (188 runs at 31.33) has underperformed. The bowling has been better: Glen Chapple got off to a flyer, and Mike Smethurst (19 wickets at 18.15) is a candidate for the Unsung Hero of the Year Award. Should avoid relegation in the one-day league, but will Schofield and Keedy be able to match Saqlain and Salisbury as the pitches dry out and prevent Surrey standing in the way of Lancashire's first outright title since 1938?
Performance of the season Mike Smethurst 7-50 v Durham
Disappointment of the season Chris Schofield's bowling in the second Test against Zimbabwe at Old Trafford

Leicestershire

Ch'ship (Div 1) 5th NCL (Div 1) 3rd

Like a Phil DeFreitas over, the Foxes are always there or thereabouts. They've lost some of their bite since the days when James Whitaker was captain, but a team containing DeFreitas (averaging 43.00 with the bat and 25.56 with the ball) and Aftab Habib (506 runs at 50.60) can't be written off yet. Anil Kumble's 20 Championship wickets have cost as much as 28.10, mind you, and only three men average more than 26 with the bat.
Performance of the season Aftab Habib's 164 v Derbyshire, out of 270 while he was at the wicket
Disappointment of the season Trevor Ward (110 runs at 12.22)

Somerset

Ch'ship (Div 1) 4th NCL (Div 1) 2nd

You tend not to think of Somerset as a force in county cricket. But you'd better think again, because Dermot Reeve and Jamie Cox have turned an amiable group of Westcountrymen into an extremely competitive force in both forms of the game. Only England new boy Marcus Trescothick (453 at 45.30) averages more than 35, but the key has been packing the lower order with bowlers who can bat, like Ian Blackwell and Graham Rose. Andy Caddick (25 wickets in five innings) has again been outstanding.
Performance of the season Caddick's 12-126 against Hampshire
Disappointment of the season All out for 58 against Middlesex in the NatWest fourth round

Surrey

Ch'ship (Div 1) 1st NCL (Div 2) 2nd

Love 'em or hate 'em (and most teams hate 'em) you can't keep 'em down. Surrey had to wait until June for their first Championship win, but since then it's been one-way traffic - and Leicestershire stumbled into the path of the juggernaut last week. They have four strike bowlers - Saqlain Mushtaq, Martin Bicknell, Ian Salisbury and Alex Tudor - while the batting is starting to warm up.
Performance of the season Alistair Brown's 295* v Leicestershire
Disappointment of the season Ben Hollioake - he may have been injured, but still, that 63 v Australia at Lord's in 1997 seems decades ago.

Yorkshire

Ch'ship (Div 1) 2nd NCL (Div 1) 4th

Every season Yorkshire set off like a greyhound on speed. Every season they slow up like a St Bernard on dope. This year's deceleration has already started: trounced by Lancashire in the Roses match, knocked off the top by Surrey and humbled in the NatWest by Northants, Yorkshire are in danger of throwing away their fine start when they trounced Hampshire and Derbyshire by an innings. Michael Vaughan and Darren Lehmann both average over 60, but they need more support. And the young seamers need to take more wickets outside Headingley: so far they have combined to take 63 wickets in Leeds, but just 35 elsewhere
Performance of the season Michaal Vaughan's 155 against Derby on a Headingley greentop - the innings in which he broke his finger
Disappointment of the season The traditional crisis

And the young seamers need to take more wickets outside Headingley: so far they have combined to take 63 wickets in Leeds, but just 35 elsewhere Performance of the season Michaal Vaughan's 155 against Derby on a Headingley greentop - the innings in which he broke his finger Disappointment of the season The traditional crisis Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com.
