webTitle: Class-riven UK exposed in new study

fields.headline: Class-riven UK exposed in new study
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is still a class-ridden society with the gap in educational and job opportunities between rich and poor as deep as ever, according to a new "map of inequality in Britain" to be published this week.
fields.body:
Britain is still a class-ridden society with the gap in educational and job opportunities between rich and poor as deep as ever, according to a new "map of inequality in Britain" to be published this week.

The report, commissioned by the health minister Yvette Cooper, will form a central part of the factual and ideological justification for the big increases in public spending to be announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his spending review next week. Mr Brown is billing the £40bn extra cash over three years as part of a crusade to extend opportunity in Britain.

The findings, which suggest that today's 30-year-olds are still haunted by disadvantage and poverty at birth, are likely to be highly sensitive within New Labour. Tony Blair fears that any overt drive to cut inequality might alienate his middle-class base.

In the past, he has implied that the class divide is already over in Britain, arguing that the real enemies are the forces of conservatism.

The new research, by the Smith Institute, is based on two massive tracking surveys of 16,000 people born in single weeks in 1958 and 1970.

In a foreword, Ms Cooper writes: "The opportunities gap between those from different social backgrounds was no different from those born in 1970 than it was for children born in 1958.

"Although those born in 1970 had better educated parents and so started from a better position, the gap between those from professional and unskilled backgrounds has remained the same."

In some areas, she claims, "the detrimental effects of inequality of opportunity are actually growing stronger and more debilitating. The relative risk of becoming a teenage mother from unskilled families compared to professional families almost doubled between the 1958 and 1970 generations.

"Daughters of unskilled men born in 1970 were an astonishing nine times more likely to become a teenage mother than girls whose fathers were more highly qualified," she says.

Even daughters of skilled manual fathers in both generations were four times more likely to have a teenage child than the the daughter of a professional couple. Other findings highlighted include:

 Men born in 1970 with no qualifications were 12 times more likely to be out of work by the age of 26 than those with degrees. Of those who were in work, their pay was also considerably lower than the children of professional parents.

 Women's chances of being in full time employment - rather than in part-time work or staying home with children - were eight times higher for graduates than for those with no qualifications.

 The impact of class on qualifications was just as great for the 1970 generation as for the 1958. "The average gap between the daughters of an educated professional father and the daughters of an unskilled man who left school at the minimum age represents about three rungs of a six-rung educational ladder. For sons, the gap in both generations is about two and a half grades." The three rungs are equivalent to the difference between a degree and GCSEs.

 In both generations, those with no qualifications were about three times more likely to be classed as depressed at ages 33 and 26 than graduates.

 For both generations, if one or both of a child's parents had left school at the minimum age, the chances of the child doing the same were doubled. In 1970, the sons of an unskilled male were seven times more likely to leave school at the minimum age than those of a professional man.

The researchers say at the end of their exhaustive analysis that "the figures demonstrated convincingly that family social class and parents' educational level at the time our respondents were born were critically important factors in determining what was going to happen to them 16 years later".

The report does, however, find that a child's performance at school, as much as their class background, is starting to become a major predictor of whether someone will leave school at 16.

Nevertheless, a child's family background at birth and subsequent poverty are still a clear influence.

The researchers also found that boys were less capable of breaking out of their class background than girls.

The study examined whether people born in rural Britain fared less well than their urban counterparts, but the research shows there is no discernible independent impact.

In her report, Ms Cooper warns that Labour has failed in the past to reduce inequality, and emphasises that the government of which she is a member will ignore the research at its peril.

fields.headline: Vodafone forced to explain £10m bonus
fields.trailText: Corporate activists have forced Vodafone AirTouch, the world's fifth largest company, to prepare an embarrassing "explanation" of the £10m bonus it has paid its chief executive, Chris Gent.
fields.body:
Corporate activists have forced Vodafone AirTouch, the world's fifth largest company, to prepare an embarrassing "explanation" of the £10m bonus it has paid its chief executive, Chris Gent.

Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the global telecommunications group, said last night: "In order to correct some of the misleading comments made in the press recently, we are preparing a statement which will be issued in the near future."

It is believed the statement will include a pledge that no such bonus will be paid in future.

Shareholder protests about the payment to Mr Gent have been led by the Association of British Insurers, whose members hold about a quarter of British shares.

They have been pressing Vodafone to issue a declaration that the payment to Mr Gent was a one-off and there would be no repetition of such an arrangement.

What particularly angered investing institutions was that the payment was not based on performance but on the value of deals struck by Mr Gent as he has built up Vodafone's worldwide mobile telecoms network.

The shareholders argued that the value of these deals in terms of profits for Vodafone would not be quantifiable for years to come.

Other investors to have voiced concerns include the National Association of Pension Funds, whose members hold more than £800bn of assets, and the Pensions and Investment Research Company, which advises local authority pensions funds and has been a fierce critic of boardroom largesse.

Although Vodafone is preparing to promise not to make such payments again, it is adamant that the £10m is a fair reflection of Mr Gent's contribution to the company.

It is expected to say the bonus is not a precedent for Vodafone or for other companies to follow.

The company has told institutions that most of the payment is to bring Mr Gent's remuneration into line with that of other leaders in the competitive telecoms industry.

Only a minor element is a re-election of his pivotal role in clinching the takeover of the German telecoms group Mannesmann.

The NAPF had been advising its members to abstain at the annual meeting on July 27 from the vote to re-elect Mr Gent to the Vodafone board.

The Vodafone statement is expected to result in withdrawal of that threat although individual protests may occur.

webTitle: Tory tax plans 'would leave £16bn hole in key services'

fields.headline: Tory tax plans 'would leave £16bn hole in key services'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives would fund their promise to cut taxes in the next parliament by cutting billions of pounds from the public spending blueprint to be unveiled by Gordon Brown next week, the opposition admitted last night.
fields.body:
The Conservatives would fund their promise to cut taxes in the next parliament by cutting billions of pounds from the public spending blueprint to be unveiled by Gordon Brown next week, the opposition admitted last night.

As the two main parties fired the opening shots in a tax-and-spending battle that is likely to dominate the general election campaign, ministers said that the proposals from the Tory leader, William Hague, and the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, would leave a £16bn hole in key public services by 2004.

Tony Blair will today outline how the big increases in spending planned for the next three years have only been made possible by the government's hard line in its first two years in office. The prime minister will say that voters will increasingly be able to see the benefits.

Labour, after its recent problems, is eager to exploit Mr Hague's decision to water down his much-vaunted "tax guarantee", and Mr Blair is keen to publicise good news coming from the labour market, where a million new jobs have been created since the general election and the number of people out of work and claiming benefit is now - at 1,109,000 - only 23,000 higher than when Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979.

Though Tory strategists refused to confirm Labour's figures about spending, they admitted that a series of interviews by the Conservative leader and shadow chancellor were designed to give credibility to the opposition's pledge to reduce the burden of taxation in the next parliament by saying that the promise would not apply during an economic downturn.

Ministers said last night that the Tories had dug themselves into "an even deeper hole" by explicitly stating that they were determined to cut the growth of public spending from the 3.3% a year that Mr Brown has set to around 2%.

On their own private admission, shadow ministers say that that would mean cuts of at least £10bn a year, although Hague aides said last night that the health service - currently the voters' chief concern - would be protected.

The Conservatives claimed that David Willetts, their social security spokesman, had already found £3bn worth of cuts and that the opposition was convinced that it could net a further £1bn from Labour's extra spending on government itself.

However, Andrew Smith, the chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "Now they have admitted what Labour has always said - that their tax guarantee is a public spending cuts guarantee, a cuts guarantee so extreme that it will hit the health service, education, law and order and transport."

Unveiled at the Tory conference in October, the original Hague plan "guaranteed" voters that a Tory government would cut taxes as a share of national income over the lifetime of a parliament - regardless, critics were quick to say, of whether the economy was in boom or recession.

Hague aides now say they were misrepresented and that yesterday's initiative - a Hague interview and Portillo article, both in the Daily Telegraph - was designed to "refine" or "clarify" the leader's position.

Although it is emphatically denied, many MPs on both sides believe that Mr Portillo, who returned to Westminster and rejoined the shadow team soon after the Hague guarantee, is the driving force to give real intellectual weight to Tory economic policy - and to fulfill his own long-standing commitment to cutting public spending as a share of GNP.

Mr Portillo remained loyal to Mr Hague yesterday, saying that the Tory leader "had good reasons for making that pledge. It is what Conservative governments normally achieve - we normally manage to increase the amount of spending on vital public services and reduce the burden of tax."

But he admitted the plan's weak spot, that in a recession - what he called "pretty unusual circumstances" - tax cuts would be impossible if key public services were to be maintained.

"We need to make it clear that of course, although we are committed to the reduction of taxes, we are not going to do that in circumstances where it would be imprudent with the public finances, and we are not going to do that in circumstances where we would have to cut vital national services."

In his crucial passage he argued that targeted higher spending on key services was compatible with tax cuts and that Labour's own plans showed it would keep on raising taxes without providing voters with better services.

"We are saying that the prudent thing to do with public spending is to allow it to increase. That gives us the scope to spend more on vital public services, we have made that commitment to the national health service, but it means that overall, the amount by which public spending increases has to be less than the rate of growth of the economy."

Mr Brown will outline next week that he is boosting government spending by around £40bn over the three years to 2003-04.

Although the big increases for health were announced in the Budget earlier this year, it is expected that the chancellor will have enough left over to increase spending on education by just over 5% in real terms and to divide up the remaining £18bn between transport and fighting crime.

Overall, spending will increase by 3.3% a year in real terms, faster than the economy's normal growth rate, which averages around 2.25% to 2.5% a year.

Mr Portillo said yesterday that Mr Brown could only afford to raise spending at this rate by increasing taxes, but tax experts said that the extra taxes paid since the election would comfortably finance Labour's plans, unless the economy nosedived.

fields.headline: Virgin threatens Railtrack with court
fields.standfirst:
Delays on west coast line could result in £10m penalty
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Trains last night threatened legal action against Railtrack if it does not try to reduce delays on the west coast main line between Glasgow and London, which are causing misery to thousands of passengers.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Trains last night threatened legal action against Railtrack if it does not try to reduce delays on the west coast main line between Glasgow and London, which are causing misery to thousands of passengers.

Virgin could ask the courts to issue a performance order against the company requiring it reduce the delays within 28 days or face a penalty of up to £10m. The provisions for the penalty payments are enshrined in the contract between Virgin and Railtrack under which Railtrack agreed to modernise the line.

The delays are of Railtrack's making. They are centred on the approach to Euston station in London, where re-signalling is being carried out. Virgin said last night that on some days half of its services had been delayed.

The work is part of the £2.2bn upgrade of the line that will allow Virgin to operate new trains capable of speeds up to 140mph. These will cut the journey time between London and Manchester to less than two hours.

Chris Green, Virgin Rail's managing director, said he was shocked by the level of avoidable delays passengers were experiencing.

"There is no reason why passengers should be subjected to these continuing problems which could go on for three years," he said.

Railtrack is expected to offer a rescue plan to Virgin's board today in an attempt to avoid the courts, but senior Virgin managers said it would have to be detailed and positive or the company would resort to legal action.

Earlier yesterday the much-criticised commuter service operator Connex removed its managing director, Geoff Harrison-Mee, in an attempt to ensure that it is awarded a new franchise for the south London suburban routes.

Mr Harrison-Mee is the most high-profile victim of a purge by the company's French parent, Vivendi. A statement said that Mr Harrison-Mee will join Connex's headquarters team as corporate rail development director. He is replaced by Olivier Brousse.

Connex is battling with another transport company, Govia, for a 20-year contract to operate the franchise, but has been told that it must strip out much of its current management team before it can be considered.

The company yesterday announced a £1.45bn investment plan in an effort to improve services. It said that it was also putting staff through training programmes to make sure that they were "passenger friendly".

Antoine Hurel, chairman of Connex, said: "I know we are criticised but we are now putting our money where our mouth is." He said that all slam-door trains would be removed by 2002 with a new fleet of sliding-door trains costing £400m.

The company has one of the worst records for punctuality on the network.

webTitle: Will 20 men dressed as sheep in a field bring the crowds flocking to the dome?

fields.headline: Will 20 men dressed as sheep in a field bring the crowds flocking to the dome?
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau has not had much to smile about in the six months since he took over the Millennium Dome. But the self-styled "ugly little French guy", who still insists he has the "best job in the world", says the laugh will soon be on his critics.
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau has not had much to smile about in the six months since he took over the Millennium Dome. But the self-styled "ugly little French guy", who still insists he has the "best job in the world", says the laugh will soon be on his critics.

The first of a series of three TV ads will be shown tonight depicting its detractors as dumb sheep being led by a flock of naysayers. One shows a field full of men in sheepskin coats with woolly wigs saying: "I wouldn't waste my time going to that bloomin' great marquee. Naa, Naa."

The campaign - which carries the slogan "You've got a mind of your own, take it to the dome" - will run in tandem with a presumably tongue-in-cheek celebration of all things British including tea dances, stand-up comedy, giant Cluedo and Scrabble games and It's A Knockout. Its humorous potential, however, seemed to have passed Mr Gerbeau by yesterday as he declared his mission was to make the British people "proud of their dome".

Asked if his commitment to staging "traditional British dance in historical costumes" would take in morris dancing, Mr Gerbeau replied: "What is this morris dancing? It is one of the things about your culture which I have yet to experience, but I'm looking forward to seeing it."

Mr Gerbeau hopes the ads will cut through all the bad publicity the dome has suffered by appealing to the "famous British sense of humour" and fair play.

"I know people here do not like to be told what to do or what to think. I know that the British people really love this little ugly Frenchman and they want me to fight back against all the bad things that have been said. This is the best ever visitor attraction in Britain and the second biggest now in Europe, and we will beat the other one [Disneyland Paris] by the end of the year."

The timing of the campaign could not have been better for Mr Gerbeau. The dome's architect, Richard Rogers, has won the prestigious £90,000 Praemium Imperiale award.

webTitle: It still does not add up

fields.headline: It still does not add up
fields.standfirst:
But Mr Hague has ditched a crazy pledge
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague is being both politically shrewd and economically realistic in dropping the guarantee made at his last party conference that taxes would fall as a share of the nation's income over the term of the next Conservative government. This was a barmy commitment, since the tax burden (as a percentage of GDP) naturally rises during a recession as output flags, increasing social disbursements and cutting tax revenues. The spending cuts needed to honour this pledge (from which, he told us, there were to be no escape clauses) would plunge the economy into a deeper mire and be very unpopular with the electorate. For the second time in a month Mr Portillo has engineered a U-turn in economic policy (last month he pledged the party to full employment).
fields.body:
William Hague is being both politically shrewd and economically realistic in dropping the guarantee made at his last party conference that taxes would fall as a share of the nation's income over the term of the next Conservative government. This was a barmy commitment, since the tax burden (as a percentage of GDP) naturally rises during a recession as output flags, increasing social disbursements and cutting tax revenues. The spending cuts needed to honour this pledge (from which, he told us, there were to be no escape clauses) would plunge the economy into a deeper mire and be very unpopular with the electorate. For the second time in a month Mr Portillo has engineered a U-turn in economic policy (last month he pledged the party to full employment).

The trouble is that when you are in a hole you can spend a lot of time digging without getting very far. If Messrs Hague and Portillo believe they have regained the initiative in the debate about taxes and public spending, they may face a nasty surprise.

They have promised to maintain Labour's huge increase in public spending on health (a whopping 6% a year for three years) while pledging themselves to reducing Gordon Brown's "unsustainable" increases in overall public spending of 3.3% a year in real terms at a time when the economy is expected to grow by barely 2%. But if they are to keep spending in normal times down to 2% while maintaining Labour's spend on health, other areas of spending will have to be axed in order to maintain the new fiscal pledges.

It remains to be seen whether Labour's claims that the Tories will now have to cut £18bn a year by the end of the three year period are true. But the Conservatives may have to make savage cuts in areas (transport? crime?) where middle England wants to have its cake and eat it. There may be an appetite there for tax cuts, but there is an even bigger one for good infrastructure, falling crime and decent schools as well as for a flourishing health service.

If Mr Hague can meet all those requirements and bring down taxes as well, then he will deserve free membership of the Magic Circle. But if he is forced to make an even stealthier retreat, few will be surprised. Labour, remember, fought the last election on a pledge to maintain Tory spending cuts . Hague will fight the next one pledged to maintain Labour's record rise in health spending. It's a funny old world.

webTitle: Police image of man in hunt for Sarah

fields.headline: Police image of man in hunt for Sarah
fields.trailText: Police looking for the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday issued a computer likeness of a man they are seeking in connection with her disappearance in what detectives described as a "significant" step forward.
fields.body:
Police looking for the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday issued a computer likeness of a man they are seeking in connection with her disappearance in what detectives described as a "significant" step forward.

The man was seen with a girl resembling eight-year-old Sarah at a motorway service station, nine hours after she disappeared from Kingston, West Sussex.

Police said they had received more than 1,200 calls since the fresh lead was announced on Monday when they revealed that a man and child were seen at Knutsford service station on the northbound carriageway of the M6 in Cheshire. A woman told police she found a distressed girl in toilets at Knutsford at 5am on July 2 who told her she was called Sarah.

South Wales police yesterday joined the search after receiving a call about a possible sighting of the girl outside a pub in the village of Cilfynydd near Pontypridd. A police helicopter scoured the area.

But despite the deluge of calls - some from Greece, Israel and Spain - there were no clues to the identity of the man in the e-fit, police said.

The assistant chief constable of Sussex, Nigel Yeo, said officers from the investigation team were interviewing staff at Knutsford, and were checking CCTV film from other motorway service stations.

He added that the man could be unaware of events, as he might be on holiday or out of the country. The man was described as white, aged about 30, around 6ft tall, with a solid build, sandy hair, and clean shaven.

Detectives revealed yesterday that the woman who saw the girl had a short conversation with him.

The girl, who spoke with a southern accent, was wearing a mid-blue short-sleeved dress and dark shoes, not unlike those worn by Sarah.

Det Supt Alan Ladley, leading the inquiry, described the witness as "credible and genuine". He said the woman noticed that the girl "did seem slightly inappropriately dressed for 5am".

She had found the child crying in the toilets and had "tidied her up".

He added: "At the time she had initial concerns but she sorted it out as best she could. She spoke to the male and established that the girl was with him. There was a short conversation which gave the woman some confidence that everything was OK. When they were reunited she had no undue concern. They held hands and walked out."

Detectives continue to sift through the calls which have surged to over 5,000 since the investigation began. Police said they had conducted more than 220 interviews.

Mr Yeo confirmed that a total of £80,000 had so far been offered as a reward for Sarah's recovery. He added that there had been a handful of malicious calls.

A 14-year-old boy had been charged with wasting police time after allegedly telling them he had seen Sarah alive.

fields.headline: No: 1375
fields.standfirst: Tenby
fields.trailText: Tenby
fields.body:
Age: Over 900 years.

Reasons to visit: Tenby has been "the premier resort of south Pembrokeshire since the 1700s", it says on the official website. And it boasts two of the Reader's Digest's top beaches in Britain.

Hmm. Situated in the centre of Britain's only coastal national park, the town's clifftop paths are renowned for their stunning beauty.

Any other attraction? How about Tenby's supposedly health-giving powers, which wooed Victorian tourists by the thousand?

We no longer believe in that mumbo-jumbo. Au contraire - Tenby is once again seducing visitors bent on sampling its, ahem, medicinal properties.

Enlighten me. The once-peaceful Welsh resort is now piss-up capital of Britain, having been named the world's second-best stag night location by Maxim magazine.

What's the best place? Los Angeles.

And Maxim magazine? As in "Melanie Sykes: Nude Bathing - By 'Eck, She Is, You Know!"

Not quite Judith Chalmers. You'd rather see Judith nude bathing?

No, I mean Maxim doesn't sound as authoritative as, say, Wish You Were Here. Well, it's turned Tenby's tourist trade around. "Now we're getting these groups from all over Wales," says councillor Lis James, who had to dodge flying pint glasses last weekend when a scrap broke out between rival pre-nuptial parties.

Twinned with Charleroi, is it? "It's got to the stage where Tenby is a no-go area for family holidaymakers," says James, whose council wants to ban such hedonistic high jinks.

A ban on fun! "There is a witch-hunt going on," declaims one local hotelier. "It is against civil liberties."

Might history hold a better solution? In the 13th century, the Earl of Pembroke built a ring of walls, towers and gateways around Tenby, for which the town remains famous.

So, with a little minor fortification . . . The lager-guzzling hordes can be rebuffed at the city gates.

Start boiling the oil! There's a job for you in the Home Office, my boy.

Not to be confused with: Ibiza, Ayia Napa.

fields.headline: Changing a losing side
fields.standfirst:
The BBC needs stronger governors
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: What BBC governors are there to do has not always been clear, beyond making life hell from time to time for incumbent directors-general. The first, John Reith, fought with Ethel Snowden, wife of the turncoat Labour politician, like dog with cat. Charles Hill was drafted in as chairman by Harold Wilson to bring Hugh Carleton Greene's flamboyant Auntie to heel. What BBC governors are there to do has not always been clear, beyond making life hell from time to time for incumbent directors-general. The first, John Reith, fought with Ethel Snowden, wife of the turncoat Labour politician, like dog with cat. Charles Hill was drafted in as chairman by Harold Wilson to bring Hugh Carleton Greene's flamboyant Auntie to heel. Their selection, based on fancy algorithms to do with gender, race and territory, has not always thrown up first-rate advocates of programmes that are original, necessary, different and public-spirited.

Now the culture secretary Chris Smith is about to redraft the regulatory apparatus for what is still, quaintly, called broadcasting. When material can be transmitted from a host of "platforms", including new-generation mobile phones, the overlapping remits of the radio and television and broadcasting standards commissions and the Office of Telecommunications certainly need reworking. But Mr Smith as he plots reform should bear two points in mind. The governors may seem anomalous in the wider scheme of early 21st-century transmissions technology but are no more peculiar than the BBC itself.

They are the public's trustees, ultimate carriers of the "gene" of Reithian public service. Appointments are in Mr Smith's gift. The board is as good or bad today as his predecessors made it. If he wants a better performance, he must choose its members more diligently than they did. Only then can the board sustain on behalf of autonomous licence-funded broadcasting that wonderful, anachronistic ideal for which the BBC still stands.

webTitle: Vivendi to subsidise staff's home PCs

fields.headline: Vivendi to subsidise staff's home PCs
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Media and communications group Vivendi is planning to demonstrate its belief in the convergence of the "old" and "new" economies by providing all its employees with a discount-price computers and free internet access.
fields.body:
Media and communications group Vivendi is planning to demonstrate its belief in the convergence of the "old" and "new" economies by providing all its employees with a discount-price computers and free internet access.

Chief operating officer Eric Licoys told a Paris conference yesterday that the Net.generation program, which will be introduced over the next 12 months, was "one way for our company to give all our employees a key resource to ensure they feel personally concerned by the great changes now taking place".

The scheme is likely to prove expensive with the group recouping only "a few euros a month" on the cost of the PCs from those of its 250,000 employees - including those in Britain - who take up the offer, although Vivendi is not yet putting a figure on how much it is likely to have to spend. "That will depend on what we can negotiate with one of the big PC companies," Mr Licoys said.

But the group reckons the investment will be worthwhile. "We believe the old and new economies are in the same world. Even the unions approve of the initiative," he added.

Mr Licoys said the main factor behind Vivendi's merger with the spirits, films and music group Seagram was the latter's music business - because it complemented the group's internet and multimedia strategy. At present 75% of music sales go to just 5% of the world's population.

The internet, he said, was opening new markets, cutting inventories and costs while boosting volumes. He acknowledged that music via the internet faced a problem of piracy but said: "We are reasonably optimistic we can find an intelligent solution in the US and Europe."

Mr Licoys defended the price the group was paying for Seagram and said he was surprised by analysts "who say 'this is the price' and, when someone comes along and pays that price, they then say its expensive".

fields.headline: Heavy weather
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Eye Of The Storm/Bare Necessities
fields.body:
Did the programmers at ITV know something that the rest of us didn't? The scheduling of Eye Of The Storm slap bang in the middle of the most disgusting spell of summer weather in living memory struck a chord with those of us huddling in our winter wardrobe, regretting all that money spent on light summer casuals that will be out of fashion by the time the sun reappears.

Eye Of The Storm was the latest manifestation of that strangely popular phenomenon of the past five years, the bad weather show. Richard Madeley kept warm and dry while linking a handful of stories in which death and destruction literally rained from the sky. "Beautiful golf course, this, isn't it?" he asked, basking in the sunshine (where did he find it?) and sporting a hairdo that wouldn't survive a light driz zle, let alone a "catastrophic natural event". "But you wouldn't want to be out here in a thunderstorm, would you?" he added, with a hint of sternness in his voice, as if we had suggested that we might. Later he told us that playing sport "statistically increases your chance of being struck by lightning", which was music to the ears of sport-haters everywhere.

Footage followed of a Johannesburg football team who were indeed struck by lightning, leaving the pitch littered with twitching players. The opposition unkindly suggested that they had deliberately stood in the way of Jove's thunderbolt because they were 2-0 down. In Oklahoma seven tornadoes cut a swathe through a built-up area, ripping people out of their closets and flinging babies across the landscape like confetti; one was found dangling in a tree, and rescued. "I think The Wizard Of Oz is the sickest movie ever made", said one woman, revisiting the concrete patch where once stood her house. In Sydney, 9cm hailstones punctured tin roofs and smashed windscreens. It all goes to show that there's always someone worse off than you, but it isn't Richard Madeley.

It didn't get much worse than the ordeal faced by the six contestants in Bare Necessities (BBC2). This was the bastard offspring of Castaway 2000 and The Crystal Maze, in which two teams (three nurses, three estate agents) were landed in the middle of the Mexican jungle and told, basically, to get on with it. They had to build shelters, prepare food and keep themselves healthy for five days, with the added indignity of presenter Ed Hall and survival expert Hugh McManners coming round to award them points for achievement and "team spirit". Needless to say, in the 80% humidity, team spirit gave out pretty quickly, and we watched six very dispirited young people attempting to gut and skin an iguana for their supper.

At night, the contestants confided to a video camera, and it all went very Blair Witch Project. Happily, daybreak revealed no sinister disappearances, nor did anyone's severed nose turn up wrapped in a hanky. The nurses played by the rules and worried about hygiene; the estate agents cheated like mad and got away with it. Danny, as handsome as a football player and clearly used to charming his way through deals, was caught out smuggling tobacco and stealing food, and just grinned when he got told off. "It seems like the estate agents have broken every rule in the book", said Ed Hall, to nobody's surprise.

Bare Necessities would have made a pleasant 30 minutes, but instead was strung out to the full hour. How many times did we lis ten to Patrick complaining about Mari's singing? How long did we spend watching the judges wandering over to the contestants' camps and debating their points? Not enough happened to fill the time, and we were left with repeated shots of sunsets, of trivial chat to the video camera, and a long sequence of Danny retching as he attempted to gut a turkey.

By "Day 5" everyone was hysterical with hunger, the nurses were near tears and Danny had entered some kind of jungle madness, painting his body with mud tattoos and wearing a cute headband. Finally, after we'd been subjected to four rounds of painstaking scoring, the whole game rested on a race across a patch of mud, and the estate agents romped to victory. They were whisked off to a five-star hotel to enjoy champagne, massages and plunge pools; the poor old nurses trudged tearfully back to their stinking hovel. There's a moral in there somewhere.

webTitle: Aids vaccine for Africa to begin human trials

fields.headline: Aids vaccine for Africa to begin human trials
fields.standfirst:
International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: The first vaccine to hold out the prospect of protecting the millions in Africa from HIV infection and Aids, pioneered by scientists at Oxford University, is about to go into human trials in the UK and Kenya, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The first vaccine to hold out the prospect of protecting the millions in Africa from HIV infection and Aids, pioneered by scientists at Oxford University, is about to go into human trials in the UK and Kenya, it was announced yesterday.

The Liberal Democrat health spokesman, Evan Harris, is to be one of the first volunteers to take part in trials on the safety of the vaccine.

A vaccine is the holy grail of HIV/Aids research, seen as the only way to stem the tide of death and misery across Africa, which is predicted soon to sweep through India and China, the world's most populous nations. But the vaccines in trials so far have been focused on a strain of the virus found mainly in North America and Europe.

Yesterday in Durban, South Africa, at the 13th international Aids conference, Andrew McMichael, of the Medical Research Council's human immunology unit at Oxford University, said he had received permission to start human trials on a vaccine for Africa from the UK's medicines control agency.

The team already has 13 of the 18 healthy volunteers it needs for the phase I trials, which will test the vaccine's safety.

Mr Harris, who is MP for Oxford and who has worked with HIV-positive patients in his previous job as an NHS hospital doctor, said: "My volunteering for the safety trial will hopefully encourage other people in Oxford to participate. First-world treatments for HIV are sadly not affordable in the developing world. It is appropriate that British scientists and British politicians work together to provide a vaccine-based approach to combat the HIV devastation that we see in Africa today."

The work is backed by the International Aids Vaccine Initiative (IAVI), set up four years ago to channel funds and scientific expertise into efforts to help the developing world, in the knowledge that the multinational pharmaceutical companies were funding only research into vaccines for the west, where they stand to make large profits. IAVI is delighted by the swift progress Prof McMichael's team, in collaboration with the University of Nairobi, has made. "The goal is in sight," said Wayne Koff, IAVI's vice president for research and development. "We are increasingly confident that a protective vaccine will be ready in five to 10 years."

The breakthrough stems from the realisation that 10% of Kenyan sex workers had not become HIV positive, even though they were constantly exposed to the virus. "We found that about 70% of them make an immune response involving killer T-cells," said Prof McMichael. "You can't detect the virus in their blood. We believe they are protected by this immune response."

The vaccine is aimed at the A subtype of the virus, which accounts for 70% of HIV in Kenya. The North American and European strain is B and sub-Saharan Africa suffers from C. An IAVI-backed effort between a North Carolina-based biotechnology company called AlphaVax and the University of Capetown is focused on a vaccine for type C, but it is not yet ready for human trials.

Prof McMichael's team have made their vaccine from synthetic DNA of the HIV virus, delivered by means of the old smallpox vaccine. The object is to prime the immune system so that, when it encounters HIV, it will overcome it before the virus has a chance to multiply.

"People infected make quite good T-cell responses, but the virus is always ahead and can always mutate," he said. "What we're hoping to do is to have such a good immune response lying in wait that it zaps it before it gets going."

If the vaccine proves effective, he believes he can make small alterations so that it will work against the other types of HIV as well. "It might be possible to put them together to make a universal vaccine."

The first trial on humans will take place in Oxford in August, followed by a trial in Nairobi three to six months later.

fields.headline: Mr Putin's two faces
fields.standfirst:
Russia's likely future is growing clearer
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Four months after his landslide poll victory, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has belatedly produced an election manifesto. His state of the nation address last weekend, coupled with recently promulgated foreign policy, national security, and military "doctrines", have finally shed some light on how he intends to run Russia. Our pre-election question, "who is Vladimir Putin?" may now be confidently answered. It transpires he is two quite different people wrapped into one.
fields.body:
Four months after his landslide poll victory, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has belatedly produced an election manifesto. His state of the nation address last weekend, coupled with recently promulgated foreign policy, national security, and military "doctrines", have finally shed some light on how he intends to run Russia. Our pre-election question, "who is Vladimir Putin?" may now be confidently answered. It transpires he is two quite different people wrapped into one.

To the world at large, Mr Putin presents a plausible if unlovable face. Sidestepping the vexed question of Nato enlargement, and burying the Kosovo hatchet, his administration now says it wants a constructive relationship with the US and the west. On arms control, Mr Putin has deftly gained a moral advantage, pushing through Duma ratification of the Start II accord while leading the charge against America's treaty-busting national missile defence plans. Far from alienating the west, these and similar initiatives have impressed European governments, who have their own concerns about NMD and proliferation.

Mr Putin's desire to create a "multi-polar" world free of American hegemony has appeal in capitals as far apart as Paris and Beijing. The Russian leader will use a coming visit to China (and North Korea) to explore other areas of cooperation. One is a shared abhorrence of anything that smacks of interference in their internal affairs. For Russia, this means Chechnya; for China, Taiwan and Tibet. They also agree on the need to uphold the primacy of the UN in international affairs and, for example, the necessity of lifting sanctions on Serbia and Iraq.

But such convictions will not prevent the pragmatic Mr Putin attending the G8 club's summit in Okinawa on July 21, where he will hope to exploit his recent acquaintance with Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. Mr Putin's canny message to the outside world is that his post-Yeltsin Russia will be a stable, business-friendly democracy, committed to open markets, lower taxes and state sector reform; a Russia with which the west would do well to engage through trade, aid, investment and common-sense realpolitik. It is in fact the message he knows the west badly wants to hear. How else to explain its silence over still unchecked atrocities in Chechnya, and the EU's sickening, cynical decision this week to resume $90m of suspended Russian aid?

To the Russian people, however, Mr Putin presents a very different face. Since taking office he has sought swinging powers enabling him to suspend political parties, impose emergency rule, close down independent media and monitor email and internet traffic. He has placed his old KGB/FSB and St Petersburg cronies in key jobs, moved to reduce the autonomy of elected regional governors, and secured a rubber-stamp Duma majority. Mr Putin's apparatchiks have targeted in particular the Media-Most opposition media group, arrested its boss, Vladimir Gusinsky, and gravely harassed brave reporters like Andrei Babitsky.

In his national address, the president resurrected the age-old Russian ideal of strong state, strong leader, while warning of fearsome chaos if his will were thwarted. Authority, he said, "should rely on the law and a single, vertical line of executive power". At last, all is clear! Here is a true Platonic solution. Mr Putin and his pals in his unelected security council will be the unfettered arbiters of the laws, while ultimate decision-making rests with him alone. For those in the west who have not already turned a blind eye, Mr Putin's two-faced, tsarist tendencies will bear close watching.

fields.headline: Random view
fields.standfirst: What cake-makers are watching on television
fields.trailText: What cake-makers are watching on television
fields.body:
Sarah (Choccywoccydoodah, Brighton)

"I guess I am a bit soapy actually, I do watch the soaps. I work during the day so don't see much of the telly in the afternoon or early evening. I'm a late-night person, I like the stuff everyone likes, like the 11 O' Clock Show Daisy Donovan she's clever and funny, she holds herself well and makes me laugh. Obviously I like Friends. I think everybody likes that though, don't they? Everyone I know likes it. I like Chandler, that's obvious too. I quite enjoy wildlife programmes. On otters are good - because er, they're sweet. What do I hate? I can't stand This Is Your Life - it does my head in and Emmerdale, but I don't know why exactly, I just don't like it. No, I didn't watch that teenage sex season on Channel 4. I don't want to know about 16 year olds getting pregnant, what can I do about that? And I thought it would tell me things I already knew, hahaha! I do actually watch cookery programmes and food programmes, because I like cookery. I love Jamie Oliver, yeah, he's irritating, but I like seeing what he cooks. Personality I most hate? Charlie Dimmock. Really annoying."

Jean (Cake Magic, Birmingham)

"I don't watch anything. I have two TVs - sitting-room and bedroom - but I still don't watch anything. Sends me to sleep. My boyfriend finds it so irritating! Do I cook instead? No, not really. Person I hate on TV? Can't think of anyone no, no one at all. Is that it?"

Phillip (Mr Bun The Baker, Cheltenham)

"No time for TV. Last thing I watched was probably Songs Of Praise with my old mum, in the mid-80s. Always reminds me of her. No, she wasn't particularly religious, but she refused to watch ITV. Cake shows? Are there any?? Yeah, bit of cookery - Two Fat Ladies, I got their book from the bookshop - but well, if the country has to be told how to boil an egg like Delia thinks they do, then I've given up hope. I'm retiring soon anyway."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Stagecoach/Ocean's Eleven/Point Blank/Carla's Song
fields.body:
Stagecoach

(John Ford, 1939)

8.30am, Carlton Cinema

The plot rolls along as fast as the wagon wheels: a motley bunch of characters, including Claire Trevor's hooker-with-a-heart, Oscar-winning Thomas Mitchell's drunken doc, and John Carradine's Southern gambler, on a hazardous journey through Apache country. Social tensions mount, and the Injuns attack like dervishes. Luckily for the travellers, the Ringo Kid is on board, John Wayne taking his first long strides as a western legend, appropriately enough in the genre's true home, the monolithic Monument Valley.

Ocean's Eleven

(Lewis Milestone, 1960)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Massive rat pack caper movie in which Frankie goes to Vegas to knock off five casinos with 10 of his pals: Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr and Angie Dickinson all included. Of course, with all these highly organised heists, things never quite go according to plan, but that's half the fun.

Point Blank

(John Boorman, 1967)

11.15pm, TCM

Boorman's first Hollywood venture is a thriller lean and hard as its star, Lee Marvin. His Walker is an old-school crook, double-crossed by partner Reese (John Vernon) and left for dead on Alcatraz, but returning to seek vengeance and the loot from the Organisation. He moves through a gleaming bright LA, shadow-like in dark suit, implacable and coldly violent.

Carla's Song

(Ken Loach, 1996)

12.20am, FilmFour

This bittersweet cross-cultural romance works better in the first half, when chirpy Glasgow bus driver Robert Carlyle is wooing beautiful Nicaraguan refugee Oyanka Cabezas on home territory. The shift into violent central America leaves Carlyle with nothing much to do but observe the troubles pointed out by human rights worker Scott Glen, while the engaging romance gets overpowered. But none the less it's typically intelligent and committed film-making from Loach.

fields.headline: C&W opens web centre
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless's chief executive, Graham Wallace, yesterday opened the company's largest European data and web hosting centre - based in Swindon.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless's chief executive, Graham Wallace, yesterday opened the company's largest European data and web hosting centre - based in Swindon.

Mr Wallace said the global telecoms group, which provides data, internet and voice services to the business sector, was aiming for 20 hosting centres globally by 2002.

He said: "Revenues are modest at the moment but I expect in five years there will be hundreds of millions of pounds in revenue."

The web hosting market is predicted to rise from today's $3bn (£1.9bn) a year to $23bn by 2002, according to market research analyst Forrester.

Cable & Wireless is investing $2.5bn in extending its global internet protocol network and building the data and web hosting centres in the next few years.

The Swindon centre has Xerox as an anchor client and will house the development of Cable & Wireless's application service provider products which it is working on with Microsoft and Compaq.

The centre will be the development and support site for Cable & Wireless's proposed mobile internet platform which will bring together software applications for mobile devices, including information services such as news and weather, across Europe.

Cable & Wireless is working with Nokia on that venture.

Mr Wallace said he expected the Swindon centre to be operating at full capacity within 12 months.

webTitle: Lips sealed over costly euro error

fields.headline: Lips sealed over costly euro error
fields.trailText: It may be an extra squiggle. It could be a wrongly coloured dot or a mistakenly angled line. The men and women who knew were last night refusing to say.
fields.body:
It may be an extra squiggle. It could be a wrongly coloured dot or a mistakenly angled line. The men and women who knew were last night refusing to say.

But the result was that a tiny printing error had nullified millions of €100 notes now in production in Euroland's biggest economy, Germany.

The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reported that the mistake would cost at least 65m marks (£20m) and could mean the loss of six months' production. It said 325m new bills were affected by what the European Central Bank called a "slight visual deviation".

A spokesman at the ECB in Frankfurt refused yesterday to confirm or deny the figures on security grounds. But, he added, "I could laugh if it weren't so tragic".

Each of the countries taking part in the single currency is responsible for minting and printing as many euros as it reckons will be needed to cover its own initial requirements. The money will soon find its way to other parts of Euroland, however, so every country's output has to be identical - otherwise counterfeiters will have new room for manouevre.

The problem arose in a run of notes produced for the ECB by a Munich firm, Giesecke & Devrient. A spokeswoman said the printing company had an order to print half of all the euro notes for Germany.

The Frankfurter Allgemeine said the problem was linked to a security feature, known as the Omron effect, developed in Japan. The feature was designed to prevent the reproduction of banknotes using colour photocopiers, the paper said. The printing firm seemed to indicate security features were not involved.

Giesecke & Devrient's spokeswoman said: "If the ECB decides to give back the notes, it is no problem. We can redo them on time and in sufficient quantities, so there is no question of the euro not coming out on time in Germany."

Neither the company nor the bank, though, were willing to discuss who would pay for a new run of notes.

webTitle: Elf spent $60m a year on bribes, investigators told

fields.headline: Elf spent $60m a year on bribes, investigators told
fields.trailText: France's biggest postwar corruption scandal yesterday threatened to discredit scores of leading politicians at home and abroad after it was revealed that the state-owned oil company, Elf, had spent around $60m a year in bribes.
fields.body:
France's biggest postwar corruption scandal yesterday threatened to discredit scores of leading politicians at home and abroad after it was revealed that the state-owned oil company, Elf, had spent around $60m a year in bribes.

Details of worldwide fraud involving presidents, ministers and royalty were given by André Tarallo, 70, who formerly managed the company's African affairs. His evidence came three years after he was released on bail under suspicion of corruption.

The inquiry, started four years ago, has already resulted in preliminary charges against the company's former boss, Loik Le Floch-Prigent, and the socialist former foreign minister, Roland Dumas. But at least another 40 people, mostly in the entourages of the late president, François Mitterrand, and Gaullist former interior minister Charles Pasqua, are also under suspicion.

Judicial sources indicated yesterday that Mr Tarallo decided to give details of the fraud after he failed in his effort to win protection from well-placed political allies.

A judicial source described Mr Tarallo as "the living memory of the firm".

"With his evidence, we have reached the last stage of this inquiry in which Mr Tarallo could name the domestic politicians who benefited from the fraud," the judicial source said. "He's been thinking things over for quite some time and he seems to have made the only choice possible and reveal all."

Official accounts of his last interrogation on June 27 showed that Mr Tarallo spoke for the first time of an automatic deduction of 40 US cents a barrel for a slush fund kept in Liechtenstein by Elf. The company has since merged with TotalFina.

On average, $60m a year had been distributed for 20 years to buy influence from foreign and domestic politicians. According to Mr Tarallo, money transfers were personally approved by Mr Mitterrand.

In effect, Elf's forecourt customers unwittingly contributed the equivalent of a 2% tax on every litre of fuel to the slush fund, described by Mr Tarallo as "part of a long tradition which gave entire satisfaction to the beneficiaries as far as secrecy was concerned".

"The list of beneficiaries was drawn up by the petrol producing countries and included heads of state, ministers and reigning families," he added. "The system was operated for all oil producing countries except those in the OECD. The Russian situation was particularly complex but the commissions that went to political leaders were very important."

In Africa, the biggest share of high-level kickbacks, described as "subscriptions" by Mr Tarallo, went to Gabon, followed by Angola, Nigeria, the Congo and Cameroon. In the case of Angola, the bribes ensured French oil concessions in the face of US competition.

"The undercover financing system always operated under the direct control of the chairman," Mr Tarallo said, an allegation that throws suspicion on some retired executives.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: An interesting fact about bananas. The curvy yellow fruit - which prompted a trade war between the superpowers last year - accounts for 1% of a superstore's sales.
fields.body:
An interesting fact about bananas. The curvy yellow fruit - which prompted a trade war between the superpowers last year - accounts for 1% of a superstore's sales.

So a ploy by Safeway to chop the price of a pound of bananas from 49p to 29p could have a profound effect on sales.

Simon Laffin, the finance director who is shortly to spend three months managing a store, believes sales of bananas might double overnight as result of the discounting.

Some promotions - on Kellogs cornflakes or Nescafé, for example - can lead to a 40-fold increase in sales.

Fascinating stuff, which might appear to suggest that at certain times of the week Safeway should become a banana, cornflake or coffee store and not bother to stock hundreds of items.

The flaw with the idea is that the chain already appears to be boosting its overall sales by running heavily discounted price deals on targeted items, advertised on leaflets pushed through letterboxes close to its stores.

Mr Laffin argues this is why sales volume is up by 11%, compared with a sector average of 1%. It also supports his claim that 1m more customers are shopping at Safeway each week than this time last year.

This is despite the decision to ditch its ABC loyalty card.

Because each promotion is targeted locally, Safeway believes it is difficult for its rivals to undercut the offers on a national basis. Local rivals appear able to do little more than watch out for trucks of bananas or coffee.

The effect on overall prices has been a fall of 6.1% although Mr Laffin insists that profits margins are holding steady. He boasts that profits are growing again and in the first quarter are ahead of last year.

The big challenge for Safeway now is to keep the sales volume growing. The cutprice strategy was initiated by the new chief executive, Carlos Criado-Perez. His ambition is to get Safeway profits back to their peak through stronger sales.

Although the shares have put on more than a £1 since March - and closed yesterday at 279.5p - they might yet be worth buying.

webTitle: AT&T chief strikes discordant note about Concert

fields.headline: AT&T chief strikes discordant note about Concert
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Armstrong, chairman and chief executive of AT&T, said yesterday that there were no plans to float Concert, its joint venture with BT which provides international voice and data links for big business.
fields.body:
Michael Armstrong, chairman and chief executive of AT&T, said yesterday that there were no plans to float Concert, its joint venture with BT which provides international voice and data links for big business.

The comments came amid signs of tension between the two companies over the future direction of the joint venture. They also came at the same time as the wireless divisions of AT&T and BT announced a new global roaming service.

Speaking after a conference in Japan, Mr Armstrong said he knew "nothing about a flotation plan". He then added in an interview with Reuters that "British Telecom and AT&T have no plan at this time" to float Concert. The comments were subsequently repeated in a statement from AT&T head office in New York.

Mr Armstrong's statement appears to contradict recent comments by BT. After weekend reports of a $30bn flotation plan, BT said that it was keeping the issue under review and had not ruled it out.

In spite of this apparent con tradiction, he denied any tension between the two partners.

The speculation about Concert, which provides connections in 49 countries, has developed following BT's announcement in April that it intended to split its activities into separate divisions - and would sell share stakes in some of them.

Both companies were yesterday keen to praise the first fruits of their global wireless venture, Advance. Its new roaming service will allow customers to use the same phone number in more than 100 countries throughout the Americas, Europe and Asia. In particular it will allow roaming between the GSM and TDMA mobile phone systems used on opposite sides of the Atlantic.

Meanwhile, AT&T has accused Bell Atlantic, the New York phone company, of breaking the law by steering clients to its own new long-distance service.

AT&T has filed a formal complaint to the US telecoms regulator, the Federal Communications Commission, in an attempt to stop Bell At lantic from marketing its long-distance services, which would compete with AT&T.

AT&T's monopoly of the US phone system was broken up by the courts in the 1980s, but since then the competitive landscape has changed.

Long-distance traffic, then a moneyspinner, is now a low-margin, highly competitive business - but this is the first time AT&T has issued legal proceedings in its increasingly acrimonious battle against its rivals.

webTitle: Marshall made to say sorry for Ayling pay-off

fields.headline: Marshall made to say sorry for Ayling pay-off
fields.trailText: Lord Marshall, chairman of British Airways, was booed by shareholders yesterday after admitting that the company had made a mistake in allowing its chief executive, Bob Ayling, to walk away with a package worth £5m when he was sacked earlier this year.
fields.body:
Lord Marshall, chairman of British Airways, was booed by shareholders yesterday after admitting that the company had made a mistake in allowing its chief executive, Bob Ayling, to walk away with a package worth £5m when he was sacked earlier this year.

Amid cries of "rubbish" and "shame" from a packed audience at the Barbican Centre in the City of London, Lord Marshall said that BA's settlement with Mr Ayling would be reviewed and that the company would take steps to see that a similar situation did not happen again.

The new chairman of BA's remuneration committee, Logica chief executive Martin Read, is to examine the contracts of all board members and will rule out the two-year rolling contract enjoyed by Mr Ayling.

That contract allowed Mr Ayling to obtain an immediate pay-off of almost £2m plus a pension of £260,000 starting from last May and payable for the rest of his life. The deal is described in BA's report as "a special non-pensionable payment of remuneration and damages for breach of contract".

Lord Marshall admitted that Mr Ayling had been legally entitled to a bigger settlement but it was not pressed. The deal includes unlimited free travel for Mr Ayling and his family.

Company sources said later that the deal with Mr Ayling was legally watertight and that there was nothing BA could do to unstitch it.

At one stage during the meeting, Lord Marshall dodged a question from one shareholder suggesting that the responsibility for BA's disastrous recent performance lay with Lord Marshall and other board members as well as Mr Ayling.

After the meeting he conceded the point, but walked away as he was asked if he thought he should resign as well. In spite of BA's appalling results, he had been able to promise shareholders that they would receive a dividend of 17.9p a share, the same as last year.

Lord Marshall had been forced to rewrite his speech in response to a threat from Standard Life, a shareholder with 2.3% of the airline, that it would vote against the Ayling package. He agreed to say that BA had blundered, in return for which Standard Life abstained.

He told shareholders: "The final payout to Mr Ayling is a large one. I accept that. Employee morale deteriorated. However, my board is mindful of and is sensitive to the views expressed by shareholders.

"It has decided to review carefully the process it followed in reaching its settlement with Mr Ayling to see what lessons can be learned for the future, and to satisfy itself that there is nothing further can be done in respect of that settlement."

He said pension contracts were less generous at BA than when Mr Ayling's contract was agreed and the issue would not come up again.

In his first speech since his appointment, BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, warned of the threat to the airline of fast trains in Europe, particularly to Paris and Brussels. He also highlighted the threat from low-cost airlines, saying that BA must adjust its short-haul business.

He avoided mentioning job cuts, although these are inevitable, particularly if the proposed merger with the Dutch airline KLM goes ahead.

At one stage during the meeting, Lord Marshall dodged a question from one shareholder suggesting that the responsibility for BA's disastrous recent performance lay with Lord Marshall and other board members as well as Mr Ayling. After the meeting he conceded the point, but walked away as he was asked if he thought he should resign as well. In spite of BA's appalling results, he had been able to promise shareholders that they would receive a dividend of 17.9p a share, the same as last year. Lord Marshall had been forced to rewrite his speech in response to a threat from Standard Life, a shareholder with 2.3% of the airline, that it would vote against the Ayling package. He agreed to say that BA had blundered, in return for which Standard Life abstained. He told shareholders: "The final payout to Mr Ayling is a large one. I accept that. Employee morale deteriorated. However, my board is mindful of and is sensitive to the views expressed by shareholders. "It has decided to review carefully the process it followed in reaching its settlement with Mr Ayling to see what lessons can be learned for the future, and to satisfy itself that there is nothing further can be done in respect of that settlement." He said pension contracts were less generous at BA than when Mr Ayling's contract was agreed and the issue would not come up again. In his first speech since his appointment, BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, warned of the threat to the airline of fast trains in Europe, particularly to Paris and Brussels. He also highlighted the threat from low-cost airlines, saying that BA must adjust its short-haul business. He avoided mentioning job cuts, although these are inevitable, particularly if the proposed merger with the Dutch airline KLM goes ahead.

fields.headline: Unilever sells bakery supplier
fields.trailText: The great sell-off of Unilever's "non-core" brands brought £450m into the Anglo-Dutch group's coffers yesterday.
fields.body:
The great sell-off of Unilever's "non-core" brands brought £450m into the Anglo-Dutch group's coffers yesterday.

The consumer products group sold its European bakery supplies business to food products and ingredients company CSM of Amsterdam.

Unilever's reorganisation, outlined in February, aims to increase sales growth and margins by concentrating on the top 400 brands and selling marginal ones.

Despite the strategy, Unilever has actually spent much of this year in an acquisitive mode. Last month it announced the takeover of Bestfoods, the US maker of Knorr soups and Hellmann's mayonnaise, for $20.3bn (£13.4bn). Earlier Unilever acquired Ben & Jerry's and SlimFast Foods.

The European bakeries supplies business operates in 13 countries and employs 3,900 people. Last year it had an operating profit of around £90m.

Unilever's shares closed unchanged at 403.25p.

fields.headline: Commission's euro pamphlet taunts Tories
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The European Commission will today enrage British Conservatives when it publishes a pamphlet condemning 25 years of "wilful" distortion by British Euro-sceptics.
fields.body:
The European Commission will today enrage British Conservatives when it publishes a pamphlet condemning 25 years of "wilful" distortion by British Euro-sceptics.

Geoffrey Martin, head of the commission's representation in the UK, will attack on "the constant bombardment and misrepresentation by the British press and Euro-sceptics".

He will claim: "The destructive impact of 25 years of distorted accounts pervades every aspect of the British attitude to Europe. It has left many people with a mindset about Europe based on wilful misrepresentation of its purpose and how it works.

"These distortions have infected perceptions of the EU well beyond the sceptic press, as national and indeed international media fall into the trap of looking at Europe through a lens twisted by the sceptic vision."

Given the constant bombardment of Euro-sceptic bias, Mr Martin admits, "it is all too easy to understand why people begin to fall for some of these ideas".

The glossy 46-page pamphlet entitled "a glossary of Euro-sceptic beliefs" is to be distributed throughout Britain, including opinion formers and libraries. Fifteen thousand copies have been printed at a cost of £11,000.

Attempting to deal with some of the most common British fears of the EU, the pamphlet denies that unaccountable bankers in Frankfurt have far too much power. It claims that "the European central bank is politically accountable to the European parliament and to EU governments through the finance ministers".

It also insists that the euro has proved a success with the markets.

The pamphlet concedes that the euro means "at some time in some country monetary policy will not be as closely aligned with national needs as if the policy was set nationally". But countries concluded that the benefits of membership outweighed the costs.

The pamphlet also denies that unelected bureaucrats in Brussels dominate EU decision making pointing out that only 10% of measures come from the commission.

Any suggestion that the EU is bent on a crude attempt to create a superstate is also dismissed by the pamphlet.

It states instead: "Political union is a process of gradual integration with the countries taking part in the EU co-operating in an increasingly varied number of ways." Any suggestion that Europe wants Britain to fight under the European flag is also rejected: "British troops are not being dragooned into some single force to fight under the European flag".

The report admits that the common agricultural policy is one of the most controversial of EU policies, but claims there is a clear shift in the CAP towards a greater emphasis on rural development, food safety and quality.

It criticises as anti-Europe opinion formers journalists Christopher Booker in the Daily Mail and Richard Littlejohn in the Sun, Bernard Connolly, the former EU official, and economist Tim Congdon.

The pamplet was attacked yesterday by Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, as "another disturbing sign of the European Commission spending tax payers money to peddle propaganda rather than information".

He said he was already lobbying peers to press them to tighten up the rules on commission and government propaganda on Europe.

Mr Herbert said that the peers urgently needed to amend the political parties and referendums bill so as to block commission propaganda in the run-up to any referendum on the euro.

webTitle: $5m advance for GE years of Jack Welch

fields.headline: $5m advance for GE years of Jack Welch
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: After more than 40 years with one company and 20 as its boss, Jack Welch is preparing for a new career: record-breaking author.
fields.body:
After more than 40 years with one company and 20 as its boss, Jack Welch is preparing for a new career: record-breaking author.

Mr Welch is expected to receive an advance of more than $5m (£3m) for a planned book on the lessons learned during his time at General Electric, the American conglomerate.

The record-breaking sum was the result of fierce bidding by rival publishers in New York. Few books, let alone business books, attract such large advances.

Mr Welch, 64, is set to retire next April. His literary debut, described as more management guide than memoir, will be published later in 2001.

A spokesman for GE said Mr Welch, who earned $93.1m last year as chairman and chief executive, will give the proceeds of the book to charity.

Mr Welch became one of the most widely followed managers by preaching a strategy of always aiming for the number one or two slot in any market and for global reach. He is held in wide esteem for his management of a disparate empire which extends from machine tools to the NBC television channel and GE Capital, a financial services group.

The company, which posted revenues of $11.6bn last year, has the highest market capitalisation in the world.

Mr Welch has been one of the most aggressive chief executives of a traditional business in recognising the threat and opportunity of the internet. Under a strategy dubbed dyb.com or destroy-your-business.com, his managers were forced to become more webcentric.

Last year, Mr Welch was voted manager of the century by Fortune magazine. A Guardian poll of chief executives last year rated him the best ever.

Mark Reiter, Mr Welch's literary agent, said the as-yet-untitled book would be "about the lessons he's learned along the way, managing GE". Mr Welsh will collaborate with John Byrne, a senior writer at Business Week.

fields.headline: Wedding isle memento for Gates
fields.trailText: Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has decided that he likes the Hawaiian island where he was married so much he wants to own part of it. Mr Gates has bought 6.3% of the property company that owns Lanai, where he tied the knot with Melinda.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Anne Hyland
fields.body:
Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has decided that he likes the Hawaiian island where he was married so much he wants to own part of it. Mr Gates has bought 6.3% of the property company that owns Lanai, where he tied the knot with Melinda.

The regulatory filing relating to the acquisition by Cascade, Mr Gates' private investment company, yesterday did not reveal financial details of the stake in Castle & Cooke, the property group. However, with shares in the company up a slightly at around $19.5 yesterday, the purchase could have cost about $19m (£12.5m).

Some Wall Street analysts suggested the purchase of the stake in Castle & Cooke could be a prelude to the outright purchase of Lanai. The portfolio the property company owns includes other resorts throughout America as well as in Hawaii.

Cascade, which is run as an entirely separate business from Microsoft, has made no comment about its purchase of the stake in the property company.

Mr Gates, who owns about 15% of Microsoft, has made hundreds of investments through Cascade in recent years.

In a separate development yesterday, Cascade was part of a group of investors to commit $1bn to ICO-Teledesic Global, the satellite concern founded by Craig McCaw, the US telecoms investor.

Mr Gates, who was one of ICO-Teledesic's two founding investors in 1994, has agreed to invest a further $100m in the company through Cascade.

Private equity firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice will also invest $150m in the project and has an option to provide a further $200m at a later date.

ICO-Teledesic also received a $500m fillip from Eagle River Investments LLC, McCaw's private investment company. This $500m was part of the previously announced $1.2bn McCaw-led financial restructuring of London-based New ICO.

ICO-Teledesic plans to launch some 288 low-orbit satellites to support millions of two-way connections that provide a high-speed data network which would operate about 2,000 times faster than standard modems.

The intention is for ICO-Teledesic to offer "very high speed" access to the internet by 2003.

Its success in attracting further investment comes after the other global satellite concerns have suffered serious financial difficulty.

webTitle: Cancel the pre-election spree, say farmers and steel users

fields.headline: Cancel the pre-election spree, say farmers and steel users
fields.trailText: Britain's farmers yesterday forged an unprecedented alliance with the country's leading steel users to urge the chancellor to forswear a pre-election spending spree in favour of a £12bn boost to capital programmes.
fields.body:
Britain's farmers yesterday forged an unprecedented alliance with the country's leading steel users to urge the chancellor to forswear a pre-election spending spree in favour of a £12bn boost to capital programmes.

The National Farmers Union joined forces with engineering employers (EEF), the UK Steel Association, aerospace companies (SBAC) and machine tool groups (MTTA) to call on Gordon Brown to begin rebalancing the economy in next week's spending review.

The five bodies, representing around a fifth of the British economy, said the fiscal loosening in Mr Brown's last Budget had damaged the traded sector by pushing up interest rates and the pound - and squeezing investment and output.

They demanded a £12bn switch from current to capital spending and/or the introduction of 100% capital allowances - equivalent to a 1.5% shift in GDP or a £10.5bn cut in departments' spending programmes in the run-up to the general election.

A report for the alliance by consultancy Oxford Economic Forecasting, using both its own and the Treasury models, showed that this policy change would increase investment and productivity in the next four years without creating inflationary pressures, and allow the traded sector to grow at the expense of services.

Richard Macdonald, NFU director general, said: "The reason why farmers and metal-bashers are working together illustrates the feeling of crisis affecting our industries."

Mike Legg, MTTA president, said: "There's never been a better time for government to come out and say we must improve productivity and the way to do it is through investment."

Mr Macdonald said agriculture in the past four years had seen prices decrease by 31%, output by 20%, farm incomes by 61% in real terms and investment by 40% while the pound had risen 37%.

The pound's strength has cut the value of each tonne of steel exported from £410 in 1996 to £300 last year. In the first quarter of this year EU steel consumption rose by 7.1% but Britain's share of exports to the EU fell by 8.9% compared with a 50% rise for Germany.

The five bodies claimed their policies would benefit the whole economy.

According to the OEF report, a government switch to capital spending would boost GDP by 0.5%, amounting to $5bn (£3bn) over four years, manufacturing investment by 3%, productivity by 0.4% and bring a 0.5% decline in the real exchange rate.

The analysis says that the granting of 100% capital allowances would see the real value of sterling fall by more than 4% and base rates by 0.8% while GDP would rise 0.8%, investment by 2% and productivity by 0.6%.
