fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Roche caught up in EC inquiry
fields.body:
Roche caught up in EC inquiry

The European commission has sent legal warnings to 13 vitamin producers, including leading European companies such as Roche and BASF, implicated in an alleged price-fixing cartel, Roche admitted yesterday.

"This investigation concerns the same vitamin cartel case which was investigated and concluded in 1999 with the US and Canadian authorities."

The formal warning of legal proceedings can lead to fines. The companies targeted will have time to give their version of events, and may demand a hearing before the commission takes a final decision. Firms found guilty of anti-competitive practices can be fined up to 10% of annual sales, although such a large fine has never been levied.

Exchange asks for approval

The board of the London stock exchange yesterday put the final touches to documentation to be sent to its members to win support for its controversial merger with German rivals. The same process will be conducted at the Frankfurt-based Deutsche Börse today.

The report is expected to say savings and strategic benefits will quickly outweigh initial costs.

House price optimism

House prices will remain firm for the rest of 2000, with the north and the Midlands notching up significant gains, Nationwide building society forecast yesterday, in contrast to a downbeat report from Halifax last week.

It believes that average house prices will rise 14% during 2000, after a 13.3% rise in 1999. The Halifax index is showing an annualised rise for 2000 of 11%, but last week said that prices are likely to remain flat for the rest of this year.

Grid continues options talks

Last-ditch negotiations between the National Association of Pension Funds and National Grid were taking place last night in attempt by the company to try to win the backing of the influential pensions group for a controversial options scheme for senior executives which ditches performance criteria.

However, the NAPF appeared unlikely to abandon the decision in its draft report that shareholders should vote against the option package.

New pension explained

The individual pension account (Ipa), which offers the tax breaks of traditional pensions plus the flexibility and low charges of equity Isas, was announced by the government yesterday.

Ipas, which use collective investments such as unit trusts, will be available from April 2001 to stakeholder pensions, personal pensions and money purchase occupational schemes.

fields.headline: BP Amoco opens cash tap
fields.standfirst: Crude hits record level so group decides to end era of austerity
fields.trailText: BP Amoco yesterday turned its back on two years of cost-cutting and restructuring by announcing plans to increase capital spending and take advantage of oil prices at a nine-year high.
fields.body:
BP Amoco yesterday turned its back on two years of cost-cutting and restructuring by announcing plans to increase capital spending and take advantage of oil prices at a nine-year high.

The chief executive, Sir John Browne, told the company's annual strategy meeting he would raise spending to $13.5bn annually over the next three years from $12bn now.

He plans to increase oil output by up to 5% a year and gas by up to 10% but will offload $1.5bn of assets. Most of the disposals will come from Amoco, Arco and Burmah Castrol which were bought over a two-year period for $80bn when they were going cheap due to lower crude prices.

Renewable energy expenditure will double to $500m a year but the bulk of the investment will reinforce BP Amoco's position as a traditional oil and gas group.

Much of the cash will be concentrated on high-return projects such as gas production in Trinidad and oil production in the US Gulf where it has new finds such as Crazy Horse.

Sir John said the extra spend, which excluded acquisitions, would be accompanied by a continuing focus on unit costs and enhanced productivity from existing assets.

"Let me be clear, there is no question of us taking a pause in earnings growth while we go through an investment phase. We will work our existing assets as well as the new ones so that the new level of performance can be achieved without any such pause."

BP Amoco has raised its estimates for crude prices from $14 per barrel to $16 although upstream schemes will be tested at the existing $11. The new estimates will increase the amount of excess cash available for BP Amoco to distribute to investors by way of share buybacks or dividend payments.

Sir John said the BP name would gradually be used in place of BP Amoco.

The City gave the spending plans the thumbs-up and the shares rose 12p to 627p.

Peter Nicol, energy analyst with ABN Amro, said the company had come through a remarkable transformation from "just a boring old oil company".

He added: "Not many companies would be capable of consolidating the takeover of three or four other companies while producing record earnings at the same time."

fields.headline: Big gaps on the issues - but room for hope too
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The battle of wills that commenced yesterday between Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak will be conducted on exhaustively examined terrain. Before departing for the summit, both leaders set out their positions - or "red lines" in Israeli parlance - with unusual clarity. On the face of it, they seem hopelessly far apart after seven years of stuttering negotiations.
fields.body:
The battle of wills that commenced yesterday between Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak will be conducted on exhaustively examined terrain. Before departing for the summit, both leaders set out their positions - or "red lines" in Israeli parlance - with unusual clarity. On the face of it, they seem hopelessly far apart after seven years of stuttering negotiations.

 The starting point

For the Palestinians,Yasser Arafat wants a commitment that Israel will recognise the state he has pledged to declare on September 13, or some time later this year. The date marks seven years to the day since President Clinton tugged his arm towards that historic handshake with the assassinated Israeli prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, on the White House lawn.

If Mr Arafat declares a state unilaterally, Israel says it would annex large chunks of territory.

So far, Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority has full sove reignty in 40% of the West Bank - but with Israel controlling all main roads, his domain is a string of islands.

The fear is that the new state will be born in blood if the talks fail and Mr Arafat makes a unilateral declaration. Israeli security officials been issuing dire warnings about huge stockpiles of arms in Palestinian areas.

The Israeli prime minister's vision of the future is of a complete separation between Arab and Jew, with the two peoples fenced into their respective enclaves. He calls this security. Israeli peace activists call it apartheid.

The two sides also expect others to sweeten any deal. For Mr Barak, that means new arms and missile-busting radar from the US. Mr Arafat's chief economic adviser spoke last week of a $40bn (£26bn) package for the Arab side, much of it to compensate refugees.

 Territory

Abandoned by his coalition partners who accuse him of making dangerous territorial concessions, Mr Barak has vowed that there will be no return to the pre-1967 borders, before the Jewish state took east Jerusalem and the West Bank from Jordan.

Mr Arafat is insisting that Israel return all lands occupied since the 1967 war. Even so, this is a considerable compromise: Gaza and the West Bank make up only 22% of mandate Palestine; he gave up claims to Israel proper when the peace process began.

Possible solutions: Despite the rhetoric, there has been a great deal of progress at talks in Sweden earlier this year. The prospects for a deal now hinge on exchanges of territory in Israel proper for settlements in the boundaries of the Palestinian state. Israel appears willing to cede up to 92% of the West Bank.

 Settlements

Discussion on territory is hopelessly entangled with the future of some 145 Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. Since 1967, nearly 200,000 Jewish colonisers moved into these two areas.

The Israeli leader has promised to safeguard the majority of the settlers - but not all. As many as 40,000 settlers may have to move to Israel proper, or live under Palestinian rule. Smaller settlements would go, particularly in the Jordan Valley, but three large blocs would stay.

 Security

Israel's security demands are the stuff of science fiction. Mr Barak hopes to encircle the Palestinian state - even from below. Already, tunnelers are at work beneath the Mount of Olives so Jewish settlers can go from the Maale Adumim to the Hebrew University at Mount Scopus. An elevated highway is envisaged linking the West Bank and Gaza.

Mr Arafat hopes to negotiate a Palestinian state with borders. He wants Israeli troops out of Gaza's airport.

Possible solution: Despite official assertions,Israel is prepared to phase out its presence in the Jordan Valley, perhaps after leasing the land from the Palestinians. It is also reconciled to the evacuation of settlements in the Jordan Valley.

The fate of the holy city is so contentious that Mr Barak and Mr Arafat may decide to ignore it for now.

The Israeli leader refuses to contemplate its division. The Palestinians have a toehold in Abu Dis, the village straddling the city boundaries that is the site of a Palestinian parliament now under construction.

Possible solutions: Official leaks suggest Mr Barak would be happy to shed two Palestinian neighbourhoods in the north of the city - Shuafat and Beit Hanina.

 Refugees

The plight of some 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees in Jordan, driven out when Israel was created in 1948, is heart-wrenching.

Israel flat out refuses to recognise the Palestinian right of return endorsed by UN resolutions, or to accept moral and legal responsibility for their suffering.

The Palestinians say Israel must accept responsibility for the expulsions and allow the refugees to go home.

Possible solutions: Japan, Europe, and the US could contribute to a fund to help the PA handle some 500,000 returnees over two decades, or compensate those who choose not to go back to their original homes.

fields.headline: Clinton's last ditch peace bid
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Beset by ill omens on all sides, the 52-year Israeli-Palestinian conflict tentatively approached its endgame yesterday as the US president, Bill Clinton, launched negotiations between Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat at Camp David.
fields.body:
Beset by ill omens on all sides, the 52-year Israeli-Palestinian conflict tentatively approached its endgame yesterday as the US president, Bill Clinton, launched negotiations between Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat at Camp David.

Low, dark clouds gathered over the presidential retreat where the Middle East peace process began 22 years ago. Countless summits and conferences later, the fundamental, most visceral issues remain unresolved - the fate of 3m Palestinian refugees, the shape of a Palestinian state, and most intractable of all, sovereignty over Jerusalem.

There were few obvious reasons yesterday to believe that the divide could be closed in the coming week of final-settlement talks in Maryland -before President Clinton is due to fly to an economic summit in Japan - other than the clear possibility that failure could mean a resurgence of violence in the West Bank and Gaza.

Mr Barak arrived 12 hours late, having scraped through a vote of no-confidence in the Israeli knesset. A suspicious Mr Arafat only came after considerable US state department arm-twisting.

As he set off for the talks from the White House, President Clinton portrayed the summit as a pivotal moment, and said the "weight of history" hung heavily on the shoulders of both leaders.

"We have an opportunity to bring about a just and enduring end to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. That is the key to lasting peace in the entire Middle East. Of course, there is no guarantee of success, but not to try is to guarantee failure," Mr Clinton said.

The talks began with him holding separate meetings with Mr Barak and Mr Arafat, followed by plenary sessions, with both sides fielding 12-strong teams of negotiators.

This week's talks will cover the question of the right to return for the Palestinian diaspora, forced to flee their homes in the successive military defeats of 1948 and 1967. The most likely outcome, officials on both sides say, is some token returns of refugees to their pre-war homes, but with the great majority being financially compensated from an international fund.

The second major issue will be the extent of a Palestinian state and how much of the occupied West Bank will be annexed by Israel for settlers, but that, the diplomats say, is merely a matter of percentages and square miles, in which a compromise is quite possible.

The hardest issue will be Jerusalem, which both sides view as the spiritual core of their identity; there was no compromise in sight between Palestinian demands for a share of the city and its holy sites and the Israeli insistence that it remain the "eternal and undivided" capital of the Jewish state.

An Israeli official accompanying the delegation said that the attempt to unseat Mr Barak on the eve of his departure demonstrated his narrow room for manoeuvre, especially regarding Jerusalem.

The Palestinians, too, know that excessive compromise will carry a heavy price. "The Palestinian mood is more volatile even than the Israelis," one official said. "If we come back with the wrong settlement the explosion will be worse than if we came back with no settlement at all."

fields.headline: Zimbabwe, the success story
fields.standfirst:
Its race relations are good, its judiciary unbowed, its civil society vibrant. Its leaders are a problem though

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Now that the furore over Zimbabwe's election has abated, let's draw a deep breath and admit it. Zimbabwe is an African good-news story.
fields.body:
Now that the furore over Zimbabwe's election has abated, let's draw a deep breath and admit it. Zimbabwe is an African good-news story.

The country has a literacy rate of around 90%, one of the highest on the continent. Its race relations are excellent. The attempt to fan black hostility against white farmers during the election campaign was a failure, and a European can move comfortably around in Harare's African townships or the so-called communal areas where most rural Africans live without hassle or fear.

The political tension which once divided the country's two main ethnic groups, the Shona and the Ndebele, has almost disappeared. Zimbabwe's civil society is vibrant. A plethora of civic groups deal with issues from gender equality and human rights to job creation and poverty reduction.

Zimbabwe's judiciary is as firm and unbowed as it was during the colonial era. There are powerful trade unions and, though the ruling party maintains iron control over broadcasting and routinely rejects licences for independent radio stations, there is a thriving independent press.

The elections have given the country a two-party system with a strong opposition for the first time in its history. Zanu-PF's terminology may have an antiquated feel with its politburo, central committee, and comrades, but a series of government ministers and officials are welcoming the arrival of pluralism. Nathan Shamuyarira, Zanu-PF's secretary for information, expects it to "produce lively debates in parliament". This change of official tone has already had an effect on the state-owned media with unprecedented space suddenly being given to opposition views and criticism of the government.

Few other African states can rival Zimbabwe's natural advantages. It has a tourist potential which is bound to revive as the election images of intimidation fade. This year, too, the dams are full and the country is not going to starve, whatever Peter Hain may gloomily predict.

Still, there is a downside. Zimbabwe faces three major problems, and only one can plausibly be blamed on President Robert Mugabe. It is suffering from the Aids crisis more than almost any other country in Africa. About a quarter of the adult population, both rural and urban, is infected and 1,000 people are dying every week.

One key reason for Zimbabwe's vulnerability is the colonial system with its preference for migrant African labour. One of the last great crimes of the racist Ian Smith regime is the town of Chitungwiza, built 20 miles from Harare to keep the workforce well away from the European suburbs. The huge number of men forced to live on their own produces a sex industry and a climate ripe for Aids.

Controlling the disease is not helped by Zimbabwe's second strategic problem. It is an overwhelmingly patriarchal society, where women still curtsey to men. HIV-positive men go home to their villages and soon infect their wives. Only a massive expansion of sex education in schools and a shift in gender relations will have an impact.

The third difficulty is the weakness of the economy in the face of global tendencies, including the ideological havoc caused by the first wave of neo-liberal thinking in the 90s. Zimbabwe began life as an independent state a decade earlier. The massive spending on health and education in the 80s resulted in a high budget deficit, which was not helped by lower than expected foreign investment and poor prices for export commodities. This was not a case of government mismanagement but of adverse factors beyond its control.

In 1991 the government accepted an IMF structural adjustment programme which devalued the Zimbabwean dollar, opened the way to more imports, and cut the government deficit by charging for welfare services, including schools and medicine. The infant mortality rate in Harare shot up from 23.6 per 1,000 live births in 1989 to 43.2 in 1992.

The economy's liberalisation did not attract the new investment the IMF predicted. In the mid-90s, the IMF and World Bank shifted their emphasis to poverty reduction and sustainability. But in Zimbabwe the damage was done and the Zanu-PF government reacted with a volatile love-hate approach to the international financial institutions.

The crisis over white-owned land is the climax of these frustrations. But, as many Zimbabwean NGO experts on land reform point out, the government's plans are dominated by statist thinking.

Therein lies Zimbabwe's current tragedy. It is run by a generation of elderly men who have not been able to move on from the liberation struggle. Challenged for power, they fall back on a single issue, and increasingly on racism. The intimidation in the latest elections was the reflex defence of people threatened by loss of power and too inflexible to find ways of achieving consent through dialogue and compromise.

But Zimbabwe is in transition to a new generation, a new style of government, and perhaps in two years' time to a president from a new party. Coupled with its many inherent advantages, this is a story of African success.

webTitle: 250 feared dead after Nigerian pipeline explodes

fields.headline: 250 feared dead after Nigerian pipeline explodes
fields.trailText: As many as 250 people were believed to have been killed when a vandalised petrol pipeline exploded into flames in southern Nigeria, witnesses said yesterday.
fields.body:
As many as 250 people were believed to have been killed when a vandalised petrol pipeline exploded into flames in southern Nigeria, witnesses said yesterday.

A reporter for the Lagos newspaper the Daily Times, Sola Adebayo, said he counted 100 charred bodies, many of them young children wearing school uniforms.

The blast occurred early on Monday morning outside the villages of Adeje and Oviri-Court, about 12 miles north of the port city of Warri in the oil-rich Niger delta.

The fire continued to rage yesterday and clouds of black smoke hung over the area, as state petroleum company workers and firefighters tried to bring the blaze under control.

Dan Akpele, a farmer near the village at Oviri-Court, said he heard a loud explosion and saw swarms of people running and screaming.

"There was total confusion. We were all shocked and confused," Mr Akpele said. "I just thank God all 13 of my children are safe."

Although no cause for the blaze has been given, witnesses said the pipeline had been punctured on Sunday night by local people who stole the petrol in buckets to sell by the roadside.

Explosions of this type on Nigeria's pipelines have become so common that fire crews did not arrive at the scene until 24 hours after the blast; normal practice is to shut down the supply of pe troleum to allow the fire to burn itself out.

"When we heard the explosion and saw the raging fire we considered it as normal because the breaking of pipelines and siphoning of fuel is happening all the time," said Monday Ochuko, who lives in Adeje.

"But when people started screaming we rushed there and saw the bodies," said Mr Ochuko, who added that he had taken his family to Warri for fear of a police swoop on suspected fuel thieves.

Industry officials say petrol theft has become such a booming business in southern Nigeria that some people now use road tankers.

"The tanker drivers puncture the pipeline and pump gasoline into their vehicles and then drive off, leaving fuel gushing out. Villagers then come in with their buckets and jerry cans," one official said.

The incident occurred close to the town of Jesse, where as many as 1,000 people died in a similar disaster in late 1998.

Some cases of sabotage are also carried out by militant activists trying to force the government and oil companies to give compensation to communities for land use and industrial pollution.

Nigeria is the world's sixth-largest oil exporter.

Sales of crude oil account for more than 80% of the government's revenue, and disruptions caused by sabotage are especially painful at a time when oil prices have risen dramatically from the lows of 1998.

fields.headline: Takeover halts Murdoch book
fields.trailText: A planned biography of Rupert Murdoch last night appeared to be the first victim of the takeover by his HarperCollins publishing company of its small but highly regarded rival, Fourth Estate.
fields.body:
A planned biography of Rupert Murdoch last night appeared to be the first victim of the takeover by his HarperCollins publishing company of its small but highly regarded rival, Fourth Estate.

The unauthorised book by Michael Crick on the Australian born media owner promised to shed light on the apparently unstoppable rise of Mr Murdoch - but will now not be published by the British company.

Mr Crick, best known for unearthing John Major's first love and tracing the long lost relatives of Lord Archer, received a six figure advance last year for the Murdoch book.

Mr Crick was unavailable for comment last night. But his wife - and his sometime researcher - said: "Both sides [Fourth Estate and Mr Crick] have agreed he cannot do the book and his agent is trying to reach some kind of settlement."

The takeover has sent shivers through Fourth Estate staff who remember the furore at HarperCollins over a planned book about Hong Kong by former governor Chris Patten. The book was dropped amid allegations that Mr Murdoch had personally forced HarperCollins to do so because it was critical of China, where the media baron was keen to do business. Victoria Barnsley, the founder of the London based independent Fourth Estate, yesterday sold the company for an estimated £12m to the US based group. She has been appointed chief executive of HarperCollins UK.

She dismissed the political implications of Mr Murdoch being the new owner and insisted no definite decision had been made on whether or not to go ahead with Mr Crick's book.

"I have spoken to Michael and I will be speaking to his agent again," she said. "It is difficult for him and we recognise there is a general conflict of interest."

The 36 staff at Fourth Estate are expected to move to HarperCollins' London base in Hammersmith. No significant redundancies are expected although Ms Barnsley refused to rule out job losses.

Fourth Estate was launched in 1984 and quickly built up an impressive reputation, bringing award winning authors such as Annie Proulx and Dava Sobel to a wider UK audience.

HarperCollins would not say how much it had paid for Fourth Estate, whose biggest shareholder was the Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper. But well placed sources confirmed the £12m figure and said Ms Barnsley held around a quarter of the shares.

The Fourth Estate founder said she was not motivated by personal financial gain. The decision to sell was taken unanimously by the executive directors.

HarperCollins was the most attractive of a number of offers. It was important that HarperCollins offered a big step into the US market, where Fourth Estate has no presence.

But well placed sources confirmed the £12m figure and said Ms Barnsley held around a quarter of the shares. The Fourth Estate founder said she was not motivated by personal financial gain. The decision to sell was taken unanimously by the executive directors. HarperCollins was the most attractive of a number of offers. It was important that HarperCollins offered a big step into the US market, where Fourth Estate has no presence.

webTitle: Unions hit back at retirement crackdown

fields.headline: Unions hit back at retirement crackdown
fields.standfirst: Anger over minister's accusations against public sector workers
fields.trailText: Anger over minister's accusations against public sector workers
fields.body:
Trade union leaders last night angrily hit back after the government announced a crackdown on the £1bn cost of sickness retirement among public sector employees, accusing ministers of unfairly attacking teachers, police officers and firefighters.

Union leaders claimed the government was using a "sledgehammer" approach to blame ordinary workers for the funding problems in the public sector after the chief secretary to the Treasury, Andrew Smith, published a report claiming workers in some public sector jobs are abusing the system and viewing sickness pensions almost as a right.

The report called on government departments to set out five year action plans by this October to cut back the "unacceptably high" numbers of early retirements due to ill-health in the public sector which cost the taxpayer £1bn a year in pensions.

Dave Prentis, the general secretary-elect of Unison, accused the government of "whipping up hysteria" over the report, which was a "slur" against his members.

A Treasury review found that although the numbers taking ill health retirement have fallen since a mid-1990s peak of 40,000 a year, the present figure of 22,000 a year was still one third higher than that in the private sector. The report also revealed that rates of early ill health retirement vary widely within the public sector, with 68% of firefighters taking early retirement compared with 49% of police officers and 25% of teachers.

Mr Smith set out 36 recommendations to ensure that only those employees incapable of working until normal pensionable age should qualify for early retirement. He said: "There's no question of victimising anybody, simply a question of following successful industrial relations practices so that we tackle incidences of ill health and don't let people get away with it if they are playing the system." Among recommendations to be implemented by government departments is for workers no longer able to carry out their current duties to be redeployed to less physically onerous desk jobs rather than take early retirement.

The report, which also called for more "rigorous" medical assessments to be carried out by two doctors, was greeted with anger by many public sector unions.

Dave Prentis, of Unison, said: "If there is abuse in the system, it should be dealt with. Those people who have been retired are not only the victims of stress, of violence or injury but now victims of a whispering campaign to portray them as swinging the lead."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the teachers' union NASUWT, pointed to the fact that the number of teachers taking ill health retirement had fallen from 4,400 in 1997 to 2,100 in 1999, adding: "Constant government reforms backed up by unrelenting pressure to improve results and cope with ever more disruptive pupils, inevitably results in some casualties.

"Denying even more sick teachers the right to a pension would be tantamount to shelling the lifeboats. What will the government do next? Carry sick teachers back on stretchers into the classrooms?"

A Fire Brigades Union official said: "Most firefighters who retire early would much rather continue working. It would be much better to tackle health and safety problems and under-funding of the service."

webTitle: 'Quitting early not the soft option it's cracked up to be'

fields.headline: 'Quitting early not the soft option it's cracked up to be'
fields.trailText: The teacher
fields.body:
The teacher

At 4.30am on May 14, 1996, Ingleby Kernaghan, a physics teacher at Sydenham high school, south east London, suffered a brain haemorrhage that left him unconscious in intensive care for four weeks. He returned to duty a year later, but struggled to cope and was advised by his doctor to apply for early retirement.

"I wasn't too hopeful ," he said. "A lot of my colleagues had been having terrible problems with the system. But I must have been a pretty desperate case because the teachers' pensions agency wrote to me two months later saying my application had been accepted. It couldn't have been simpler."

Despite his experience, Mr Kernaghan does not believe it is too easy to apply for early retirement, and argues that the present pension system actually penalises teachers who do not complete their contracts.

"Early retirement isn't the soft option it's cracked up to be. My income is a third of what it used to be, and I estimate that the decision to stop working has already cost me £100,000."

The policeman

West Midlands police inspector Ken Hawkins was knocked unconscious as he tried to arrest a drug dealer in 1997. Four youths dislocated his jaw and left him with severe whiplash and bruising. He was given two months sickness leave, but a few days later the headaches began, "an intense, burning pain that increased when pressure was put on my neck, and left me completely shattered".

He was offered desk work but the headaches worsened and in March 1998, aged 46, he applied for early retirement. Whilst Mr Hawkins' case was considered, he was suspended on full pay, but after six months this was reduced by 50%: "I have three children, and the financial pressure was enormous."

The chief constable was spearheading a campaign to reduce medical dismissals, and Mr Hawkins had increasing problems dealing with the force's personnel department.

"My consultant had to complete four different reports before they would believe I was actually sick." The retirement was not granted until October 1999, two and a half years after the original assault and 18 months after application.

"Anyone who thinks the system is too soft wants their head examining. Of course there are people who cheat the system, but a far greater number of people like me are having their lives ruined because it is already far too tough."

The firefighter

Phil Wright, a firefighter with West Yorkshire fire service, was told at a routine medical that the arthritis in his knees had deteriorated to a point where he was no longer fit for operational duties. Mr Wright, 53, had only a few years left on his contract, but his request for early retirement was refused by senior officers in 1997. They said he should continue working at Gipton fire station.

Although he is not one of the 68% of firefighters who take early retirement, Mr Wright is still a burden on the public purse. He is unable to continue active service, and spends his time doing maintenance work.

"I would be quite happy to take the pension now and do something useful with myself. But management policy makes that impossible. Instead, they are paying me a full firefighters' wage to do an odd job man's work."

webTitle: Orange protests bring more violence to Ulster

fields.headline: Orange protests bring more violence to Ulster
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orange Order supporters yesterday staged a second consecutive day of protests across Northern Ireland, blocking dozens of roads and again sending workers scurrying home.
fields.byline: John Mullin  in Belfast and  Jamie Wilson  in Portadown
fields.body:
Orange Order supporters yesterday staged a second consecutive day of protests across Northern Ireland, blocking dozens of roads and again sending workers scurrying home.

Despite several bomb hoaxes, disruption was less severe yesterday. Police were hoping today's public holiday would prove to be a turning point in the intensity of the dispute, focused on Drumcree.

Violence broke out for the 10th successive day, and loyalists, some wearing masks, forced businesses in Portadown, Co Armagh, to close at lunchtime. Tensions were high as 11th night bonfires were lit across the province, marking today's climax of the marching season.

Police in riot gear yesterday dispersed a group of 150 protesters who gathered at the bottom of the Garvaghy Road. They used dogs to force them away from the flashpoint.

Orangemen have criticised the police for heavy handed tactics in their approach to trouble in Portadown.

But Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, minister for education, yesterday accused the police of failing to take action against loyalist law breakers. He said that the RUC had used much tougher tactics to deal with nationalists and republicans in previous similar disputes.

RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan retorted: "We seem to be blamed for every ill in our society. I ask people to bear with us as we get through the next few difficult days, but I would hope they direct their anger not at us but at the appropriate quarter."

New rules governing the use of plastic baton rounds permit officers to fire only when there is a threat to life - only four have been fired during this year's dispute.

Security forces fear thousands of Orangemen may tonight congregate at Drumcree, just outside Portadown, after July 12 celebrations in their own areas. They mark the victory of William of Orange over Catholic king James II at the battle of the Boyne in 1690.

But the Orange Order is now split. Many Orangemen have said they will avoid Drumcree, where the Portadown district has been prevented from marching down the nationalist Garvaghy Road for the third year running, because of the violence involving loyalist paramilitaries.

There has been a lack of political support for the Orangemen, even among hardline unionists appalled at the Portadown district's ambivalent approach to violence.

Protesters at Drumcree used clubs to fire golf balls at officers early yesterday.

The RUC yesterday revealed there had been 146 arrests since the dispute began on July 2. They listed 288 petrol bomb incidents, some involving dozens of devices, and said police had recovered 941 petrol bombs.

There have been 280 attacks on the security forces, including 13 shooting incidents. A total of 57 RUC officers and five soldiers have been injured.

Seventy seven homes, 55 commercial premises and 358 vehicles have been damaged. Protesters have hijacked 88 vehicles.

Northern Ireland effectively closes down at this time every year for two days for the Orange Order celebrations.

webTitle: Grief and anger at death site

fields.headline: Grief and anger at death site
fields.standfirst:
Harrowing pilgrimage for Srebrenica Muslims

Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of Bosnian Muslims returned to Srebrenica yesterday, defying jeers and rock-throwing to mourn relatives who lie decaying in surrounding fields, slaughtered exactly five years ago in the worst massacre of post-1945 Europe.
fields.body:
Thousands of Bosnian Muslims returned to Srebrenica yesterday, defying jeers and rock-throwing to mourn relatives who lie decaying in surrounding fields, slaughtered exactly five years ago in the worst massacre of post-1945 Europe.

They offered prayers of peace but not forgiveness. Watching and whistling from surrounding hills were Serbs who have taken over the Muslims' houses.

A convoy of 64 buses ferried 3,000 mourners, mostly women, for a 20-minute ceremony at the former UN compound where males more than 13 years old were separated and taken away to be executed in a four-day slaughter in July 1995.

Loudspeakers relayed the Dzennaze Namaz , a prayer for the dead, led by a dozen blue-robed imams, and Bosnia's senior mufti asked for justice.

Faint voices from the hills reached the crowd: "Turks go fuck yourselves." Serbs making three-fingered victory signs had greeted the buses as they approached the town.

Thousands of US, Portuguese and French troops from Bosnia's stabilisation force, backed up with armoured vehicles, made a show of force to protect the convoy. Rocks were thrown but no injuries were reported after the buses entered Republika Srpska, the para-state granted to Serbs within Bosnia under the Dayton peace accord.

International aid agencies and diplomats were divided over whether to attend the ceremony. Privately, many complained that it damaged reconciliation efforts by raising tension.

Embassies queasy about participating felt obliged to do so after Thomas Miller, the US ambassador, vowed to go. "The least the international community could do was come here and show its face, to try to show some understanding," he said.

Srebrenica was overrun towards the end of Bosnia's 1992-95 civil war by Serb forces who killed more than 7,000 after brushing aside 100 Dutch soldiers supposed to make it a UN "safe area".

For many women, the converted battery factory was where they said goodbye to their men. One group stared disbelievingly at still-visible UN markings. "I thought they would have had the decency to hide that. We want the UN commanders tried for war crimes. They abandoned us," said Razim Selimovic, who lost his father Ramo, 75.

Widows with headscarves, wedding rings and flowing skirts queued to wash themselves at four water trucks before praying. Many had suffered dehydration five years ago.

Some of the younger ones struggled to remember events that they had witnessed through children's eyes. Alma Hasanovic, 19, lost 20 male relatives, including her father who left the compound to seek help and never returned.

The concrete hulk of the factory, the car park and road appeared unchanged, they said. Refija and Kamenica, in their 50s, stared in disbelief at one bush. "That's where we lay for two nights." Both lost husbands.

Others were unable to speak. Behara Alic, 54, sat on a verge tearing strips from the grass, weeping. Her daughter, Mirsada, explained that her three sons, aged 27, 24 and 17, had tried to break through the woods but had been captured. "My brothers were just boys. Their bodies haven't been found," she said.

Osmic Nedzad, 26, sitting beside her, was one of the lucky ones. His column of Muslim fighters was ambushed repeatedly as it tried to flee but he escaped.

"It wasn't about tactics or luck. It was about who could keep the strength to go on. God gave me that strength," said Osmic who is training to be a cleric.

Hours before the convoy arrived arsonists burned a house earmarked for three Muslim women in a street overlooked by international aid organisations.

The fourth house-burning in six weeks, it was a warning that Muslim resettlement would be resisted, said a US official. A majority before the war, there are now only four Muslims in Srebrenica's population of 18,000.

Srebrenica's Muslim mayor, Nesib Mandzic, elected by former residents now scattered through Bosnia, spoke of the future, not the past. "We have to be optimistic. We have no other way." The whistling started soon after.

fields.trailText: Bad day
fields.body:
Bad day

Labour's Martin Salter came within a whisker of arrest after being mistaken for a car thief's accomplice. The Reading West MP was on a shadowing exercise and had joined police arresting a suspect thief. He said: "The policewoman thought I was some kind of horrible thug and I thought she was the mouthy girlfriend of the car thief." Reading police said: "He was not getting VIP treatment so, under the circumstances, it is not surprising he could be mistaken for a criminal."

Crossbench hereditary peer Lord Cobbold resumed his seat in the Lords, eight months after losing it under the terms of the House of Lords Act 1999. The 62-year-old peer, runner up in last year's elections for the crossbench hereditaries' 28 remaining seats, replaces Lady Wharton who died in May.

fields.headline: Tale of a 'truant'
fields.trailText: Nick Davies's article (The tower block children for whom school has no point, July 10) was particularly well timed for me. For the last 10 weeks I have been struggling to find a school place for a Year Seven child.
fields.body:
Nick Davies's article (The tower block children for whom school has no point, July 10) was particularly well timed for me. For the last 10 weeks I have been struggling to find a school place for a Year Seven child. I don't wish to name her or the LEA as she has finally started at a new school this week, and I want to avoid any further difficulties for her.

Despite a daunting array of family problems, she was doing well and enjoying school until December, when her family became homeless and came to London. In February her mother was told by the LEA there was only one school, on the far side of the borough, with vacancies for girls. She turned this down for several reasons, including the length and cost of the journey. She was also worried about the reputation of the school, which is said to have problems with bullying.

She asked to be told when other schools had vacancies, but heard nothing. At the beginning of this term I decided I had to intervene. Secretly I believed her mother wasn't really trying, so I expected it would be easy. After 10 weeks of arguing the child's case on the phone I now know better. Because her LEA still asserted that they had no other vacancies, I approached schools in a neighbouring borough, which I knew to have places. However, as soon as these schools discovered any details of the girl's background they insisted that they could not admit her at least until September.

Two weeks ago the educational social worker in her own borough told me that one of the schools nearest to the hostel had had vacancies all the time. We were finally invited for an interview at this school last week. This was the worst shock of all. The child was by now very nervous.

After being at home for nearly two terms, in one bare hostel room with her severely depressed mother and her two younger brothers, she has understandably low self-esteem. But the headteacher hardly looked at her. Instead she launched an attack on her mother. "Casual admissions," she told us, "are always trouble. Parents always lie". She implied the child was disruptive or a truant, or both, and suggested that she had already found a school in London, and been excluded. When I explained how difficult it had been to find a place there was no apology, still no acknowledgment of the child, but at least a reluctant offer of a place.

I hope she is settling into her new school. I hope her head of year, form tutor and classmates are more welcoming than her headteacher. But I wonder how the last six months have affected her; how long it will be before she joins the children Nick Davies's write about, and becomes a voluntary, rather than involuntary, truant?

Helen Fletcher
London

 Nick Davies's article uncovering "an epidemic of emotional damage" should concern us all. It is not enough to judge by exam results alone how well we are raising our children.

Our recent report, Bright Futures, based on a two-year inquiry into the mental health of children and young people, recommended that school league tables include measures to promote children's social and emotional wellbeing alongside academic results. We need to support schools by providing clear guidelines on how to develop programmes of emotional and social learning throughout the curriculum, with Ofsted establishing a means to evaluate them.

It is not good enough to exclude children from school and provide limited services and support only when situations reach crisis point.

Ruth Lesirge
Director, Mental Health Foundation

Because her LEA still asserted that they had no other vacancies, I approached schools in a neighbouring borough, which I knew to have places. However, as soon as these schools discovered any details of the girl's background they insisted that they could not admit her at least until September. Two weeks ago the educational social worker in her own borough told me that one of the schools nearest to the hostel had had vacancies all the time. We were finally invited for an interview at this school last week. This was the worst shock of all. The child was by now very nervous. After being at home for nearly two terms, in one bare hostel room with her severely depressed mother and her two younger brothers, she has understandably low self-esteem. But the headteacher hardly looked at her. Instead she launched an attack on her mother. "Casual admissions," she told us, "are always trouble. Parents always lie". She implied the child was disruptive or a truant, or both, and suggested that she had already found a school in London, and been excluded. When I explained how difficult it had been to find a place there was no apology, still no acknowledgment of the child, but at least a reluctant offer of a place. I hope she is settling into her new school. I hope her head of year, form tutor and classmates are more welcoming than her headteacher. But I wonder how the last six months have affected her; how long it will be before she joins the children Nick Davies's write about, and becomes a voluntary, rather than involuntary, truant? Helen Fletcher London  Nick Davies's article uncovering "an epidemic of emotional damage" should concern us all. It is not enough to judge by exam results alone how well we are raising our children. Our recent report, Bright Futures, based on a two-year inquiry into the mental health of children and young people, recommended that school league tables include measures to promote children's social and emotional wellbeing alongside academic results. We need to support schools by providing clear guidelines on how to develop programmes of emotional and social learning throughout the curriculum, with Ofsted establishing a means to evaluate them. It is not good enough to exclude children from school and provide limited services and support only when situations reach crisis point. Ruth Lesirge Director, Mental Health Foundation

fields.headline: Lost in the translation
fields.trailText: Gary Younge (Single minded, July 11) thinks Esperanto is "idealism masquerading as common sense".
fields.body:
Gary Younge (Single minded, July 11) thinks Esperanto is "idealism masquerading as common sense". Given the millions spent annually by the EC alone on translating and interpreting, Esperanto is common sense, inspired by idealism, yes, but regrettably blocked by linguistic chauvinism.

Ged Taylor
Oxford

 Hugo Young is wrong (It was our hot air that inflated Blair's balloon, July 11) when he talks about disappointment with New Labour being caused by our inflated expectations. I voted Labour with no illusions at all and still ended up disillusioned.

Peter Ryley
Hull

 Hugo Young may well have pinpointed New Labour's problem. A hot air balloon is not a dirigible and as a result will tend to be tossed about by prevailing winds.

Keith Hayward
London

 Jack Straw (Letters, July 11) claims innocence that the annual recorded crime statistics will be "slipped out" - but does not deny that the comprehensive spending review will be announced the same day. Is it the Treasury's fault then - or is Gordon Brown not speaking to him either?

D Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent

 You reveal (Bonus row at National Grid, July 11) that the number of top directors required to energise a light bulb is 98. How many might have been needed if the economies and disciplines of privatisation had not kicked in?

Mike Brown
Newcastle upon Tyne

 Vodafone offers some free national calls in "off peak" times. My bill shows they count bank holidays as "normal working days". Does Chris Gent justify his huge bonus (Leader, July 11) because he spends bank holidays working?

Dr J Taverne
London

fields.headline: More lessons in cheating
fields.trailText: As an English teacher of 25 years experience I was horrified by the cynicism of your unnamed cheating teacher's "justification" for her actions (The big cheat, July 11).
fields.body:
As an English teacher of 25 years experience I was horrified by the cynicism of your unnamed cheating teacher's "justification" for her actions (The big cheat, July 11). The example she is setting the children in her charge - that if you don't like the system it is permissible to cheat - will have a far greater effect on their minds than any flaws in the National Curriculum.

Has it not occurred to her that the time she spends on writing 18 spurious essays could be better used helping those students to develop their own responses to the complexities of Shakespeare?

Anthony Purcell
Chelmsford

 The cheating techniques Nick Davies describes were first exploited in the 11-plus. Many years ago I was sent to another school to supervise the exam alongside the class teacher. He wandered among the desks frowning and shaking his head when an answer was incorrect. At the end he told me about the dummy runs which the pupils had had for the previous weeks.

These practices and the early opening of the envelopes and checking of papers have been taken up in Sats testing because of the profound effect good results have on a school's reputation.

Bob Tutton
Retired primary headteacher
Reading

 Before he continues his increasingly hysterical assault on state education, Nick Davies should spend more time day to day with working teachers. Why write our pupils' Macbeth essays when they carry only 5% of the total English mark? Any teacher who does so must have a lot of excess energy.

Stress how much poverty and home background matter by all means, Mr Davies, but spare us your rewrite of Apocalypse Now.

Graham Foster
Head of English Midhurst Grammar School

 I am a private tutor working for a reputable agency and, among other things, I "help" GCSE "failing" students whose parents pay me to correct/rewrite their children's course work.

As far as I am aware there is nothing illegal about it. Even the BBC and Guardian have websites with admirably accurate information and likely questions covering all English syllabuses.

The real issue is that for students not on the internet at home, or with poor parents, none of this help is available.

Unless payment by results, league tables and the like are abolished, these practices will become even more widespread, and will accentuate further the divide in education between the rich and poor.

Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Fantasy politics: the struggle continues
fields.trailText: Mark Perryman (Fantasy politics, July 11) is bemused that some 6,000 people turn up to the Socialist Workers party's week of discussion on anti-capitalist ideas, Marxism 2000, to be enticed into a "bizarre dream world" where fighting against the present system might one day be successful
fields.body:
Mark Perryman (Fantasy politics, July 11) is bemused that some 6,000 people turn up to the Socialist Workers party's week of discussion on anti-capitalist ideas, Marxism 2000, to be enticed into a "bizarre dream world" where fighting against the present system might one day be successful.

Bemusement must be natural for someone like Mark, who abandoned a Stalinist version of socialism to put his faith in "designer socialism" and then transferred it to New Labour. But that hardly justifies replacing rational argument with snide jibes against those of us who did not follow this strange intellectual odyssey.

What attracted people to Marxism 2000 were rational arguments about a world in which, according to reports in the Guardian in the last week, inequality is greater than ever; hunger, Aids and civil war afflict huge swathes of Africa; promises of debt cancellation are quietly forgotten; and a third of children in Britain live in poverty.

I am accused of concluding that "reforms" have proved "illusions". I can only plead guilty. As Hugo Young tells us, "New Labour was a huge balloon of inflated expectations".

I am also accused of believing that "the power to turn demonstrating against the system into fighting it lies with the workers". Again, I have to plead guilty. At Marxism 2000 we heard Susan George and Naomi Klein describe the key role played by American unions in the Seattle protest. Perryman could read the praise by France's most eminent sociologist, Pierre Bourdieu, of its workers in December 1995 for "fighting against the destruction of civilisation".

If Mark Perryman has got anything better to say on these matters, let's hear it.

Chris Harman
Editor, Socialist Worker

 Mark Perryman's excellent article on the Socialist Workers party could perhaps be summed up in one old joke. They don't understand socialism, few have done a proper day's work in their life and they wouldn't know a party if they went to one. What's more, any attempts to work their old entryist charms on the decentralised direct action movement will certainly be amusing to watch.

James Mackenzie
Edinburgh
james@mackenzie.nu

fields.headline: Dome truth
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel (Comment, July 11) describes the Millennium Dome as an "irredeemable turkey". It is in fact the second most popular visitor attraction in Europe; 85% of visitors give it the thumbs up.
fields.body:
Matthew Engel (Comment, July 11) describes the Millennium Dome as an "irredeemable turkey". It is in fact the second most popular visitor attraction in Europe; 85% of visitors give it the thumbs up. He claims that it costs £73.50 for a family of four to visit the dome. The actual price is £57.

If he gets such elementary facts wrong, one wonders if he even bothered to visit the dome before penning his diatribe.

Nick Raynsford MP

fields.headline: This woman rates India
fields.trailText: Charlotte Raven (G2, July 11) writes that she has never heard a good word about India Knight from a woman. Well, here are several.
fields.body:
Charlotte Raven (G2, July 11) writes that she has never heard a good word about India Knight from a woman. Well, here are several.

I was given the proof of her novel My Life On A Plate several months ago. I regarded it with trepidation because I don't read chick-lit novels and was terrified of having to be nice about something I hated. Raven accuses Knight of writing a novel only about herself rather than about some Bridget-Jones-type everywoman, a person I definitely can't relate to. But then, unlike Raven, I don't read novels to read about myself. As I discovered, the brilliance of My Life On A Plate is its originality rather than its pandering to some now worn-out formula.

My own life is nothing like India's (or her heroines). What I admire about her writing is that she is a great stylist, and underneath the enjoyable froth there is always an undertow of morality and even sadness.

Linda Grant

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nine hostages freed in Fiji
fields.body:
Nine hostages freed in Fiji

Rebels who have held 27 people captive for more than six weeks in Fiji's parliament released nine early this morning, part of a deal negotiated three days ago.

The nine included all the ethnic Indian politicians being held except for the deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his son. The remaining hostages are MPs and, like the rebels, are indigenous Fijians.

AP, Suva

Assad heir wins one-man poll

Bashar al-Assad got more than 97% of the vote yesterday in a one-candidate referendum to confirm him as Syria's new president, succeeding his late father Hafez al-Assad. Parliament inaugurates him Monday.

At the Golan Heights, soldiers facing the Israeli military made a show of marking their ballots with blood.

Reuters, Damascus

200 dead under rubbish slide

Philippine officials said yesterday that more than 100 bodies had been found and another 100 people were feared dead after an avalanche of rain-soaked rubbish crashed down on the bleak Manila shantytown known as Promised Land (Lupang Pangako) where 80,000 people live.

"It's a recovery operation, not a search and rescue operation," the defence secretary, Orlando Mercado, said.

Reuters, Manila

Big tobacco case climaxes

A Miami jury was asked by the plaintiffs in a class action yesterday to impose punitive damages of $154bn (£100bn) on the five main US cigarette makers. The jury had already found them guilty of producing a "deadly and defective" product.

The companies - Philip Morris, RJ Reynolds, Brown & Williamson, Lorillard and the Liggett Group - were expected to argue they should not have to pay more than their combined stated net worth of $15.3bn. The stock market value of the five is currently estimated at about $157bn.

The jury is likely to retire this week. The companies are expected to appeal.

Martin Kettle, Washington

Journalists join hostages

Three French TV journalists covering the 11-week hostage drama in the southern Philippines confirmed yesterday that they had been seized by the Abu Sayyaf group already holding 37 other people, including 18 foreigners.

If the group runs true to form, it will now demand money to free the French station TV2, and colleagues Jean-Jacques Le Garec, 46, and Roland Madura, 49.

Agencies, Manila

Heart surgery for Depardieu

The veteran French actor Gerard Depardieu has undergone successful coronary bypass surgery and is recovering well, his film agency said yesterday.

The 51-year-old actor underwent surgery on Monday at a hospital outside Paris. The operation was carried out after Depardieu was admitted last week, suffering from chest pains. He is expected to make a full recovery.

AP, Paris

fields.trailText: The figures for internet access among British households in our chart, page 3, yesterday, were based on figures for the whole year from April 1999. But the overall figure for internet access across the UK of 25% was based on the most recent available quarter, January-March 2000. The regional access figures were averages for the year, and with internet access growing fast, therefore lag behind the latest figure.
fields.body:
The figures for internet access among British households in our chart, page 3, yesterday, were based on figures for the whole year from April 1999. But the overall figure for internet access across the UK of 25% was based on the most recent available quarter, January-March 2000. The regional access figures were averages for the year, and with internet access growing fast, therefore lag behind the latest figure.

In a chart accompanying our front page report about Aids, July 8, we said that 1.4m people in Zimbabwe were living with HIV/Aids and that this represented 25.1% of the population. In fact, 1.4m represents about 11% of the total population of Zimbabwe. The 25.1% referred to the HIV rate in adults (aged 15 to 49). Figures from Unaids and WHO.

In our piece on citizenship, page 8, Education, yesterday, we knighted Professor Bernard Crick (an accidental honour). Julia Talbot referred to in the same piece is Jenny Talbot of the Institute of Citizenship. Apologies.

The photograph of the euro sign, page 2, G2, yesterday, was flipped. In addition the viewpoint chosen by the photographer showed it upside down.

Thornton Manor, the family home of the late Lord Leverhulme, Obituaries, page 20, yesterday, is actually on the Wirral (not Wirrel) peninsula, or in Wirral, rather than "near" it.

In our piece about "Christian films", page 5, The Guide, July 8, we referred to Salem, New Hampshire as "the town where Christians once burned witches..." That was Salem, Massachussetts (one of at least 18 Salems in the US). In fact, the "witches" were hanged, not burned.

In a column about National Service, page 5, G2, July 10, we suggested that the national servicemen took the "Queen's shilling". The term applies to those who enlist - until 1879 they actually received a shilling on signing up - not to conscripts, which is what the national servicemen were.

In an Arts piece about the musician John Fogerty, page 14, G2, yesterday, we said he was the "lynchpin" of Creedence Clearwater Revival. Guardian style is "linchpin" (although most dictionaries give lynchpin as an acceptable variant).

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Law Society blamed for crisis in profession

fields.headline: Law Society blamed for crisis in profession
fields.trailText: The Law Society sat idly by for most of a decade while the solicitors' complaints system "lurched from one self-destructive strategy to another", the legal service ombudsman, Ann Abraham, said in a damning report yesterday.
fields.body:
The Law Society sat idly by for most of a decade while the solicitors' complaints system "lurched from one self-destructive strategy to another", the legal service ombudsman, Ann Abraham, said in a damning report yesterday.

The result has been a "crisis in the organisation and governance of the legal profession" and a system which has failed to get to grips with a huge increase in complaints against solicitors, according to her 1999-2000 report.

The Office for Supervision of Solicitors, the arm of the Law Society which handles complaints, "habitually takes far too long to do too little", said Ms Abraham. "It is not just that case after case demonstrates unacceptable delay, still often of well over a year. In addition, the end result of that protracted investigation is frustration that the crucial issues have so often been ignored, overlooked or misconstrued."

Backlogs at the office, which is overseen by the ombudsman, grew to such a level that the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, took powers in the Administration of Justice Act 1999 to remove self-regulation from the profession. He warned the society that he would hand the role over to a new independent complaints commissioner if targets to reduce the backlog and process new cases were not met.

By last month, the office had reduced its July 1999 backlog of 17,074 cases to 11,284 against a target of 6,000 outstanding cases by the end of December. But it is falling substantially short of the turnaround target which stipulates that 90% of new cases should be dealt with in three months.

In May only 31% of cases were completed in that time. Numbers of complaints last year reached one for every five of the 80,000 solicitors in practice. Complainants dissatisfied with the way the office has handled their complaints can ask for a review by the ombudsman.

Instead of improving, standards are slipping, with only 59% of complaints dealt with to their satisfaction, compared with 70% in 1996.

"There are far too many cases where the quality of the OSS's decision making is simply not acceptable," said Ms Abraham.

Last month David Lock, minister in the Lord Chancellor's Department, said the government had "grave concern" over the office's ability to deal with cases fast enough and to a high enough standard.

Ms Abraham accused solicitors of professional arrogance and failing to adopt a consumer culture, reacting defensively to complaints as an attack on their professional integrity.

She quoted the former Law Society president, Martin Mears, who described clients who complained as "whingers and grievance mongers whose primary object in making a complaint is to avoid paying a bill".

Ms Abraham said: "We come across very few people who could ever be labelled 'professional complainers'. What we do see are many, many people who have been poorly served by lawyers in what is often their first and only encounter with the legal system and who have come away disappointed and disillusioned by the experience - and with their respect for the legal profession sadly diminished."

The Law Society has ploughed an extra £11m into the complaints system in an effort to keep the right to regulate solicitors.

Michael Napier, who was elected president this week, said: "I am determined that we will continue to do whatever it takes to achieve the right level of quality and turnaround in dealing with clients' complaints." He pledged to try to bring about a "more customer-focused attitude" in the profession.

But it is falling substantially short of the turnaround target which stipulates that 90% of new cases should be dealt with in three months. In May only 31% of cases were completed in that time. Numbers of complaints last year reached one for every five of the 80,000 solicitors in practice. Complainants dissatisfied with the way the office has handled their complaints can ask for a review by the ombudsman. Instead of improving, standards are slipping, with only 59% of complaints dealt with to their satisfaction, compared with 70% in 1996. "There are far too many cases where the quality of the OSS's decision making is simply not acceptable," said Ms Abraham. Last month David Lock, minister in the Lord Chancellor's Department, said the government had "grave concern" over the office's ability to deal with cases fast enough and to a high enough standard. Ms Abraham accused solicitors of professional arrogance and failing to adopt a consumer culture, reacting defensively to complaints as an attack on their professional integrity. She quoted the former Law Society president, Martin Mears, who described clients who complained as "whingers and grievance mongers whose primary object in making a complaint is to avoid paying a bill". Ms Abraham said: "We come across very few people who could ever be labelled 'professional complainers'. What we do see are many, many people who have been poorly served by lawyers in what is often their first and only encounter with the legal system and who have come away disappointed and disillusioned by the experience - and with their respect for the legal profession sadly diminished." The Law Society has ploughed an extra £11m into the complaints system in an effort to keep the right to regulate solicitors. Michael Napier, who was elected president this week, said: "I am determined that we will continue to do whatever it takes to achieve the right level of quality and turnaround in dealing with clients' complaints." He pledged to try to bring about a "more customer-focused attitude" in the profession.

fields.headline: Gushing praise
fields.standfirst: Tap water better than bottled, says minister
fields.trailText: The British public will be better off drinking tap water than spending millions of pounds a year on bottled water, Michael Meacher said yesterday.
fields.body:
The British public will be better off drinking tap water than spending millions of pounds a year on bottled water, Michael Meacher said yesterday.

The environment minister - who himself enjoys drinking a bottle of sparkling water over lunch - was praising the virtues of tap water in advance of today's annual report of the drinking water inspectorate.

During questions on the environment in the Commons, Mr Meacher said: "The quality of drinking water is second to none in this country." He said it was "as good as anywhere in the continent and, I would say, considerably better than bottled water".

He even praised his Tory predecessor, John Gummer, for improving the quality of water, although adding that Labour had "extended substantially" the investment in the industry. He predicted that today's report would show a "welcome further improvement in water quality". Privatised water companies have had to spend billions improving the quality as well as taking responsibility for cleaning up beaches and replacing outdated sewage systems. Drinking water has tended to have a bad press since in London alone water is reused seven times.

Mr Meacher's praise for tap water comes as the British public drinks more bottled water every year. The market is now worth £500m a year and consumption has jumped 25% over the past five years, according to a new report.

webTitle: Harry makes mincemeat out of Hannibal and Delia

fields.headline: Harry makes mincemeat out of Hannibal and Delia
fields.standfirst:
Harry Potter website
Interview with JK Rowling at www.booksunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: The fourth Harry Potter story broke all publishing records by selling 372,775 copies on its first day, according to authoritative figures yesterday.
fields.body:
The fourth Harry Potter story broke all publishing records by selling 372,775 copies on its first day, according to authoritative figures yesterday.

The total - described as "amazing" by the market research group Whitaker BookTrack - netted the author JK Rowling nearly £300,000 in extra pocket money and shrivelled the achievements of recent bestsellers like Hannibal Lecter and Delia Smith.

The records overtaken by Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire were nearly all set by Ms Rowling's three earlier Potter books.

Spurred by unprecedented publishing hype, the new story sold in a single day - last Saturday - nearly two-thirds of the total achieved by its predecessor, The Prisoner of Azkaban, in the last five months of last year.

Ms Rowling can count on a further boost in income when sales figures for yesterday and Monday come through from supermarkets like Tesco. Most of these stores get no wholesale deliveries on Saturdays, so that the publisher Bloomsbury's strict embargo on sales meant they could not get copies on their shelves for the weekend.

Goblet of Fire's total sales figure covers not only purchases at bookshop electronic tills but sales on the internet and through newspaper offers.

Total sales in bookshops alone were 256,246. These were more than half the 503,473 copies of the first Harry Potter story, The Philosopher's Stone, sold in the whole of last year. The next story, The Chamber of Secrets, sold 417,171 in 1999. The Highway Code - regularly king of bestseller lists till Ms Rowling came on the scene - sold 393, 396 in that year. Thomas Harris's third Lecter novel, Hannibal, sold 58,319 in its first five days last year. Delia Smith's How to Cook, Book 2, sold 110,425 in its first three days last December.

Internet and newspaper sales made up more than 116,000 of the book's first day total. Britain's biggest internet bookseller, Amazon, yesterday claimed some 65,000 of these, adding: "Thousands of orders are still coming in every day".

According to the Society of Authors last night, writers get an average 8% royalty on each hardback copy sold. Goblet of Fire is being sold at an average of £10. On this arithmetic - assuming that she has not by now negotiated a higher personal royalty - Ms Rowling was £298,220 better off on Saturday night.

webTitle: Dock legal aid fees for lawyers who cause delays, say MPs

fields.headline: Dock legal aid fees for lawyers who cause delays, say MPs
fields.trailText: Defence solicitors who delay court hearings should have their legal aid cash docked as part of a scheme to speed up justice and cut down on waste, a report by MPs recommends today.
fields.body:
Defence solicitors who delay court hearings should have their legal aid cash docked as part of a scheme to speed up justice and cut down on waste, a report by MPs recommends today.

The Commons public accounts committee says that up to £85 million is wasted every year because of ineffective hearings and "cracked" trials. The cost of lack of co-ordination between police, magistrates' courts, and defence and prosecution counsel is higher than the money the government originally wanted to save by cutting down on trial by jury.

David Davis, Tory chairman of the committee, said yesterday: "The current failure by the criminal justice agencies to work in a properly co-ordinated way causes endemic delays in the system, which increase costs and undermine public confidence."

The report says 25% of the lost hearings are caused by defendants failing to attend court but another 23% of delays are caused by defendants' lawyers not being prepared for the hearing.

"While defence lawyers owe a duty to their client, they have a responsibility to the court. We urge the lord chancellor's department to reflect this responsibility in the terms of the new legal aid contracts with criminal defence lawyers. The contracts should include standards of preparedness for hearings and arrangements for monitoring, using performance information produced by the courts."

The report "names and shames" the worst performing magistrates' courts. These include Doncaster, which averaged 94 days in 1998 and 71 days in 1999 from summons to completing petty criminal cases. Birmingham, Leeds, Northamptonshire and Walsall are among the worst performers, taking between 115 and 71 days to handle indictable offences. The report also reveals a deterioration among previously well-performing courts. Barnet, which took 59 days to handle indictable cases in 1998, took 74 days the following year.

The report says that the justice system does not have a proper information base to encourage co-operation between the various parties.

It says that computerisation is at a very early stage and the Crown Prosecution Service will not have a state-of-the-art computerised national case management system until 2003.

In the meantime, MPs say, it must improve access to present fragmented system to speed up justice.

They also call on the Lord Chancellor's department to mount an investigation into the disparity between convictions at magistrates' and crown courts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Disabled girl gets £3.5m
fields.body:
Disabled girl gets £3.5m

A 17-year-old girl who has been severely disabled since her brain was starved of oxygen at birth, yesterday won £3.5m damages at the high court in London.

Claire Penny, of Alvaston, Derby, gets around in a motorised wheelchair and can communicate by computer, the court heard.

The South Derbyshire health authority admitted liability.

Duke battles for mining rights

The crown estate and the Duke of Westminster are locked in legal action over ancient land rights, it emerged yesterday. The Duke's Grosvenor Estate applied to the crown estate for rights to minerals in north Wales which it claims it has owned for nearly 400 years. But officials objected.

Mountain bike paramedic

Health chiefs yesterday unveiled the country's first mountain bike paramedic service - to cut through traffic-clogged city centres.

The bike, with blue flashing lights and panniers containing a defibrillator and oxygen, will be tested in Norwich before being introduced all over Britain.

Racing pigeons mutilated

Fifty racing pigeons died after their feet were cut off for their identity rings, police said yesterday. Norman and Mary Jones who kept the birds in Kirkdale, Liverpool, said they believed the birds were mutilated by teenagers, who wear the rings.

Fayed appeals for heli-pad

Harrods yesterday appealed against Kensington and Chelsea council's refusal to allow the Knightsbridge store's owner Mohamed Al Fayed to use its roof as a heli-pad.

webTitle: Ballerina raped after being lured by movie conman

fields.headline: Ballerina raped after being lured by movie conman
fields.trailText: A "charismatic" conman, who posed as a film producer to lure would-be stars to his office, was yesterday convicted of rape.
fields.body:
A "charismatic" conman, who posed as a film producer to lure would-be stars to his office, was yesterday convicted of rape.

Mabrouk Melliti, 36, hired smart offices, scoured nightclubs and approached agents for "wild and sexy" women.

He particularly liked models, actresses, gymnasts and ballerinas, and after inviting them to late night auditions he used his powerful personality to bend them to his will, Snaresbrook crown court, in east London, heard.

He would often undress before pressing the women to dance, remove their clothes and stroke him. He would often talk them through a sham script, exhorting them to carry out "wilder and wilder" acts, intent only on his own sexual gratification. Those who resisted were made to feel prudes who stood no chance of breaking into the big time.

Sometimes there was simulated love making, but on one occasion it ended in rape.

A 22-year-old ballerina cried as she recalled Melliti shouting "scene one, scene two" as he abused her in different positions.

Louise Kamill, prosecuting, told the court of the ballerina's intense suffering and months of depression after the attack. She had to undergo HIV treatment as a precautionary measure, suffered weight loss, sleepless nights and panic attacks. "She was so scared she had to sleep with her mother ... and was unable to train."

Adjourning sentence until next week, Judge David Radford told Melliti, of Piccadilly, central London, that he faces a substantial prison sentence.

Miss Kamill told the trial it was not the first time Melliti had pretended to be a producer. He had turned up in Canada, Finland, Italy and Czechoslovakia over the years to announce multimillion pound plans for productions, which never got off the ground.

On one occasion he spoke of Al Pacino playing one of the roles, with Robert de Niro possibly also part of the cast.

When Melliti arrived in London in June last year he hired expensive offices that he never paid for.

After setting up a company called M&M Productions, hiring an assistant and a professional casting director, and printing cards announcing a mass audition, he approached agents in nightclubs such as Stringfellows.

But, said counsel, his company, its expensive address, the name dropping and the audition, were all part of an elaborate ruse to fulfil his hunger for beautiful conquests.

Melliti was also convicted of indecent assault. He was cleared of raping a second aspiring actress.
