fields.headline: Stress plagues lives of women
fields.trailText: One in seven women has felt suicidal due to the stress of modern life, according to new research.
fields.body:
One in seven women has felt suicidal due to the stress of modern life, according to new research.

Most of the 2,000 women interviewed for Good Housekeeping magazine were found to have poor diets and insufficient time to exercise or visit their GP.

The report says 86% of women often feel tired and stressed and that one in seven has been exhausted to the point of feeling suicidal.

Amanda Kirby, a general practitioner, commented: "Most women are used to being carers first and individuals second. Their own health is often secondary."

According to the report, almost 40% of women, and 46% of full-time working women, turn to alcohol and comfort food to help them cope with increasing demands on their time.

Almost 30% had missed medical appointments because they were too busy to attend, and 59% of respondents with partners said they often felt too tired for sex.

"Most of us would probably single out cancer, heart disease or stroke as the biggest threat to women's health, but it is actually lack of time that puts an almost intolerable strain on our well-being," according to Lindsey Nicholson, editor-in-chief of Good Housekeeping, which publishes the research in its August edition.

fields.headline: £1bn navy order boosts shipyards
fields.trailText: Britain's troubled shipyards were given a huge boost yesterday as the Ministry of Defence announced a £6bn programme to replace the navy's ageing fleet of destroyers.
fields.body:
Britain's troubled shipyards were given a huge boost yesterday as the Ministry of Defence announced a £6bn programme to replace the navy's ageing fleet of destroyers.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, told MPs that the ministry is negotiating an initial £1bn order for the construction of the first three of 12 Type 45 destroyers which will be assembled by BAE Systems and Vosper Thornycroft.

The first ship, HMS Daring, will be assembled at BAE's Scotstoun (formerly Yarrow) yard on the Clyde and the second, HMS Dauntless, by Vospers at Southampton or Portsmouth.

Ordering more than one ship at a time from more than one yard will bring the ships into service quicker and less expensively, with companies sharing the risks, the MoD said. In another innovation, sections of the ships will be built at different locations before they are assembled at Clydeside and the south coast.

These decisions are also politically astute, providing jobs across the country. The first batch of three new destroyers would sustain some 3,000 jobs in shipyards and almost as many elsewhere, Mr Hoon said.

However, the ships will be five years late by the time they start entering into service in 2007. The delay is mainly the result of the cancellation last year of the Horizon project in which Britain, France, and Italy planned to collaborate on a new frigate.

That project, with a total of 22 frigates costing £8bn, would have produced cheaper ships but it was abandoned over arguments about equipment and performance.

Meanwhile, the navy will have to continue with its Type 42 destroyers, spending an extra £530m keeping them operational with an out-of-date anti-missile system.

The new class of destroyers will be equipped with the Principal anti-air missile system (Paams) developed jointly by Britain, France and Italy, and designed to counter modern anti-ship missiles.

The MoD described the new destroyers as a "general purpose platform capable of operations across the spectrum of tasks from peace support to high intensity warfare". The Paams system could give air cover to British forces engaged in a land battle, the MoD said.

The new destroyers could carry nearly 200 marines and be equipped with "land attack missiles" - a reference to US Tomahawk cruise missiles - Sir Michael Boyce, the first sea lord, said yesterday.

Yesterday's announcement comes amid a continuing row over the decision not to award orders for roll on, roll off ferries for the armed forces. The MoD has decided to re-tender.

BAE Systems have three shipyards - Scotstoun, Govan - also on the Clyde - and Barrow. It is not clear where it will assemble the third of the first batch of destroyers.

The second one will be assembled by Vosper Thornycroft whose shipyard is in Southampton. It said it was examining the possibility of assembling the ships in the Portsmouth naval base.

This is the second big defence procurement package the government has announced. It recently earmarked £5bn for leasing large US transport aircraft and investing in a military airbus in a joint project with France and Germany.

fields.headline: Home wrecked by teen party
fields.trailText: It will take teenagers Hayley and Natasha Ford more than a flick through Yellow Pages and a visit from the french polisher to hide the destruction wreaked at last weekend's house party in the Suffolk village of Long Melford.
fields.body:
It will take teenagers Hayley and Natasha Ford more than a flick through Yellow Pages and a visit from the french polisher to hide the destruction wreaked at last weekend's house party in the Suffolk village of Long Melford.

Returning from a holiday in Turkey, parents Mark and Trish Ford opened the door of their recently refurbished semi-detached home to find carpets ripped up, curtains torn down, light fittings pulled from the ceiling, clothes and bed linen soiled, and nearly all the furniture smashed.

With an estimated £10,000 worth of damage, the house is uninhabitable and the Fords are now living in a tent in their back garden while the clean-up operation begins.

Mr Ford, a postal worker, believes that Hayley, 14, hosted the all-night party - intended for 15 to 20 friends - while she and her sister were supposed to be staying with relatives. By the time Natasha, 16, arrived, the party was swamped with gatecrashers and out of control.

"It was like a burglary, only worse," Mr Ford told the East Anglian Daily Times yesterday.

Mrs Ford said that all the carpets in the house had to be thrown out, including one laid on the stairs and landing a few months ago.

"Beans were poured over the cooker hob and cooking utensils used as receptacles for vomiting," she said.

"We are very disappointed in our daughters, but we have forgiven them because family life has to go on."

Suffolk police said they are following up the incident and have interviewed 30 people. Two have been arrested and bailed.

Two have been arrested and bailed.

fields.headline: 'Cambridge Two' freed pending appeal
fields.standfirst:
Jubilation greets release of charity workers jailed over drug dealing

More about the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for knowingly permitting drug dealing at a hostel for the homeless were yesterday freed on bail pending an appeal.
fields.body:
Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for knowingly permitting drug dealing at a hostel for the homeless were yesterday freed on bail pending an appeal.

The release of Ruth Wyner and John Brock by the appeal court in London brought relief to social workers and volunteers in the homeless field who have campaigned against the pair's conviction and sentence.

There has been concern that the jailing of Wyner and Brock, for five and four years respectively, after police discovered heroin was being peddled at the hostel they managed, set a dangerous precendent.

Some centres have turned addicts away rather than risk similar accusations, while others have seen a drop in volunteers.

A campaign backed by Julie Christie, Tom Stoppard and Michael Winner has called for an overhaul of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971, which led to the jailing of the pair. A full appeal in the autumn will decide whether the convictions of Wyner and Brock were fair.

Wyner, a director of the Wintercomfort charity in Cambridge, and Brock, a charity manager, were convicted in December of knowingly permitting the supply of heroin.

The pair, both 50 and with years of experience working with the homeless, were arrested after police mounted a surveillance operation at the shelter. A spy camera captured dealing in the shelter's courtyard while two police officers posing as homeless men visited the centre 12 times and bought heroin on eight occasions.

During the trial at King's Lynn crown court, the prosecution claimed the centre was "almost a supermarket for heroin". Wyner and Brock insisted that they were shocked at the extent of the dealing and it was accepted that they were never present when dealing was taking place.

At the heart of the case was the charity's policy of confidentiality which effectively prevented them from handing over the names of those suspected of being involved in drugs to the police.

Such a policy is common in the homeless sector. And as there is a high level of drug addiction among the homeless - up to 70% say some estimates - many experts believe that some dealing is almost inevitable in many hostels.

Yesterday Michael Mansfield QC, counsel for the pair, argued that at the trial, Judge Jonathan Haworth did not give the jury enough leeway to decide if Wyner and Brock had taken all reasonable steps to prevent drug dealing.

He said Wyner and Brock had felt bound by the policy of confidentiality "and felt they should not save in extreme circumstances hand over information to other agencies including the police".

Wintercomfort was not an "isolated maverick" organisation, but a respected charity set up to confront an urgent social problem, said Mr Mansfield.

He added: "Unfortunately in this day and age there are a larger number of people than ever before who have no other home than the street.

"Wintercomfort filled a gap where others fear to tread, hoping to restore dignity to individuals so they could re-enter the mainstream of life and make a contribution."

Mr Mansfield said that the centre, funded by the local health authority and local councils and overseen by a board of trustees, provided shelter and food to around 100 homeless people a day.

He pointed out that the police were closely involved in the project. A senior officer attended advisory meetings and a local beat officer frequently visited. During the trial he had said that he felt Wyner and Brock were doing "as good a job as could be expected".

Mr Mansfield said the case was of considerable importance for many others who worked with the homeless.

He said that Wintercomfort now had a different system, operating a "closed door" policy in which all visitors' names were taken, and opening for shorter hours.

A public gallery packed with supporters of the "Cambridge Two" erupted in loud and sustained cheering and applause as Lord Justice Rose announced the appeal court's decision to grant bail. Wyner turned to Brock and planted a kiss on his forehead.

There were more scenes of delight outside the court as the pair were released.

Hugging in turn her husband, Gordon, 52, daughter Rachel, 16, and son Joel, 23, Wyner said: "I am absolutely delighted. I'm looking forward to spending some precious time with my children and private time with my husband. I'm also looking forward to a good cup of coffee. The past seven months have been very tough indeed."

Brock, who was greeted by his wife Louise, 39, and sons Lloyd, 16, and Dillon, 11, said: "I'm overjoyed to be with my family again. I'm looking forward to being with them. It's a cause for cautious celebration."

Peter Bottomley, Tory MP for Worthing West, who has backed the pair's campaign, said: "There is an expectation that the convictions will in the end be overturned and there is also a view that the grossly excessive sentence will receive adverse comment in the court of appeal."

He said social workers across the country had been horrified by the case.

webTitle: Turmoil for rap superstar as wife attempts suicide

fields.headline: Turmoil for rap superstar as wife attempts suicide
fields.trailText: The wife of the controversial white rapper, Eminem, who is the subject of some of his violent lyrics, was recovering yesterday from a suicide attempt.
fields.body:
The wife of the controversial white rapper, Eminem, who is the subject of some of his violent lyrics, was recovering yesterday from a suicide attempt.

Kim Mathers, 25, supposedly tried to take her own life after seeing one of her husband's concerts in the Detroit area over the weekend.

Ms Mathers is the subject of the song, Kim, in which her husband - whose real name is Marshall Bruce Mathers III - sings about killing her and dumping her body in a lake.

The song features on The Marshall Mathers LP that currently tops album charts on both sides of the Atlantic. In the US it has sold over 5m copies and is the fastest-selling hip-hop release ever.

Paramedics were called to the Mathers' home in Sterling Heights, Michigan, where Ms Mathers was treated before being being taken to a nearby hospital. She had reportedly slashed her wrists.

She was later released after treatment, according to statements from the local police and from Eminem's record label, Interscope.

A spokesman for Eminem's record company said: "Eminem is obviously concerned about his wife's well-being. It's a private matter."

Eminem, 27, is currently touring North America as part of the Up in Smoke tour with other rappers such as Dr Dre, Snoop Doggy Dog and Ice Cube. The tour has come under scrutiny because it features a video that portrays violence and graphic sexual situations.

One scene on the controversial video shows the rapper Snoop Doggy Dog robbing a liquor store and asking the audience, "Shall I shoot?".

Dr Dre has been accused by local police of promoting pornography through the video which was dropped by the show for one night after local officials threatened to cut power to the hall.

Eminem was also prevented from bringing a naked inflatable doll on stage.

The show's promoters are arguing that by-laws stopping them from showing the video are a breach of their first amendment rights to free speech.

Eminem, who wrote such songs as I Just Don't Give a Fuck and Brain Damage, is due to appear in court on assault and weapons charges connected with an incident last month after a confrontation with a man whom he allegedly saw kissing his wife.

His wife said that he had misunderstood a friendly kiss. The trial proper is likely to start next week.

The rapper, who was born in Kansas City but was brought up in Detroit, made a debut album, Infinite, in 1996 but has only become internationally famous over the last year.

He won two Grammys this year for best rap album and best rap solo for the song My Name Is. On his official website he is quoted as saying: "I don't know how long I'm going to be on this planet so while I'm here I might as well make the most of it."

Eminem is also being sued for $10m by his mother, Deborah Mathers-Briggs, for defamation of character, citing comments her son made about her last year in three magazines, Rolling Stone, The Source and Rap Pages.

Eminem and Ms Mathers have a five-year-old daughter.

Rebel rappers

Sean 'Puffy' Combs , 30, a hip hop record mogul, faces two gun possession charges in connection with an incident in Club New York in December last year. He was alleged to have waved a gun in the club after an altercation after which another man shot and wounded three club-goers. In a profile in Vanity Fair, he describes his behaviour as just some "wild Dennis the Menace shit".

Snoop Doggy Dogg , real name Calvin Broadus, was acquitted in 1996 of a murder charge shortly before his debut album appeared. His driver, who was also cleared of murder, shot dead a drug dealer in Los Angeles. Both men pleaded self defence.

Tupac Shakur , the son of a former member of the Black Panthers who performed under the name of 2Pac, died in Las Vegas in a drive-by shooting in 1996. He was 25 and had been in the car of the owner of Death Row records Marion 'Suge' Knight. He had convictions for assault and robbery and had the words Thug Life tattooed on his belly.

Notorious BIG , real name Christopher Wallace, died in 1997 in a drive-by shooting. He had a conviction for beating autograph hunters with a baseball bat. His first album was entitled Ready to Die

webTitle: Paper weight Waterstone's drags down HMV profit

fields.headline: Paper weight Waterstone's drags down HMV profit
fields.trailText: Declining sales at Waterstone's bookstores continue to cause problems for its owner, HMV Media Group, it emerged yesterday. Waterstone's sales were down 3.7% and pre-tax profits fell more than a quarter to £37.2m in the 12 months to April.
fields.body:
Declining sales at Waterstone's bookstores continue to cause problems for its owner, HMV Media Group, it emerged yesterday. Waterstone's sales were down 3.7% and pre-tax profits fell more than a quarter to £37.2m in the 12 months to April.

HMV confirmed that it had rejected bids for Waterstone's, saying they "undervalued" the chain - but declined to give details. The German group Bertelsmann and US bookseller Borders were each reported to have offered about £300m.

HMV said it had been a "challenging year". The music division increased earnings by £13.7m, helping lift total pre-tax profits to £121m, up £2.4m.

Chief executive Alan Giles said that the book trade generally had over-stretched itself last year, while growth of internet bookselling had compounded the problems.

The group had invested heavily in e-commerce, including a "make your own CD" service in HMV stores. But Waterstone's has struggled in the growing online book market.

HMV Media Group was formed in 1998, bringing together HMV, Dillons and Waterstones. EMI retains a 40% stake in the group.

fields.headline: Going under
fields.standfirst: Debts mount as tourists shun Japan's spectacular water park
fields.trailText: If Robin Cook has any free time during today's G8 foreign ministers' meeting in Miyazaki, he would be well advised to take his trunks and towel to the Ocean Dome indoor water park next to the conference venue.
fields.body:
If Robin Cook has any free time during today's G8 foreign ministers' meeting in Miyazaki, he would be well advised to take his trunks and towel to the Ocean Dome indoor water park next to the conference venue.

There, he can see what should rank as the eighth wonder of the world, while learning at first hand why the Japanese economy is in such a mess.

The Ocean Dome is part of the 200bn yen (£1.25bn) Seagaia resort, built in the middle of a seashore pine forest to attract the world's leaders to this remote part of southern Japan.

It boasts an entry in the Guinness Book of Records for the world's longest artificial beach, 140 metres of crushed marble imported from China because it glistens attractively and never sticks to the skin. The temperature simulates the ideal tropical climate, and overhead is an artificial sky that guarantees cloudless afternoons, perfect sunsets and a galaxy of stars every night.

Conceived at the overoptimistic height of the "bubble economy" in the late 1980s, it was supposed to impress the world but has all gone horribly wrong.

The resort is on the verge of bankruptcy, for there is one thing missing: people. Visitor numbers have declined steadily since Ocean Dome opened in 1993. Last year it was lucky to reach a quarter of its capacity most days, and the decline is continuing, despite a cut in the entry fee from £26 to £16.

"It's just too expensive," said local resident Sumiko Shida. "And, even if they dropped the price, a lot of people in the town wouldn't go because they are so angry that their money has been wasted in this way."

Half of the capital put into the resort has come from the public purse. It is one of about 40 large-scale facilities built as partnerships between local authorities and companies since the late 1980s. Poorly planned, all of these projects are deep in debt. And none more so than Seagaia, which said in April that it had run up an accumulated deficit of £750m.

Analysts say the resort will be lucky to stay in business for another six months, and if it fails much of the cost will fall on Miyazaki's inhabitants.

webTitle: In the name of the father

fields.headline: In the name of the father
fields.standfirst: In 1997 Fela Kuti, the legendary Nigerian musician who married all 27 of his backing singers, died from Aids. Now, his son Femi Kuti has joined Unicef to fight the disease.  Maya Jaggi  reports
fields.trailText: In 1997 Fela Kuti, the legendary Nigerian musician who married all 27 of his backing singers, died from Aids. Now, his son Femi Kuti has joined Unicef to fight the disease. Maya Jaggi reports
fields.body:
When Femi Kuti's father, the Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti, died in 1997, it was the first his family knew for certain that he had Aids. "We suspected much earlier, in 1986," says Kuti. "But we never knew till the doctors confirmed it; he was never tested when he was alive."

The family decision to announce the cause of the Nigerian superstar's death at 58 marked the start of a campaign by his eldest son against "silence and stigma". Kuti recalls: "There wasn't enough information in Nigeria about Aids, just news from outside saying it was caused by homosexuals, or that it came from monkeys in central Africa. Many of us didn't believe it - and I was one. I thought it was racist propaganda. I'm saddened that it took my father's death for us to take Aids seriously."

Kuti has added his voice to a new Unicef report, published today, which focuses on Aids as "the greatest catastrophe facing the continent of Africa" and beyond. It follows news from the Aids summit in Durban at the weekend that the pandemic kills 2m people a year in Africa and that 23m Africans are infected with HIV. At 37, Kuti is among a growing number of African musicians - including Miriam Makeba and Youssou N'Dour - using their fame to promote HIV awareness on and off stage. While personal bereavement gives Kuti's message an edge, it is carried by his rocketing worldwide success as a vocalist and saxophonist with his band the Positive Force, whose backing singers include his wife Funke and sister Yeni.

Shoki Shoki, Kuti's first album on the Talkin' Loud label, was a recording highlight of last year. At the World Music Awards in Monte Carlo in May, he was named bestselling African artist, after being voted best male artist last September in the pan-African Kora awards - Africa's Grammies. Even staunch fans of his father now hail the son as Fela's reincarnation.

Yet the sudden glare of publicity after years in his father's shadow has put Kuti in reflective mood. "A lot of fame is coming to me now," he says in London as he heads for a north American tour this month, after sellout concerts in Paris and at the Barbican, London. "I could say I'm living my dream: it's what I've worked so hard for for 13 years - to be internationally known. But I can't stop thinking about what's going on in Africa. When I go back to Nigeria I'll be able to afford whatever I want, but my people will always be suffering."

Political dissent is second nature to Kuti, whose father's culture of underground protest against successive military regimes led to frequent jail sentences. His grandmother died after being thrown from a window by soldiers raiding Fela's self-declared republic of Kalakuta. Kuti chose his father's birthday in 1998 to launch his own student-allied Movement Against Second Slavery (Mass), on the eve of elections for Nigeria's first civilian government in 15 years.

Noting that 2.7m people in Nigeria are HIV positive, Kuti writes in the Unicef report: "Failing to educate people about the disease is like signing their death sentence." He is outraged that "no campaign against Aids started in Nigeria until 2000", and cites poverty and bad leadership as hurdles to altering high-risk behaviour - not least among the Lagos street children once dismissed as "area boys", now called "Fela's people".

"The youths are hungry and they have no future," he says. "You want to tell them they should not have the only pleasure they get in life - sex? It has to be handled by people who care. The government in Nigeria for the past year has been corrupt and greedy, and these are the leaders who want to educate people about Aids. If I were a youth and didn't have the opportunities I had, I'd never take them seriously; they don't look like people who care."

More than 1m mourners turned out for Fela's funeral in Nigeria's commercial capital, which Kuti, who played there, remembers with mixed emotions. "I was sad but overjoyed so many people came. People were weeping, crying 'Fela, Fela'; my father was truly loved. The whole of Lagos was on holiday. The police said no crime was recorded for two days; all the robbers were paying their respects."

But the man who famously married all 27 of his backing singers in addition to Femi's mother Remi, was often absent from his son's childhood. "I feel bad he wasn't there when I was young," he says. "But as a father today, I can understand and love him for who he was: a good, courageous man, who stood his ground, with the beatings and jailings - and a man of the people. It's difficult for a man who's loved by millions to have time for his family; he took everybody as his family."

Kuti joined his father's band, Egypt 80, as a teenage saxophonist. It was a difficult apprenticeship. "I knew he was a living legend, like a god, a unique genius, and that if I wanted to play music, everyone would be comparing me, saying, 'You're Fela's son, so what have you got to show for it?' " Fela believed those with a gift need not be taught. "I had no musical education; I learned in his band, just keeping my eyes and ears open. He'd dictate his songs to me; he might sit on the toilet and say, 'Get a pen and paper and write this down.' "

Kuti took on his father's mantle in 1984, fronting the band at the Hollywood Bowl after Fela was detained at the airport and jailed for 20 months on dubious currency charges (Amnesty International made him a prisoner of conscience). Kuti was by then restless. "I knew I'd never get what I wanted in his band - to play music. I was in charge of so many affairs; he relied on me."

There were other frustrations: "My father had so many wives, every time I picked up my saxophone somebody complained about the noise. My grandmother said, 'Eh, what kind of musician are you? I never hear you practising.' I couldn't sleep that night. I went on a vegetarian diet and started teaching myself scales and to read music. I listened to jazz tapes and read books on Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, John Coltrane."

Kuti, striving to become a worthy successor, remained in his father's band till his release from jail, then left in 1986 to found his own. "He was really mad the day I said I was resigning. We didn't talk for five years." They were reconciled in 1990, on his grandmother's birthday, when Fela invited his son's struggling band to play on Sundays at his club, the Shrine. "I could feel the negative vibes that day; all the women were angry - Femi's back. But my father never missed a Sunday."

Fela's followers were sceptical. "Sometimes I played to three people in the audience; it was horrible," Kuti laughs. "It took five years, from 1986, to get any audience for our show." But by 1995, his album Wonder, Wonder was deemed so good some claimed his father had made it. Kuti has also worked with US rappers such as Common and the Roots, and a Shoki Shoki dance remix has been released. He is also recording a new album, due next year.

He plans to use his career "to do as much as possible to rectify the problems back home", and is setting up a trust for Mass. He is securely his own man, as evinced by a new song he played at the Barbican last month called 1997. The song, whose title refers to the year in which not only his father died, but also a sister from misdiagnosed cancer, and a cousin, shows that Kuti cannot only animate dancefloors but play mature, soulful sounds.

Kuti and family are building a new club not far from the Shrine, which is now closed. The Africa Shrine is to open this autumn. "It's like a temple, and people depend so much on that heritage; why should I run away from it?"

Though he declines to criticise him ("Who am I to judge my father?"), Kuti has turned his back on Fela's lifestyle - the excesses of alcohol and marijuana, and the sexual mores that contributed to his death. "It's because I saw my father's life that I can rectify some things. I can't go out of control; when I see a beautiful woman, am I not human? But I say, 'Am I ready to see my wife hurt?' No: so I'm going to do everything in my power to keep my marriage."

He also takes his four-year-old son, Omrinmade - a budding trumpeter - on the road. "It's very stressful, but I've only got one life, so I'm ready to do anything to keep him beside me. When I hear my son jumping and screaming, I can't explain the joy. That's happiness - and when my band can play every night."

fields.bodyText: When Femi Kuti's father, the Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti, died in 1997, it was the first his family knew for certain that he had Aids. "We suspected much earlier, in 1986," says Kuti. "But we never knew till the doctors confirmed it; he was never tested when he was alive." The family decision to announce the cause of the Nigerian superstar's death at 58 marked the start of a campaign by his eldest son against "silence and stigma". Kuti recalls: "There wasn't enough information in Nigeria about Aids, just news from outside saying it was caused by homosexuals, or that it came from monkeys in central Africa. Many of us didn't believe it - and I was one. I thought it was racist propaganda. I'm saddened that it took my father's death for us to take Aids seriously." Kuti has added his voice to a new Unicef report, published today, which focuses on Aids as "the greatest catastrophe facing the continent of Africa" and beyond. It follows news from the Aids summit in Durban at the weekend that the pandemic kills 2m people a year in Africa and that 23m Africans are infected with HIV. At 37, Kuti is among a growing number of African musicians - including Miriam Makeba and Youssou N'Dour - using their fame to promote HIV awareness on and off stage. While personal bereavement gives Kuti's message an edge, it is carried by his rocketing worldwide success as a vocalist and saxophonist with his band the Positive Force, whose backing singers include his wife Funke and sister Yeni. Shoki Shoki, Kuti's first album on the Talkin' Loud label, was a recording highlight of last year. At the World Music Awards in Monte Carlo in May, he was named bestselling African artist, after being voted best male artist last September in the pan-African Kora awards - Africa's Grammies. Even staunch fans of his father now hail the son as Fela's reincarnation. Yet the sudden glare of publicity after years in his father's shadow has put Kuti in reflective mood. "A lot of fame is coming to me now," he says in London as he heads for a north American tour this month, after sellout concerts in Paris and at the Barbican, London. "I could say I'm living my dream: it's what I've worked so hard for for 13 years - to be internationally known. But I can't stop thinking about what's going on in Africa. When I go back to Nigeria I'll be able to afford whatever I want, but my people will always be suffering." Political dissent is second nature to Kuti, whose father's culture of underground protest against successive military regimes led to frequent jail sentences. His grandmother died after being thrown from a window by soldiers raiding Fela's self-declared republic of Kalakuta. Kuti chose his father's birthday in 1998 to launch his own student-allied Movement Against Second Slavery (Mass), on the eve of elections for Nigeria's first civilian government in 15 years. Noting that 2.7m people in Nigeria are HIV positive, Kuti writes in the Unicef report: "Failing to educate people about the disease is like signing their death sentence." He is outraged that "no campaign against Aids started in Nigeria until 2000", and cites poverty and bad leadership as hurdles to altering high-risk behaviour - not least among the Lagos street children once dismissed as "area boys", now called "Fela's people". "The youths are hungry and they have no future," he says. "You want to tell them they should not have the only pleasure they get in life - sex? It has to be handled by people who care. The government in Nigeria for the past year has been corrupt and greedy, and these are the leaders who want to educate people about Aids. If I were a youth and didn't have the opportunities I had, I'd never take them seriously; they don't look like people who care." More than 1m mourners turned out for Fela's funeral in Nigeria's commercial capital, which Kuti, who played there, remembers with mixed emotions. "I was sad but overjoyed so many people came. People were weeping, crying 'Fela, Fela'; my father was truly loved. The whole of Lagos was on holiday. The police said no crime was recorded for two days; all the robbers were paying their respects." But the man who famously married all 27 of his backing singers in addition to Femi's mother Remi, was often absent from his son's childhood. "I feel bad he wasn't there when I was young," he says. "But as a father today, I can understand and love him for who he was: a good, courageous man, who stood his ground, with the beatings and jailings - and a man of the people. It's difficult for a man who's loved by millions to have time for his family; he took everybody as his family." Kuti joined his father's band, Egypt 80, as a teenage saxophonist. It was a difficult apprenticeship. "I knew he was a living legend, like a god, a unique genius, and that if I wanted to play music, everyone would be comparing me, saying, 'You're Fela's son, so what have you got to show for it?' " Fela believed those with a gift need not be taught. "I had no musical education; I learned in his band, just keeping my eyes and ears open. He'd dictate his songs to me; he might sit on the toilet and say, 'Get a pen and paper and write this down.' " Kuti took on his father's mantle in 1984, fronting the band at the Hollywood Bowl after Fela was detained at the airport and jailed for 20 months on dubious currency charges (Amnesty International made him a prisoner of conscience). Kuti was by then restless. "I knew I'd never get what I wanted in his band - to play music. I was in charge of so many affairs; he relied on me." There were other frustrations: "My father had so many wives, every time I picked up my saxophone somebody complained about the noise. My grandmother said, 'Eh, what kind of musician are you? I never hear you practising.' I couldn't sleep that night. I went on a vegetarian diet and started teaching myself scales and to read music. I listened to jazz tapes and read books on Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, John Coltrane." Kuti, striving to become a worthy successor, remained in his father's band till his release from jail, then left in 1986 to found his own. "He was really mad the day I said I was resigning. We didn't talk for five years." They were reconciled in 1990, on his grandmother's birthday, when Fela invited his son's struggling band to play on Sundays at his club, the Shrine. "I could feel the negative vibes that day; all the women were angry - Femi's back. But my father never missed a Sunday." Fela's followers were sceptical. "Sometimes I played to three people in the audience; it was horrible," Kuti laughs. "It took five years, from 1986, to get any audience for our show." He is securely his own man, as evinced by a new song he played at the Barbican last month called 1997. The song, whose title refers to the year in which not only his father died, but also a sister from misdiagnosed cancer, and a cousin, shows that Kuti cannot only animate dancefloors but play mature, soulful sounds. Kuti and family are building a new club not far from the Shrine, which is now closed. The Africa Shrine is to open this autumn. "It's like a temple, and people depend so much on that heritage; why should I run away from it?" Though he declines to criticise him ("Who am I to judge my father?"), Kuti has turned his back on Fela's lifestyle - the excesses of alcohol and marijuana, and the sexual mores that contributed to his death. fields.headline: Attacks rain down on Mbeki
fields.standfirst:
International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: A leading US Aids researcher added his voice yesterday to the chorus of criticism of the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, for his attitude to the causes of the disease.
fields.body:
A leading US Aids researcher added his voice yesterday to the chorus of criticism of the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, for his attitude to the causes of the disease.

"President Mbeki, I beg you not to let your legacy be defined by inaction on this human tragedy," Dr David Ho said in a speech to the 13th International Aids Conference in Durban.

The fears of the South African government that the conference would become an "Mbeki-bashing affair" were realised as fresh salvoes were launched against him for courting so-called "Aids dissidents" who deny that HIV causes Aids.

Dr Ho, who is at the Aaron Diamond Aids research centre at New York's Rockefeller university and the researcher best known for showing that strong drug cocktails can keep Aids at bay, showed a microscope photograph of the HIV virus attacking a cell. "This, ladies and gentlemen, is the cause of Aids," he declared.

His attack was the latest in a string of criticisms of Mr Mbeki's opening speech to the conference on Sunday which many of the 10,000 delegates saw as a wasted opportunity for Mr Mbeki to draw a line under his controversial stance on the disease.

The furore surrounding the president has overshadowed the conference's purpose of fighting the scourge of HIV-Aids which now infects more than 34m people and poses a major economic and security threat to the developing world.

The London-based Panos Institute told the conference that at least 12m people with HIV worldwide needed drugs to suppress the virus which would cost an estimated $60bn a year at current prices.

But Mr Mbeki's role in the debate remained centre stage.

Eminent researchers from the US, Europe and South Africa have hit out at Mr Mbeki's speech which, though repeating his determination to fight Aids, focused more on the devastating role of poverty.

The president's office dismissed Dr Ho's criticism. "It's unfair to jump to the conclusion that, because he has the right to ask questions, we are going backwards," a spokeswoman said.
Reuters

webTitle: No reprieve on Aids, expert warns west

fields.headline: No reprieve on Aids, expert warns west
fields.standfirst:
Durban conference HIV levels on rise again

International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: Western complacency over Aids is ill judged because globalisation means we cannot escape the consequences of major epidemics in Africa or Asia, a British expert warned in Durban yesterday.
fields.body:
Western complacency over Aids is ill judged because globalisation means we cannot escape the consequences of major epidemics in Africa or Asia, a British expert warned in Durban yesterday.

Roy Anderson of the UNAids collaborating centre for epidemiological research, based at Oxford University, said the numbers of people infected with HIV were rising again.

"We have not by any means seen the worst of this problem," he said. "It will get progressively worse over the next 10 to 15 years. People often cite the 1918 influenza pandemic, which caused over 30m deaths. This is going to be many factors bigger than that."

There is an assumption among some in the west that the problem of Aids has gone away, he said. Drugs are suppressing the virus levels in infected people so that they can live normal lives.

But researchers in the field are finding that, as people live longer, so the pool of people infected with HIV who could potentially pass it to others increases, and there is no way of eradicating the virus.

"In the US now, mortality is beginning to rise again very slowly," said Professor Anderson. "The virus becomes resistant to the drugs if people do not take their medication exactly as stipulated by doctors. There has also been an increase in risk-taking behaviour by people who assume the drugs will protect them from Aids and an early death."

In the UK, there has been a very slow but progressive spread among heterosexuals.

"It is creeping along. We're at the beginning of an epidemic for heterosexuals," said Prof Anderson, warning that the full enormity of the global disaster is difficult to estimate. "People don't fully understand that the timescale is 40 to 50 years for this epidemic."

The crisis in sub-Saharan Africa, where 25m people are infected with HIV, is a tragedy for the world, he said.

"This is the biggest infectious disease problem that has faced humanity in the course of human history. We can't isolate ourselves. What happens in Africa does matter to us. There are also economic fac tors too. If labour markets are not there because of the enormous burden of disease, that will have a knock-on effect."

Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in the US yesterday told the Aids 2000 conference in Durban that even when virus levels had been undetectable in infected people for considerable periods, they soared again within a month of stopping drug treatment.

The drugs appear to have little effect on a reservoir of virus in body tissues, even when they suppress it in the blood, he said.

But vaccines and cheaper drugs are, nevertheless, the hope for the future. Dr Fauci said he was running trials on interrupted drug regimes - where people whose HIV is under control are taken off medication every other week. His preliminary results show that the viral levels did not go up during the week off.

He warned that nobody should experiment alone with stopping their medication, because of the dangers of the virus developing resistance to the drugs.

"The numbers are still small and we need to look at the critical effect after a year or two. But it is encouraging," he said.

fields.headline: Nip, tuck, sheen and buff
fields.standfirst: Manipulated images
fields.trailText: Manipulated images: So, impossibly skinny models promote an unhealthy image of the female body? That's not the half of it - judging by a new book of fashion photography, thinness is no longer enough.
fields.body:
So, impossibly skinny models promote an unhealthy image of the female body? That's not the half of it - judging by a new book of fashion photography, thinness is no longer enough. To really stand out, a girl has to sport a gash in her forehead, antelope horns in her shoulders or get herself modified into an S&M coffee table. Fortunately technology is so advanced that it can all be done in the painless, sterilised environment of the digital post-production lab.

Digital image manipulation is now so sophisticated that you wonder why any model needs to be a standard shape. In The Impossible Image, a new book edited by Mark Sanders, Phil Poynter and Robin Derrick, the link between the images and the bodies they represent is so tenuous that you wonder whether a real person ever shivered in a G-string in front of a real camera. Yet even the most abstract pictures seem to have involved physical participation at some point. As the credits reveal, there were hair and make-up artists even on a series like Sister Honey, where Nick Knight transforms women's bodies into an amorphous blur.

In his breathless introduction, Derrick enthuses about the new possibility of creating images that could never exist without digital intervention. He rightly points out that we expect to see artifice in fashion photography. And yet we do usually expect it to refer to reality, to convey at least some workable impression of what a particular shape of body might look like wearing a particular article of clothing.

But the most extreme of these digital pictures turn up their artfully modified noses at the very idea of flogging frocks. Many jettison the clothes entirely, not to mention any coherent image of the human body. Some are so abstract that you can't imagine how they could conventionally be classified as fashion photos at all. A lot of the work goes way beyond the imaginations of even our nuttier film-makers. In some photos, the body is mutated in ways so subtle you have to look twice. The young couple in Lee Jenkins's pictures seem normal enough at first - except that his mouth has been tweaked into a gently skewy shape and she has had her nose removed.

Some artists spin out entire narrative riffs. Andrea Giacobbe's brilliantly barmy La Comédie presents a wax-faced, grey-haired man and a little girl with horns, wearing name tags that identify them as God and Humanity. In stills from an weird unmade movie, the two of them play chess and hitchhike. Elsewhere, bodies dissolve entirely into smears of light. Nick Knight, in particular, seems to have an animus against the physical condition, and does everything he can to warp it: in his two series, Sweets and Dolls, he revels in colour and shape, leaving the body as a bendable matrix or a surface for graffiti-like daubs.

The best of the book's images venture into textures and images that are autonomous, that have nothing to sell beyond their own aesthetic thrill. But considering the possibilities, it's amazing how many of the artists opt for romantic high gloss, like Vincent Peters, or to the clean visual punning of 70s rock album covers by studios like Hipgnosis. Solve Sundsbo's The Office could be 10cc, Norbert Schoerner's water bottle suspended in mid-air is Pink Floyd, and Poynter's Cunning Stunts - a sci-fi vamp farting fire - has a nasty odour of German heavy metal.

While the book is full of big, striking images and expensively executed conceits, what is most exciting is to find a telling detail that brings the technology itself into perspective. Stéphane Sednaoui's series of Mary Anne frolicking with a blurred-light incubus cleverly merges 3-D physicality with 2-D abstraction, but the genius touch is a rainbow streak in the model's hair that apparently has no logical reason to be there, and so suggests a glitch in the otherwise flawless imaging process. Of course it's not really an accident, but it suggests the possibility of a random factor. The pictures in The Impossible Image that give space to the ghosts in the digital machine genuinely justify their claims to a new futuristic beauty; the ones that use the technology simply to nip and tuck and sheen and buff are stuck in a retro hinterland of Athena-poster kitsch.

The editors of The Impossible Image (Phaidon, £24.95) discuss it tonight at the Photographers' Gallery, London WC2. Details: 020-7831 1772.

webTitle: 'Nine times out of ten the theatre is boring'

fields.headline: 'Nine times out of ten the theatre is boring'
fields.standfirst: Don't worry, Bob Crowley is here to make it interesting.  Lyn Gardner meets the designer bringing a touch of Liberace kitsch to The Witches of Eastwick
fields.trailText: Don't worry, Bob Crowley is here to make it interesting. Lyn Gardner meets the designer bringing a touch of Liberace kitsch to The Witches of Eastwick
fields.body:
Over the past few weeks, designer Bob Crowley has been dividing his time between two London theatres. At the Donmar Warehouse, he has been putting the final touches to his designs for Orpheus Descending. A stone's throw away at the Theatre Royal Drury Lane, he has been working flat out on The Witches of Eastwick, the latest musical from the stable of Cameron Mackintosh, the producer behind such hits as Les Misérables and Miss Saigon. At the Donmar, Crowley's entire design budget was about £30,000. For The Witches of Eastwick he has had a figure in the region of £2m.

So what is the difference, besides the size of the budget, between working on a straight play and a musical? "The state of people's nerves," says Crowley dryly. "There is just so much at stake."

Certainly Drury Lane looks like it is in mayhem. Rehearsals on stage are competing with the theatre's regular backstage guided tours, and every nook and cranny of the huge theatre is filled with hustle and bustle as even at this late stage songs are rewritten and the action reshaped.

"When you start working on a play, you have a script and the shape of it doesn't change very much. But a musical changes all the time. It is like a wet fish - you can't ever get hold of it." Amid all this chaos the rumpled, amiable Crowley looks remarkably relaxed.

"That's only because I know that they can't really change the set at this stage," says Crowley, who finished the designs last November and has been in the theatre since February, watching the set take shape. " Is it that long?" he queries himself. "My, doesn't time fly when you are having seizures."

For all his self-effacement and slightly bumbling air, Crowley, 48, is about as big as you can get in stage design. He has just scooped a Tony award for Elton John's Aida, and is working on a new John Guare and Marvin Hamlisch musical Sweet Smell of Success with director Nick Hytner; he also has Chekhov's The Seagull lined up (to be performed in New York's Central Park), plus Falstaff at the Metropolitan Opera in New York next summer. He worries about becoming cynical: "You see a lot of cynical design, particularly with the blockbuster musicals. It is design that is more redolent of a car launch rather than a theatrical experience. You do have to guard against it." Crowley also thinks that technology has its place, but only a limited one, in the designer's repertoire.

There is nothing cynical about Crowley's designs for The Witches of Eastwick, based on John Updike's novel about three sparky women. Bored out of their minds in a sleepy New England town, they conjure up strange events, and their fantasies are made flesh in the shape of the devilish Darryl Van Horne.

Anyone who has followed Crowley since his work with the RSC in the 80s (where he designed Les Liaisons Dangereuses and a memorable As You Like It) and his subsequent work in the late 80s and early 90s at the National Theatre, will recognise Witches as a classic Crowley show. The budget may be bigger, but there is the same exquisite simplicity, a leaning towards the suggestive rather than the explicit. In Crowley's realisation, Eastwick is a place in which "Norman Rockwell meets Edward Scissorhands", where beneath the perfectly manicured lawns something strange is taking place.

Crowley knows the US east coast mentality and geography well. His first big musical, in 1993, was Nick Hytner's National Theatre revival of the clambake classic Carousel (which also won Crowley a Tony), and he spent some months a few miles outside Salem designing the costumes for the film of The Crucible, starring Daniel Day Lewis and Winona Ryder. Those big, federal houses, restored to within an inch of their lives, and their white picket fences are transfigured into 70s disco kitsch in Crowley's design for the Van Horne mansion as "Hugh Hefner meets Liberace".

With Crowley getting to play with almost half of the show's projected £4.5m budget, there is an argument for saying that we've reached a point where the designer of a big musical is taking precedence over the director, that he is in fact the more important member of the creative team, reducing the director to the position of steering traffic, ensuring the actors don't bump into the set. Crowley insists that this isn't the case on The Witches of Eastwick, although he says: "I don't see myself as someone who designs backgrounds for other people's productions. I do conceptualise quite strongly."

Certainly the equal status of designers and directors is a far cry from the late 70s when Crowley, inspired by the late, great Sean Kenny's pared down, almost Brechtian sets for Oliver!, went to study theatre design at the Bristol Old Vic. fields.bodyText: Over the past few weeks, designer Bob Crowley has been dividing his time between two London theatres. At the Donmar Warehouse, he has been putting the final touches to his designs for Orpheus Descending. A stone's throw away at the Theatre Royal Drury Lane, he has been working flat out on The Witches of Eastwick, the latest musical from the stable of Cameron Mackintosh, the producer behind such hits as Les Misérables and Miss Saigon. At the Donmar, Crowley's entire design budget was about £30,000. For The Witches of Eastwick he has had a figure in the region of £2m. So what is the difference, besides the size of the budget, between working on a straight play and a musical? "The state of people's nerves," says Crowley dryly. "There is just so much at stake." Certainly Drury Lane looks like it is in mayhem. Rehearsals on stage are competing with the theatre's regular backstage guided tours, and every nook and cranny of the huge theatre is filled with hustle and bustle as even at this late stage songs are rewritten and the action reshaped. "When you start working on a play, you have a script and the shape of it doesn't change very much. But a musical changes all the time. It is like a wet fish - you can't ever get hold of it." Amid all this chaos the rumpled, amiable Crowley looks remarkably relaxed. "That's only because I know that they can't really change the set at this stage," says Crowley, who finished the designs last November and has been in the theatre since February, watching the set take shape. " Is it that long?" he queries himself. "My, doesn't time fly when you are having seizures." For all his self-effacement and slightly bumbling air, Crowley, 48, is about as big as you can get in stage design. He has just scooped a Tony award for Elton John's Aida, and is working on a new John Guare and Marvin Hamlisch musical Sweet Smell of Success with director Nick Hytner; he also has Chekhov's The Seagull lined up (to be performed in New York's Central Park), plus Falstaff at the Metropolitan Opera in New York next summer. It is design that is more redolent of a car launch rather than a theatrical experience. You do have to guard against it." fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Any patriotic soul, depressed by the state of British sport and the third-world standard of our public services, will be cheered to learn that there is still one area in which this country leads the world ... corporate bribery. Of the 54 firms the World Bank has barred from involvement in its projects, no less than 36 are British. Hurrah!
fields.body:
Any patriotic soul, depressed by the state of British sport and the third-world standard of our public services, will be cheered to learn that there is still one area in which this country leads the world ... corporate bribery. Of the 54 firms the World Bank has barred from involvement in its projects, no less than 36 are British. Hurrah!

Meanwhile, four UK firms are on trial in Lesotho for alleged bribery concerning a Lesotho dam project. Apparently one of these, Balfour Beatty (the civil engineering giant whose office was recently raided by the FBI over a rail modernisation scheme in Boston) is suggesting that it is not on trial in Lesotho at all.

We are happy to clear up any confusion. The firm is still on trial as part of a consortium, but the case has been suspended due to the disappearance of a key witness, one Max Cohen, the Swiss businessman accused on the charge sheet of carrying a bribe for Balfour Beatty.

Interpol, which has issued a warrant for Mr Cohen's arrest, may be interested to know that his address in Switzerland is Rennweg 32, Zurich.

 Did anyone else know that actor Russell Crowe is a first cousin of the great New Zealand batsman Martin Crowe? Their fathers are brothers. This is not the only sport/movie acting family relationship to concern us (you recall that Sun football writer Steven Howard is the nephew of Gone With the Wind star Leslie Howard), and if we have many more days as quiet as yesterday, it almost certainly won't be the last.

 And people dare to suggest he's cracking up under the strain! Behold, Alastair Campbell, newly installed as odds-on favourite for Mr Lovely Legs 2000, snapped outside his children's school, Gospel Oak primary, by the Hampstead and Highgate Express. (Anyone who finds themselves strangely excited by this is directed to Busking With Bagpipes, a story available on request from Forum magazine.)

 The Daily Telegraph's campaign to dominate the youth culture broadsheet market moves on apace. "Eminem," says a portentous front-page trailer, "the situation gets worse." Well, yes, it is a worry if you're a Telegraph reader, the troubled private life of an American rap artist. Sometimes, I don't know how they get to sleep at night. On page 7, meanwhile, pictured at a Paris fashion show, is Puff Daddy. Where will it end?

 A possible solution to the chronic British problem of NHS bed shortages comes from the orient. Doctors in Japan are petitioning for the right to perform minor operations on the golf course. "We're not talking transplants or bypasses," says a spokesman. "But many operations don't require elaborate operating theatre procedures and could easily be performed between rounds."

 A reader calls with more news of Boris the Jackal Johnson, the would-be Tory MP for Henley, whom he spotted driving that blue convertible Roller down the Holloway Road last Friday evening. Clearly, from the RR1 number plate, this is a car he has borrowed from the firm, presumably for an article. This gives me an idea, and we hope to report back shortly.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: At first I don't know what to make of Laura. She resigned from her secretarial job after a campaign by her boss of the sort of unimaginative smut that would make most people flee. "Are you a natural blonde? Shall I take a look?" (Fingering her skirt.) "If you're hot, why not take that blouse off? I won't tell anyone."
fields.body:
At first I don't know what to make of Laura. She resigned from her secretarial job after a campaign by her boss of the sort of unimaginative smut that would make most people flee. "Are you a natural blonde? Shall I take a look?" (Fingering her skirt.) "If you're hot, why not take that blouse off? I won't tell anyone."

If thousands of men recognise themselves in these remarks, I'm not surprised. You don't need much experience of harassment cases to know that the lines are pretty standard. Sometimes I think there must be special sexism conferences these blokes attend, with "Tits and bums" lectures (how to make a young woman who works for you feel uncomfortable about her appearance) and "bait and switch" role-play (how to alternate saucy remarks and innuendos with hostility/criticism/silence to maximise employee discomfiture).

Laura, who is 19 and shivery, didn't have any training. She tried a strategy a lot of people in power-deficit positions try. I call it humorous appeasement. The blokes call it "banter" or "she liked it really". So when Bossman Fingers delivered his line about natural blondes, Laura giggled and said: "Get off. I don't ask if you're bald all over."

Fingers chuckled off back to the water cooler. Laura sat at her WP wondering where this was leading. A few more of these interchanges and she wasn't sleeping much. Once Fingers started suggesting extracurricular weekend trips Laura could attend as his "assistant", her GP put her on antidepressants.

What I found hard to understand and what I ask Laura in conference is what she said about the "last straw" that caused her to hand in her notice. She is in tears for the first time: "The other girls wouldn't have lunch with me."

"Why?"

"Because they thought I was sleeping with him, that I would repeat stuff to him."

"But why was that worse than what went before?"

Laura covers her face and tears slide through her fingers. "Because then, you know, it was just me on a bench, eating my sandwiches alone. I was so alone."

I suddenly feel I've been slow and insensitive. Even more so when I go with some other barristers to lunch in one of the Inns of Court halls. On the table is a sheet of paper announcing the results of the Inn's survey of some modest alterations made to the lunch arrangements. Among the encomia of the food and the dinner ladies and the plaintive grumbles about "breaks with tradition", there is a comment about the disadvantages of the new table arrangement which stabs me to the heart: "Unable to sit with friends."

fields.headline: Angels with dirty faces
fields.standfirst: It started as a celebration and ended as an elegy to a lost world. Playwright  Alan Plater describes the bizarre life of Close the Coalhouse Door
fields.trailText: It started as a celebration and ended as an elegy to a lost world. Playwright Alan Plater describes the bizarre life of Close the Coalhouse Door
fields.body:
A third of a century ago, a meeting was convened in the Newcastle front room of the late Sid Chaplin, Durham pitman turned short story writer and novelist. Those present were singer-songwriter Alex Glasgow, director Bill Hays and myself - all native north-easterners. Indeed, I once said to a Labour MP during a radio interview: "I was born in Jarrow - beat that for credentials."

Sid gave us some stories, Alex wrote the songs, Richard Fynes's 1873 classic The Miners of Northumberland and Durham gave us all the history we needed, and inherited prejudice did the rest. I assembled the bits into a show called Close the Coalhouse Door, which opened in April 1968 at the old Newcastle Playhouse (later demolished in the cause of "road improvements") to rave notices and sell-out business.

On the first night my agent, Peggy Ramsay, grabbed my arm after and said: "My God, darling, this is revolutionary." Later, when the London managements came hot on its trail, she said it was much too tough for the West End. She was right. Brian Rix, a former Bevin boy, bravely put the show on at the Fortune Theatre to more rave reviews - the critics voted it the best musical of the year - and sparse audiences, most of whom I subsequently met.

It was when the revivals began that the project got a little complicated. The form of the show is the golden wedding party of Thomas and Mary Milburn. The guests reminisce about the history of their village and Brockenback pit (a real name Sid provided), starting in the 1830s and finishing in the present. The style of the piece begins with documentary realism, then drifts through vaudeville into a kind of unspoken surrealism.

In the third act Lord Hailsham turns up and sings a song called My Little Cloth Cap, closely followed by Harold Wilson with the words: "Good evening, brothers, I've just popped in to explain the government's fuel policy."

The problem was defining the "now". Ted Heath arrived on the scene and was written into the show, as were the successful miners' strikes of 1972 and 1974. I wrote the amendments for the 1974 Leeds Playhouse revival by candlelight, during the blackouts resulting from Sailor Ted's three-day weeks. But the narrative logic meant that our central couple, Thomas and Mary (named after my grandparents) became older and older and the show got longer and longer.

Arguably, the most adventurous version was performed by a fringe company from Wales, as a three-hander. They presented it as a radio play, with the three performers gathered around a microphone in the centre of the stage.

The most explosive was a production in Musselburgh, a (then) mining community east of Edinburgh, during the 1984-5 strike. At the end, the local colliery band marched in and lined up behind the actors, banners flying, for Alex's final sardonic chorus: "It's only a story - a fanciful tale."

I took part in an onstage discussion after the show with NUM and community representatives. British Coal had promised a spokesperson - presumably one of Thatcher's lesser lackeys - but he didn't show up. It was a wise decision.

The show continues to be performed by amateur groups and schools - even once in a prison - wherever there's a mining tradition. A decade ago, when working at the Australian Film School in Sydney, I had a call from a campus in Newcastle, New South Wales, to say it was on their syllabus and would I come to talk to staff and students about it?

So far, so nostalgic. At this point, one of my lesser fantasies takes over. My desk has a visit from a royal personage who accepts the flowers and says: "One must have seen a great many changes while one has been writing one's plays." To which one says: "You bet, babe."

For a start, when we were casting the original show, it was difficult finding actors who would admit to being Geordies. Bolton-born Bryan Pringle qualified by having an Auntie Bella in Gateshead.

On the other hand, we were able to afford a bigger and better cast because the BBC threw some money (memory says it was £400) into the stage production in exchange for the television rights which, in those days, meant a single showing on The Wednesday Play. The tape was apparently wiped long ago.

T hirty years on, the Geordie accent is part of our national culture and, according to research, is universally trusted. Robson Green, Kevin Whateley, Jimmy Nail and Tim Healy are bankable lead actors in the eyes of television executives.

Consequently, casting the most recent revival at Newcastle's Live Theatre was easy, except in terms of economics. Most regional theatres have lived on the breadline since the 80s. The original production had a cast of 11, plus a five-band brass ensemble. The revival had a cast of eight brilliant and versatile performers who played their own instruments. Both productions had a brass band on special occasions. We didn't bother to ask whether anyone would be interested in a television version.

So much for luvvie talk. What about the subject - the pits, the pitmen and their communities? It's no state secret. Thatcher and her imported hitman, McGregor, set out to destroy them and succeeded. In the latest, and probably last, version of the play, there's a brief exchange among the characters about the 1984-5 strike.

"The best ever. Because it wasn't about money."

"But we lost, didn't we?"

"It's still too early to say."

The cute people in Whitehall who are doing their best to remove the politics from politics would love us to believe that there are no longer such things as the working class, union solidarity or folk memory. To be sure, something very profound happens to a region when there are more art galleries than shipyards on the Tyne, when mining is something that happens in heritage museums, when disused pits are turned into dry ski slopes.

The industrial revolution is apparently over and our show, originally written as a hymn of praise to the miners, is now an elegy for a lost world. Memory becomes history and history becomes legend. But politicians should take note: legends endure and have a habit of making mischief in the debating chamber while the focus groups are taking a decaffienated coffee break.

The updated version of Close the Coalhouse Door is published by Bloodaxe Books at £7.95.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Quiet Revolution/Connect
fields.body:
Whitehaven, on the edge of the Lake District, is hardly one of England's fun spots, suffering chronic unemployment and one of the nation's highest suicide rates. Against this dismal background the Rev Jim Baker persuaded the council to sell part of the market hall to his Whitehaven Youth Trust. The building now houses facilities for unemployed youngsters and a cafe which they run themselves. As Felicity Finch (pictured) discovers in Quiet Revolution (11.0am, Radio 4), the Trust has become the mainstay of local regeneration.

Quentin Cooper launches an eight-part series to "explore the relationship between technology and humanity". Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) sounds at first like one of those tedious efforts to make us love our computers. However, its direction becomes clearer in the first episode, which explores the development of container transport and the revolution it brought in world trade. The fall in transport costs has given consumers an unprecedented choice of goods from around the world.
fields.bodyText: Whitehaven, on the edge of the Lake District, is hardly one of England's fun spots, suffering chronic unemployment and one of the nation's highest suicide rates. Against this dismal background the Rev Jim Baker persuaded the council to sell part of the market hall to his Whitehaven Youth Trust. The building now houses facilities for unemployed youngsters and a cafe which they run themselves. As Felicity Finch (pictured) discovers in Quiet Revolution (11.0am, Radio 4), the Trust has become the mainstay of local regeneration. Quentin Cooper launches an eight-part series to "explore the relationship between technology and humanity". Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) sounds at first like one of those tedious efforts to make us love our computers. However, its direction becomes clearer in the first episode, which explores the development of container transport and the revolution it brought in world trade. The fall in transport costs has given consumers an unprecedented choice of goods from around the world.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge?
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge?
fields.body:
In stark contrast to the hiii-yah posturing of his oft-celebrated film work, Belgian martial arts icon Jean-Claude Van Damme (pictured) took his punishment rather meekly this week, pleading no contest - and through his lawyers, to boot - to charges arising from his arrest for drink-driving last September. The DUI rap came after the (oh, how I wanted not to use this phrase) Muscles from Brussels was apprehended driving "erratically" down Sunset Boulevard in the wee small hours of September 23rd, whereupon he was found to have a blood-alcohol level which somewhat contradicted his 1997 declaration of sobriety (made having wound up in a Californian substance-abuse clinic to undergo treatment for cocaine dependency). In his absence, Beverly Hills Municipal Judge Charles Rubin handed the actor three years probation and a $1,200 fine, as well as banning him from driving excepting journeys to and from work: which, bearing in mind the current state of the man's career, basically means he's banned from driving.

Meanwhile, just as Van Damme was swallowing his medicine, another courtroom habitué, R'n'B crooner Bobby Brown, exited clink 10 days early on the unexpected grounds of good behaviour. Brown, still best known as the spouse of Whitney Houston, had originally been sentenced to 75 days in Fort Lauderdale's Joseph Conte Center after repeatedly violating his parole on a 1996 DUI conviction, only to walk within four weeks when time served in custody and his spotless record inside were taken into account. Brown was greeted by his wife (who arrived at the prison in a white stretch limo) and the comic Chris Rock, busy conducting a spoof candlelit vigil outside the gates. Being hugged by all and sundry upon his departure, Brown boldly yelled "it's beautiful out here" to nearby reporters. It sure is Bobby; it sure is.

fields.headline: The same old faces
fields.standfirst: In its heyday Spitting Image was hailed as the most savage satire in TV history. But as the show's makers sell off their infamous puppets,  Adam Sweeting  asks whether it really was so revolutionary
fields.trailText: In its heyday Spitting Image was hailed as the most savage satire in TV history. But as the show's makers sell off their infamous puppets, Adam Sweeting asks whether it really was so revolutionary
fields.body:
'They've got a puppet of John that's completely grey, haven't they?" Norma Major once asked ruefully, of ITV's satirical latex-fext Spitting Image. "I think they've gone too far to be funny." You could pick up a matched pair of John and Norma for an ironic 1,600 quid at the current Sotheby's auction of more than 200 puppets and 100 pencil sketches culled from the personal collection of Spitting Image creator Roger Law. But if you were that interested in the first place, you'd probably prefer something that lingered more vividly in the memory from the show's golden years, like the disgusting saliva-squirting Roy Hattersley, the Queen Mother brilliantly warped into a gin-guzzling Gracie Fields, or - reflecting the show's beginnings during the white heat of Thatcherism - one of its sequence of increasingly deranged, eyeball-rolling Margaret Thatchers.

If merely portraying people as grey was as far as Spitting Image had ever gone, it would never have deserved to get on television at all, let alone run for 14 years after its inauguration in 1984. Instead, it thrived on a recipe of situations pushed far beyond their logical extreme, and puppets which turned caricature into something closer to the hideous mutations you might expect to find in the aftermath of a nuclear war. Sometime education secretary Kenneth Baker was depicted as an oleaginous slug (he is reported not to be interested in buying his puppet), while former Liberal leader David Steel blamed Spitting Image for destroying his political credibility after it persistently depicted him as a finger-puppet poking out of a macabre David Owen's pocket, squawking excitable nonsense. Mick Jagger appeared as a monstrous gargoyle whose body was concealed behind his ballooning rubbery lips, while Norman Tebbit became the epitome of the Chingford Skinhead with his leather jacket and boot-boy sneer.

But satire is uniquely the product of its time, and Spitting Image outlived its era by an impressively wide margin. As it staggered on through the 90s, it became increasingly difficult to recognise it as the show which had originally rocked the barriers of popular taste and dared its targets to rise to its foul-smelling bait. In the mid-80s, yuppies soaked in Laurent Perrier champagne skidded their Porsches around the City's Square Mile against a backdrop of the Falklands War and the police-state brutality which the Thatcher government had mobilised against Arthur Scargill's striking miners. It was enough to generate a panicky sense that the foundations were slipping underneath a society which had previously been fairly calm and orderly, give or take the occasional political sex scandal or punk rock revolution. Before anyone would notice it at all in the uproar of political skulduggery and a nation of Loadsamoneys on the make, satire needed to equip itself with huge slavering fangs and rid itself of such encumbrances as good taste or pity for its subject-matter.

The origins of Spitting Image dated back to 1975, when Peter Fluck and Roger Law formed a working partnership and began making plasticine caricatures of assorted celebrities and public figures. In 1981, they first proposed a TV series using puppets based on their original models, though Spitting Image didn't go into production until 1984. Fittingly, Fluck and Law based themselves in a workshop in Limehouse, in the midst of the Docklands that came to sym bolise the 80s property boom. The show's first season was nearly its last. Having initially grabbed an impressive audience of eight million, Image found its viewers abandoning it in droves as the debut series wore on. The puppets were criticised for being sub-standard, while its satirical barbs lacked the required degree of deadly accuracy. However, by the time it returned for a second series, the problems had been solved while the audience seemed to have decided that it needed Spitting Image after all.

The programme proved to be a magnet for a whole generation of comics and satirical writers. The puppets' voices were supplied by the likes of Chris Barrie, Rory Bremner, Harry Enfield, Hugh Dennis and Pamela Stephenson, while under the writers' column you could find such durable comedy-land bylines as Ian Hislop and Nick Newman, Steve Punt, Moray Hunter and John Docherty.

It's hard to imagine any politician enjoying being ritually disembowelled on Spitting Image, but a few of them managed to put a brave face on it. Jeffrey Archer sent in a tape of his voice, to enable the production team to mimic him more accurately, while Denis Healey made a piece of mini-history by appearing on the programme in person.

But as years ticked past, the impression grew that the only worthwhile element was its puppets, as wit was replaced by witless abuse. Where the diet of Thatcher-era politicans, the brain-dead Ronald Reagan and the soap opera of the Royals originally offered oodles of comic mileage, the creeping political bland-out of first John Major, then the paranoid image-mongering of New Labour, found the satirical tank running dry. Still, the show lives on in Euroland. A French version, Les Guignols d'Info, is one of the most successful programmes on French TV.

fields.headline: Heads call for intelligence tests
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: National intelligence tests should be held at the start of pupils' secondary school careers as the only fair way of measuring improvement, headteachers said yesterday.
fields.body:
National intelligence tests should be held at the start of pupils' secondary school careers as the only fair way of measuring improvement, headteachers said yesterday.

The Secondary Heads Association said the "value added" by secondary schools could be assessed by comparing results of tests measuring potential at the start of secondary school with average points performance at GCSE at 16.

The Department for Education and Employment said it intended to publish, within the next few years, tables measuring how schools have improved pupils' performance. But John Dunford, the SHA general secretary, said it was "deplorable" they were not yet piloting ways of doing so.

Mr Dunford said tests by the National Foundation for Educational Research or the "Midyis" tests produced by Durham University, already used by many schools, should be extended nationwide and used at the start of whichever year a child moves to secondary school.

They were a much better guide than key stage two examinations held at age 11, which were a flawed guide to future performance, he said.

The SHA also criticised Ofsted, the school inspection service in England, for using free school meals as a way of comparing schools.

An Ofsted spokesman said benchmarking on the basis of free school meals was not its policy but the government's.
