webTitle: MS drug in prescribing row 'could save money'

fields.headline: MS drug in prescribing row 'could save money'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A prized anti-multiple sclerosis drug, set to be banned from NHS prescription pads because of its high cost, could actually save the country money in the long run, a new study claims.
fields.body:
A prized anti-multiple sclerosis drug, set to be banned from NHS prescription pads because of its high cost, could actually save the country money in the long run, a new study claims.

The drug, beta interferon, is at the centre of the row over "postcode prescribing", with variations in availability from one health authority to another across the UK.

Last month the government agency assessing whether the annual cost of the drug per patient - £9,000 a year - represented value for money confirmed a leaked report saying that it believed the NHS should stop prescribing it altogether.

But yesterday an alliance of MS sufferers and one of the manufacturers of the drug, the US biotech company Biogen, joined to promote new research challenging a key assumption by the agency, the national institute for clinical excellence. The author of the new study, Malcolm Kendrick, said Nice had based its calculations on a two-year course of the drug, because the clinical trials of beta interferon had been two years long.

Dr Kendrick argued that MS sufferers, of which there are about 85,000 in Britain, would actually get the drug for much longer, would continue to benefit, and would have better, longer, more useful lives as a result of treatment.

If the full cost to society of MS - such as time and workdays lost by patients and carers - was counted in, he said, beta interferon might actually save money for Britain as a whole.

"If two years is not long enough to show that a drug is effective, then we would have to stop prescribing almost every drug which has ever been developed," Dr Kendrick said.

The new study was funded by Biogen, but is published in this month's edition of the journal PharmacoEconomics.

Articles in the journal are subjected to vetting by independent experts.

According to one estimate, half of British MS sufferers have a clinical need for beta interferon, yet only 2% get it. The drug is widely prescribed in continental Europe.

Multiple sclerosis progressively destroys nerve cells, leading to increasing disability over decades, until sufferers are forced to give up their employment.

Josephine Timms, a 39-year-old who was diagnosed with the illness in 1998, said yesterday that after a 20-month struggle with her local health authority, she had persuaded it to fund beta interferon treatment for her.

"If this drug is the one thing that will buy me that very valuable time I need to be an active wife and mother, I would challenge anybody to try to take it away from me," she said.

webTitle: 'Gangster link' to bar in hostess case

fields.headline: 'Gangster link' to bar in hostess case
fields.trailText: A former hostess at the Tokyo bar that employed the missing British woman Lucie Blackman fled Japan because she was being stalked by a gangster client - a member of the notorious Yakuza.
fields.body:
A former hostess at the Tokyo bar that employed the missing British woman Lucie Blackman fled Japan because she was being stalked by a gangster client - a member of the notorious Yakuza.

The revelation came as police acknowledged the possibility of ties between the Japanese underworld and the Casablanca club, which is a focus of the investigation into Miss Blackman's disappearance.

Miss Blackman, 21, a former British Airways stewardess, had been working at the club for less than two months when she went missing on July 1. Police suspect she may have been abducted by a customer.

Last night her father, Tim Blackman, flew out to join her sister, Sophie, in the search for his daughter.

Her mother issued a statement saying: "If you are a parent, then maybe if you have a very close relationship with your child, then maybe you have some idea of what I am going through. I have no desire to speak with the press about how I am feeling."

According to a source familiar with the city's seedy Roppongi district, the Casablanca is known among hostesses as a popular haunt for gangsters.

"It pays well and recruits only the most attractive foreign women, but all the girls bitch that it is dangerous because lots of Yakuza go there," the source said.

That reputation dates back at least five years, when an American woman working at the Casablanca suddenly packed up her bags and took the next plane home. "She was freaked by a customer who followed her around for three or four days. She thought he was a big time gangster because he would wait for her after work in a big car with tinted windows," the source said.

"Although she tried changing her routes to and from work, she eventually left the country because she was so scared."

Toshiko Mii, deputy superintendent of the Azabu police station, did not rule out a gangster connection with Lucie's disappearance.

"It is true that Yakuza are often linked to these kinds of bars, but we don't yet know if that is the case this time. We need to gather more information. Police are also investigating a call from a man claiming that Miss Blackman, who was in debt, had gone with him to join a religious sect.

The Guardian was present when detectives visited the Casablanca to inquire about two men, believed to have been customers. They also requested records of Miss Blackman's salary.

Located on the sixth floor of a building that hosts a transvestite bar and a "topless, bottomless" gentleman's club, the Casablanca appears innocuous.

Walk through the heavy iron door and the interior is simple, Apart from a dozen high padded stalls and a few low tables, the only features are a bar the size of a kitchen counter and a large karaoke machine.

Customers, however, pay a minimum of £150 to sit here, having their drinks poured and their cigarettes lit by attractive blonde foreign women.

It is not prostitution, although the Casablanca, like many Roppongi hostess bars, operates like an escort agency. Hostesses are encouraged to go on afternoon dates with customers and then bring them back to the club in the evening. For this service, they can earn about £250 on top of their hourly pay of £30 to £60.

On the day of her disappearance, Miss Blackman told a friend she was going on a date. "She said it was one of the new customers at the bar," said Louise Phillips, who also works at the Casablanca.

Tetsuo Nishi, manager of the Casablanca, ruled out a mob connection. "None of our customers are Yakuza," he said. "Zero per cent."

webTitle: £40m BNFL deal to heal Tokyo rift

fields.headline: £40m BNFL deal to heal Tokyo rift
fields.standfirst:
Cash and fuel compensation after row over false data

Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels is to pay £20 million in cash and offer £20 million worth of free fuel to Japan as part of a compensation deal for sending plutonium fuel with falsified quality control data last year.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo, Paul Brown  in London and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels is to pay £20 million in cash and offer £20 million worth of free fuel to Japan as part of a compensation deal for sending plutonium fuel with falsified quality control data last year.

The deal is an attempt to heal a damaging rift with both the Japanese government and its main customer Kansai Electric which suspended all dealings with the Cumbrian company when the falsification scandal broke in the autumn.

BNFL is also taking back at its own expense the plutonium fuel delivered last October with false papers. Under international treaties the fuel, enough to make eight nuclear weapons, must be brought back on armed merchant ships to Britain. This will take at least 18 months to organise because it need permission from the United States and a dozen countries on route, many of which are opposed to the plutonium trade.

The company is hoping the free fuel offer will spark Japanese utilities into ordering more. If it can get enough orders it will force the Department of Environment to give permission for the as yet unused £300 million manufacturing plant at Sellafield to be brought into production. The original fuel, known as Mox, was made in a demonstration plant and it was the falsification of data at this plant which led to Japan suspending all dealings with BNFL.

Alan Grant, of BNFL's Tokyo office, said "The cost of returning the fuel is commercially confidential but £20 million in cash will be paid within 30 days and Kansai will have the option of receiving £20 million in the form of replacement plutonium fuel assemblies."

He added:"We don't have any new contracts at the moment. This is a first step. I think this is a very positive step towards regaining consumer confidence in Japan."

Anna Walker, for the DTI in Tokyo, said "We are pleased that the shadow over our long relationship with Japan on civilian nuclear power issues has been lifted."

But the deal was immediately condemned both in Japan and among environmental groups in Britain and the United States. Mizuho Fukushima, Japanese MP, said "Offering MOX as compensation seems like a fraud. This is what was the problem in the first place. It is like giving drugs to a person who is trying to kick the habit and return to health. Today's announcement will not restore confidence in BNFL."

Greenpeace campaigner Bridget Woodman said "The agreement to return the MOX fuel is a desperate attempt to secure vital contracts for the new, but unopened, Sellafield MOX plant, which so far have less than 7% of their order book signed, and no Japanese contracts. Today's announcement threatens the health and environment of the many countries along the shipment's global route."

Last year's shipment from the UK, on board the armed transport ship Pacific Pintail took over two months and travelled 18,000 miles via the Cape of Good Hope, South Africa, the Tasman Sea, between Australia and New Zealand and the South Pacific. Over fifty countries opposed the shipment from passing through their seas.

In Washington the Nuclear Control Institute and Greenpeace both announced lobbying campaigns to try and block the path of the return shipment - the US has a potential veto because some of the fuel originated in the US. Norman Askew, BNFL's chief executive, arrived in Washington yesterday morning to plan strategy. One Washington lobbyist said: "This is going to be the biggest single lobbying effort of any British company in the US."
fields.bodyText: British Nuclear Fuels is to pay £20 million in cash and offer £20 million worth of free fuel to Japan as part of a compensation deal for sending plutonium fuel with falsified quality control data last year. The deal is an attempt to heal a damaging rift with both the Japanese government and its main customer Kansai Electric which suspended all dealings with the Cumbrian company when the falsification scandal broke in the autumn. BNFL is also taking back at its own expense the plutonium fuel delivered last October with false papers. Under international treaties the fuel, enough to make eight nuclear weapons, must be brought back on armed merchant ships to Britain. This will take at least 18 months to organise because it need permission from the United States and a dozen countries on route, many of which are opposed to the plutonium trade. The company is hoping the free fuel offer will spark Japanese utilities into ordering more. If it can get enough orders it will force the Department of Environment to give permission for the as yet unused £300 million manufacturing plant at Sellafield to be brought into production. The original fuel, known as Mox, was made in a demonstration plant and it was the falsification of data at this plant which led to Japan suspending all dealings with BNFL. Alan Grant, of BNFL's Tokyo office, said "The cost of returning the fuel is commercially confidential but £20 million in cash will be paid within 30 days and Kansai will have the option of receiving £20 million in the form of replacement plutonium fuel assemblies." He added:"We don't have any new contracts at the moment. This is a first step. I think this is a very positive step towards regaining consumer confidence in Japan." Anna Walker, for the DTI in Tokyo, said "We are pleased that the shadow over our long relationship with Japan on civilian nuclear power issues has been lifted." But the deal was immediately condemned both in Japan and among environmental groups in Britain and the United States. Mizuho Fukushima, Japanese MP, said "Offering MOX as compensation seems like a fraud. This is what was the problem in the first place. It is like giving drugs to a person who is trying to kick the habit and return to health. Today's announcement will not restore confidence in BNFL." Greenpeace campaigner Bridget Woodman said "The agreement to return the MOX fuel is a desperate attempt to secure vital contracts for the new, but unopened, Sellafield MOX plant, which so far have less than 7% of their order book signed, and no Japanese contracts. Today's announcement threatens the health and environment of the many countries along the shipment's global route." Last year's shipment from the UK, on board the armed transport ship Pacific Pintail took over two months and travelled 18,000 miles via the Cape of Good Hope, South Africa, the Tasman Sea, between Australia and New Zealand and the South Pacific. Over fifty countries opposed the shipment from passing through their seas. In Washington the Nuclear Control Institute and Greenpeace both announced lobbying campaigns to try and block the path of the return shipment - the US has a potential veto because some of the fuel originated in the US. Norman Askew, BNFL's chief executive, arrived in Washington yesterday morning to plan strategy. One Washington lobbyist said: "This is going to be the biggest single lobbying effort of any British company in the US."

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText:
Martin Wainwright writes:
In her captions for the Headliners section of You, the Mail On Sunday colour magazine, Genevieve Cooper (Obituary, July 8) achieved the distinction of inventing a type of journalism - making almost every celeb-mocking word a pun of great wit and crosswordy pith - which is much copied, but has yet to be excelled. She had the same effect with the humdrum in her own life.
fields.body:
Martin Wainwright writes:
In her captions for the Headliners section of You, the Mail On Sunday colour magazine, Genevieve Cooper (Obituary, July 8) achieved the distinction of inventing a type of journalism - making almost every celeb-mocking word a pun of great wit and crosswordy pith - which is much copied, but has yet to be excelled. She had the same effect with the humdrum in her own life.

Boarding a tube train once, she caught her skirt in the doors - at the same time as bending down to pick up a newspaper which she had dropped. Her account of the journey, carrying on normally at a half-crouch - with the help of London commuters' famed denial of the bizarre - was unforgettable. Scattiness has seldom taken such a lovely and intelligent form.

A Dali writes:
As a friend and compatriot of Shaykh Kadhim Al-Raysan (Obituary, July 5), the prominent leader of the 1991 uprising against Sadam Hussein's regime in Iraq, I write to point out that he was not born in Nasiriyya, but in the Dirah, the headquarters of the Hacham tribe, 10km south of Suq ash Shuyukh, and so 30km south of Nasiriyya.

Moreover, the Hacham tribe does not live in the marshes of southern Iraq, the habitat of the so-called mad'an described by Wilfred Thesiger in his 1964 classic, The Marsh Arabs. The Hacham live on both western and eastern banks of the southern Euphrates river, some 25km north of the nearest marshes. They cultivate wheat and rice, as well as tending gardens of date palm trees.

However, they have close contacts with tribes inhabitating the northern shores of the marshes, and rally under one flag in times of crisis or national emergency.

fields.headline: Kemal Sunal
fields.standfirst: Turkish comic star who spoke for the dreams of his people
fields.trailText: The Turkish actor and comedian Kemal Sunal, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, made his name by articulating the hopes and dreams of the Anatolian masses. A huge body of work made him, perhaps, the country's most popular comic. In a 30-year career, he appeared in more than 80 films and numerous television sitcoms, usually portraying lovable downtrodden characters; his films, endlessly repeated on television, always drew huge audiences.
fields.body:
The Turkish actor and comedian Kemal Sunal, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, made his name by articulating the hopes and dreams of the Anatolian masses. A huge body of work made him, perhaps, the country's most popular comic. In a 30-year career, he appeared in more than 80 films and numerous television sitcoms, usually portraying lovable downtrodden characters; his films, endlessly repeated on television, always drew huge audiences.

His forte was to represent the trials and tribulations of ordinary Turkish villagers. In a country where millions of people have migrated in the last two decades from the countryside to the cities, Sunal instinctively understood their sense of dislocation. He expressed, as the sociologist Ozcan Koknel pointed out, the "feelings, opinions, expectations and goals of society" and released people from their inhibitions.

Born in Istanbul, Sunal began his career on the stage in the 1960s, but soon moved into film. One of his best-loved characters was a good-hearted but dim-witted student, known as "Saban the Cow". The name has entered the Turkish language as a byword for the well-meaning fool who makes people laugh at each other - and by implication at themselves.

Sunal rose to prominence during a period of social upheaval in Turkey in the 1970s and 1980s, which was marked by widespread street violence between political rivals and a military coup. Through it all, he provided comic relief and a voice of clarity amid considerable confusion.

More recently, Sunal had hoped to develop his career as a film producer. His last film, Propaganda (1999), had shown a harder political edge than some of his earlier work. It portrayed a village divided with barbed wire by two rival gangs, lampooned the state's apparent inability to understand its citizens, and was seen by some as a comment on the artificial divisions between Turks and Kurds.

Sunal had a lifelong fear of flying and had not been on a plane for many years. Last week, however, he was persuaded to take an early morning flight from Istanbul to the Black Sea city of Trabzon, where he was due to start work on another film. Just before take-off, Sunal suffered a heart attack. Fellow passengers said it took 21 minutes for an ambulance to arrive - and then it had no doctor on board. The man who spent his life poking fun at the system was finally defeated by it.

Sunal was a modest man, who avoided the limelight, but his funeral in Istanbul drew thousands of people and was televised across Turkey. Mourners and viewers alike felt they had lost a beloved member of their family. People, observed the commentator Mehmet Ali Birand, liked the way Sunal spoke the truth.

He is survived by his wife, a daughter and a son.

 Kemal Sunal, actor and comedian, born November 11 1944; died July 3 2000

fields.headline: Nancy Cato
fields.standfirst: Novelist and poet capturing the spirit of the Australian outback
fields.trailText: The first published novel of the Australian writer Nancy Cato, who has died aged 83, was a bestseller. All The Rivers Run (1958), a saga of life along the Murray, Australia's largest river, made her modestly rich and famous, popularised Australia overseas and became a television series.
fields.body:
The first published novel of the Australian writer Nancy Cato, who has died aged 83, was a bestseller. All The Rivers Run (1958), a saga of life along the Murray, Australia's largest river, made her modestly rich and famous, popularised Australia overseas and became a television series.

The novel took a decade to write, and its success, especially in the United States, enabled Cato to give up journalism - she had been the Queensland correspondent of the Canberra Times - and focus on her writing and love of conservation. The book became the first of a trilogy - with Time, Flow Softly (1959) and But Still The Stream (1962) - which, when published in a single volume, became popular around the world.

Ever the patriotic, fifth-generation Australian, Cato was unimpressed when her British publishers mistakenly put a Mississippi steamer, with its stern paddle, on the cover instead of a Murray steamer, whose paddles are amidships.

Cato had discovered the Murray river on a holiday in the 1930s. Her family believed the first novel's leading character, Philadelphia Gordon, was in part modelled on the author, who married at 24 and had three children in three years.

In all, Cato wrote more than 10 big novels, often featuring strong, outback women. She also produced volumes of poetry, short stories and The Noosa Story: A Study In Unplanned Development (1979), an environmental work about her adopted Queensland home.

She started writing at the age of eight - when she composed a short poem about a violet - and 10 years later won a short-story competition run by the News, the local paper in her hometown of Adelaide. Her imaginary "interview" with Oliver Twist led to her being taken on as a trainee journalist - with time off to go to university - but she recalled that, as a woman, she had to fight to get into the reporters' room.

In 1941, she married the racing driver Eldred Norman and started writing seriously. There were short stories in the Bulletin magazine and, in 1950, she published her first poetry collection, The Darkened Window.

Cato was a founder member of the Lyrebird Writers, a group that published verse collections, and was part of the Jindyworobak literary movement, which respected and worked with the Aboriginal perception of the outback.

But her early novels were not always well received, and the manuscript of one ended up being flung into the Thames. It was read by Paul Scott, of Raj quartet fame, who said Cato had a good writer's eye - but still turned it down. "I had rejection, rejection, rejection," Cato recalled. "If you can't take rejection, you'll never be a writer." Seven years later, another collection, The Dancing Bough (1957), brought her wider acclaim before the appearance of All The Rivers Run.

Brown Sugar (1974), a novel about Queensland and the trade in indentured workers from the south Pacific, was another success. Cato also wrote three books about Tasmania, one about the last Aboriginal woman on the island, Queen Truganini (1976), and A Distant Island (1988), based on the life of botanist Ronald Gunn. The Heart Of The Continent, about two generations of outback and wartime nurses, followed in 1989. Cato was honoured with a doctorate of letters by the University of Queensland in 1990.

She became something of a local icon in the popular seaside resort of Noosa, where a park and a restaurant are named after her. She was a founding member of the local euthanasia society and received awards for her conservation work. In later life, she suffered from rheumatoid arthritis and mini strokes, which never diminished her lust for life. Her daughter and two sons survive her.
Nancy Cato, writer and poet, born March 11 1917; died July 3 2000

fields.headline: Sir Michael Hamilton
fields.standfirst: Promising Tory MP whose career floundered in a pit of China clay
fields.trailText: Driven by his love of the environment and belief in democratic procedures, the former Conservative MP Sir Michael Hamilton, who has died aged 81, fought an obsessive 15-year crusade against the then-powerful English China Clay Company for what he saw as its invasion of Wiltshire's beautiful Dean valley, in the wake of a supposedly public inquiry - held in unprecedented secrecy.
fields.body:
Driven by his love of the environment and belief in democratic procedures, the former Conservative MP Sir Michael Hamilton, who has died aged 81, fought an obsessive 15-year crusade against the then-powerful English China Clay Company for what he saw as its invasion of Wiltshire's beautiful Dean valley, in the wake of a supposedly public inquiry - held in unprecedented secrecy.

At the inquiry, the company convinced an inspector that local Wiltshire chalk was an indispensable mixture for its Cornish clay. Hamilton's indignation produced at least 10 Commons speeches, including one, in 1970, stretching over six pages of Hansard. It wound up with his 1982 private member's bill, which generally made secrecy in planning inquiries illegal.

This was a surprising climax for the career of Hamilton, who had seemed the classic promising postwar Tory MP. A former guardsman, he was tall, good-looking, well-spoken and well-connected, a successful businessman with conventional views on defence and foreign affairs. MPs like that were said to come in two categories: those aiming to be ministers quickly, and those hoping to be knights slowly.

Hamilton got his knighthood in 1983, after serving as MP for Wellingborough from 1959-64, and Salisbury from 1965-83. He had no hope of ministerial preference after Mrs Thatcher became party leader in 1975; he was one of the pro-Heath "Wiltshire Wets", led by Charles Morrison, then MP for Devizes. His crusading streak was even more damaging.

He had been born in London, the son of the Rt Rev EKC Hamilton, who became Bishop of Shrewsbury and Dean of Windsor. After Radley and University College, Oxford, Michael saw wartime service with the Coldstream Guards. His brother was killed in action in Italy.

In 1947, he married Lavinia, daughter of the former Tory MP, Sir Charles Ponsonby. She had served in the British embassy in Moscow during the war, and subsequently carved out a business career as a director of the Army and Navy Stores and Royal Exchange Assurance, and as a special member of the Hops Marketing Board.

Hamilton's excellent connections - his brother-in-law, James Ramsden, was already a Tory MP - enabled him to make his first attempt at Wellingborough, where, in 1959, he turned a Labour majority of 926 votes into a Tory margin of 606. Within two years, he was an assistant whip in Harold Macmillan's government.

Hamilton lost his seat in 1964, but he had a fairy godfather, the fabulously wealthy Major John Morrison, who stepped down as Salisbury's MP to take a peerage, thus freeing his safe seat for Hamilton. He held it at the February 1965 byelection, capping his campaign by singing a local drinking song about "vlies" (flies) on "turmits" (turnips) in broad Wiltshire dialect.

Because Labour was in office until 1970 - and he was obsessed with china clay matters - Hamilton never regained his place on the promotion ladder, only becoming parliamentary private secretary to the foreign secretary, Francis Pym, in 1983. He leaves his wife, a son and three daughters.

Sir Michael Aubrey Hamilton, politician, born July 5 1918; died July 3 2000

fields.headline: Manfredi Traxler
fields.trailText: In 1977, the Italian film buyer and distributor Manfredi Traxler, who has died of cancer aged 63, founded Academy Pictures in Rome with his wife, Vania. The company immediately won attention in the trade because of its imaginative promotion of its first release, Rainer Werner Fassbinder's The Marriage Of Maria Braun.
fields.body:
In 1977, the Italian film buyer and distributor Manfredi Traxler, who has died of cancer aged 63, founded Academy Pictures in Rome with his wife, Vania. The company immediately won attention in the trade because of its imaginative promotion of its first release, Rainer Werner Fassbinder's The Marriage Of Maria Braun.

Traxler put arthouse film into the mainstream, opening the Italian market to independent productions otherwise confined to the festival circuit. He and his wife were a charismatic couple, and became familiar figures at international markets. Their example encouraged other independents to buy films with criteria of per sonal taste - rather than sheer business shrewdness.

Their preference was for European film and, in the 1980s, they had another German hit with Wim Wenders's Wings Of Desire. They introduced many directors to Italy and were the only distributors prepared to take a chance on one of Fellini's last films L'intervista (The Interview), made originally for television.

Their many successes with British films began with Peter Greenaway's The Draughtsman's Contract, and they boldly decided to release Jim Jarmusch's Down By Law in the original version, with subtitles, knowing that Roberto Benigni was already popular enough to make Italians curious to hear him speaking English.

The Traxlers also tried their hand at film production. They were partners in an ambitious, but shortlived, pan-European conglomerate, Eurotrustees, which paid off with The Crying Game but came a cropper with Utz, adapted from Bruce Chatwin's novel.

Traxler was born into a noble Florentine family; his brother became an ambassador. Bored with the life of a playboy, he found a job in Rome with the public relations department of Italian state television, RAI. In 1969, he married Vania, whose Mantua family included two generations of cinema management - experience the couple turned to good use.

In 1989, the Traxlers opened their own de luxe cinema in Rome, the Alcazar, with Dead Poets Society. The film was expected to have a brief run, but stayed on for four months and launched the Alcazar as the city's foremost quality cinema in Trastevere, Rome's Greenwich Village. More than 10 years later, the area is inundated with venues merging arthouse and mainstream tastes.

Cancer did not stop Traxler from continuing to support independent cinema, now again under siege in the age of Italy's capitulation to the multiplex. At the time of his death, he was president of the Italian Distributors Union. Vania survives him.

 Manfredi Traxler, film buyer, born October 4 1936; died June 20 2000

webTitle: The best derelict house scene: Jesus' son

fields.headline: The best derelict house scene: Jesus' son
fields.trailText: Iowa City. FH (Billy Crudup) has taken up a non-specific offer of work from his drinking acquaintance Wayne (Denis Leary). The two men pull up outside an anonymous suburban house.
fields.body:
Iowa City. FH (Billy Crudup) has taken up a non-specific offer of work from his drinking acquaintance Wayne (Denis Leary). The two men pull up outside an anonymous suburban house.

"What are we doing?" enquires FH. "A burglary?"

Wayne stares out of the window, a bag of tools on his lap.

"You can't burgle an empty house. This is a salvage job."

Wayne gets out of the car, and heads for the house. FH follows, a couple of steps behind.

"This house has a terrible feeling about it."

He catches up with Wayne, then bangs on the door.

"Don't do that."

"Why not?"

"Because it's stupid, that's why."

Wayne pushes the door open. The house is completely bare. Wayne takes a hammer to the wall.

"We'll sell the copper for scrap."

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: We risk losing our heads if we run headlong into pervasive computing
fields.trailText: We risk losing our heads if we run headlong into pervasive computing, says John Thackara
fields.body:
What happens to society when there are hundreds of microchips for every man, woman and child on the planet? What cultural consequences follow when every object around us is "smart", and connected? And what happens psychologically when you step into the garden to look at the flowers... and the flowers look at you?

You might think that such questions would preoccupy anyone involved with computers - namely, all of us. But you'd be wrong. We think about technology in the same way that a frog thinks about boiling water.

You remember the story: if you drop a frog into the pan when the water is boiling, it will leap out; but if you put the frog into a pan of cold water, and then heat it steadily towards boiling point, the frog - unaware that any dramatic change is taking place - will just sit there, and slowly cook.

Is technology cooking us? Many hard things are certainly beginning to soften. Products and buildings, for example, once described as "frozen software", are beginning to "melt". Almost everything man-made, and quite a lot made by nature, will soon combine hardware and software: intelligence and connectivity are suffusing ships, aircraft, cars, bridges, tunnels, machines, fridges, door handles, lighting fixtures, shoes, hats and packaging.

The world is already filled with eight, 12, or 30 computer chips for every man, woman and child on the planet (depending who you ask). Within a few years - say, the amount of time a child who is four years old today will spend in junior school - that number will rise to thousands of chips per person. A majority of these chips will have the capacity to communicate with each other. Many of them will sense their environment in rudimentary but effective ways.

The way things are going, as writer Bruce Sterling put it, "you will look at the garden, and the garden will look at you". Pervasive computing is not just about flowers. Pervasive means everywhere, and that includes our bodies. Bio-mechatronics and medical telematics are growing exponentially. The space where human ends and network begins is becoming blurred. British Telecom, which spends a million dollars an hour on R&D (or is it a million dollars a minute? I forget) is working on an interactive corneal implant.

It is confident that by 2005 its lens will have a screen on it so that video projections can be beamed straight onto your retina. In the words of BT's top techie, Sir Peter Cochrane, "you won't even have to open your eyes to go to the office in the morning".

By 2010, BT expects to be making direct links to the nervous system. Links to the nervous system, links from it - what's the difference? Presumably, BT's objective is that you won't even have to wake up to go to work. I call this passive acceptance of technology into our bodies 'Borg drift'. It features a million small, specialised acts. It is what happens when knowledge from many branches of science and design converge - without us noticing, but only because we don't look.

We are designing a world in which every object, every building - and everybody - has become part of a network service, even though we did not set out to design such an outcome. Railing against technology per se is pointless. But we do need to reflect on the bigger picture if we are to have any influence over what it looks like. This is why, to provoke a discussion within the human-computer interaction industry, I recently circulated some Articles of Association Between Design, Technology And The People Formerly Known As Users - aka Thackara's Cookery Lesson - which provoked a lively, and generally positive, response.

The articles go like this:
Article 1: We cherish the fact that people are innately curious, playful and creative. We therefore suspect that technology is not going to go away: it is too much fun.
Article 2: We will deliver value to people, not deliver people to systems. We will give priority to human agency, and will not treat humans as a factor in some bigger picture.
Article 3: We will not presume to design your experiences for you - but we will do so with you, if asked.
Article 4: We do not believe in "idiot-proof" technology, because we are not idiots, and neither are you. We will use language with care, and will search for less patronising words than "user" and "consumer".
Article 5: We will focus on services, not on things. We will not flood the world with pointless devices.
Article 6: We believe that "content" is something you do, not something you are given.
Article 7: We will consider material end energy flows in all the systems we design. We will think about the consequences of technology before we act, not after.
Article 8: We will not pretend things are simple, when they are complex. We value the fact that by acting inside a system, you will probably improve it.
Article 9: We believe that place matters, and we will look after it.
Article 10: We believe that speed and time matter, too - but that sometimes you need more, and sometimes you need less. We will not fill up all time with content.

 John Thackara is director of Doors of Perception, the design conference and knowledge network based in Amsterdam. www.doorsofperception.com

www.thackara.com

webTitle: A sharpened fang among the sweet-toothed

fields.headline: A sharpened fang among the sweet-toothed
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The Commons presented a humble address (not a vainglorious address; they are fastidious where royalty is involved) on the occasion of the Queen Mother's birthday.
fields.body:
The Commons presented a humble address (not a vainglorious address; they are fastidious where royalty is involved) on the occasion of the Queen Mother's birthday. Dennis Skinner made a surly but affecting speech in which he talked about the other pensioners who had reached the same age, but who had lost husbands down the pits, and who had only pennies to scrape together three days after getting their pension.

Admittedly, he made it 20 years ago, on July 31 1980. Nostalgically for some, the late Willie Hamilton was still around to describe the occasion as "nauseating".

Yesterday there was no contribution from Mr Skinner. As holder of the ancient office of Curmudgeon Herald Pursuivant, he would normally have a ceremonial role, like the Scottish missionary in India who used to rail at the annual Hindu procession of the Jaganath. When he died, the locals wrote to Scotland to ask for a replacement as the ritual would not be the same without him.

So Mr Skinner sat there, chafing and cross, but silent - feeling, perhaps, that the tributes, while sincere, were like being buried under a ton of molten ingredients at a chocolate assortment factory.

Tony Blair started off with, I thought, the right tone of praise blended with detached amusement. "She has enthused thousands of people with her familiar smile, her sparkle and of course her wonderful hats," he said, but soon we were riffling through the Cadbury's special selection: "zest for life ... rock of stability and strength for our nation ... heartfelt good wishes and gratitude..." The montelimar oozed out, the flavour sharpened only when he said that people wanted to know the recipe for a long and happy life.

"I don't know what her recipe would be!" he beamed, at which point a loud, gruff and ruffianly Labour voice went "Hurr, hurr, hurr!", meaning I know not what.

Nothing would stop the house. "This truly remarkable lady," said William Hague, throwing in "leadership ... inspiration ... her tireless and ceaseless devotion to official duties" (a new one on me), plus "indestructible" and "gracious".

Charles Kennedy rummaged through the box and found "inspiration and a beacon who has enriched all our lives". Even Ian Paisley, whose views on gin are probably the direct opposite of hers, managed "steadfastness, courage, dignity and majesty". When the Scottish National party paid yet another nougat-covered tribute, I decided I had had enough of this All Gold assortment.

An hour earlier, at environment questions, our gracious and much-loved deputy prime minister was asked about regional development agencies. He didn't so much answer the question as hurl himself at it. Mr Prescott is a have-a-go hero: he sees the question escaping and charges after it with no thought to his own safety.

"As for the investment of £10m, I have already informed the house that £4m in regeneration, 35,000 jobs by the active intervention by regional development agencies on its own is a justification for such investment, but I might say to the honourable member since in Scotland when we did bring in the development agencies, there they have seen an improvement in Scotland where they went from 1986 to seventh highest in UK to the fourth, they showed the success of development agencies of working in Scotland and Wales, so why does he want to deny it to the English regions, or is this just a promise made in opposition that will be changed in government?"

You might say I am being unfair and should put in some punctuation. But why should I, when he doesn't?

webTitle: Boys boast of murder plot on internet

fields.headline: Boys boast of murder plot on internet
fields.trailText: A race against time across cyberspace led Berlin police to thwart a murder foretold, minutes before the would-be killers had announced they would strike.
fields.body:
A race against time across cyberspace led Berlin police to thwart a murder foretold, minutes before the would-be killers had announced they would strike.

Officers swooped on a school in the southern suburbs of the German capital to arrest one of two teenage boys claimed to be behind a macabre boast to an internet chat forum.

The night before, a chatroom user had indicated that he and an accomplice would murder their teacher the next day. The threat was seen by an employee of an internet service provider in the southern German town of Augsburg who noted down the details and alerted the police.

By the time the tip-off found its way to the relevant unit, investigators had two hours and 40 minutes in which to track down the source of the threat, acccording to the Berliner Morgenpost newspaper.

An ad hoc group of Berlin police officers came together to discuss the case at 9.00 the following morning. The visitor to the chat forum had said the murder would be committed at 11.40, during "long break" at the school he was attending.

The threat had been delivered anonymously, but the Berlin police's tiny, four-person cyber-crime unit linked it to an email address, presumably through the service provider. The email address was linked to a pupil at the Nikolaus-August Otto school in the Steglitz-Lichterfelde area of southern Berlin.

The school, with 240 pupils, is for "problem children" rejected by other establishments.

The cyber-hunt took place at the end of last month. But details began emerging only yesterday in the Berliner Morgenpost's report.

The headmaster of the Nikolaus-August Otto school, Uwe Duske, and a spokesman for the Berlin city council's department of education, youth and sport both confirmed the broad outlines of the affair. But neither was prepared to go into details on the grounds that the case was the subject of legal proceedings.

Berliner Morgenpost said the two boys had been removed from the school and that they were the subject of a judicial investigation.

Mr Duske said he did not believe that a murder would have been committed had the police not intervened.

"The temptation to use the internet as a springboard to notoriety is very great," he said.

Recent months have nevertheless seen a spate of violent incidents planned or committed in German schools. Last November, in the Saxon town of Meissen, a teacher was stabbed to death by a 15-year-old pupil.

The following month, police swooped on a school in Bavaria to arrest three 14-year-olds who, prosecutors said, had decided to shoot and kill the headmistress. Police said they had also plotted a massacre of their classmates.

Also in December, a 12-year-old pupil in Berlin threatened fellow-pupils and his teachers with a knife. A teacher at another school in the capital had earlier been terrorised by anonymous threatening letters thought to have come from a student.

webTitle: Football and the internet keep ONdigital on track to 1m target

fields.headline: Football and the internet keep ONdigital on track to 1m target
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: ONdigital, the pay-television operator, yesterday announced that it would meet its target of 1m subscribers by the end of the year, boosted by its acquisition of rights to English league football and a new television internet service.
fields.body:
ONdigital, the pay-television operator, yesterday announced that it would meet its target of 1m subscribers by the end of the year, boosted by its acquisition of rights to English league football and a new television internet service.

It said that 774,000 households are now signed up to the digital terrestrial TV network, up 15% in the last quarter. But analysts said there were signs of that the rate of growth is beginning to slow.

ONdigital, owned by the ITV broadcasters Carlton and Granada, said it would start a TV internet service in the autumn, and a new premium sports channel next year. The chief executive, Stuart Prebble, said sports rights were driving up its subscriber base, and it would seek to acquire more.

The broadcaster said it had experienced a three-fold increase in subscribers in the past year and was on course to reach 2m by the end of 2002. It would break even at 1m, and had the potential to make a £250m profit when the number of subscribers reached 2m, Mr Prebble said.

However, ONdigital admitted that of its 774,000 subscribers 34,000 are yet to switch on their smartcards. It is understood that a further 15,000 have received free or discounted integrated digital television sets.

BSkyB, ONdigital's satellite rival, has notched up 3.4m digital subscribers, half of whom did not have digital television before.

Mr Prebble predicted that its new internet service, ONnet, which is available with a second set-top box, would help widen internet access across Britain. He said it removed the last barrier to internet access - the cost of a personal computer.

When the service begins, subscribers will receive a free or heavily discounted "net-top box". ONdigital said it had already signed up partners for a planned portal, including Abbey National and its new internet bank Cahoot, and was negotiating with nearly 100 more.

The "look" of ONdigital's net portal is being developed by BBC Resources, and the e-business consultancy Rubus is doing the technical development work. Mr Prebble said viewers would be able to "click through" from television programmes or advertisements to supporting websites - this facility, cross-linking, was a "world first".

"The introduction of internet and interactive services provides us with significant opportunities to increase average subscriber revenue levels. And every interactive digital television that is sold, even to non-subscribers, represents a potential customer for ONdigital's pay-per-view and interactive services," Mr Prebble said.

ONdigital's premium sports channel will launch next year based on its rights to show English league, Worthington cup and Uefa champions league football, and the ATP men's tennis masters series. ONdigital now claims it shows more football than any other platform.

Mr Prebble said he did not expect the upheavals in the ITV system to affect ONdigital's business plan. Carlton and United intend to merge, subject to the approval of the Department of Trade and Industry, while Granada has signalled its intention to bid for either Carlton or United if their merger plans fail.

Analysts believe that if ONdigital were wholly owned by a combined Granada and Carlton its stock market flotation would be hastened.

Mr Prebble would only say yesterday that he expected flotation "sooner rather than later".
